description:
If you are looking for a top notch Spanish Tapas restaurant then you are in for a treat at Contigo.
The wait staff and kitchen are extremely friendly and if this is your first visit, you definitely want to do the tasting menu which does change weekly.

Note: Tue-Thur is chefs choice Paella night so try a weekday if you want Paella.

We decided for the 4 of us who went that the chef's choice was the way to go after our food ambassador advised us to do so.

We had:

Croquets de Jamon Serrano
Pan Con Tomate
Warm delicata squash salad
Berenienes Fritas (Eggplant)
Squid ala Plancha
Black Cod
Albondigas (meatballs)

Every dish was fantasic bursting with flavor. The fritas were the first time I had eggplant fritas and they were addicting. Not greasy and very light crispy breading, these lovely morsels of eggplant fantastic.

The tomato bruchetta or Pan con Tomate was fantastic. Rather than chunks of tomato, the tomatoe was blended to a thick but creamy spread which meant you didn't have to worry about taking a bite and having chunks of tomato go sailing down your mouth to the plate!

Everything was great including the bottle of 205 Viña Sastra Crianza which I highly recommend for this type of food. 

We had a great time and we will be back for another tasting menu in the near future.

I keep hitting 5 star recommendations and this one is another 5 stars for me.
author: Jay G.

description:
Excellent tapas excellent service 
Highly recommand
Portion a little smaller but perfect for européen ;-)
author: Sylvie R.

description:
I took my mom here for a belated mother's day dinner. My mom absolutely loves Spanish tapas places (especially their sangria). 

I think the food here is a bit over priced for such small portions. There were some dishes we liked (the squid dish was a highlight), but everything else seemed to be standard affair.
author: Natasha S.

description:
The restaurant clearly uses fresh ingredients, and the service is good.  My opinion is that these were the blandest tapas, I've ever had.  If you have enjoyed tapas in Spain, then don't expect similar tapas here. We had the Serrano jamon, squid a la plancha, albondigas, patatas bravas, croquetas. With our two sparkling sangrias, the bill came to 107 for the two is us. We both agreed that there was not any dish that we really loved. Everything was ok, with the croquetas being the best of the bunch. 

The restaurant was packed and loud, because all diners are yelling in order to be heard. This is probably better so that the people at the next table 8 inches from ours couldn't hear us yelling to each other our disappointment over the food.
author: Freedy H.

description:
Delicious tapas, great service, and cute venue- worth the trip to Noe Valley!  Came here with my bf on a Tuesday night for a late dinner.

Venue / Service: well-lit interior and plenty of space to walk around/ sit down.  They also have outdoor seating with canopies.  Definitely didn't have a feeling of being cramped or in tight spaces, though it might have also been because we came in during a quiet time (8:30/9pm weekday). Service was pretty good- they came by frequently to check in and make sure we were done with dishes before they served the next one, waters were filled, etc.

Jamón Serrano (Monte Nevado, Aged 15-20 Months, Rioja)($16) - lightly salted and still very savory!  My bf and I love jamon though this was a rather large portion of jamon; just enough bread to accompany the jamon too.

Wood Oven Roasted Monterey Sardine and Avocado Toast (Pickled Onions, Smoked Salt)($3.50 per toast) - huge fan of sardines and this was a pretty good toast.  Surprised that they were able to get the sardine less salty by pairing it with avocado and onions and thankfully the toast wasn't too thick.

Croqueta de Jamón Serrano (Crisp and Creamy Fritter of Spanish Serrano Ham)($3.50 per piece) - hard to go wrong with a croquette; this one was deliciously cheesy and not too much breading on the outside.  Lot of ham chunks inside too so you can really taste it!

Little Gem Salad (Roasted Beets, Garlic Chips, Mint, Sherry Mustard Vinagreta)($13) - recommended by our waitress out of the salads selection.  The mint and vinaigrette really made this salad, adding a lightness that was much needed in an otherwise somewhat-heavy meal.   

Squid-Ink Seafood Paella (??) - Tuesday nights are paella night and so we ordered the special paella.  Yay for the plentiful seafood on the paella- they also included small bits of cod which I particularly liked.  Was kinda bummed that they didn't include the soccarat at the bottom of the paella, since I personally LOVE the crispy rice that you would normally find at the bottom of a paella.  The paellas are MASSIVE btw; I bet 3 people would be satisfied assuming they ordered tapas as well- we barely finished half of it.

Butterscotch Flan (Fresh Strawberries, Dark Chocolate-Sea Salt Cookie)($9) - loved the flan and a great way to end the meal!  Not too creamy/ heavy, and the caramel was salted a bit to cut the sweetness.

Little bit on the expensive side overall, but we were pretty satisfied with the quality of food- I'd place it as one of the top tapas places I've been to in SF so far.  Might not frequent it much as I would like to since it is a bit far for me to get to, but I would gladly put it on the top of the list in terms of places to try good tapas.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Such a cute spot!!! We sat at the counter and ordered the chefs tasting of seven dishes. Even though it was delicious, it was way too much food for two hungry people. I would suggest 2 people only need about 4 dishes. 

But loved our waiter and the list of unique wines. Our dishes included this goat cheese salad, sardine and avocado toast, split pea toast, cod, meatballs, squid, and croquetas. Our favorites were definitely the goat cheese salad, the cod, and the squid.

Will be back and hopefully have room for dessert this time!
author: Shabnam E.

description:
Ambiance: Came here for dinner for the first time yesterday. The overall interior of the restaurant is very comfortable and warm, but also very spacious for a SF restaurant. We sat in the outdoor segment where it was well heated and well-lit (5/5). 

Food: I believe most of the menu are smaller sized tapas, though some dishes may be more filling than others such as the short-ribs. What I love about the food is that the ingredients are kept simple to only compliment the dish as opposed to restaurants that use many ingredients to try to create something sophisticated. (5/5)

For example, the short ribs had roasted almond and cauliflower that perfectly balanced the meaty taste all while adding a crunchy texture. The meatballs were very fresh, juicy, but not too overpowering. We also tried the coca flatbread, which was interesting because of the broccoli rabes, but it was pretty good as it added texture. The only dishes I wasn't really impressed by were the ones with sardines in them, but maybe I'm not just a fan of sardines to begin with. However, I can say that they paired the dish well to minimize the fishy taste. As for drinks, the sparkling sangria is nice and minty and has some pomegranate at the bottom.
author: Angus L.

description: We had a wonderful date night here. It actually started in a very awkward way - none of us brought the purse...luckily they assured us we can pay with credit card info. We ordered signiture pre-fix and it's amazing. We tended to eat a lot but the pre-fix portion is very generous. Dessert menu is very limited though.
author: Iris W.

description: Cannot recommend this Noe Valley restaurant. The food is mediocre and overpriced. We ordered six dishes, both hot and cold. None of it was good, especially the $29. Lamb chops which were fatty and undercooked. The salad was watery and tasteless. The hot vegetables were oversalted. The service was fine, but I won't return.
author: Julie R.

description: Contigo didn't meet the hype, in my opinion. The food was just ok, wines were the same and everything was incredibly overpriced.  The best dish we had was a little crab croquette but if you fry almost anything and dip it in aioli, it's probably going to be pretty good.  This was one of the most expensive meals I've ever paid for, keeping in mind that we had enough food to leave uncomfortably stuffed, but still, get ready to drop a pretty penny here. I wouldn't return.
author: Emma H.

description:
Really good spanish food. We chose the 7 step chez menu and loved every dish. Highly recommend the squids, they are amazing. Loved the Halibut and the goat cheese salad. 
Very nice place and friendly service. We went on a week night and did not have to wait to be seated. 
Also great for group dinners. Really enjoyed this restaurant and highly recommend it.
author: Maria P.

description: Food was beyond mediocre - actually quite bad. We ordered the tasting menu at the suggestion of our waiter (who was amazing, btw). I wasn't expecting the dishes to match the quality of San Sebastián or Barcelona, but the food at Contigo was so far off the mark and so overpriced for what they serve: the tasting menu for 2 is $110, which somehow doesn't jive with what is supposed to be the "chef's recommended dishes"; try tomato paste on toast and bland croquettes for starters, or, how about halibut that was old and rubbery? Or, how about a squid dish that was overwhelmed by chorizo? Or, how about 2 meatballs that were just uninspiring? With two alcoholic drinks, the tasting menu for 2 two, tax, a 4% health-mandate surcharge, and despite how bad the food was - a good tip because the waiter was extremely on point - the meal came to $170. Not. At. All. Worth. It.
author: John S.

description:
I've always shyed away from tapas, since it usually entails copious amounts of decision-making for each small plate, which then rack up a daunting bill and may still leave you hungry. However I found myself quite fond of Contigo with its Tuesday special tasting menu ft. a giant pan of paella at $40/person.... First world problems solved.

The unique Spanish/Catalan flavors, combined with the fresh and sustainable sourcing in Californian spirit, in a cozy rustic space create a memorable dining adventure. I especially appreciated how all the dishes were carefully prepared with marked attention to detail in composition and quality. 

Despite its favorable Michelin rating, the service and atmosphere were gracious and not the least bit pretentious. One could describe it as homecooked Barcelona fine cuisine, though the Yelp brand of Spanish tapas bar speaks to its classiness. 

(+) Wood Oven Roasted Monterey Sardine and Avocado Toast, Pickled Onions, Smoked Salt ($3): Lol, of course there has to be avo toast in an SF restaurant. As denizens accustomed to chunky avocado toast, Contigo's version is a bit of a tease with its thin bread and light smear of avocado, used primarily to add a creamy dimension to contrast the savory sardine and sour pickled onions. The sardines are a feat in themselves, not fishy at all and not overpowered by salt or smokiness.

(++) Croqueta de Jamón Serrano ($3.50): Mmm, a crispy panko-like exterior surrounding a lusciously creamy filling, interspersed with Spanish ham. It's hard to appreciate the artisan jambon on its own the way you can focus on charcuterie board cuts, but the croquet as a whole is comfort-food tasty. Caution that the inside is really hot when it arrives, so you may want to take your sweet time on cross section pictures and such.

(++) Hand Picked Dungeness Crab Salad, Chicories, Clementines, Avocado, Fennel, Lime Vinagreta ($16): Arguably among the most interesting salads I've had; it utilized the bitterness of chicory and made it very palatable by placing it in stark contrast to tangy clementines and lime vinaigrette, the earthiness of fennel, and the creaminess of pulled crab and avocado. 

(++) Smashed Pumpkin Tosta, Wild Mushrooms, Idiazábal, Baby Mustard Greens, Pepitas ($14) Although the trendiness of pumpkin is restricted to PSL season, I enjoyed the winter veggies take on toast. I think I would have liked more variety in the tasting menu than two toasts; nonetheless this turned out an excellent combination of familiar pumpkin with hearty mushrooms and rich smokey idiazabal. The hard cheese shavings are similar to Italian parmigiano reggiano, except it's made from sheep and has more zing.

(+++) Seafood Paella of Jumbo Gulf Shrimp, California Rock Cod, Monterey Squid, Clams, Baby Artichokes, Saffron, Alioli: I was actually starting to get full before we even got to the paella, and then the huge pan arrived, occupying most of the table space. The paella is deliciously al dente like risotto, sauteed with a mix of saffron and tomato-based aioli. The seafood was also very generous, and the jumbo gulf shrimp were jumbo indeed. The shrimp was possibly my favorite item of the night--juicy, meaty, and a hint of peppery. Also, bonus points to the aesthetics. While paella is usually a hodgepodge, Contigo added flairs of microgreens, an artsy swirl of white sauce, and a fancy charred lemon.

Overall, I think Contigo excels the most in balance; it boldly experiments with contrasting flavors which turn out surprisingly delicious. Prices are also very reasonable considering the large portions. (It's the first time in awhile we couldn't finish our food!)

Note: prices listed are referenced from the regular menu. I'm not sure how they portion out the tasting menu for different numbers of people. If I were to go by myself, I wonder if I would get the same amount of food :3

Contigo is situated in the relatively quiet neighborhood of Noe Valley, where the small cluster of stores and restaurants is reminiscent of a quaint downtown of a smaller town--an alcove in SF where you can breathe and relax for a peaceful dinner (and find parking.)
author: Edna C.

description:
Hands down the best restaurant in Noe Valley, and also the best tapas destination in SF.

My favorites here are the anchovy/avocado toast, the hot date, and the tripes. The jamon iberico is awesome but it's more of a sourcing thing. It's good though. Get it!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Who doesn't like tapas? You get to try more dishes without getting full so easily! Contigo is a Spanish Tapas restaurant serving farm to table dishes family style. Since they serve seasonal foods, their menu changes quite often.

My husband came on a Sunday night for date night and since I'm not familiar with Spanish cuisine, we opted for the Tapas Tasting Menu (chef's selection of 7 of their best dishes served family style) for $48/person. It does not include dessert though...The portions are generous so you will get very full!

Boquerones (White Anchovies), Avocado, Lemon Zest, Espelette on Toast - I love how flavorful the tomato spread was! But our bread was so soggy and I think because there has been an avocado shortage in California, ours didn't come with avocado...

Croqueta de Jamón Serrano - Crisp and Creamy Fritter of Spanish Serrano Ham - Crispy on the outside, creamy with ham on the inside. Delicious!

Oxtail Hamburguesita, Salsa Secreta, Pickled Onions, chips - the bun was cold and all I could taste on the chips were the red seasoning (paprika?) and it was too overwhelming. The oxtail was moist and flavorful though.

Seared Caña de Cabra Goat Cheese, Chicories, Persimmons, Pomegranates, Hazelnuts - the seared goat cheese was sooo good! Persimmons were sweet and both cheese, persimmon and pomegranate flavors intensified each other.

Seared McFarland Springs Trout - Brown Butter Squash Purée, Romanos, Meyer Lemon Mojo - Very moist and flaky fish, brown butter squash purée was very sweet and creamy paired very well together with the trout.

Monterey chipirones (Squid) a la Plancha, Arroz Negro, Chorizo, Ink, Artichokes, Alioli - Maybe I'm not used to Spanish grains but the black grains was very hard and chewy. Overall flavor of the dish was good.

Albóndigas - Pork, Lamb and Jamón Meatballs, Tomato Sherry Sauce - felt like this dish was a bit out of place because it felt more like an appetizer! Our meatballs were only warm...

I wish the food was hotter, some of the dishes came out just warm. Our drinks also didn't come until after the 2nd meal. I ordered Sparkling Sangria - with cava, pomegranate, lillet, orange and mint. My husband ordered Bony Fingers black lager. But overall our server was very nice and friendly. She checked on us multiple times and kept our water glass full. The restaurant ambiance is cute, it feels romantic but can get loud when it get busy. I wish the tasting menu swapped out the last dish for a dessert, it would have felt more complete!
author: Janny S.

description:
Quiero tener relaciones carnales CONTIGO. Jajajajaja!

The sparking sangria is lit! Cava is my friend so I downed two of these with my meal. The food isn't exactly like what I had in Spain, but good in its own right. The Seared Caña de Cabra Goat Cheese salad and Oxtail Hamburguesitas were off the hook! I also liked how the Pan con Tomate was served with a generous layer of tomato, although the bread could have been crunchier. Overall, a solid tapas spot in the city. Suany approved.
author: Suany W.

description:
Tapas tapas tapas.
The bigger the variety, the better.
South Bay friends invited me for an early mid August dinner here on a typical cool weeknight.  We were seated at an outdoor table that was comfortable as there was just a few occupied tables which gave a spacious feel.  Never been here, I trusted my gracious hosts in ordering our meal.  Asking for some advice from our waiter, here's what we enjoyed:

Tapas
1) Boquerones (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=4VhP4B71bHzq4Y5NFaaOgw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - white anchovies, avocado, lemon zest, espellete on toast.  This little fishy went to the market... this little fishy went to my tummy!  Not overly fishy, the avocado spread tamed the seafood flavor here.

Raciones frias
2) Melon con jamon (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KUtemOeLxn1ugHIhyjll3g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Jamon Serrano, melon, mint, black pepper syrup, roasted pistachios.  Call it a Spanish take on prosciutto and cantaloupe, let's confirm, yes, it works.

Raciones caliente
3) Samfaina (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SFY3Kh7X8mzBxE8ZfMcp9A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Catalan summer vegetables ratatouille  roasted in wood oven with farm egg.  My favorite of the small dishes, country style heartiness.

4) Monterey chipirones (squid) a la plancha (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=jOsONF9AEut8PiUqVIWN1w&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - shelling beans, Nardello peppers, chorizo, aioli.  Reminds me more of roasted octopus, but it is squid.

5) Lamb rib chops (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=gH4YpwMdMaRpP4ficNwqbg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)- piracicaba, smoked potatoes, cumin yogurt, preserved lemon charmoula. Just as lamb should taste, without a trace of gaminess.

6) Albondigas (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=0sGfy3nUsmZSn-8v4y5JJw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - pork, lamb, and jamon meatballs, tomato sherry sauce.  Give me a bowl of rice or a plate of noodles!  This would disappear with every last drop of the sauce.

Our waiter was attentive in removing and bringing plates as well as refilling water and drink glasses as needed.  It was a very relaxed environment since we came before dark.  However, you'll need to order more if you are hungry or have a hearty appetite.  My friend somewhat joked about having a bowl of Thai noodle soup to finish the evening, so we compromised and went to Mitchell's for some ice cream for dessert.
Nice neighborhood spot and away from the heavy foot traffic 24th Street corridor.  Yes, I would come back if and when the craving for tapas appear again.
author: Mike C.

description:
I've had Contigo bookmarked for a long time now and was excited I was finally able to try it last Sunday. 

We had considered doing the pre fixe menu but decided we wanted to pick our own options

Pan Con Tomate - fresh, sweet, robust tomato flavors come through 
Croqueta - good texture and seasoned fine 
Hot date - date sweetness definitely took the show 
Patas Bravas - underwhelming in texture and flavor 
Warren Pears w/ Jamon Serrano - copious amount of jamon balanced with the pear and assertive blue cheese 
Smoky Braised Pork Shoulder - what sounded like a promising dish yielded to be a letdown, flavors were lacking and not tender 
Albondigas - good meaty texture yet still light, flavors were complex and not your typical meatball
author: Eddie W.

description:
This place is perfect in every way - and I've been to many Michelin started restaurants that could learn here. The food is incredibly sourced from local farms and fisheries with only periodic exceptions like the barnacles from Spain. It's equally accessible to meat eaters (even sometimes oxtail and always tripe) and vegetable lovers. Two real hens: the sautéed greens with garlic and pine nuts and curants / great combo. The squid is always incredible and sometimes with Brussels sprouts and other times with black rice.
The servers and owners work as a wonderful team. If I had to eat at only one restaurant fir the rest of my life, this would be it
author: Clark F.

description:
Our first visit here was outstanding. We tried six dishes, and they were all outstanding: jamón ibérico, sardine toasts (fantastic!), croquetas de jamón serrano (best croquettes we've had in the Bay Area), espinacas con garbanzos (best we've had since we were in Madrid 5 years ago), trout with serrano ham, and chard Catalán style with pine nuts, pickled raisins, and roasted garlic (fantastic!). 

Nice atmosphere, comfortably spaced tables, and very friendly service. Crowded and popular, yet we still got a table booking the same day. 

Can't wait to go back.
author: David K.

description:
Finally got to try this local spot. Sat in the cute back  patio area on some flimsy chairs, (friend had to ask for a sturdier one because she felt like it was going to break or she'd fall.) 

Started off with some great sangria. Ordered a few different plates of food because we wanted to try it all. Although there were a lot of anchovy dishes so it limited us to anything non anchovy. I love tapas, but it's crazy how expensive they are for the portions.

Croquetas were probably the best thing I had.
Iberian ham and cheese was good.
Flat bread was good.
Calamari was tasty especially the squid ink risotto like stuff at the bottom!
Flan was probably some of the best I've tasted.

All in all, pretty good tapas - but pricey. Split the bill and didn't even feel like I ate worth the amount spent.
author: Nawal W.

description:
They really cram you in here at Contigo. I've almost caught my jacket on fire trying to slide into my table. The tables are really close together, and you will need help getting out.

They mix up their menu, but the most memorable thing I've had is some oxtail sliders. I could have eaten them all day. 

Overall, Contigo is expensive for tapas, and the plates are quite small, but their jamon and their other offerings are very tasty!
author: Christina S.

description:
Yummy!

This is one of the best / highest end food options in Noe. The atmosphere is great -- very slick and clean. They have a wide selection of options, and the food is super tasty and fresh. 

Understandably, you pay for the great service and food.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Contigo was a fantastic tapas/Spanish restaurant in the heart of Noe Valley. I came for dinner in a group of three on a Friday night, and I found that the food and service here were both excellent, and the atmosphere of the restaurant was so welcoming and modern. 

After ordering a bottle of Bobol red wine to share, we were started off with bread and olive oil for the table. Our first dish to share was the seared goat cheese salad, which came with chicories, persimmons, apples, pomegranate, hazelnut, and a toasted crouton. This dish was absolutely delicious and perhaps one of my favorites that we tried--the salad was so lightly but perfectly dressed in a slightly acidic vinaigrette, and everything paired so well together--the freshness of the vegetables/fruit, the creaminess of the cheese, and the crunchiness of the crouton.

Next, we had the oxtail hamburguesita, which was a hamburger "patty" made of strips of pulled, braised oxtail served with pickled onions in a bun. This dish was great, as the beef was so tender, but perhaps a tiny bit underseasoned. We also had the jamon crouquetas (fried fritter with serrano ham), which was nice and creamy, but not as hearty/savory as the name suggests. 

We continued our meal with the smashed pumpkin tosta, which was basically pureed pumpkin on toast (with some other ingredients) and the espinacas con garbonzos (spinach and chickpea stew with moorish spices). Both of these dishes were decent with very clean flavors, but nothing all that mind-blowing. Finally, we finished with the squid a la plancha (also one of my favorites of the night), which was grilled calamari over roasted Brussels sprouts--the squid and the sprouts were unbelievably flavorful, and the dish also had a very nice texture to it. We also had the albondigas (the pork/lamb/jamon meatballs), which were so juicy and tender, but the tomato sauce that the meatballs were drenched it wasn't particularly flavorful and left something to be desired.

Overall, Contigo offered some excellent food with clean flavors (definitely nothing too salty here, as I sometimes find in some tapas restaurants) and extremely friendly service. I'd definitely recommend this place for tapas in SF, though given the limited menu, I probably wouldn't be back myself anytime soon.
author: David K.

description: The secreto (iberico pork) tastes like an angel came down from heaven and French kissed you. The squid is grilled to perfection. And the atmosphere is intimidate and cozy (esp the back patio).
author: Ray H.

description: I adore this place. The interiors are cute, the service is incredible, and the food is just delicious. It is on the pricey side but well worth it. I had the best squid here and also their new chicken soupy paella was hitting all of the right spots. Highly recommend for a date night, girls/boys night, or family gatherings.
author: Terrie C.

description: As usual excellence in service, quality, flavor and authenticity comes home in Contigo. Lena, our waitress, and my favorite bar-dude made this night epic. I had my dream dinner, the paella tasting menu which included the sardine toast, croquettes, and the best paella I've ever had mated with a wonderful half-carafe that was so good, I bought some for the table next to me! After that, we all owned Contigo, transforming dinner into a family party that night! Contigo has it all going on. My favorite!
author: Kevin F.

description: Laid back yet lively ambiance at this Noe Valley gem. Tapas-style menu that's great for sharing. Good for dates and groups.
author: Jan R.

description:
It's a tapas world and we just live in it. Even Japanese izakayas here refer to themselves as tapas spots to cash in on the small plate trend. Like a lot of people around here, I was drawn to Contigo when I watched the three foodie guests rave about it on "Check, Please! Bay Area" a couple of years ago. Funny thing is that Jamie W. and I ended up visiting several other tapas joints in the city in the meantime - Beso, Canela, Bocadillos, Coqueta - before finding an excuse to meet up here with our friend Maggie in Noe Valley. We entered to see the wood-burning oven in full roar, and fortunately it was just starting to fill since the space is pretty compact.

We were a bit hesitant to be seated in the back patio since it was a particularly chilly evening, but they amped up the heat lamp in preparation for our arrival. It just felt comfortable back there next to the chopped wood and watching the more high-maintenance diners insist on being reseated indoors. Jamie and I both ordered the $11 Sparkling Sangria, which was a refreshing starter with cava, blood orange, lillet and rosemary (photo: http://bit.ly/1Y1fb8z), while Maggie had a $12 glass of the 2015 Ostatu Tempranillo/Garnacha, a crispy rosé ideal for what we were about to eat (photo: http://bit.ly/1SGINo1). We started with the $15 Seared Caña de Cabra Goat Cheese over a bed of arugula and radicchio with citrus, hazelnuts and PX vinagreta (photo: http://bit.ly/1QKt84O).

It was lovely and easy to share with the cheese reflecting the perfect soft consistency with a nice crust from the grill. Next came a trio of small bites on a serving paddle, the delicious Smoked Salmon Montadito with yogurt, truffle honey on toast, quimet and quimet style ($4 each, photo: http://bit.ly/1TDKyVm). Another trio came in quick succession, the Boquerones, Spanish white anchovies on toast with a spread of avocado and a splash of Meyer lemon ($2.50 each, photo: http://bit.ly/23gYkA3). The freshness of the fish made this my favorite of the two true tapas of the evening. We then graduated to the raciones calientes with the spectacular $15 Asparagus a la Plancha (photo: http://bit.ly/24tw2Vn).

The impeccably fresh asparagus were flash-fried on a grill and served with an olive oil-fried farm egg, mojama (salt-cured tuna), and pimentón almonds. The succulent $18 Local Dungeness Crab was a seasonal dish prepared simply by roasting it in the oven and seasoning it with black pepper, paprika, garlic and butter (photo: http://bit.ly/1pW9c9f). It came with an Asian-inspired hot chile sauce as well as some rustic bread for wiping up what was left of the sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1QKt0T4). But wait, there was more. Next came the $13 trio of Albóngidas, hearty meatballs made of pork, lamb and jamón swimming in a piquant tomato sherry sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1NeZbQ1). It really made me wish we made room for more of the jamón.

The $10 Patatas Bravas are probably the most common dish to be seen on a tapas table, or at least we order them as a must. These are no exceptions with the crispy-soft fried texture perfect and the accompanying aioli and salsa brava generous for dipping (photo: http://bit.ly/1W0Fjm6). This could be my favorite rendition of this Spanish standby. Finally came our hot ticket item, the $25 Lamb Rib Chops with broccoli, smoked potatoes, cumin yogurt, and preserved lemon charmoula (photo: http://bit.ly/1Y1eY5n). Even though it was logistically difficult to split two chops for three, the effort was worth it for the juicy tenderness of the lamb. You would think at this point that we were done, but no, since the guy on "Check, Please!" raved about the churros, well...

For $9, we managed to snag four of the legendary Churros, sugary doughnut pipes quite hot to the touch, while indulging in the Chocolate Caliente, a cup of thick Barcelona-style TCHO chocolate sprinkled with sea salt (photo: http://bit.ly/1Y1f1y2). Decadent richness with or without the churros which were a tad too sweet for my taste. Maggie had the wherewithal to order the $8 Brokaw Ranch Clementine Sorbete, a refreshing end to the meal with the snap of the sweet lemon shortbread (photo: http://bit.ly/1QKtEjp). All the while, the service was accommodating without being intrusive, and even as the patio started to crowd with equally enthusiastic diners, it never felt rushed or deafening. I think Contigo may very well reign supreme in the competitive tapas market.

FOOD - 5 stars...impreccably prepared from small plates to main dishes with a thick hot chocolate for the ages
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...compact space but comfortable in the back patio where conversations can be held without fuss
SERVICE - 5 stars...you can tell when long-time staffers serve you
TOTAL - 5 stars...definitely my favorite tapas spot in the city bar none
author: Ed U.

description:
3.5 stars

Good food? Yes, but it was definitely not what I expected from a Spanish restaurant.

Contigo has a Catalan-inspired menu in that you'll find a lot of Mediterranean flavors in their dishes (I.E. "Moorish spices," couscous, chickpeas). I was craving Spanish comfort food/tapas and had a hearty meal. But were my cravings satisfied? No.

I don't just eat Spanish food because I'm craving gambas al ajillo, patatas bravas, or even manchego/jamon serrano. I ain't no basic bitch! I love Spanish cuisine for the flavors; some pimenton, some garlic, some saffron, some good olive oil. Contigo just caught me off guard because they highlight the Mediterranean and it just wasn't what I was looking for. It was comparable to eating at a Moroccan restaurant, tbh.

That said, I'm not docking off stars because the restaurant is "Not Spanish"; it totally is Spanish. After all, the Moors occupied Spain for hundreds of years and even dominated up to 70% of the country at one point in time. 3 stars is more of a reflection of how I felt about my meal; it just fell short.

We ordered:
-Hot DATE: Not the best bacon wrapped dates I've had, so I was pretty underwhelmed. I could skip this.
-CROQUETA de Jamón Serrano: Also not the best croquettes I've had. These were the consistency of the hash browns at McDonalds, which is not necessarily a bad thing but I expected something more refined.
-Salt Cured Spanish ANCHOVY MONTADITO: I'm one of those people who really likes anchovies, so this was a guilty pleasure of mine. I liked the house made mató cheese (whey cheese of ricotta consistency). Black pepper was a little overpowering though. I'm in no position to offer menu changes but tomato would've been a great combo w/ the mató and anchovy.
-ALBONDIGAS: Very Mediterranean tasting. The sauce was good and reminded me of shakshuka with hints of harissa (or at least the ingredients of harissa aka bell peppers, paprika, etc.). The meatballs themselves left something to be desired though because I couldn't really detect the different meats
-ESPINACAS CON GARBANZOS: Super flavorful and maybe my favorite thing that we ordered, but again this was a more Mediterranean dish. It tasted like an amped up hummus. Technically this dish is more from Andalucia/Sevilla than Catalonia, but whatever it's good! ;)
-COLIFLOR- Kind of limp and not crispy :( I still ate it all because I needed some vegetable and the cauliflower was nicely seasoned.
-JAMON SERRANO & MANCHEGO pasamontes: We ordered this as more of an afterthought for familiarity. Served with rustic country bread, membrillo, and hazelnuts, I'm glad we got this.

I actually came here for the tripe with chorizo and chickpeas (which I'm assuming is their take on menudo gitano?), but they weren't serving it. Callos is one of my favorite Spanish dishes ever, but I guess this was just not my night :(

Other notes:
-I really liked the staff. Both people helping us were pretty cool and our waiter was very funny.
-Completely farm to table menu, awesome
-No pitchers of sangria; sparkling sangria is $11/glass and very pretty w/ pomegranate seeds
-Wines are all from Spain. $11-15 for a 5oz pour, $60 and up for a bottle, half bottles also available
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: Got the tasting menu for me and my girlfriend and had lots of food leftover! First time here and wanted to get a tour of the food. Good way to go. Nice service. Comfortable ambiance
author: Sophia N.

description:
Girlfriend and I play catch up and we were unable to decide where to because we both are on a diet, it's the race to the who's going to go down to size 0 and she's clearly winning. I recall the night before at a party, a nice woman and I met for the first time and we bonded over our travels and food. She raved about this restaurant and that's how Yvonne and I ended up at Contigo, a Michelin recommended restaurant in the sleepy part of Noe. That evening the street parking was aplenty and it felt a nice relief to be able to park and walk straight into the restaurant, which was crowded.

For women who are watching their waistline, this is an excellent restaurant with a lot of one bite options I think tapas should all look like this. These little one bites are delightful and quite complicated to assemble. Definitely do the quail eggs and Spanish white anchovies, What a delightful sight. Almost too pretty to eat.

For the shared plates, the tripe reminds me a lot of the Italian version at Cockscomb in SoMA and the traditional German Swabian dishes found in Stuttgart. I liked it quite a lot, for all those nice flavors evoked my memories of last year dining at Cockscomb and getting all excited about their menu, and my past travels to one of my favorite regions in Germany. The Monterrey squid was a nice plate of fresh tender squids with good veggies around it. Makes me want to give that dish a swirl at home. So healthy and fun to eat. Oxtail mini burgers were very hearty and the buns were exceptional, so for someone who does not want to do carbs, please just simply give in and take a bite at that damn heavenly thing already. 

There are a tasting menu on the offering. For an average American male I think that's the way to go, for two petite Asian women, that would eat up our entire weekend's calories. So we did not go for that option.

The decaf is lovely at the end of the meal, especially if you go with their house dessert choice of flour less cake.

I know very little about Spanish food. But this is for sure one of the nicer ones out there, the attention to the detail was clearly present. The things that shined the most are their one bite tapas. I still think about the quail egg and spanish fish toasts.

I'm a terrible party goer, the woman I met at the party handed me her card, she is also an accomplished musician. I had promised to get in touch after the party to catch up. But... I think I left her card at the party and I'm too embarrassed to ask the host what her contact info is. I couldn't remember her name or her band name, but I did remember going to her favorite Spanish spot in town immediately after the party. So I guess in the grand scheme of things, I did have my priorities straight.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Date night winner dinner!!!

My man heard me mention this place - that I wanted to go - after seeing it on Check Please.  

He made a reservation and we took a Lyft. We were 15 mins late for our 5:45 reservation on a Saturday - but "no problem" they said.

We were seated in the back heated garden. I will say that there were quite a few parents who took their kids here on a Saturday night (which I find a bit odd, it isn't super kid friendly food to my mind, but what do I know? I don't have any, and in general don't like 'em).

Our waiter Kyle was adorable and very accommodating - when we were deciding on wine he offered us a taste of two to decide between.

We ordered a bunch of items: the salad with the goat cheese, the cheesy hammy fritters, the mushroom toasts, the churros, the abogando Meatballs, and my favorite was a couple of small pieces of spanish salami on toast with an itty bitty perfectly fried quail egg on top- GAR!...SO YUM-MY!

The first few things came out and we gobbled them up. Them we asked Kyle to S-L-O-W the pace down. He was perfect and got to a great pace for the remaining courses.

This place was a perfect little treat, I loved it!! - AND right on the 24 bus line.
author: Amy W.

description:
Worth all the good reviews. We had dinner yesterday here and loved the tasting menu. Highly recommend.  Probably 4.5 stars. 

We started with two small bites
- smoke salmon 
- croquette with ham
Both were great to warm up the appetite.  We were hungry so the starch settled our stomach as well

Next was the smoked trout salad.  Very refreshing and tasty.  Smoked trout was salty as you would expect so we asked for some bread.  Olive oil that came with it was yummy. Hubby ate all of it all in a sec. :-)

4th course- asparagus with fried egg and paprika almonds. Wow.  Great mixture of flavor.  Really good. 

5th course grilled squid with squid ink rice.  The squid was perfected charred.  Hubby loves the rice.  

6th course - halibut wrapped in a leaf.  I almost asked not to serve this one as I have never been a halibut fan.  Not enough flavor not soft enough.    Boy was I happy to keep this dish. Was delicious and the lentil was very flavorful and a perfect compliment. Definitely getting this again

Last course - albondigas.  Pork and lamb meatball. Only had a few bites as I was soooo full.   Very fresh meatball.  

Next time maybe only six dishes.  We will definitely be back and with friends. :-)
author: Lei H.

description: This is my Favorite place to eat Spanish Tapas,everything is so flavorful and the owners are so nice! Lauren the Chef is Amazing! The staff is very attentive!Anytime you are looking for Tapas this is the place for you!
author: tommy b.

description: Wonderful, authentic, fresh, bright flavors and a great wine list. One of my favorite restaurants in the whole city.
author: Jackie C.

description:
Food was great. But they sat us right at rear door. Every time a waiter went in and out they would leave the door open and the cold wind would hit my back.  So I literally had to close it behind them cuz they're too stupid to notice.  I closed it at least 10 times meanwhile trying to enjoy my dinner. 

Then some waiter said they are aware of it and was kinda annoyed that I kept closing behind them.  He called me "Pappi". Lol

I used to love coming here all the time. I think I'm done with this place. I hope they take my last $180 and buy a self door closure. 

Goodbye
author: Karma Is Coming 4 U.

description:
Whether dining a prixfixe tab or Contigo eats
I eat all it, food comas make me falling asleep
I keep ballin, and always order 6 dishes deep
I'm out for apps entrees to represent me
Eat what?
I'm out for apps entrees to represent me
Drink what?
I'm out for #eatallthefoods to represent me
Whose meal is this?
The meal is mine, the meal is mine
It's mine it's mine it's mine whose meal is this?

Classy-enough ambience. Service is friendly but spread thin, especially during crowds. Eat here if you're ready to move out the ConGETO to the ConTIGO. #movinonup #totheeatside

(^_^) Croqueta De Jamon Serrano $3.5 (http://bit.ly/1jJsBbb)
Like hot pockets but awesome.

(^_^) Albondigas $13 (http://bit.ly/1iYmJdq)
Is the new chef boyardee.

(^_^) Tripe w Chorizo & Chickpeas $10 (http://bit.ly/1WHvzLv)
Chitlins what chitlins who?

(^_^) Boquerones & Avocado Toast $2.5 (http://bit.ly/1GrCIWV)
These sardines weren't from a can.
And they weren't even sardines!

(^_^) Dirty Girl Farm Tomato Gazpacho $4.5 (http://bit.ly/1jJsL21)
Best ketchup soup ever.

(^_^) Sawed-off Wine Bottle Glasses $0 (http://bit.ly/1RqkFa3)
Dope as feezy.

(-_^) Lamb Rib Chops $24 (http://bit.ly/1FRJSJ5)
Dem dispensary potatoes doe.

(-_^) Housemade Strawberry Soda $4 (http://bit.ly/1NfPJdZ)
Call syzzurp; tell her she's fired.

(-_^) Housemade Vanilla Orange Kombucha $4 (http://bit.ly/1hkUvbA)
OE? Nah gimme the 40oz OK.

I need a new eata for this menu to follow
Cause while it's front of me I'm too hangry to eat tomorrow
Trying to maintain I sip fill the glass to the tip
Picturing each dish now the camera make my insty skip
And I'm fed up they locked the chef up
Even mah belleh's in handcuffs
author: Dan B.

description:
TLDR - cozy ambience and yummy tapas! opt for the tasting menu if you don't know what to get, but make sure you get the croquetas and squid!

I'm not sure why, but for some reason, I really love tapas. I don't know if it's the tiny portions and me liking tiny things or if it's the shared plates and me liking to try a little bit of a lot of dishes, but a tapas restaurant is pretty much always a good choice for me, so I ended up picking Contigo to have my birthday dinner with friends. Not sure if reservations are usually needed/recommended since we came for an early dinner, but they take them so might as well make one in case.

The restaurant is modern and trendy but still has a cozy, intimate atmosphere. There's normal seating and bar seating inside, but my friends and I chose to sit on the patio out back. Limited seating out there though!

The menu has a good selection of tapas ranging from single bites to small plates to larger "entree" plates as well as beer and wine. I had done my Yelp research beforehand so I knew what I wanted, but since most of those dishes ended up being on the tasting menu for the night, we ended up just going with that. 

Service was great! Our waiter was super friendly, energetic and very attentive. Food came out at a good pace, but each dish came out one at a time and I wish they had brought out multiple at once, but only more so for pictures than anything else.. (yes, guilty as charged)

Food overall was pretty good. The tapas I loved and would recommend ended up being the ones that Yelp had recommended and that I had wanted to get in the first place: CROQUETAS, MONTEREY XIPIRONS (squid) and ALBONDIGAS (meatballs). The HALIBUT was pretty good too. The rest were mostly pretty forgettable - still really good but not special enough for me to want to order them again. If you're indecisive and/or unsure of what to order, then the tasting menu is definitely a good option! Otherwise, just skip the tasting menu and order what you actually want to try. There are definitely things on the menu I wish I had gotten instead of some things in the tasting. 

Our TASTING MENU ($46/person) consisted of:

-GULF SHRIMP (off menu) - 3/5
Didn't really leave an impression on me, neither good nor bad. Just normal shrimp. 

-CROQUETA DE JAMON SERRANO (normally $3.50 each) - 5/5
[crisp and creamy fritter of spanish serrano ham]
Perfectly fried! Crispy on the outside without being greasy, and creamy and savory on the inside without being too cheesy. Nice contrast of textures.

-WARM DELICATA SQUASH SALAD (normally $14) - 3/5
[chanterelles, pomegranate, fennel, frisee, shaved idiazabal]
Nothing memorable. The squash was cooked well but there was nothing special about the flavors or the salad in general. Not really worth getting.

-SAMFAINA (normally $15) - 3.5/5
[catalan autumn vegetable ratatouille, topped with farm egg]
I love runny, undercooked eggs! Aside from that, the ratatouille was made well - veggies were tender and not too salty - but didn't really stand out much.

-MONTEREY XIPIRONS (SQUID) A LA PLANXA (normally $16) - 5/5
[arros negre, chorizo, ink, baby artichokes, allioli, guindilla chile]
YUM. Superrr tender squid! Plump and full of flavor. I've never had squid ink before and thought it would have a more distinctive/unique taste, but while savory and tasty, the rice/ink was more normal than I expected. Also supposed to be a little spicy but I didn't feel any of the chile/heat. Definitely recommend!!

-OLIVE OIL FRIED ALASKAN HALIBUT (normally $27) - 4/5
["gazpacho salad" of tomatoes, cucumbers, grapes, croutons, basil allioli]
Beautifully plated! Halibut was incredibly moist and flaky and, like the croquetas, perfectly crispy on the outside. The basil allioli was deeeeelicious!

-ALBONDIGAS (normally $13) - 4/5
[pork, lamb and jamon meatballs in tomato sherry sauce]
Meaty, tender and juicy. Well-cooked, but I didn't find the flavor of the meatballs or the tomato sauce to be special or unique. Still really tasty though so I'd probably order it again.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Delighted to have finally found the best Spanish restaurant in the Bay. Came here with my boyfriend based on the yelp reviews and it's safe to say that it did not disappoint. We shared the broccoli and chorizo flatbread to start with, it was so so good! We shared the paella for mains, this particular night it had duck, asparagus and mushrooms. I wouldn't normally be ordering duck but based on the reviews I knew it would be tasty and wow it's totally changed my perspective on duck. We paired this with a lovely bottle of red wine, we asked for the closest to pinot noir and the waiter was spot on with the bottle he suggested. For dessert we got the almond cake with rhubarb and fresh cream. Finally a place that doesn't use cream from a can! 
All in all great service and ambiance, we paid roughly about $130 excluding tip which was quite good considering we had a bottle of wine in that too. 
Can't wait to return with our friends!
author: Sinead M.

description:
Loved the tasting menu. It's a really great price and value. I wasn't sure about the portion size and whether it would be enough food for our group but it was actually perfect! We were full and satisfied, I wish I had room for dessert!

Now I just have to remember what we ate...

- croqueta de jamon serrano: super creamy filling, yummy
- mackeral + avocado toast: interesting combo, it was unexpected but really good
- warm squash salad: well balanced textures and flavors
- squid with black rice: squid was perfectly tender, rice was a bit too spicy
- ratatouille with baked egg: prob my least favorite, egg gets rubbery overcooked
- fried halibut: this was really good, the basil aioli was a good complement
- albondigas: was okay, nice and moist, but was full by this point

They were also super friendly with our toddler. It's not a huge space so I'm glad we had a reservation. Love the decor and layout. There's even a tiny patio for the warm nights to enjoy dining al fresco. I think the neighborhood it's in adds to its charm.

Creative for tapas in my book. Wondering if they change their menu much. Would recommend trying it.
author: Sarah A.

description:
i came here with a party of 4. we decided to make reservations a week prior and i'm really glad that we did because by the time we got to the restaurant, it was pretty packed. we decided to order 4 tapas each and share two entrees.

hot date (4/5) - i'm not a fan of dates, but bacon wrapped date was a very interesting combination. i would recommend to eat this last because it's more sweet than savory

pinchos morunos de pollo (4/5) - i love meat skewers and the chicken wasn't dry

croqueta de jamon serrano (5/5) - i'm a fan of croquettes. this tapa dish reminded me of Porto's Bakery in socal haha.

oxtail hamburgueslta (5/5) - this oxtail slider was really delicious. i recommend this!

monterey chipirones (squid) a la plancha (5/5) - the squid and the rice (i'm guessing it's covered in squid ink) was really delicious. i recommend this dish as well!

albondigas (4/5) - i'm usually really picky with meatballs, but these meatballs were bad. our waitress even offered us free bread to eat with our meatballs and dip in the tomato sauce.

this was my 2nd time eating at a tapas restaurant. the food and the service were excellent. our waitress kept checking up on our table frequently. they left us with a jar of water and even helped us refer our cups from time to time. there's a bar near the front entrance. the restaurant isn't really big so i would recommend to make reservations for parties of 4 or more. there's one unisex restroom for everyone to use. the ambience is good for a dinner date. there's plenty of meter parking outside, but i'm not sure how easy it is to find parking in this area. i would definitely come back here for tapas!
author: Sylvia H.

description:
Ok, the place is nice, has a welcome atmosphere, quaint neighborhood, and the food is good, although the portions are small. ( I know is a tapas place) but they are smaller than a tapa. Affordable price in the menu but if you don't want to leave hungry; the prices add up and it turns out the place is very expensive.
One thing that REALLY TURNED ME OFF, is how aggressive the waitress was up selling.
I get it, she wanted to make money which benefits her and the restaurant, but there is a professional and subtle way to do it.
I have countless check ins and I'm a foodie and certainly not a " cheap" person. We were three people having a good time and ordering away on a Friday night. But she diminished our choices always offering more/ extra portions because " that was not enough" or the one you picked is " not that great" offering the most expensive on the menu. 
Bottom line, I know what I want and like. What I order, is what I want. Don't be aggressive, trying to rip people off.
I will certainly not be going back. I'd rather go to Bellota or coqueta.
Dear management/ ownership, please teach your stuff not to be so aggressive upselling! Is a turn off and disrespectful.
We were three and still spend 320 dollars. Do you want more than that? NO. Give me a break.
author: Junior V.

description: Good service. Solid selections. Order the churros y chocolate, it's totally spanish style with high end chocolate.
author: Chi C.

description: I like this place and would definitely return if I was in the area. The food was good, the ambiance was nice, and the service was good.
author: Araceli G.

description:
My husband recommended to try this place. And let me tell you, he is a big foodie. I guess I am a bigger foodie now, since I am so picky and I want only the best. 
I didn't like the place as much as I wanted. The dishes were too salty and cheesy. Literally cheese was everywhere. 
The dishes are not unique at all. 
But the service: the service is amazing. The manager is a sweetheart. He gave me flowers, because I joked with him. 
We over ordered food, and decided to cancel on fish last second, the manager accommodated us. 
I always say you gotta try it for yourself and see. People have different taste, so never judge other foodies. Try and see.
author: Jenna F.

description:
Tucked away, yet not tucked away, in Noe Valley away from the chaos of The Mission and Castro, Contigo adds to the great addition of the tapas scene of San Francisco. Catalan inspired menu, this place has great vibes, relaxed, slightly dimmed for a nice conversation with friends or a date night kind of place. 

FOOD: Croqueta de Jamon Serrano, Octopus Pinchos, Asparagus a La Plancha, Albondigas, Patatas Bravas. Churro con Chocolate. I must say, what an exquisite and tasty menu. The croqueta came out well with bits of jamon inside. The only thing is I wish there was more ham inside! The octopus pinchos came out super well because the octupus was cooked to perfect. Not rubbery at all and the right amount of seasoning with the pepper as well combined made for the perfect bite. The asparagus came out cooked right with the asaparagus bitterness nowhere to be found. The albondigas (meatballs) were tender and had the right lamb/pork/jamon mix in it. The tomato sherry sauce was also great on it. The patatas bravas were fried to the right crisp and the salsa brava was to die for. Finally, the churro con chocolate was the creme de la creme with the right amount of fullness and richness to the chocolate. I wish the churro was a little bit larger and had a little bit more dough in the middle, but the dessert came out well to end the meal on a nice note. 
 
SERVICE: Attentive and great! 

Overall, this locale is one for the books if you want to come for a higher end, fancier kind of place to impress friends or your date. With so many options on the menu, you can try so many things at once. Maybe it transported me back to Barcelona or Bilbao, but this place is uniquely San Francisco!
author: Albert H.

description:
I walk by Contigo all the time and FINALLY made it in for a meal.  I was with a large group that included 3 small children, on a busy Saturday night.  Contigo is one of the better Spanish restaurants in SF.

Contigo is a small restaurant with city-wide appeal.  We ordered a bunch of dishes to satisfy multiple tastes and preferences.  My favorites were the tripe, churros and patatas bravas.  The group also enjoyed the albondigas, squid, octopus, and croquettes.  The food was fresh, well seasoned and cooked to perfection.

The sangria was quite good, a I found it refreshing, light and well balanced.  It was a perfect beverage for the heat wave we were experiencing that weekend.

Service was great.  The kids with us are well behaved and are comfortable eating in restaurants with "adult" food.  Our waitress was fantastic and had some great recommendations for the adults and for the kids.  She even joked around with the kids during the meal.  I would like to thank her for making our experience so enjoyable that night.  

They have a covered patio in back, tables in the main section of the room and bar seating near the door that provides a great view of the kitchen.  It was noisy in the dining area, but not overly loud.  Tables are placed close to one another.

Parking was relatively easy as we found several parking spots within one block of the restaurant.  Reservations are a must for large parties.  I would say this restaurant is geared towards adults looking for a fun and lively night out.  While we were there our table was the only one with children.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Excellent service. Extremely polished and attentive.

In a nutshell, I felt the tapas outshone the raciones (with the exception of the flatbread and albondigas, both excellent) Would recommend this place for a glass of fino or albarino rather than a full meal.
author: Dylan L.

description:
Great food, great service, low-key, and very affordable. Easy to get a reservation which is surprising considering the high-quality of the food. Think Star Belly for ambiance and higher quality everything else.

We had a party of four: appetizers, main course, drinks, and dessert for $120 -what!!! -
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
ABSOLUTELY UNACCEPTABLE.

One star assessment is fair for tonights experience. As an elite yelper to tell their followers and fellow yelpers it sucks to write one of these one star reviews on a restaurant you would give five stars to. For the 9 yrs of observing restaurants it's rare to experience an evening like this. I love eating here and tasting their delicious tapas and sipping on wine. However, it is quite a major disappointment when people at the bar seats become neglected. Only fed free water and never come back to take an order or to check up on them. After waiting for 15 minutes trying to get the attention of someone, even the host (who isn't doing her job and blabbing with people instead of "hosting"), it was a walk-out... an evening of finish the free water, idling wondering wth is going on, and walk out the door with an empty stomach. That's a bummer!!! The other people sitting to the right of the bar seats section had empty dishes around them as if nobody has bothered to swing by to pick them up and ask them for anything else. Don't forget this part of the restaurant... It's the front of the house sitting in front of the chefs, it should get a lot of attention. For such a great establishment to have such poor quality customer service was a real disappointment.
author: Jane A.

description:
Came here on a busy friday night. Very friendly waiter, gave us some great suggestions and since this is our first time here we decided to do the tapas sampling which cost about 46 per person. 

Started off with the famous oven roasted sardines, very good, goes well with the brad. Then came the arugula salad with goat cheese, I think it was a ok but all my friends loved it. Third course was the croquetas filled with ham and cheese, I think this is a must try dish on menu, very very tasty. Fourth course was the prawns with squid ink rice, another must try on the menu. We all loved it. Fifth course came the roasted asparagus, again I think it was just a okay. Sixth course was the meatball, very rich in flavor and we all loved it. Seventh and final dish was the salmon, it was just a okay. 

Came dessert time we ordered the signature chocolate sauce with churros, strawberry sorbet and flan, all very delicious. Great coffee as well. 

Great service, great staff and great atmosphere. We will be back again!
author: William C.

description:
I love Spanish tapas and I've been to quite a few tapas restaurants. Overall this place was ok but probably won't be coming back.

Food: Nothing really stood out. We had the jamon serrano, hot dates, octopus skewer, asparagus, albondigas, and Dungeness crab.

Drinks: No sangria pitchers!! They only have sangria by the glass (and small glasses at that). Most of our bill was the sangrias. Go to a different tapas place if you want to get more for what you pay for.

Service: excellent, no complaints there
author: Laura D.

description:
I love options, which is why I really love the concept of tapas. I want to taste everything! Lol. I've been blessed to find awesome authentic tapas spots in the DMV area, so I had some expectations for this Michelin mentioned place. 

What I ordered: 
The beet salad - this wasn't too bad. The beets were sweet, but the dressing was too much. 

Jamon Iberico, Sarró de cabra - I'm partial to goat cheese, but the jamon was more like a jerky - did not expect that. Anyways, what a weird combo right? But I chose them to enjoy separately, not together. And besides, the charcuterie options was lacking. Then again, this is not what I came here for. 

Tapas -
1) anchovy gilda - delicious bite. Ugh, I had 2 of these
2) sardine and avocado toast - another delicious 2-biter. Also had 2 of these. The avocado mellowed out the sardine. That shouldn't have surprised me but it did. 
3) anchovy montadito - this was also very yummy. Both anchovy bites were not at all fishy. Bravo. 

Pricing- 
The tapas were decently priced for the taste and quality, I would definitely just go here for these. Maybe it was the company I went with that I felt items were slightly more expensive (by $0.50 for the tapas alone haha). 

Atmosphere- 
They have a well-lit outside seating area in the back with heating lamps. The inside dining area is more dimly lit and can get loud. I think next time I'd sit at the bar.  The service was ok. I wish the servers were more interactive haha. 

Overall- this place could definitely be better - have more charcuterie options (get better jamon iberico). Come to experience the tapas. But honestly, I don't think I can give a complete review without trying a main dish. I will see you again Contigo.
author: Moni A.

description: Went to contigo a few days ago for a friends birthday. First off, the waiter was really good. Attentive, polite and friendly. Ordered a gazpacho tapas- which was excellent. Most of the food used seasonal veggies which were delicious. The vegetable ratatouille was very flavorful and a must try. The meatballs and squid are staples. They always turn out to be good here. My only complaint is with the salad- I would have liked to see less frisée. Dessert time- Churros were just okay but the dipping chocolate was delicious. The best was the helado- vanilla bean icecream with olive oil and sea salt...Yummy.
author: Chet L.

description:
I would say 3.5 stars. We got the tasting menu, which actually was a really good deal given that we got to try many items and were stuffed at the end!

Unfortunately,, the taste of some of the dishes were lacking. I agree with the other reviewers who said some is great and some are really lacking. I really enjoyed the white anchovy avocado toast, the calamari with Brussels sprouts, and the trout with forbidden rice! Yummmm. The rest of what we tried was forgettable IMO.
author: Jen B.

description: Came to Contigo with some friends on a weeknight. We started with the sparkling sangria - so refreshing. We shared a flatbread, croquetas, pratatas bravas, and octopus. It was all delicious. We loved being able to try a little bit of everything. Can't wait to come back
author: Christina S.

description:
Who doesn't love tapas in a cute neighborhood. Noe Valley is always cozy and Contigo has good vibes with a big open bar, roomy booths,and a romantic back heated patio. Most of the tapas plates are really small so I suggest you get the bigger plates to share. 
Notables:
Sautéed Greens Catalan Style
Patatas Bravas
Flatbread~ pizza style
Lamb Chop Ribs
Squid a la Planxa
Albondigas~ meatballs

Contigo is a good place for tasting everything and sharing everything so good for groups or a romantic date. They always have a tasting menu which is worth a try. Food always fresh, tasty and delicious! Four stars!
author: Maria M.

description: I wasn't expecting much and I'm glad I didn't.  Was there this past Saturday with some friends from SF and decided to dine here.  I like Tapas but there wasn't any dish that was outstanding.  In fact, I had a dish they recommended which was pretty terrible b/c of the quality of the albacore.  Aside from the food, service was very good.  I would've given it 2 stars but service gets an extra star.
author: Khoi N.

description:
Came here for a birthday celebration with a small group so I was able to sample a good amount of dishes across the menu. Menu changes everyday.

The stand out was the lamb chop dish but we all thought $19 for one small lamb chop is a bit steep. Croquetas were also steep. $5 a piece. No, you are not reading it wrong. It's $5 bucks a pop. It was good but not $5 good. I would give it $3 max. Goat cheese salad with pear and persimmon was nice and bright.

Food overall was good, service was nice but nothing was mind blowing.

The restaurant is small but good looking. Contemporary, clean, fun and earthy.

They didn't sell pitchers of sangria but they did by glass ($10). It was nice and I liked that it was bubbly. I also liked that they had non-alcoholic options. The strawberry lemon soda ($4) was great. Peach iced tea was nice as well ($2), unsweetened. 

We ordered all the desserts on the menu. All were good but the stand out was the hot chocolate with churros ($9). They did add a candle to one of the desserts for our birthday celebration.

Solid 3 stars.
author: Andy W.

description: Fresh, delicious food. Super friendly staff and comfortable yet upscale. Definitely high quality and fantastic flavor all around!
author: Kelly R.

description:
I had the option to dine pretty much anywhere I wanted to in San Francisco to celebrate a huge achievement in my life. I chose Contigo and I don't regret any second of it! 

I have heard great things about Contigo and was so excited to dine there. However, I was a bit sceptical because being that I've been to Spain and have tried their amazing cuisine, I was worried that this place wouldn't be as "authentic." I'm very happy to say that I was wrong! Every bite that my party and I took kept on getting better and better with every dish that would arrive at our table. 

A few things to note: Although I looked on Open table and did not see an available table for 4 for the time that we needed, I was able to call the restaurant and they had a table for us. This happens a lot in SF so don't be afraid to call the restaurant if Open Table isn't giving you a table. Also, I wouldn't recommend the tasting menu. Although it seems as though you will get a large variety of food, it actually made sense to order a few things off the menu and create your own "tasting menu." 

Food: You MUST get both of their anchovy tapas. The avocado one is to die for and my mouth is watering as I'm typing this review. The signature tomato toast tapa reminded me of Spain and dining at a small cafe eating this toast while sipping my sangria. The salmon, I would pass on that as it wasn't anything special. I don't eat meat, so I can't vouch for their duck and meatballs, but the rest of my party absolutely loved it. Same goes with the calamari, although I don't eat it (and wish that I did because the dish's presentation was to die for), everyone else at my party said it's their favorite meal! Make sure to leave room for dessert. Their warm churros and chocolate... speechless! 

All in all, this place is a MUST go if you're visiting SF or are an SF local. The service was outstanding, the food was mouth watering and I loved the ambience. I can't wait to go back and hopefully be able to sit outside!

Thanks Contigo for bringing Spain to San Francisco!
author: Anastasia N.

description:
Our third visit to this neighborhood beauty, and like other visits, we were impressed with the authenticity of the dishes, their straightforward presentation, and their complete deliciousness. The food is truly the best you can get at a Spanish restaurant or tapas bar in the Bay Area, and we try them all. 

Also impressive is the service, which goes beyond mere attentiveness. They pay such close attention to your table that they don't overload your table with all the different things you've ordered, but bring the next one as soon as you've finished something, so that you always have a few things on the table but it's never overcrowded. And the staff behaves and speaks as if they truly enjoy having you there. 

I would strongly recommend this restaurant to couples or groups up to 8.
author: Mark P.

description:
this place has amazing value for the quality of the food - the $40 tasting menu is a steal! I also really like the warm ambience of the place.

some of the best things from the menu:
Calamaras or Squid a la Plancha - great balance of flavor. tasty calamari with crunchy favor-infused rice
Albodigas - lamb and pork meatball. signature dish

solid:
smashed pea toast with porcini and trumpet mushroom -- wished that it was more on the mushroom side, the smashed pea was by contrast overwhelming the mushroom taste. but still good
Chocolata Calenta with Churro -- rather than a churro dish with chocolate dipping, this is actually just hot chocolate with churros on the side. after one finishes churros, feel free to drink up the hot chocolate. This may be quite rich at the end of a long meal.

avoid:
tripe with chorizo and chickpeas -- a bit too salty and saucy, and didn't bring out the best characteristic of trip

For a first timer, the best way to explore the restaurant is the $40 set menu.
author: Rebecca C.

description: I first came to this restaurant in October and loved it. The tasting menu is where it's at! However, the menu is seasonal so when I came here yesterday night, the tasting menu was not as good as last time. Instead, I chose my own tapas etc. I will come back again, but only when the menu changes again.
author: Ricardo R.

description: This is my favorite Spanish restaurant in San Francisco! I love the friendly staff, unpretentious service and fresh/seasonal tapas. My favorites include the sardine + avocado toast, flatbread and squid a la plancha. It's a great neighborhood spot that we're lucky to have in Noe.
author: Nicola L.

description:
I was there with my work mates for a celebration dinner. The food was good.

As soon as we paid, we were asked to vacate our table. Just left a weird taste for my group, as if we were not welcome there or had left a scant tip.

I understand that they have other patrons who were waiting. However, it's just not how service works at a high end restaurant. I mentioned this to the maître d' as I was walking out, so this isn't a passive-aggressive way to get back at the restaurant. 

Maybe the owners aren't paying close attention to these details anymore.
author: U S.

description: The food was superb. I really liked the meatball and churro. The waitress was very nice and attentive. I wish the tables weren't so close together, but that's SF for you. I would go here as a first date or with a good friend.
author: Savvy P.

description: Good tapas! Not amazing, but we concluded that everything on the table was solid. We got two orders of the Albondigas (blended meatballs), everything else we were happy to try just once. For 4 people the bill came out around $200... with a tip included $240. We had one bottle of wine and probably 5 or 6 tapas, which filled us up. They have my mom free dessert (galette) on the way out which was unexpected and tasty. Our waitress was very kind. Open kitchen. Medium amount of seating. Parking was okay, we found a spot on the side of the road, granted it was metered parking so it's always a gamble.
author: Vivian L.

description: First visit but not last. Service impeccable and food superb. Somewhat chilly due to strong winds outside but ambience very nice. Seemed like a favorite with neighborhood as several people greeted as regular visitors. That speaks well to both food and service. We shared tapas as well as both hot and cold plates. Everyone very pleased with the experience here. Kudos to entire staff!
author: Patricia N.

description: Delicious food, in particular the flatbread, ribs and croquettes. Other dishes are good but tend to be a little salty for my taste. Terrific churros and wonderful service.
author: Nancy R.

description: For drinks, we ordered the sparkling strawberry soda and apricot ice tea. They were pretty yummy. No refills. For starters we had the coca with summer squash. It tasted like a very thin pizza. It was delicious. Next came the Monterey squid...it came with beans. It was nothing spectacular. Later we had the seafood squid ink paella. It was absolutely delicious. Would I come back? Why not? I would come back for the paella.
author: con c.

description: This place had great potential but the service was abysmal (with the exception of the attentive and pleasant busboy). Great example of a restaurant that has the advantages of a SF location, without the delivery of a pleasant dining experience. It's been over 20 years since I've taken such pleasure in not tipping the wait staff (busboy did get tipped). Customer service 101 training needed for this front of house krewe! Won't be back.
author: carol d.

description: This is my favorite place to have tapas in the City. The selection of small plates is has many similar items I remember eating in Spain. Albondigas, jamon serrano, patatas bravas, and vegetable dishes as well. I am never disappointed with the wine I order. The ambiance and service is also stellar. This is my go to place when friends or family come from out of town and I want to go someplace special.
author: G F.

description:
Mi amigo came into town to visit, hinting that we should do dinner. Easy going as he was, did not have a preference of where to dine. While we talked for hours, a conversation came up about how much he'd enjoyed tapas style dining and have not found a good one near his area. With that said and done, I thought about Contigo being a perfect place to surprised him. 


The weekend approached and it was time I met up with him over dinner. Without telling him where we were eating for dinner, he drove and drove until we reached our destination in the heart of Noe Valley. Located on the quiet end of Castro Street which made parking manageable. The restaurant was small with an intimate and romantic feel to it. We dined inside but the outdoor dinning area seem so cozy with pretty lighting.

We started off with sardine and avocado toast. It was one of my favorite tapas of the night. Got ourselves some coca (flatbread) and slow northern halibut as our main. Everything came out delicious and tasty. Portion was small but its all about quality over quantity. 


I regret for not getting the dessert because I heard it was a killer. Instead, I was at Mission Pie for those scrumptious banana cream pie. Guilty as charged, I know...
author: Owie N.

description:
Contigo, much like its translation, exudes the warmth of friendship. The small plates are meant to be shared, the soft lighting and wood invite relaxation, and our amicable waiter had the easygoing manner of the Spanish. 

There's not much going on in this little stretch of neighborhood other than the neighborhood bar next door. Which unfortunately means there's not much to do while you're waiting (unless you're smart and make a reservation in advance, which I highly recommend if you want an actual table or patio seat!) other than catch a basketball game and play some pool in The Peaks Bar. 

Stool seats at the sturdy wooden counter opened first, so that's where we two ended up sitting after a 15 minute wait. Not bad considering we came on a whim! Way before our waiter even came I was already hard at work with my iPhone, snapping pictures of EVERYTHING because the whole setup is so picturesque. The stiff linen napkins, blooming red tulips... You can bet when I discovered the outdoor patio and the charming bathroom that I wished I had taken my phone with me on the short journey. The bathroom isn't one of those sterile, polished places - it feels more like a country cottage with its nature-y paint and wooden pallets under the toilet and sink. Contigo is the kind of place where everything has its place, from the decorative mortar and pestle pieces to the defined role of each cook. There's even someone solely dedicated to wiping completed plates clean before setting them out for the waiters (you can tell I took major advantage of the people watching). 

Okay, onto the meat of the matter:
- Croquetas: we chose two crispy Jamón Serrano croquetas that immediately jump-started our meal. It's pricy, at $3.50 for one meatball sized croquette, but the creamy-crispy combo is something you really need to try. If ham is not your thing, get a different filling! 
- Papas Braves: no bravery necessary for this saucy dish! Jokes and poor pronunciation aside, these are a Spanish favorite (also called papas bravas). Crispy-skinned potatoes for dipping in both aioli and tangy tomato salsa brava. Think  homefries, but better.
- Tripe with Chorizo and Chickpeas: I didn't know what to expect, even after seeing it in front of me. But the sauce is a party on your tongue. The tripe makes for an interesting slippery texture (like glass noodles) and you never really know what you've scooped out of the stew until it's in your mouth.
- Sauteed Greens Catalan style: this is not the way to go if you want bang for your buck. The greens seemed to be large leaves of spinach (or a relative) topped with pine nuts and raisins, with flavor assistance from garlic and lemon. Nothing special, would probably order a salad to get my greens next time.
- Albondigas: these are also supposedly another Spanish classic, but the gaminess of the lamb was very much present. Texture-wise, I loved how crumbly yet juicy they were, but I think this could have been better.

The dishes here can be hit or miss, and I think as long as you like the ingredients going into the dish, you're safe. It's up to you to take the $12 bite-sized chance. After seeing the check I think Contigo is worth checking out once or twice for the ambiance, but I'll have to see some menu revamp before coming back.
author: Helen S.

description:
Worth the calories:  tripe, sardine and mashed avocado on toasts topped with pickled onions, squid over black ink rice and roasted artichokes, hot chocolate with churros that are richer and crisper than chocolateria san gines'.  

Only thing I would suggest is less salt in the tripe and squid dishes.  And refill the water more often.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
I trust 7x7 as much as I trust my Uncle Charlie in a seedy strip club with a bunch of strippers in butt floss.

It's a good thing I don't have an Uncle Charlie. 

Last week, the 7x7 2013 Eat + Drink Awards named Mission Chinese Food as "Best Chinese", Slanted Door as "Best Vietnamese", Dosa as "Best Indian", and Tacolicious as "Best Mexican" based on a readers' poll (http://www.7x7.com/eat-drink/2013-eat-drink-award-winners#/11). I've been to all. Where they good? YES. "Best" in SF? HELL NO. All were overpriced and none were authentic nor mom & pop owned. IMO, ethnic food should be cheap (especially Asian and Mexican) and natives should be present in the restaurant.

Contigo has been on my mental list for a while and when 7x7 named them as "Best Spanish" it peaked my interest even more for some odd reason. Even though 7x7 has failed me countless times, what does this Asian girl know about Spanish food? Besides, patron and corona...NADA.
