Contigo is a neighborhood gem in Noe Valley serving Spanish and Catalan tapas using local, seasonal, and organic ingredients. It may not be authentic but everything for the most part was solid with well-balanced flavors and textures. Two to three plates are recommended per a person which can really rack up at $7-$25 per a dish so beware. Expect to spend about $70 a person including a glass of wine, shared dessert, tax, and tip. 

F O O D
*Creamy Dungeness Crab Croqueta ($5/ball): 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/10ljOjS
The crab croqueta was heavenly! A crunchy crust led way to a decadently creamy center chockfull of dungeness crab meat. I would come back just to have more balls in my mouth, I mean more crab croquetas.

*Local Sardine & Avocado Toast w/ Pickled Onions ($2.50/toast): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/12wVv48
An interestingly delicious combo of flavors and textures with the crunchy toast, salty sardine, and uber buttery avocado. 

*Charred Asparagus w/ Serrano Ham & Fried Egg ($13): 4.5 STARS
 http://bit.ly/WwNklt
The way ALL veggies should be eaten: topped with a layer of salty serrano ham and a fried egg with an oozing yolk. I loved the crushed nuts on top for that layer of crunch. 

*Coca of Wild Nettles, Sausage, Manchego & Housemade Mato Cheese ($15): 5 STARS
http://bit.ly/XVbCUH
Mr. NSS hates cheese (what a weirdo!) but he had the mato cheese all over his face which goes to show just how spectacular this flatbread is. The earthiness from the nettles and creaminess from the duo of cheeses along with a super crisp crust throughout rivals the best Neapolitan pizzas I've had.  A definite must order!

*Garlicky Marin Sun Chicken Wings w/ Harissa & Celery Salad ($10): 3 STARS
 http://bit.ly/YP9Ro4
I love my wings as much as I love my liquor but I would have passed on these Spanish rendition of buffalo wings because they were over fried and dry.

*Tripe Stew w/ Chorizo & Chickpeas ($9): 4 STARS
 http://bit.ly/10lkTZc
As one of my favorite offal meats, the tripe stew was wonderfully comforting. The tripe was melt-in-your mouth while the chickpeas still had a bite to them. I wish it was accompanied with rustic country bread to soak up all the goodness. 

*Liberty Duck Breast w/ Blood Oranges & Honey ($22): 4.5 STARS
 http://bit.ly/YDhYHo
A good breast is hard to come by but this breast was PERFECTLY cooked. The duck breast was rendered just enough leaving the skin super crisp and the meat (medium rare) succulently tender. The blood orange and honey gave it a good lip-smacking pop of citrus and sweetness which was undeniably mouthwatering. 

*Tcho Hot Chocolate w/ Churros ($9): 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/ZhaKd8
Served fresh out of the fryer, the churros were nicely crunchy and sweet but too dry and dense. The hot chocolate was a bit watery. Too bad I'm sensitive to caffeine otherwise I would have ordered the Sightglass Coffee Caramel Flan.

S E R V I C E
The entire staff at Contigo were professional, friendly, and attentive. Food service was fast which is a plus. 

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
I adore the contemporary simplicity of Contigo. Most places can't pull off a lime green without looking tacky but Contigo does it well with all the shiny wooden furnishings. The counter seating with front view of the open kitchen, intimate dining area and back patio make it a perfect place for a casual dinner or a hot date. Speaking of hot date...request seats at the counter so you can be the annoying PDA couple as you sit side-by-side. Or if your date sucks, you can ignore him/her by romancing the wine bottle and watch all the action in the kitchen.

P A R K I N G
Easy street parking. 

Contigo is one of the MOST solid restaurants that I've been to in a while. "Best Spanish"? Like I said, all I know about Spanish "food" is patron and corona. It's a bit pricey so I can't give it 5 stars.

Now if I won $5k every week for 25 years from the "Lucky for Life" scratcher then that would be a different story. I would be at Contigo on a regular basis and making it rain with "Uncle Charlie".
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
TCHO hot chocolate with churros!  

I do apologize to my readers for not writing a more interesting hook for this place, but...TCHO hot chocolate with churros!

*composes self*

While it may seem that dessert stole the show during dinner, the appetizers and main courses were delicious in their own rights.  The jamon iberico de bellota from acorn-fed, black-hooved pigs was delightfully savory, as were the mushrooms and corn kernels sauteed in garlic and olive oil.  The menu seems to change around a bit, but if it comes back, I highly recommend the grilled shrimp in a sweet cream sauce with the almonds and grapes.  My dinner companion (who is not easily impressed) was also a fan of everything we ordered. 

And just in case I wasn't clear, let me impress upon you for the umpteenth time the deliciousness that was the super thick TCHO hot chocolate with churros.  That alone is worth a visit to Contigo.  Or two.  Or three.
author: Nancy C.

description: I recommend you try this place and they provide good customer service.
author: Mega Team R.

description:
Wine, tapas, AND churros?! Definitely a place I need to try. 

Came here on a Wednesday night with a friend without a reservation and we were seated immediately. We had a bit of a hard time deciphering the menu because it was in Spanish, but we still managed to order some food. 

We ordered the sardine and avocado toast, the croquetas, the squid dish, the crispy potatoes, and churros with TCHO chocolate for dessert. Also, strawberry sangria for me, and a glass of rosé for my friend. 

The sardine and avocado toast was good. And as much as I enjoy seafood, it was still a little fishy for my taste. But sardines, so I guess I can't complain. 

The croquetas were okay. Crispy on the outside, warm and cheesy on the inside.

The squid dish was pretty good. The squid was super tender and not chewy at all. However, it was on a bed of some sort of grain, but it was too spicy for my friend and I to enjoy. 

I was a little disappointed with the crispy potatoes. They were crispy on the outside, and fluffy on the inside. They were perfect! Except there were two different sauces on top of them, which I thought took away from the flavor of the potatoes, instead of enhancing it. I would have been much happier if the potatoes were served with a side of ranch, but I guess that would make the dish more American than Spanish. 

The churros with the chocolate dipping sauce was my favorite dish. The chocolate was very rich without being too sweet. They dust the churros with sea salt, which brought out the flavor of the chocolate even more. However, my friend thought the churros were a little too salty. :(

The strawberry sangria was really pretty to look at, but it only had a hint of strawberry to it. I was expecting more of a strawberry flavor for how thick it seemed. 

Decent food for a steep price. Probably will not come back. :(
author: Vivian L.

description: Be prepared to have your taste buds tantalized. This is a Spanish based tapas restaurant fused with local flavors.  I love traditional Spanish cuisine and this dinner was a nice surprise.  Service is very friendly,  must haves would be the patatas bravas and croquettes.
author: Jaime H.

description:
My sister and I walked in Contigo on a Wednesday night. You instantly notice the intimate space with an open kitchen. We were taken through through the restaurant to the back patio with heating. 

We decided that all the TAPAS looked good and decided to go with hot dates, cojonudos, shrimp, and croquetas. Believe me when I say they are all worth it. I could eat these all day. The croquetas taste very authentic and the cojonudos really are "amazeballs." Not to mention they're really cute. 

From the raciones we ordered the tripe with chickpeas, mussels, and albondigas. The tripe was super flavorful, so if you like tripe/stew, try this! The mussels had good flavor, but were definitely not as fresh as I would have liked. The albondigas were good too, but I don't see why everyone seems to think they are amazing.

The table next to us ordered the lamb rib chops. I wish we had ordered this instead! Something I would try if I go back, but I probably won't haha. 

Overall, I would recommend any of the tapas. They're deliciousness in a bite.
author: Michelle L.

description: Tapas
author: Bryan W.

description: I really wanted to love this place but felt like the food was somewhat mediocre and the cocktails were a tad weak. Maybe because we spent a month in Spain this summer and well, nothing really compares to pinchos in Logrõno and the Rioja region. What was worse was that we were at a table on the covered patio outside and there is a tent door beside our table with a commercial-strength Velcro panel which the staff kept going in and out of. Every 90 seconds our conversation was interrupted with a huge RRRRIIIIIIIIIIIIIPPPP sound.
author: Natasha D.

description: Great tapas restaurant. Many dishes to choose from. Wine selection is very good. I gravitate to the wine from The Canary Islands when I visit.
author: Chrispo B.

description: Amazing tastes. Very original and fresh Spanish Cuisine. Excellent service. Wide variety of Spanish wines to chose from. A must visit place in Noe Valley.
author: Homer A.

description: This place has such a warm and welcome atmosphere. The food is delicious and the wine list is amazing. A very fun spin on Spanish classics and great for an intimate date, a catch-up with an old friend or a group party. A treasure in the neighborhood. And the staff is lovely, from the host to the servers to the floor staff.
author: D. D.

description: The portions are very small, even for the plates that are labeled "medium to large plates."  The service was fine.  The food was good, but food at this price range in SF is always going to taste "good."  Nothing wrong with the food, but also nothing outstanding from tapa restaurants of this price range.  Checked this place off my list and probably wouldn't make an effort to go back.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
This restaurant has a really great atmosphere with outside seating available. The plates are obviously small but worth sharing. The drink menu is relatively solid with both wine and sparkling options available, I recommend the blood orange sparkling sangria. As far as suggested food goes:
I would avoid the fried potatoes. 
Asparagus was delicious. 
Albondigas meatballs were delightful.
Churros and chocolate for desert were pretty good but not mind blowing. 
Try to make a reservation in advance as seating seemed a bit limited. Oh also it was a bit loud but it did not prevent conversation.
author: Kim M.

description: Beautiful place, nice service, super expensive wine list, tiny tapas. The best one: Stuffed SQuid with Squid Ink black ink, also the Bacalao fritters. Everything is good but it is hard to put together a satisfying, filling dinner.  Excellent bread.  Expensive to my viewpoint.
author: Noel K.

description:
Should have reviewed here right after I went back in July.  Darn.  

Oh well.

Churros and chocolate = good (they are northern style)

Tostada de Tomate (but they called it something else) = perfect.

Patatas Bravas = yummy

I remember being unimpressed by the cocktails.

I don't actually remember what else we got.  which of course is not the best sign.

I'm a tapas snob, so... yeah.  Good Date night.
author: Sarah C.

description: A tad above okay. I would have appreciated more and larger toast appetizer options. Experimenting with those would have been awesome. The main courses weren't particularly impressive, but we found a couple we liked. The person I was with said she needed something more to the dishes, especially when the meatballs came. The place has a warm feel on a cold day. The seating is interesting. We opted for the bar, which offered more comfy chairs than the typical bar area. We received attention because we sought it. Not sure if we would have gotten much otherwise.
author: Paulina F.

description:
One thing you will find in common amongst all the reviews are:

- It's expensive? Yes, it kind of is. But if you get the 6 plate prix fixe for $38 it's actually not bad and I felt like it was filling enough.
- Best Spanish according to 7x7? True. I typically disagree with 7x7's rankings but I think Contigo is my favorite Spanish place so far in SF. I've only tried the few in the Mission, and have heard great things about the paella at Alegrias.

I loved the fresh calamari and paella, and would highly recommend returning for the prix fixe. The ingredients are noticeably fresh and quality, something you won't find at Cha Cha Cha or Esperpento. Corkage is $20.
author: Jess C.

description:
My son and I impulsively decided to enjoy a meal in Noe Valley and walked into Contigo. We were seated at the counter and then proceeded to go slightly overboard, ordering six dishes between the two of us (five were the larger-sized ones).

The food was spot-on and many dishes beautifully spotlighted seasonal produce. The little gem salad was simply gorgeous with just the right amount of dressing and the perfect balance of sour, salty, sweet and acidic.

Other highlights included the amazing fried potatoes and the tasty summer squash flatbread.

Our waiter was also super friendly. We'll be back for more!
author: Kim N.

description:
Food:  5 stars
Service:  2 stars

Management, take note.  Do you read yelp reviews?  I'm guessing not.  

A quick scan of prior reviews shows the pattern.  It's not complicated.  

Your chefs are doing their job.  

Your waitstaff is NOT.  

The food is terrific, top-notch and authentic.  Your waitstaff is inexperienced, weirdly awkward, and honestly don't seem like they enjoy working there.  This is a big problem.  In the Bay Area, we expect excellent service.  It's part of the whole dining experience.  You need to address this problem and then you will get the accolades that your food deserves.   The food is excellent, but the difficult interactions with the wait staff detracts from the experience.

Good luck with that.
author: Karen r.

description: Pretty delicious tapas. I would highly suggest the croquettes and the veggie ratatouille - those were the highlights. The gasbacho salad was good and meatballs were alright. OH the fried potatoes were . Would go back
author: Rohan S.

description:
3 STARS. Everything at Contigo had great execution, but after my dining experience at Coqueta, I realized Contigo was just OK (food-wise).

My friends and I came here on a Sunday night as part of our monthly food outing. Parking was actually not too bad, surprisingly. We were seated in the outdoor patio with the heated lamps. However, the heated lamps got pretty hot because it was heating our backs the whole time... Anyways, the four of us decided to share family style so we could try a little bit of everything. 

Wood Oven Roasted Local Sardine and Avocado Toast: Really liked the texture of the toast as it added a crunch with the sardine. 

Coca (Flatbread) of Wild Nettles: I really liked this dish because it wasn't too cheesy nor too oily/greasy. I really liked how the crust was crispy. Felt pretty healthy just eating that.

Patates Braves: I thought this dish was just OK. The potatoes were crispy and fried. However, there was a very good portion of potatoes.

Charred Asparagus: Pretty interesting since it was served with egg and ham. But overall, the taste was just OK. Nothing too special.

Seared Local Black Cod: One of my favorite dishes of the night. The black cod was soft and moist. 

Monterey Xipirons (squid) a la Planxa: Squid was pretty chewy and wasn't overcooked. I liked how it was presented over squid ink rice and chorizo. One of my other favorite dishes of the night

Albondigas: Contained pork and lamb in tomato sauce. I wasn't too big of a fan of the albondigas here.. Didn't really like the taste nor the texture.

TCHO Hot Chocolate with Churros: Churros were the perfect portion size for dessert. The TCHO hot chocolate was really rich and chocolately, but complemented the churros well. However, after having almost the same dessert at Coqueta, I definitely prefer Coqueta's version of the churros with hot chocolate and mixed berries powder.
author: Philana C.

description:
Small restaurant, small plates! Came here with two other people, would recommend coming with only one other person. Most plates were not big enough to share three ways.

This is what we had:

Catalan tomato toast: Jammy tomatoes spread all over fresh bread: YUM!

Marinated spanish olives with marcona almonds and pickled veggies: delish

Little gem salad: Great flavors, but not enough salad-slightly chintzy on the beets

Cojondogo salad: again, great flavors, but too small.

patates braves: not sure what the sauce was, but wanted to lick the plate.

fried eggplant: i want this on a daily basis.

squid a la planxa: loved this dish, except for the overwhelming amount of peppers and I wasn't a huge fan of the tomatoes. I think a heartier vegetable would have paired better.

Sangria: overpowering taste of strawberries. good taste, not enough booze.

also had the churros with melted tcho: tasted exactly like the one I had in Madrid: impressed.

Overall, taste of most of the food impressed me. The sizes were too small, but I was impressed with the huge list of farms they use so I know their costs are high to produce this quality of food. The service was very meh. Hipster server which generally means too cool to have a personality and engage. Wasn't impressed with him.
author: Christine E.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite places but our dinner last night was not that great. I'm kind of sad having to write this review! Service as always was great for the most part (our main server was kind but seemed very disinterested in us, but that could just be a bad day! But the other servers and hostess were so helpful and friendly) and they even accommodated our friend who has a severe seafood allergy and needs to ensure meat and seafood are prepared on different grills/pans. They were great about that.

Highlights: the pear and jamon salad and the tomato/olive oil/sea salt crusty bread (can't remember the name!) and the lamb rib chops. And the Mexican hot chocolate with churros dessert was half good (see below) as the hot chocolate was dark, rich, creamy and amazing! The croquetas were nice.

Downsides: the dishes came out randomly  and we waited a long time for the lamb at the end and for our dessert. There was no "flow" to the pacing of the meal. The delicata squash salad recommended by our server was delicious but only had about 3 small bits of squash in the entire salad. It could use more.  We had a chorizo flatbread type dish that was "meh" so we didn't eat most of it (they kindly took this off our bill without us asking them to since they saw we didn't like it, so that was very classy and kind!) The patatas bravas tasted burnt. The albondigas were good but honestly I remember being blown away by them before so I was kind of sad! And the fried eggplant was so bland, I had to ask for salt which I never do. The Churro and hot chocolate dessert was half good (see above) but the churros were overcooked.

This was really disappointing as we've had amazing meals here but food quality seems to have slipped. Hope they can get back to what they were, as the ambience and location are great.
author: Maria R.

description:
Okay usually five stars are reserved for those rare, absolutely unforgettable epicurean experiences. And that's why Contigo warrants this level of praise. 

First, tip of the hat to the warm and welcoming floor staff. Superb knowledge, great recommendations, super cool. Way to be. 

Second-the jamon. Outstanding, especially paired with Remelluri Rioja Riserva by the glass. Have to give the legit card to their Squid a la Plancha with lightly browned, roasted artichoke hearts and squid ink arroz con hella-mazing chorizo aioli. 

Honorable mentions: outrageously tasty seasonal Txakolina rosé. I'll take a gallon for the road, please. Why stop at wine when the housemade sparkling white sangría makes one forget the fog outside and reminisce of the great sangria stands in Barcelona's open markets.

Cheers to Contigo for bringing an Iberian authenticity to Noe Valley, and save a seat for my hasty return.
author: A N.

description:
Not my favorite tapas choice.  In general, their approach is heavy handed and lacks finesse.  While several plates (meatballs, salmon on lentils, anchovy bruschetta) were flavorful, they were one note and/because strongly seasoned.

Industrial ambiance, but welcoming.  Prompt and attentive service.  Beer and wine only, but they have a creative selection.
author: Howard B.

description:
Great dinner at Contigo. Went early on a Wednesday night around 6pm and it was about 30% full. It was our first time there and service was attentive and the food came out quickly. They also have carafe's of wine which was perfect for two.

We brought our sleeping 2 month old in his car seat and had no problem fitting him on the bench next to us. Loved it was family friendly and had a nice blend of singles and families.
author: Allison R.

description:
Ordered take-out from Contigo since we didn't have much time and I wanted to try their dish listed on the 7x7 list. It took 15-20 minutes for our order, and we got:

-Calamars a la Planxa (Calamari w/ Chorizo and Black Rice, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c5Pog3vEqmBFOBdL7R3vAg?select=PeqiS6rwRLk6Us6xlUGo0A#KWqtBKOcAXYref-Tg31m-w): YUM! I really enjoyed this dish, and understand why it's on the 7x7. The squid ink imparts that sweet, ocean-y taste to the rice, and the calamari was perfectly tender. Highly recommend this!
-Pork Belly Slider (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c5Pog3vEqmBFOBdL7R3vAg?select=PeqiS6rwRLk6Us6xlUGo0A#PeqiS6rwRLk6Us6xlUGo0A): YUM again! It's hard to go wrong with pork belly, and they gave you a huge piece for the tiny slider bun (no complaints here), and the pickled onions gave it a little extra flavor.

Overall, I liked both dishes I tried from Contigo, and will definitely have to come back to dine-in! However, the parking here seemed tough to find.
author: Amy D.

description:
I loved the tapas ... So creative and delicious ! Came here with our not do foodie friends and they even loved the squid! We tried the $42 tasting menu. ... Two complaints ..The waiter talked too fast and / mumbled ... We had to stop him several
Times to slow down  & repeat himself ... And secondly ... We do NOT like how u tried to push us out ...in  a short 7 minutes .. At least 3 members of the staff asked if we needed anything more .... Ugh .... U r holding our doggie bag hostage ... If u want us out .. Don't keep our doggie bag and lete finish my coffee .. After 7 entree , I think we r entitled to let our food digest before Rolling out! And besides , there were at least 2 empty tables in the patio area and we only saw one group if 4 waiting for a table !  I'm giving 4 stars for the good, 2 stars for service !
author: Jay S.

description: Decent food. Problematic service: no attention to detail, slow, a bit sloppy. Pouring one wine into a half full glass of the prior wine, wasting both.
author: Farrah M.

description:
I heard so many good things about this place that i was finally excited to try this place out. We made our reservation for 8PM, but was not seated for till 830 because a party would not leave after being finished hours ago. The staff said they would give us something complimentray for our patience....never came. 

We decided to go with the tasting menu ($40 each person) just to get a feel for the place. All the things that we tried weren't the ones we wanted to try and just didn't feel like enough food to share between 3 people. The really good stuff was the expensive plates of course, but we only saw one of them. 

I want to come back and just use that $40 toward something i really want and not share it. My experience has been OK, but I'm willing to come back because it has so much potential to be a great place!
author: Ryan R.

description: Love this place!  I found out about Contigo 3 months ago, and I have been here at least 5 times. Their tasting menu is great as well.
author: Koun H.

description:
I liked Contigo! Party of seven on a Saturday night. Must have a reservation or good luck! We were lucky and were seated in the back of the restaurant which was very intimate. We did the tasting menu with seven tapas selected by the chef ($40 per person), we ordered extra dishes as well. Here is what stood out: 

-Pomegrante Sangria- mmmmmmmmmmm order this! Fruity and refreshing. 
-Wood Oven Roasted Local Sardine And Avocado Toast- I was not expecting to even try this let alone enjoy it, but I did! The sardine was so smoky and the tomato on top was a fantastic last bite. 
-Little Gem Salad- lightly dressed with huge beets. I loved this. 
-Patates Bravas- Crispy potatoes with SPICY salsa and sour cream. I enjoyed this but watch how much salsa you grab, it is hot!
-Croqueta de Jamon Serrano- Delicious. Smokey ham and creamy cheese.
-Spinach and Chickpeas- Lacked salt, easy fix. 
-Coca (flatbread) with mushrooms- Fighting over this one. So crispy! 
-Halibut- Cooked so perfect, buttery and the brussels sprouts were so yummy. 
-Churros with chocolate- Woah super rich chocolate, churros lacked flavor but they were displayed beautifully.

Our bill came to around $600, we all had drinks and ordered a bottle of cider as well. Expensive and most of us were hungry within two hours as the dishes are small (tapas). I would probably return.
author: Liana H.

description:
We liked everything about Contigo...vibrant taste to all the Tapas dishes, excellent wine selection, waitstaff very on the ball and friendly despite being very busy...
Highly recommend, will definitely go back
author: Michael G.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend for Paella Tuesday.

The tapas were nice and innovative. We had:
* Sardine Crudo (a little fishy for me, but he seafood lover that he is loved it!)
* Bruschetta -- pretty run of the mill; the least unique item of the night
* Salad with lots of cumin which was a very innovative combination of cumin that worked very well!
* Eggplant fries -- first time I've had eggplant fries.  It was nicely crispy on the outside with some sort of delicate breading and a nice texture on the inside (not too mushy as you might suspect eggplant could get)

The paella was a shrimp / white fish / artichoke paella -- quite stunning in presentation!  The toppings were delicious!  The rice was tasty, too! though maybe a little on the bland side.

Overall, charming restaurant with wonderfully executed food, good wine recommendations, and seamless service!
author: Kathryn C.

description: I love this place! My favorite local restaurant. Great wine and food, upscale atmosphere without being stuffy or pretentious. Wait staff is very nice too. Food is delicious.
author: Meredith G.

description:
4.25 stars

Contigo's mostly-enclosed patio ensures diners are protected from SF's unpredictable, ever-changing climate. Within our 90-minute stay, the weather went from so sunny, the heating lamps had to be shut off to so breezy, the patio's plastic structure shook hard. 

We were highly impressed with service here. Our waiter described menu items in such a way that it actually helped us decide what to get. A la carte dishes were brought out quickly, & in a way that made sense, so as to mimic a tasting menu (we passed on the $44 per person 7-course tasting menu.) We tried: 

-- hot date: delicious bacon-wrapped sticky, sweet dates stuffed w/ blue cheese & a marcona almond. 
-- serrano ham croqueta: fried balls filled with ham. Nice contrast of crisp outside & creamy interior. 
-- little gem salad w/ crisp garlic & beets
-- smashed pea toast: my favorite! Topped with king trumpet mushrooms & shaved manchego, I could've eaten another helping! 
-- halibut w/ sugar snap peas, farro, serrano ham, & mint salsa: not fishy. Amazing combo of ingredients...every element was fresh & cooked well. 
-- sautéed greens Catalan style: bitter greens, garlic, pine nuts, pickled raisins: perfectly wilted greens, delicious crunch, some sweetness...love the mix of unexpected flavors & textures. 
-- secreto: "butcher's secret cut of iberico pork." I believe they used shoulder meat? I didn't try, as it looked medium instead of well & had tons of visible fattiness oozing from it. He described it as juicy, but didn't appear to enjoy it. Too bad our most expensive item ($28) was the most disappointing 
-- home made lemonade. Home made strawberry soda: strongly flavored without being sweet, fizzy, refreshing.
Total: ~ $130, not including tip

Looking forward to experiencing more from Contigo!
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Humble yet posh atmosphere.  It's very warm and cozy when you first enter, which I like.  They also have surprisingly well insulated outdoor seating, with heaters throughout.  Don't be shy to eat outside!  You won't freeze, I promise.

Their menu also has today's date (as in, the day you show up, not 10/23/2013) on it, which made me feel fancy.  

But onto the food!  It's all VERY tasty.  Since we ordered so many dishes, I'll jsut give the quick rundown:

Sangria - really tasty!  I was skeptical about the bitters but it turned out fantastic with the addition of mint.  Too bad it doesnt come in pitcher form :(

Croquettes - SO good, full of deliciously molten cheese, but extremely HOT 
Pork belly - came in slider form, which I found... curious... but other than that it was very tasty and balanced by the sauteed onions
Montadito - excellently balanced appetizer, with the anchovy balanced by the mato cheese, and the mato balanced by the crunchy bread.
Squid with chorizo  - INCREDIBLE seasoning, and the chewy squid seemed to never run out of delicious spicy-chorizo flavor 
Tripe - also really well-seasoned, but would have liked a little more texture like say, Delfina
TCHO Chocolate + Churros (incredibly rich, but not enough churros :(

Overall an excellent dining experience.  Note that although "tapas" usually refers to one or two pieces, in this case "tapas" literally means a single portion.  To be prepared to double the order of any "tapas" you want.  The "raciones" are definitely shareable though.  Still, it comes out to be quite expensive.  

I was tempted to not give 5 stars because of the price (came out to ~$90 for 2), but honestly this place is just too damn cute to not give it due credit.  Our waitress was still in training, and while she couldnt give us too many food recommendations, she was extremely attentive and gave excellent service.  Overall a very fun dining experience.
author: Mike P.

description: Came here for dinner recently and had a pleasant meal. Had a handful of tapas to share, ordering a la carte versus chef tasting menu. Started off with the cojonudo, which is a small bite of chorizo iberico toast, fried qual egg, smoked butter beans, and pickled chile. The next item is no longer on the menu but I had the fig salad, which may have been my favorite dish as the figs were super fresh and added a lot to the flavors. Also had the albondigas, which is pork, lamb, and jamon meatballs in tomato sherry sauce. Great taste but nothing spectacular. And last but not least I also had the tripe with chorizo and chickpeas. This dish was a surprise winner for me, and I enjoyed it. This place has a lot of seating, including an outdoor patio area in the back but for some reason it didn't strike my as that special. Still, would definitely recommend it in the Noe area.
author: Lucy C.

description: I have been to contigo many times over the past 4 years and I have to admit that the food is very very good. The service though leaves a lot to be desired. I am of Spanish descent and have been to Barcelona many times and go there every year and I can attest to the authenticity of the food items, however they way that you get treated when it comes to the service is almost as if you are at a McDonalds where you dont have servers but order takers. In seems like the Spanish Hospitality is something they could not translate into English. So If you can be ok with the service or lack thereof and not be bothered by the unwelcoming atmosphere and attitude of the server staff and hostess then Contigo is good place.
author: A.M. E.

description:
What a horrible experience and super expensive.  Nothing was wonderful and everything was a rip off.  4 lousy asparagus from some farm for $12?  The Jamon iberico was a super small portion (maybe 1 oz)  for $32 and 6 small pieces of cheese for $16. Yes I know 5J ham is $100 a pound retail.    The jumbo wild shrimp were absolutely awful tasting-- overcooked and fishy.  It was really really bad and strange combination of flavors.  

I thought the meatballs were pretty good. Anyway, I was just in Barcelona less than a month ago (for the 9th time) and the food was amazing!  nothing like this horror show.  

We left $200 poorer (two adults and one child) and we were still hungry.  Went to Cafe Zinc a block away and ate a couple appetizers to get some nourishment in.  

What a ripoff.
author: Mike P.

description: Live in Noe and was looking for something culturally and gastronomically exotic. Did I find it here?  Despite the cozy cava name,, the answer is definitely NO.  Chairs, tables not comfortable, but most importantly one dish after another was bland, uninteresting, flavorless. Avoid the "white gaspacho."  Oily, flavorless, supposedly with hazelnuts but maybe 2 at most. The croqueta was good- but was so small, we thought it a joke. I know this was a 'tapas' course, but really, less than one bite. Spinach and chick pea stew had no flavor except burned spinach.  Needed spices desperately  And it was $15 for a shallow dish!  The exotic sounding cana de cabra goat cheese has a flavorful thin slice of goat cheese, but really! $16 for a thin slab over some undressed arugula, not worth it. Albondigas consisted of 3 ample meatballs that despite the 3 meat description had less flavor than canned meatballs and was $13.  Not recommended without a major kitchen upgrade!
author: fred w.

description:
Came in on a Saturday night without a reservation. I heard that this place fills up fast, so I was pleasantly surprised when they told us they were able to seat us right away. What luck. The vibe was California-Spain, nice open kitchen with wood seats combined with a clear Spanish influence. We ordered the sparking Sangria and some Tapas to start (Hot Date, Chicken Skewers, Creamy Fritters, and the Oxtail slider). The sparking Sangria was delicious. My favorite tapas was the Chicken Skewer, really nice flavor. 

For the bigger dishes we ordered flatbread (with sausage and broccoli), squid with rice, and the pork and lamb meatballs. We also got a side of the potatoes. I loved the flatbread, although I may be impartial to the ingredients, I swoon for any sausage, broccoli, and ricotta combination. The squid was also good, really unique and a must order.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Good tapas, if not a bit expensive.  Cute outside patio area as well, though the tables seemed to be squished a tad close.  My boyfriend and I couldn't really talk to each other over the 2 girls we were seated next to.

But the food tastes pretty good.  :)
author: Michael D.

description:
Feeling down? Stressed out? NO WORRIES, just go and pig out with some good company. Tommy N. and Andrea R. introduced me to this tapas bar and assured me that I will be blown away by the Xurros. 

At first, I had not grasped the concept of a Tapas bar, but they explained to me saying that its like... Asian's dim sum kind of where you order these small dishes to try, except this is the Spanish edition. 

It was a cloudy Friday evening. We walked in and I was blown away by the decors. The lights were dimly lit, but dim enough that you can see everything clearly. There was a brick oven, which I never saw in person before. Everything on display looked mouth watering. Waitresses were extremely welcoming! Shortly after, we found out that people usually had to make reservations here, but we were just walk ins. However, they put us down on the list and our wait time was about 45 minutes. NO STRESS! Because we all walked around the area full of very interesting boutiques and the houses were fun to photo shoot with (*** IF THAT WAS YOUR HOUSE AND YOU SAW PEOPLE OUTSIDE POSING... YES, IT WAS US... SORRY...***). 

When we returned, we were ready to try some good food! What we ordered:
I cannot pronounce HALF of the stuff on the menu X[

-Gilda $2.50: Pincho of baby artichoke, obregon olive, salt cured spanish anchovies and a pickled piaparra pepper 
-Oxtail Mini-Hamburgesa $5.00: it consisted of salsa secreta, pickled onions and pimenton potato chips. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/contigo-san-francisco-2?select=9mVed6wEWKusG8CmZ56N5A#81AGPbp1tYWUBse6qBVfDw
-Pa amb Tomaquet $3.50: catalan tomato toast with arbequina olive oil, garlic and sea salt
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/contigo-san-francisco-2?select=9mVed6wEWKusG8CmZ56N5A#CWxAq2Qw5d4GRlAjiRWyOw
-Albondigas $11: pork and jamon meatballs in tomato sherry sauce
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/contigo-san-francisco-2?select=9mVed6wEWKusG8CmZ56N5A#ZUk7RpNGnM9zBuQ2DcV29Q
-xocolata calenta with amb xurros $9: cup of thick, rich Barcelona style tcho hot chocolate with crispy fritters fried to order. NOT CHURROS, XURROS. hahha! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/contigo-san-francisco-2?select=9mVed6wEWKusG8CmZ56N5A#9mVed6wEWKusG8CmZ56N5A

WHAT STOOD OUT TO ME: 
-Oxtail Mini-Hamburguesa
-Albondigas (although I suggest ordering something to eat with this like rice... or bread... LOL i'm so Asian... )
-xocolata calenta with amb xurros (experience Xurros like you have never before)

All were extremely delicious! The atmosphere put us all in a swoon of relaxation as we looked around with cute loving couples, close friends and families having an amazing time. However, it is kind of pricey... but  it was a GOOD splurge meal. Its a well deserved pat on the back because I can now say I have experienced a tapas bar! Thank you Tommy N. and Andrea R. for taking me here!:)
author: Chena N.

description: Such a special meal! Came in for dinner by chance on a Tuesday right as they opened. Lucky for us we had the opportunity to try Paella Tuesday! Paella Tuesday includes five courses for $40 per person. All the dishes included were amazing. Especially the melon con jamon! Paella was pretty tasty and very fresh. I've had many paella dishes made by a family friend from Spain so I sorta feel like I know what I'm talking about there. Highly recommend the sparking sangria. Can't wait to come back!!
author: Mag L.

description:
Great decor.  Nice ambiance.  Friendly staff, especially Javier.

My husband and I had the:
-Coca (flatbread) of Wild Nettles
-Calamars a la Planxa 
-Moorish Lamb Tagine
-Huevos Estrellados

The food was really good.  Full of flavor (except the Huevos Estrellados was a bit salty).

Definitely a place we'd like to come back to...
author: Rose A.

description:
First of all, our group was an hour late for our dinner reservation on a Saturday night, and Contigo accomodated us, so I am thankful for that.  I love tapas bars in general because you can try a variety of items, so of course, we ordered pretty much everything on the menu.  I usually don't eat sardines, but the Sardine and Avocado Toast was actually delicious.  Similarly, I usually don't eat goat cheese, but the Fig Salad with Bruleed Goat Cheese was delicious.  A few other favorites:

Fried Eggplant with Cane Syrup, Sesame Seeds, and Mint
Sauteed Chard, Pinenuts, Pickled Raisins, and Garlic
Squid a la Planxa
Pork and Jamon Meatballs in Tomato-Sherry Sauce

This is a Catalan restaurant, so you have to try the Jamon Iberico (Catalan prosciutto) and Pa Amb Tomaquet (Catalan tomato toast).

Hip, fun, delicious...this is a great place for a first date or a night out with friends.  And hey, any restaurant that can make me eat sardines and goat cheese -- and like it --receives two thumbs up from me.
author: Ally W.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed Contigo.  It makes me wanna go there contigo haha

Food 4
Ambience 4
Service 5
Price 4 (count what u order. You could easily order too much.)

I got the Albarino which I loved.
Albarino, from Spain's northwestern Galicia region, is a steely, floral white wine that goes well with seafood, from cauldron-boiled octopus to its slithery garlic eels.  And the Octopus tapa I got was quite tasty.   2 appetizers and 5 tapas would be enough.  We would know- cuz we ordered too much! We'll be back again.  
Overall everything was very good.
author: Joey C.

description:
If possible, get yourself a table in the back patio.  It's small with a little herbal garden, and heaters on the top that keeps you warm. Jamón ibérico is one of the most famous dish, but since melon isn't in season now, they're serving it with bread with a popping cost of $25.  I opted for the pre-fix $40/person menu with 7 courses.  It was good, but not the best I've had.  What I really like best there is the Rioja ($15/glass), and the TCHO hot chocolate ($5) with crispy churros ($4).

Glad to have a place like Contigo in the city.  Keep it up!
author: Carina N.

description:
I had a double date here at Contigo and we all had an absolute blast. The food was sensational, the wine bottles were tantalizing, the dessert was enticing, the ambiance was intimate and the service was outstanding. 

Contigo boasts a modern, intimate and cozy vibe that makes it the ideal spot for date nights and chummy dinners. The location right off 24th street in charming Noe Valley doesn't hurt either. 

You simply have to order the chef's tasting menu of 7 courses for $42. It's such a freaking steal and you get the satisfaction of trying all the highlights on the menu. 

Here were our 7 courses: 
1. Ham croqueta: cheesy and crispy fried deliciousness. One of the better croquetas I've had in tapas restaurants.
2. Sardine and avocado toast with pickled onions and smoked salt: Although I was a bit hesitant about sardines, this was quite possibly my favorite of the night. It was literally bursting with flavor at every bite and the texture combination of the soft avocados on top of the smooth sardine on top of the crispy toast... dear god. 
3. Arros negre (squid ink rice with squid): This was the unanimous table favorite as the squid was so plump and oozing with flavor and the rice was perfectly soaked in yummy squid ink. I'd say this was a close second to the sardine and avocado toast for me. 
4. Pork and lamb meatballs in tomato sauce: So well cooked, meaty and tender.
5. A salad dish that I can't remember: Nothing noteworthy to write home about. It was just a salad.
6. Patates braves: So crispy and fried to perfection. One of the best patates braves I've had!
7. Brussel sprouts with jamon serrano, parsnip, capers and cava butter: So freaking flavorful and yummy! I could eat them all day in the wonderful sauce that the sprouts were covered in.
8. Trout wrapped with prosciutto: The flavor profile of the fatty prosciutto piece seeping onto the perfectly seared trout with the special sauce on top... I can't even...

All in all, we were beyond impressed with the intricate detail that went into each course. Clearly, the highlights are the unique flavor profiles and intermingling of ingredients. I highly recommend ordering the chef's tasting menu to get the full vision of the chef and soak in all that Contigo has to offer. 

So on your next yearning for some delicious Spanish food, give Contigo a try - you won't be disappointed! 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: 592 reviews?!!! Who needs any more? What can i say?  it is small, intimate and our server was somehow defined by the space which made the intimacy seem palpable. The food is thoughtful, soulful and local.. If you want a small San Francisco neighborhood experience with a local, Spanish inspired menu then you should try this restaurant.
author: Jane F.

description:
My wife and I dine at Contigo once a month ever since its open. Why we love this place?  

1) it's tapas style- we like sampling/eating just about everything
2) the food is impeccable, yet simple
3) small and intimate restaurant, where the staff knows your name after you've been there a few time
4) the menu changes seasonally
5) good variety of wines
6) great variety of cava
7) amazing sparkling sangria

Please make a reservation by going to OpenTable or calling the restaurant directly. After 6.30pm on most night, walk-ins may have to wait up to 30-45 mins. 

Also, this Noe Valley (San Francisco), do not complain about lack of parking! If you have not figured out that it's tough to find parking in San Francisco, get a reality check. So do not complain and give the restaurant a lower rating because it's tough to find parking. If you are going to drive, then figure on walking 1-5 blocks to find parking. Walking is good for you.
author: Al G.

description:
EVERYTHING was good. We came with a party of 7 to celebrate an event. Service was great - attentive, friendly and helpful, and food was amazing. There was not one dish I didn't like. However, the portions are pretty small (*hence: TAPAS (small dishes) - but still @_@). The 3 $$$ money signs here hold true indeed.

Would I return? No. (Not unless they had happy hour or something!) There are other tapas places which serve the same caliber of food that are the same price (but come in much bigger portions). This IS Noe Valley though, and I understand that. *Keep in mind location and ambiance, of course.

My favorite dish of the night was the hamburguesa (oxtail burger). SO TENDER and dericious.... except it's $5 EACH (about the size of one slider). It was pretty damn good though.
author: Emily C.

description: I've been craving good Spanish food ever since we came back from Spain.  To be honest, there aren't a whole lot of really good tapas places in SF, but Contigo is definitely one of the best ones!  We ordered a bunch of stuff including the jamon serrano (YUM!), albondigas, sardines on a crostini, smoked salmon on a crostini, croquetas and the halibut.  All these were delicious and then topped it off with some hot chocolate with churros.  Absolutely delicious.  Makes me want to go back to Spain.
author: Claire H.

description:
Would have gotten 4 stars if the server would have topped off our wine glasses maybe at least once? With a $130 bill I would expect that from a better restaurant. But no we were reduced to pouring our own wine.. how gauche.

The place is cute enough. There was long line of people waiting for most of the night, so it's a popular place. Do get a reservation.

Food:
- sardines on avocado toast (OK, not the best we've had.. order is for 1 person)
- ox tail slider (very good.. order is for 1 person)
- little gem salad (OK.. expensive at $12 and you don't get much)
- patatas bravas (good.. share 2 people)
- coca (flatbread.. good.. share 2 people)
- albondigas (meatballs.. good.. share 2 people)
- squid with chorizo (good.. share 2 people)
- churros with chocolate (good..drink the chocolate at the end)

The food was generally OK, not mind blowing. Service from those who brought the food in (not our server) was very quick and efficient. I like that they would wait to take each item to our table until after we were done with one. Our server was the weakest and most disappointing aspect of the evening. It makes it even more irritating when we see him doing a better job at another table (like pouring their wine!). Oh well, this place is something to be tried once and that's it.
author: Vol T.

description:
Cute little place in Noe Valley - a great place to try some delicious Spanish tapas! 5 SOLID stars from me! Every single dish was delicious, the ambiance was beautiful, and the service was excellent! Came here with a close friend and shared about 7 tapas. We left STUFFED........ but satisfied :)

To start we started with individual mini tapas:

Oxtail Mini Hamburguesa ($5) - I've never had oxtail meat before but was pleasantly surprised! Braised oxtail meat just melts in your mouth! The meat was tender, juicy, and bursting with flavor! But just a warning - you get one tiny hamburger that you can literally fit in one bite!

Creamy Dungeness Crab Croqueta ($5) - delicious ball of crab meat, breaded and fried to perfection. The outside breading was crunchy and topped with a spicy sauce which complimented the creamy crab!

Wood Oven Roasted Local Sardine and Avocado Toast ($3) - a delicious fishy dish! Avoid if you can't stand fishy flavors! But the creamy avocado spread and smokey flavor evens out the sardine.

Next came the bigger dishes called Raciones - plates for sharing:

Little gem salad ($11) - talk about fresh ingredients! Some of the most delicious and flavorful beets I've never had! Topped with flavor bombs = GARLIC CHIPS! Yum! The sherry mustard vinaigrette is a bit overpowering - so avoid if you like  sour flavors! 

Patates Braves ($8) - gotta have some carbs! A dish of crispy fried potatoes topped with a spicy salsa brava sauce. Generous portions - we couldn't finish this one!

Local calamars a la planxa ($11) - grilled calamari served on a bed of brussel sprouts kept piping hot on a steel plate. The salty calamari and capers paired perfectly with the hints of sweetness from the currants. Definitely would recommend this dish! 

Seared Hawaiian Ahi Tuna ($22) - by far my favorite dish of the night! 4 pieces of seared ahi tuna placed on top of a creamy celery root. The tuna was topped with broccoli and a oxtail broth was poured tableside. The tuna was seasoned delicately so that you could still enjoy the freshness of the fish but the seared skin was salty. For some reason me and my friend kept tasting something slightly sweet also, but couldn't put our finger on it. Either way - it blew us away! We licked the plate clean!

Overall, I had a wonderful dining experience. The service was excellent down to the order they bring out the plates (light to heavy) and how my water glass was never empty! Will definitely be back again!
author: Eunice K.

description:
Didn't quite cut it for me.  The flavors were not what I expected on a few of the dishes.

We didn't appreciate walking in and then being led outside again to their "outdoor" dining area. It was a tad chilly tonight.  We walked past a few open tables on the inside of the restaurant and asked if we could have one of those instead.  They graciously agreed.  (They must try to unload the outdoor seating first.)

We squeezed into a tiny table for two after being bumped by the waitstaff a few times.  The staff was great though and very inviting--no problems there at all.  The space itself is pleasing and cozy.

The oxtail sliders that we ordered first were very greasy and contained a large chunk of bone.  After pointing it  out to the server, she quickly took it off our bill--that was nice of her considering we didn't ask or expect anything.  The tiny sliders are $5.00 each!

The meatballs made with pork and lamb and served in a tomato, sherry sauce were just ok.  It tasted like the meatballs were sitting in a warm applesauce. I had to get over that thought as I ate....

The brussel sprouts were over seasoned and served with hazelnuts, capers, mint and lime.  It didn't work for me.

The pork that we also ordered was the best choice of the evening but for $27.00 --it was not worth it!    There were just 4 tiny pieces of pork sliced on the bias.  This came with a sprinkling of broccoli rabe and a couple of sliced fingerling potatoes. 

The crab salad was just ok too.  Too much endive and other unseasoned greens on a small plate.

The worst dish were the churros--they were over cooked and hard.  Tasteless too.  They were $4.00 and we also ordered the melted Tcho chocolate sauce for another $5.00.
We dipped the churros into the melted sauce but that still didn't help.

Bottom line--I didn't like the food.  I  would have rather gone back to Lolo for Mexican tapas.  The Spanish tapas here were just ok.
author: Thomas D.

description:
Early dinner on a Sunday night.  It was a bit warm in the outside area, and the staff was extremely accommodating to move us inside.
Great food + kid friendly = 5 stars!
author: Mike L.

description:
Loved everything n our server (Michael). Will def. be back! Great experience, interiors, patio n food! 
Dishes ordered:
- fried peppers 
- squid w/ white beans 
- meatballs in tomato sauce 
- sardines w avo on toasted bread
- house red vermouth (drink)
- red wine (all Spanish wines)
- patatas bravas
- hot coco w mini churros (dessert)

All great!
author: C A.

description:
There is a cute patio out back but seems like all those tables fill up first even when you get there at 6pm. Looks like for warm weather or warm evenings.

The food was good and there were lots of veggie only or meat heavy options. We really likes the flatbread w/ zucchini and the pork and jamon meatballs. Probably our two favorite dishes. Seems like the tapas options change frequently with some staples so would definitely keep in the tapas rotation.
author: Melody T.

description:
Try not to lick the bowl of chocolate when you order the beautiful, hot, delectable, fall-apart-in-your-mouth Churros - I dare you.

Contigo is a fantastic dining experience. All of the dishes are share-able, and not huge 'Murican portions. Spanish dining at its best, is how I would describe it. 

How can I even begin to laud this place? 
I've had many fabulous meals here and I hope to have many more. 

They recently changed some of the options so you can have a few appetizers and order them by item, such as the sardines on avocado toast with pickled onions - I'm not a sardine person by any means but I can eat those like candy. 

They had mussles cooked in a wine and chorizo sauce that I swear was one of the best things I've ever eaten, but it's not on the menu right this second. 

The paella, when they have it, is out of this world. I recently had a "coca" (no, not THAT kind), which is basically a flatbread with cheese, bacon, zucchini and squash blossoms that was a perfect balance of salt and vegetable. The bread itself was one of the best I've ever had. 

Everything they do here is done well. They have a cava-based sangria that you should absolutely try.

Wine list is all Spanish origin - and it's fantastic. I was just able to try a varietal that I've never seen before (and don't remember the name of) that grows only on the Canary Islands due to a phyloxera epidemic that wiped it out a while back. 

Trust your servers here, they know the food. 

They have a $40/person family style option. I'd do it if I were you. The food here is really wonderful, and just gets better and better. 

Excellent service, excellent ambiance, and outdoor seating as well. A gem!
author: Nicole L.

description:
3.5/stars

I recently went to Contigo for dinner with a client. Upon arriving the wait is long, given the rush hour for dinner. This is my first time coming here and from start to finish wow management and staff team got it locked down in giving great service. 

The inside is well built, they have tall windows for sunlight to come in and it's well kept and clean. The bathroom smells nice and fresh. 

And the workers look happy but busy which is okay. I wish they smiled a little bit as they are working even if they aren't serving your table. 

The majority of the reviews have negative comments about being over priced. But you have to know that this restaurant is only open for about 5hrs each day. So give them a break, a business needs to price at a number to stay a float. 

I tried their churro with the chocolate dipping and it's quite a weird combo but turned out tasting better then I excepted. And enjoyed 4 of their tapas. 

-1 star the hours they open at. 
Overall 5/5 if it weren't.
author: Ken S.
Marco C.

description: Since our trip to Catalonia last year, we've been missing the taste of Spain. Finally, we found it, right here in SF! Make sure to order small portions so you can sample as many delicious delights as possible.  Great for date night with your sweetheart.  Order the jamon croquettes!
author: Brian P.

description:
We were seated right away on an early Friday night and our waiter was very friendly. He recommended the blood orange sangria. It was delicious!

We ordered a few tapas and about 3 raciones, which was enough for two of us. My favorites were the patates braves and the secreto (pork belly dish). Serving sizes for the raciones were small considering the price. The food was good but I don't think I'd spend almost $50 a person again for what we got. 

Overall, the service was great, the sangria was awesome, and oh man...the churros con chocolate.
author: Katherine C.

description:
My friend and I have a monthly meal out in the city together. This was probably the most so-so experience we have had so far. 

We had an early reservation (first ones there), and was sat on a small table in the middle of a whole bunch of other tables. About 30 minutes in, a single person had the corner booth next to us. Was just a little awkward.

Service was pretty good otherwise, and we ordered several plates to share. We decided that we loved about half of them, the other half just okay.
author: Amy O.

description: Squid ink paella?!  YES, please.  Keep in mind, this heavenly paella is only available on Tuesday nights.  You have the option of selecting the tasting menu which is $38 per person for a paella and four chef's choice tapas or ordering the paella a la carte. We opted to order the paella a la carte and picked our own tapas.  The tapas were forgettable or maybe because the paella blew everything out of the water.  We would come back on a Tuesday night in a heartbeat for the paella - hopefully they start serving it on other nights!
author: Michele L.

description: I cannot say enough good things about the handful of little plates/bites I had here. The anchovies over a firm ricotta-type cheese on a crostini...DEVINE. My man's favorite was the smoked herring on a crostini with an avocado spread and pickled onions...it was such a tasty bite. I have every intention of attempting these bites at home. Will return again. Service was on the slow side but I'll chalk it up to it being Valentines weekend.
author: Maria S.

description:
I have had dinner here four times and my only disappointment is that I did not visit this restaurant sooner.

This place has it all: great decor, excellent service, wonderful food.  All four of the people I have brought here have liked it as well.  

I am so glad to have a favorite restaurant in the neighborhood.  The back patio is nice, even during a rain storm, and is a bit quieter than the inside.  

I don't eat many veggies, but the vegetable dishes here are fantastic, especially the spinach and chickpea dish.  I don't like salads, but the two I have had here won me over.  I have not tried the paella yet.  It is only offered on Tuesdays and although I have been there twice on a Tuesday, I did not want to wait 40 minutes for it.  

The menu changes a bit each week.  I always enjoy reading it when I walk past.

The hot chocolate makes the perfect dessert.  Ask for it without salt if you don't want salt crystals in it.
author: Bay G.

description: Phenomenal meal. Will be back soon. I'd re-order the squid, chard & sangria. The atmosphere & service were also fabulous!
author: Diana R.

description:
We walked in with early dinner reservations. The place was pretty quiet as there were only a few tables filled, but quickly filled as we ate.

Not knowing what to get, we decided to go for the tasting menu (a selection of 7 dishes served family style). Our tasting menu for that night consisted of:

Spanish Olives, Marcona Almonds, and Pickled Farmers Vegetables (not on tasting menu)
- High quality products and a good little snack while waiting for the other dishes to come out (I'm a sucker for Marcona almonds and pickled veggies).

Sardine on Toast
- One of my favorites of the night. Simple dish, but really tasty.

Oxtail Mini-Hamburguesa
- Surprisingly good. The hamburger patty consisting of oxtail complete with the chewy bits for lots of flavor!

Little Gem Salad
- Yum. Beets and garlic chips!

Spinach and Chickpeas Andalusian Style
- Pretty solid dish. Great mix of spices.

Local Xipirons
- Good dish with fresh squid, Padrón peppers, and tomatoes.

Local King Salmon
- Baked beautifully in/on fig leafs which helped it remain very moist and juicy. The corn, zucchini, cherry tomato medley underneath was really good.

Albóndigas
- Good quality meatball with some depth in flavor. But to be honest, it wasn't mindblowing or anything. Slightly more developed than what you would expect a meatball in tomato sauce to taste like.

Parking isn't too bad in the area. We were able to easily find parking just down the block. Service was good and our waiter did a great job. He was very friendly and helpful. Also there's a nice covered patio area in the back that looked like it would be nice to sit at for those warm summer nights.

We'll be back to try some of the other dishes!
author: Vivian L.

description:
After our trip to Spain this summer, we've been craving some Spanish food since we came back from the bay area. We ran a search on Yelp and decided to go with Contigo. 

It was fairly straight-forward to make a reservation for a Sunday on Open Table. We like the neighborhood the restaurant is in, a lot of stores and boutiques. Good to walk around before or after a meal if the stores aren't closed yet. 

When we walked into the restaurant, we were instantly attracted to the bar/kitchen area and the lights on the left hand side. The ambience was dark but earthy and warm. 

We were led to the back of the restaurant, which was an enclosed semi-outdoor area with heaters around us, so it wasn't cold at all sitting "out". We were surrounded by plants and some fire woods, which provides a homey and outdoorsy feel to it. 

We ordered 7-8 tapas, everything was decently good. All the recommended tapas by the waitress turned out to be delicious. One thing we really wanted to try was Jamón ibérico, as the ones we had in Spain were just mind-blowing. The one in Contigo turned out to be satisfying. Moreover, the cava the waitress recommended was pretty tasty as well. 

We were happy with our food and the service. Overall, we had a wonderful dining experience. Will definitely return again.
author: Kai Y.

description:
A friend had recommended this place as one of his favorites in Noe so I have been wanting to try it for awhile.   I came in  a group of 8 for a birthday dinner, and we all thought the food was great and the wine was amazing.   

If you have a party of 8 or more, you are automatically required to have their prix fixe menu of $42/person (which ended up being $73/person pre-tip by the time we added wine, dessert and tax).  My one complaint about this is that they don't actually tell you in advance what that menu is going to be, and it changes regularly, plus it doesn't include paella (apparently Tuesdays are paella nights).  Luckily, they are super accommodating about allergies, and they sent out different dishes where necessary for my friends who were on gluten-free diets. 

We were seated in the back patio area with heat lamps, and it was really nice back there!  

The menu was excellent.  A good variety of food and some standouts:
Sardine and avocado toast with pickled onion and sea salt - a sardine dish will never be a favorite of mine but surprisingly this was actually pretty good even for people who aren't in to sardines. 
Croqueta de jamon serrano - nicely done 
Melon con Jamon - yummy!  Always a good pairing but the melon wasn't too mushy and the parma ham tasted so good. 
Cojondongo - a gazpacho salad  - this was delicious!  Really fresh tomatoes, cucumbers, frisée, some crispy stuff that added texture, grapes for some added sweetness, and a light vinaigrette.  
Squid a la plancha with shelling beans, padron peppers, chorizo - really nicely cooked. Loved the peppers and aioli. 
Black cod - slightly crisped skin and super moist fish - excellent! 
Albondigas (pork lamb and jamon meatballs) in tomato sherry sauce - never a fan of meatballs so I'm not the best judge, but the sauce was tasty.  

Our server recommended 2012 Bodegas y Viñedos Ponce "PF" Manchuela which was an awesome big red, and luckily the cheapest one on the menu too! ($50/bottle).  Everyone loved it and we ended up finishing off a few.  

For dessert, we got the flan but more importantly the TCHO chocolate with churros.  Delicious!   After finishing the churro, I couldn't stop drinking the chocolate, which has added sea salt.  

In general, I found the service very friendly throughout the booking process when I had to call back several times to add people to the reservation.   I would say the service during the meal seemed super slow, and it ended up taking nearly 3 hours, which wasn't ideal on a school night.  I'm not sure if it's partly because we were outside in the back.  The restaurant was hopping throughout the evening though.  

In any case, we loved our evening and I am looking forward to trying paella night!   Well done!
author: Vivian W.

description:
I swear I've heard of this restaurant before but somehow never managed to take the time to eat here.  In all, I walked away impressed with the fact there wasn't a weak point throughout a diverse meal for a group of 4.  Our server let us know we ordered choices he thought were strong, but to get 4 people in agreement that there were no weak dishes says something about the quality of the food here.  

We had salad, soup, calamari, sautéed greens, fish, lamb.  I cannot wait to go back here and sample their extensive wine selection and completely pig out on the carbs I passed on after my wedding/honeymoon.
author: Darin E.

description:
There are 2 reasons to go to this place:

1.  Chocolate con churro - and you must get at least 2-3 churros to finish every single drop of the hot chocolate.  It reminds me the taste in Madrid.

2.  Cute waiters.
author: Anna C.

description:
Each dish is amazing and an excellent handcrafted array of flavors - fresh, delicious, and local. Great time and great service, looking forward to my next visit.

Good for small groups and a reservation is advised.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Went to Contigo now several time and I love the selection of the small plate,you can taste different flavors....
Suggestion.....if you go there seat at the bar the people work there are great!!!!
author: Alessandro B.

description:
Great tapas restaurant. 
Good: food was delicious, drinks also delicious! Great atmosphere. Nice place for birthdays, dates, and girls night! 
Bad: definitely expensive and portions were small, even for tapas. They ran out of the strawberry soda. The "date based" dish was mediocre.
author: Tulsi M.

description: Fantastic food! There's not much more to say. Been here a couple of times and tried a bunch of dishes with most of them being excellent. In particular, I remember the flatbread, the goat cheese salad standing out. Best Spanish restaurant in SF for me!
author: Manjesh N.

description:
Out of all the restaurants I tried either by walking, trolleys, and/or buses, this is the one place I would happily sit on a train and bus, then have to walk a bit.  This was as good as it gets.  It was recommended by a friend and I'm so glad we went.  It has a wonderful atmosphere, but it comes down to the food, right?

Well, it receives five stars, so you can guess I enjoyed the food. Dish after dish was spectacular. Unfortunately I don't remember the actual names of each dish, sorry, but I'll do my best to describe them.  After all, we had nine dishes while we were there. Maybe someone who works there will stumble upon this and tell me the actual names.

Our first tapas was mangos with cheese. It truly was a great way to start. It was fresh, ripe, wonderful combination of the fruit and cheese. (4.5 Stars)

We moved onto toast with tomato bruschetta.  The toast was wonderfully crunchy despite the tomato spread on it. This was probably the least favorite of all the dishes, not a home run, but a double or triple. (3 Stars)

I was the only one who wanted to try the monidito (sardines), which worked out well, all three for me. I was expecting a very salty piece of fish, but it was prepared in a way where it wasn't and the toast underneath helped to make the whole bite very mild. (4 Stars)

Next on our palate was the albondigas (meatballs). It is pork meat balls in a tomato sherry sauce. OUT OF THE PARK HOMERUN! Wow, was this one out of two favorite dishes that night. After the meatballs were done, I was still scrapping the tomato sauce.  It was slightly spicy, just enough heat, making you want more. (6 out of 5 Stars)

The second favorite dish was the brussels sprouts. Up until this evening, I never ate brussels sprouts. This dish made me do an about-face for brussels sprouts. I now say I eat them. I feel like they blanched them before cooking them because they were cooked, yet still deliciously crunchy. It also had a lemon dressing that made you lick your lips and hoping there were some sauce on them. As a surprise, there was a layer of thinly sliced almonds underneath giving it just an additional flavor, but the right amount of texture. (5 Stars)

I didn't see this one on the menu today, but if it's not, what a loss.  The next one was Pimientos de Padron (small peppers sauteed and sprinkled with sea salt). These were yummy and zero were left. I was expecting them to be spicy, but were not. They had just enough charred flavor that was complimented with the salt. (4 Stars)

The crispy potatoes arrived with a tomato dressing.  I think I would have enjoyed these more if it wasn't next to my favorite ones.  Since it was competing side-by-side, it fell to waste side. We finished them, don't get me wrong, they were tasty, but couldn't compete with the brussels sprouts and meat balls. (3 Stars)

Moving onto dessert, we tried two. The first one was an ice cream dish, but I don't remember what type, once again competing side-by-side with a better dish. (3 Stars)

The dessert that left us wanting more was the chocolate caliente con churros.  These were delicious Mexican cinnamon sticks that we could dip into hot molten chocolate. Once the sticks were gone, we were using our spoons to dig out the chocolate. Yummy! (4.5 Stars)
author: Randy G.

description:
Excellent food. Super pricey for the quantity, though. Friendly service. 

Recommend the pizza and the meatballs, as well as the ham/pear appetizer.
author: Brian M.

description:
Contigo is easily going to be my new favorite hot-spot within SF.  Located in Noe Valley this place can easily be passed up.  The small sign waves steadily outside amongst the heavy foot traffic.  Once you step inside you'll be transported into a chic dining destination with outside patio seating as well for those bright sunny days.

The tapas style menu is hard to believe with almost everything on the menu looking delectable.  Our modest party of three started off with some anchovy tapas and a couple of bottles of wine to get the festivities rolling.  The selection is pretty large for such a small space and the staff was extremely courteous and knowledgeable about the meal at hand. the ablondigas were a great way to prep for the race with simple flavors that packed a tiny little punch. The little gem and seared cheese salads were the cleansing needed after a heavy little ball, followed up by the King Salmon  being the highlight of the night. Of course we couldn't leave without trying the dessert.  The vanilla ice cream with olive oil and sea salt was the sweet-tooth's winner.

I would gladly try Contigo again, and again.... and again if only someone would take me out for once :)
author: Kevin J.

description:
Came here with an 8PM reservation and showed up around 7:45PM. There were 4 empty tables and we were walked to the table and then walked back because they wanted to make sure the people who had reservations at 7:45PM would be sat on time even though they weren't there yet. So we waited as those tables trickled in and then at 8:05PM we were seated.... at the table we were walked to in the first place. Definitely make a reservation if you plan on coming, but don't show up early unless you're okay eating at 8:45PM or 9PM because it really cleared out. 
We did the 7 course tasting menu and 2 sangrias and a bottle of white to start. The first two courses were from the Tapas menu; Croquetas and the Sardine/ Avocado Toast. The croqueta was okay but a bit mushy inside while the Sardine toast was delightful and I believe the first time I had Sardines.
Next was the Condonjongo or Gazpacho  salad which was tasty but super overdressed. 
Now it was here, after 3 courses that the waitress came back and told us the wine we ordered wasn't in stock. Meanwhile our very small Sangrias had been drained eons ago. So we ordered a different bottle.
Then came the Ham and Peaches dish which was odd, though the peaches were very tasty. 
Then we finally got our wine. 
Next was the Squid, Salmon, and Meatballs. The squid dish was tasty but mostly because of the tomatoes as the squid itself was very lightly flavored. The salmon with roasted corn was an awesome dish. The meatballs had a weird texture and felt apart on the plate.
We ordered the churros and tcho chocolate for dessert which was delish.
My biggest issue wasn't the bland food or the sadist host but the weird firing of the dishes. We would get two at a time sometimes and then one right after and then sit with an empty dish in front of us for 15 minutes before we got the next dish. Also, considering how saucy everything was, we had to ask to have our plates switched out with clean ones. Normally I don't mind these things but when you're paying $100 per person before tip, $125 after, you expect service to be on par with the prices.
author: Kajal G.

description:
Had the tasting menu and everything was great.  
Also has great wine list a wonderful sangria.  
Would go there again
author: Michael L.

description:
I came here because 1) I hadn't seen my guy bff for months maybe even a year and well 2) he got a job! 

We decided to go with the tasting menu most likely because I was hungry and because we like to try everything. This was a way to try many of the items on menu without getting TOO full. 

Our tasting consisted of the following: 
Croquet - delicious, but nothing too memorable
Avocado toast - yum. I love avocado so there's no issues there, but was also sardines which I didn't think I would like, but it added a great salty presence to it. 
Strawberry goat cheese salad - very fresh and the goat cheese was really good even though for the most part I don't like goat cheese.
Asparagus - I would have a preferred a poached egg, but that's because I preferred poached eggs to fried eggs with a great sauce. 
Halibut - so well cooked. Still so moist and I remembered this great sauce of carrots I think. I love a well cooked fish.
Squid - I remember this dish just being okay. I enjoy squid fried mostly.
Meatballs - hmm yum. the meatballs at Contigo are delicious! 

Glasses of sangria should be bigger. I feel like for the price, the glasses should have been bigger. 

Overall, I had a great experience. The wait isn't bad if you make a reservation for when the restaurant opens!
author: Nina Y.

description:
Started with Almanacs finest, which was a mash up of Miller Light, a Cider, and Anchor Steam. I learned my lesson and will avoid that San Francisco brand.  Otherwise food. I had tasting menu, first course was avocado spread on toast, very good. second course was a croquette filled with creamed beef? normally that would have been revolting, but nice texture and taste. Next was asparagus with an egg. This egg was fake poached, steamed so a little bit of a crust. Normally I dislike this technique for eggs, but this did not have the nasty taste just an unpleasant texture. Next was a crab salad, and a poached whitefish with lentils. nice chimichurri  sauce and mint on fish. waiter described fish as lamb.. but was excellent. crab salad was amazing had orange slices which added the perfect amount of acid. my next was squid on a bed of small pasta, like Israeli couscous in squid ink covered with yogurt.  Squid was perfect, pasta was a little over cooked and yogurt had no flavor and slimy texture, definitely should have stayed far away. Finally, a meatball, with middle eastern spices. meatball was perfect, sauce needed more time to build flavor. I ended with a cheese course and that was perfect. 

Some small, very minor, missteps, but an amazing meal and their decor is a delight. 

Noise is low, not a church, but not the middle of the road either. 

I will be back.
author: Dean N.

description:
Blah,

The service was super bad.  And while I walked in thinking how lucky I am to live in Noe Valley, with charming restaurants on every corner, our nervous and, well, waiter was mumbling and unaware of the menu.  We were dismissed throughout the whole meal and the food was mediocre.  Okay, the squid was super good but the salad-overdressed.  The mackerel, which I was told was sardine, super duper fishy.  

Not rushing back.
author: maker of p.

description: Great food and atmosphere. Service was fantastic .
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The food is yummy, and its always packed. The staff is helpful and kind.
It was a nice dinner in my neighborhood that I'll remember.

The Little Gem Salad is really a little piece of heaven!
author: Kristina B.

description:
Wow! The food here was phenomenal! I came here for dinner with my mom and boyfriend and we were not disappointed! 

First we ordered the anchovies, the sardines, and the croquettes. The anchovies were my mom and my favorite as they were the perfect mix of salty and savory. My bf liked the croquettes the best. The sardines were a bit too large for my taste. It was overwhelming and not as complimentary to the dish as I though the anchovies were. 

Then we ordered the mint/beet salad, fried quail, meatballs, and beef tenderloin. YUM!!!! All three were delicious. The beef was my favorite as it came with blue cheese and green beans. Both were cooked perfectly. The quail was also super impressive to me. You could clearly taste the quail even though it was breaded and fried. The salad that went with it was also tasty. The mint/beet salad was extremely refreshing and the perfect complement to the the beef and quail. The meatballs were very good and tender, but nothing unique. The other dishes were much more impressive. All the food was delicious though and you could taste how fresh the ingredients are. 

Oh, and the bread the have there is amazing! I don't know if they make it there or buy it, but it is the best crusty bread I have had in a long time! 

Overall this place is definitely worth going to. The ambiance is great and I like the set up of the restaurant. The bar area is pretty neat because you get to watch them actually cook the meal. I really enjoyed that. The staff seemed nice but our server was not that attentive, although they were at capacity that night so maybe that was it. 

The only negative is how expensive it is compared to the portion size. For three people we weren't hungry when we left, but we weren't stuffed either. The wine list they have is pretty great, but a bit overpriced. It's definitely great for a date night but bad if your starving.
