I think next time I go I will do the tasting menu that they have preset. It seem like most people were ordering that.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I love Congito.  The dishes are deceptively simple with layers of flavor.  Perfect example- the sauteed greens come with raisins marinated in a yummy rum sauce.  Highlights always include "bites" at the top.  I like to order a couple of vegetable dishes and split one "main" meat.  Finish it off with a glass of red (the wine list is stellar) and a scoop of ice cream for dessert and I'm in heaven.

The staff is also lovely- very attentive, professional, and friendly.
author: W S.

description:
Went to dinner here Sat 5/15/10.  I was pretty full before eating here which is a good thing because the portions are on the small side.  It's on Castro @ 24th St, SF.  Street parking nearby - not too hard.

Got there about 5:25 and it opens at 5:30p on Sat.  Didn't have reservations, but we got a table that in the dining room near the patio.

There's a bar area to eat at & another near the kitchen.  A bunch of tables in the main dining room, plus the patio.

Contigo is a Spanish and Catalan restaurant in the Noe Valley neighborhood on SF.  Pretty cool since I don't know much about Spanish or Catalan food.

FREE house sparkling or still water.  We picked Sparkling.  Comes in a carafe.

We got:

1 1/2 order small of Lomo $13.  It was tasty.  Lots of famous meats thinly sliced.  Served w/ bread & olive oil.

1 1/2 Iberico $15 - nice & tasty.   Served w/ bread & olive oil.

1 order anchovies $5.  It comes w/ 3 tiny slices filled w/ olive oil.  World's finest anchovies from Cantabria.  I thought it was ok.  

1 order Local calamars a la planxa $10 - Squid salad. B. liked it, not too chewy.  Comes w/ greens & fava beans.

1 order Gulf Prawns & paella $20 - 3 huge prawns & some rice.  I thought it wasn't that special.  It's a small serving enough for only 1 person.

1 order chard $7 - might be from garden in the patio.  Cut up almonds, golden raisins, & garlic.  Just ok for me.

B. got a glass of G-W Vina Valoria $10 - he liked it.

To try next time I'm there: Sardines w guac on toast - looked good. Flatbread sounds good & desserts!

Subtotal $80 + tax 7.89 + Svc charge $3 ($1.5pp Healthy SF service charge) = $90.89 Before tip!

One unisex bathroom available.  Toilet made by Vitra 1.6 Gpf/6.0 Lpf.  Push the lower button on the wall to flush.

Tip: Go Sun, Tues, Wed & get 4 courses for $35pp!!  Primer plat, segon plat, accompanyament, & postre!! Great deal.

Menu changes daily:
http://www.contigosf.com/index.html

Hrs:
Closed Mon
Tu-Sat 5:30-10
Sun 5:30-9:30
author: Ann L.

description:
This place, which at best is workmanlike, is pretentious, over-hyped and hyper-overpriced. 

Most of the eensy, teensy morsels on the $42-per-person tasting menu were pretty tasty (kudos for the squid with black rice and honorable mention for the albondigas, the only word I remember from Spanish class), but the hit-and-miss culinary experience described by other reviewers is utterly overshadowed by the shameless charges for both food and wine.  

You can pretty much replicate this experience at home for a fraction of the cost. Start by throwing some canned sardines or anchovies on a bit of toast. Accompany with good Spanish  cheese and jamon. And then wash it all down with a nice bottle of wine, or two. 

You can save a ton of money while avoiding the din and hassle of the too-full-of-itself Contigo.
author: Alan M.

description:
Good spanish tapas. A bit lengthy between the different tapas.
Very friendly staff!
author: Guillaume K.

description:
My friend and I must have had the same server as Caroline L.  We were there on the same night and seated on the patio as well.  It was a hot day in SF so we were happy to be seated outside!  It's not often we get to enjoy patio dining :)  The hostess was nice enough, but our server must have been having a really crappy day.  My friend and I are very nice, unassuming, and undemanding people!  We were so baffled at the cold shoulder we got from her.  She wouldn't really make eye contact, didn't check in with us even once to see how we were doing.  In fact, my friend had to flag her down so that we could order another drink!  It was not a pleasant, welcoming experience :( 
To end the night, she dropped the bill down on the table without saying a word. No smile, no thanks, nothing.  This was before our dessert was even served....
At least it wasn't just us!?
author: Jocelyn C.

description: Although on the expensive side (no wonder, since it is Michelin recommended), they know their tapas! The place is quite intimate and I think we got the best table inside, the first one to the right on the mezzanine. We tried several of the tapas, all to share, and none of the let us down: torradas, cojonudos, xipirons, trout, albondigas, amongst others; paired with a wonderful wine. The server was a little uptight, maybe because he was training a new member of the staff, but a smile goes a long way.
author: Pablo N.

description:
The food here really is just mediocre.  I was quite disappointed with the service as well as the quality of the food.  Unfortunately there were not any dishes that stood out, and the meal was not memorable.  Worse part is that they do not even take American Express.  It is not like the prices are cheap, but they are obviously trying to squeeze the extra dollar or two out of you.

I think I just had a bad experience there.  Based on other Yelp reviews, this place is great.  However, it is unfortunate for Contigo that they gave a Yelper bad service and mediocre food.  I will not be back.
author: Patrick M.

description: My favorite dish was the tripe with chickpeas and chorizo. Unique preparation and favors.
author: Jeannie T.

description: Love this place. The food is super good, great wine selection, cute and cozy atmosphere, really awesome staff. Was super bummed the pan con tomate wasn't on the menu last time! Hopefully it makes a reappearance!
author: Cole G.

description: Great food. Sangria was very good too. We had tasting menu. Gaspacho is my weakness they got me.... whole experience was amazing.
author: Gabrirlla P.

description:
Great food.  Fantastic service.  This tapas bar has it right.  

The timing of the plates was excellent.  I have to say that I had the best meatballs I ever had here.  And the flan is killer.

Only con, no parking.  But if you are in the area, well worth the visit.

In addition, this place is trying hard to be locally sourced.  So another reason to pull for them.
author: Abiud A.

description:
I have a love-hate relationship with this place.

First of all, the good:  wonderful appetizers including locally-sourced sardines and anchovies on toasts.  The prix-fixe menu is totally worth the money.  The "secret cut of pork" is one of the best pork I've ever had.  Amazing grilled squids and yummy churros/chocolate dipping sauce.  Cute space.

The bad:  horrendous service at times.  Servers seem oblivious and even condescending to our questions & requests.  The last 5 times we went, service was terrible for all 5.  Also, please try and space out the timing for prix fixe courses.  The simplest rule is never to bring another dish out when guests are still working on the previous one.  That's not too much to ask right?

I and my friends have been coming to Contigo since it opened in 2009 (we even followed Brett Emerson's Flickr before he started building the restaurant).  It's one of my go-to places in The City and I always take out-of-town visitors there, as well as birthdays and other celebrations.  This is why it saddens me to have received such bad service over the past year, which makes me think twice now before deciding to visit again.
author: Khanh N.

description: In full disclosure, Spanish is my favorite fare, so Contigo's marriage of authentic dishes, excellent preparation, and a cosy and inviting space in Noe Valley ticks all my boxes.  The seasonal menu always has intriguing dishes, though the Chef's Menu provides the best value and offers a diverse sampling of the menu's top selections.  I recommend the grilled seafood (squid a la plancha) and meat (lamb rib chops) dishes, in addition to the iberico ham, albondigas and anything off their tapas menu.  Their by-the-glass sherry selection is also quite good, which I also recommend.  Portions are fairly generous, but if you have room, their cheese plate is excellent...so are the churros with hot chocolate.
author: Ronald C.

description:
We LOVE this place for Spanish Tapas!
The Flatbread is amazing! The croquettes are the best we have had anywhere!
The ribs when they have them rock! The octopus! If possible leave room for their awesome churros with a dark delicious dipping sauce!
Last but not least - they have very beautiful wines from Spain, etc.
author: Kirk M.

description: This place is unbeatable for tapas. We tried the chef's tasting menu, and every bite we had was delicious. My personal favorite was probably the papas fritas, essentially fried potatoes with a yummy tomato/cream sauce on top, though it's really hard to say what the favorite was because everything was fresh and delicious.The only downside I would say is the fact that you start to get so full by the last few plates that you can't enjoy them as much as the first ones, but it's so good you manage you keep eating somehow. I would say if you decide to order the chef's tasting menu, come hungry and be prepared to leave feeling stuffed. Definitely coming back here again to try more of their dishes!
author: Erica V.

description:
My girlfriend and I had the Valentine's Day prix fixe. It was essentially a four course meal that started with a trio of teeny-tiny appetizers, a salad, a main, and then dessert. The food ranged from remarkable (a two-bite grilled cheese sandwich with jamon iberico and black truffle) to super-good (a choice of short ribs braised in sherry or a very well executed seafood paella). At $65 per person, the sum total of all the portions was relatively generous, and I didn't feel we were being saddled with the old Valentine's Day prix fixe flim-flam -- i.e., a deal that looks good on the paper menu, but is really just a profit-making vehicle for the restaurant. 

Service was fine but not great. Our waiter was prompt and attentive, but also low energy (almost solemn) and inaudible when he spoke. I would have liked to have been reminded a bit more about what we were eating. 

All in all, it was generally a great meal.  Except for the $40 wine pairing menu.

The wine itself was fantastic, especially the xarel.lo white and the special reserve madeira. But the wines always significantly preceded the courses, and the pours were just silly small. This made actually *pairing* the wine and food almost impossible. The wine was almost gone by the time the food arrived. If I go back, I'll be interested to see if their by-the-glass pours are so stingy.
author: Jon P.

description:
The food here is tasty--IF you are into dairy and lamb. Unfortunately I don't eat either, and I have to say, I found the menu pretty limiting as a result of my...pickiness :/  I also found the portions expensive and tiny. A bad combo. My favorite dish, the Iberico ham was tasty--but it was $26 for maybe 5 pieces of ham. Not cool. We also ordered the sardine (tasty), potato xip (stupidly small, hot chip and cold roe = bleh), ratatouille, tuna, two glasses of wine, and the churros. Churros and chocolate sauce were decadent and wonderful. Recommend!
I say...if you are rich, like lamb and cheese, and can't eat a lot, this is the perfect place for you!! :)
author: Sydney W.

description:
Everything on the menu is worth trying --- you can taste the thought that went into every petite dish!

Remember to get a reservation --- walk-ins are pretty much not possible. They allot 2 hours for each dining party.

I don't drink, so no comment on the wine selection.

We have had:

sardine & avocado toast --- a bite-size slice of well toasted sardine & avocado.

sauteed greens catalan style --- a simple sauteed vegetable dish that was surprisingly good! The portion is actually big (for two people), and I really like how the sweetness of pine nuts and raisins blend with the savory greens.

charred asparagus --- less interesting than the greens, but also a very healthy dish

albondigas --- meatballs! get them! I also suggest getting a plate of plain bread to soak up all the remaining meat sauce in the dish. You will not regret getting this!

for dessert, we got strawberry rhubarb pie + strawberry gelato --- it was really good in the sense that it wasn't too sweet and you could actually taste the tartness in the berry and rhubarb. Way better than your average dessert.


This place isn't cheap, but every once in a while, it is worth a visit!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I found the food to be average tasting. The wait staff were courteous but not very detailed. We received an extra order of a tapa that we didn't order but were charged for it. Our waiter delivered our lamb to the table next to us. We he was told the order was not correct he picked up the plate and put it down on our table. Let's just say we didn't eat it. Gross!!
author: Peter P.

description: Four stars, Yelp?  Really?!  Mediocre food, mediocre service, and a colossal mix up with the bill.  There are too many great restaurants in this city to bother coming back here (and frankly, too many great Spanish tapas spots to come here at all).  Disappointing overall.
author: Angela R.

description:
The food was decent, some standouts were the Smashed Pumpkin Torrada Toast and Tripe. However, the reason for the 2-star rating is that service and pacing of the meal were horrible. Our party of four ordered 8 dishes to share, and we got 7 of them relatively quickly. Then we sat and waited... and waited... for our last dish, the Pluma. It was good, but not worth the 30 minute additional wait, and honestly, not worth the $36. Wasn't that impressed with the Xipirons a la Planxa (squid) and Mushroom Flatbread... our table didn't finish those dishes. 

Our waiter was very absent throughout the meal, he seemed to spend a lot of time in the back. Actually not sure where he was, but he wasn't at our table. Additionally, the wait staff took away my friend's wine glass for some reason (even though we hadn't finished the wine we were sharing), and we had to ask 3 times for them to replace it. The 2nd time we asked, a waitress brought a wine menu because she thought we were asking to order another glass. Additionally, they took away my wine glass, even though there was still some wine left in it, without even consulting me first. It was almost comedic how bad and rude the service was.

At the end of our unintentional 1.5 hour meal, our waiter asked if we wanted to see the dessert menu. I don't know why we said yes, but we did. We decided on the Churros. However, since the waiter took 10+ minutes to come take our dessert order, we changed our minds and asked for the check instead.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Fantastic food with great service! This place is not cheap, but then where is in San Francisco? The help staff is very knowledgeable and the service is quick and polite.
I went on a birthday celebration and was EXTREMELY happy with it all.
 I am definitely going back.
author: Brian W.

description:
Been back to Contigo and did not have a problem with the service this time.

Food was fantastic and we had a great time! .. except the never ending queues to the only bathroom. 

Will definitely be back whenever I find myself craving their flat bread, sardine toast and fried seasonal goodies!
author: Amber S.

description: Nice space. Good food. Lots of light food on the menu. Smallish portions, but everything was good quality and fresh. Liked the mint in the salad. Place is a bit of a hidden gem. Was quite busy at 9 pm.
author: Andrew K.

description:
On a whim, we came here for a last minute celebration dinner. I arrived at 9:20pm. 

Highlights of our experience:

Our attempt to make eye contact with hostess upon arrival was hilarious. I've never been so unsuccessful at locking eyes with another human being. It was as if the hostess was actively averting my eyes. If i didn't know better, I'd say that the restaurant was hoping that we'd go away.

Our waitress was exceedingly awkward and unwilling to engage in dialog once she realized that we're going to only order 4 dishes total to share, and pass on the wine. She did of course recommend highly the most expensive items on the menu. 

It wasn't a particularly busy evening, but Contigo did manage to take 60 minutes in delivering 4 tapas dishes (one of which is an appetizer). The last dishes that managed to come out was missing an extra meatball, so that took another 10 minutes. 

(we were pretty envious of the table next to us, a party of 5 girls who had great service... perhaps we should have ordered wine just to get treated as actual customers instead of sad hanger-ons.)

Our professed enthusiasm for a dessert menu went ignored. I guess it's okay since 55 minutes into the limp service, any trace of desire for dessert had died. 

Our waitress asked us about 60 minutes into the meal if we're enjoying the food. I don't know what she had expected as an answer, since she was surprised when I told her the truth: our order got lost, then came out slowly, and in separate parts. Our plea for a dessert menu meant nothing. She looked offended but assured that she has told management about the evening's shortcoming. Not surprisingly, management did nothing.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Had doubts about this place, but it was really good. I was blown away. 

We came here for the Paella Tuesday. $32 a person. Table for 4, but when we thought about it, it's not worth it. Better off ordering a la carte so you can try more things. They were going to give us 2 paella and 4 side dishes, but so glad we didn't.

Everything was really good, but the Paella. It's huge, and has meat and artichokes. Never had that in a paella before. It wasn't bad, but it was nothing special. Had way better elsewhere. 

Croqueta de jamon serran-Cheese and ham filling in a crunchy ball. How can you go wrong?

$25 jamon serrana ham-very expensive thinly sliced ham with some bread. This was really good. 

Goat cheese salad-very refreshing. They give you a big piece of goat cheese that you can cut up yourself

Pardon peppers-love these. They are just like the shishito peppers

Patates braves-cripsy fried potatoes with yummy sauce. An upgraded version of french fries. Got to have them.

Chanterelle mushroom flatbread-oh so yummy and crispy crust. This was a whole pizza

Meatballs with pork, lamb, and jamon-super tender and full of flavor. The sauce was a little too sweet for me, but everyone else enjoyed it. Make sure you order some bread to soak up the sauce

Hanger steak-super small, but perfectly cooked and seasoned. 

No room for dessert
author: Karen H.

description:
Ate here twice in one week because the food was that delicious I had to share it with my mom. But unfortunately the service for a second time was a disappointment. Dishes were not served in a timely fashion and I could see tables around us who had gotten before or after us were not timed well either. I also noticed we were forgotten having to ask other waiters for more wine and bread, I don't know if they were understaffed or jut unorganized.
Be none the less it's still amazing food and I will have to ignore everything else. 

Favorite Dishes:
Tripe and chickpea - What a surprise this was almost sweet!
Squid with artichokes- Perfectly seasoned the ink rice that comes with it could have been double the serving it is so good.
Flan- Best flan I've had in a long time. Custardy and a little built salty will go back for this.
author: Alexandra G.

description:
A friend took me to celebrate a B-day dinner.  It was our first time there. The ambience was cozy & romantic. We had the "Tapas Tasting Menu".  Each dish that came out was amazing to look at & delicious to the taste! However, there was one dish, that I did not care for, which was overly salted for my taste. It was the Pardon peppers/shishito.  The other thing, I was disappointed by.... is the Service. Lack of smiles & the promptness of a request.  
All I can say is..... How sad!
author: Toi E.

description:
We purchased a BBE deal for this place, and were so happy we did! (As was the table next to us.)

Noe is a beautiful neighborhood, and while parking can be tough because so much of it is residential, it's certainly not as difficult as other neighborhoods.

We were seated in the patio area, but it's enclosed and has plentiful heaters, so it's still comfortable.

Our server was incredibly knowledgeable, and had great recommendations, he also brought out a few wines for me to try before i committed to one. I was unfamiliar with the wine list, so this was very much appreciated.

We shared:
Roasted Dungeness crab: I love crab, and this was incredible. The sauce was tasty, but not too overpowering. The freshness and sweetness of the crab still came through. I generally prefer crab without any sauce, but my husband loved this.
Croqueta de jamon iberico de bellota: We split one, and it had wonderful smokiness  that was complimented by the creaminess, (and wasn't greasy).
Patates braves: delectable potatoes with a wonderful aioli and spicy salsa brava.
Albondigas: pork and jamon meatballs in a tomato sherry sauce. These were spiced perfectly, and we both loved the meatballs and the flavorful sauce.
Coca of the day: flatbread with txistorra, broccolini,manchego and caramelized onions. This may have been my favorite dish of the night. It was AMAZING. The mix of flavors and textures, coupled with doneness of the crust made this a perfect dish.

We also shared the hot chocolate and churros for dessert. It was good, but not as amazing as I expected.

I LOVE this style of eating because i get to try so many things. The portions are small, but they're supposed to be so you can sample more items. I can't eat a huge amount at once, so I adored the size of the dishes here.

Even without our BBE coupon, prices are very reasonable. 

This restaurant manages to be both a destination spot, and cozy neighborhood gem.
author: Amanda G.

description:
This is a review of my visit on 12/21 (a Saturday night) at 8:15. I agree with some of the other reviewers that the service and pacing of the meal were terribly wrong. To begin, we were seated 20 minutes late after being reassured no less than 5 times that our table would be ready shortly. Then, throughout the night, we had 4 servers, all of whom were nice, but none of whom had the information from our previous server. 

One standout highlight of the evening came when a new server asked to see the ID of my 24 year old cousin who had asked for wine. After telling her that she left her ID at home, my 23 year old brother said, "she's older than I am." He had already been provided wine (and was not carded, unbeknownst to the new server). The server then didn't check my brother's ID, and passed it off as a joke, which was kind of sexist of them to do--carding her just because she's a girl. She told us the manager could help us, but the real problem with this restaurant was the fact that 4 servers helped us throughout the night. 

It was particularly rude to see our first server eating dinner in the dining room while we were waiting for our many courses that were taking forever to come out of the kitchen as well. We got three dishes and then waited 45 minutes for the next one to show up. Overall, the service was just appalling.

The food was good, we all thought. We ordered around 10 different items on the menu. We liked the pork croquetas, the albóndigas, and the brussel sprouts. It's a shame that the service was so terrible (not that the servers were particularly bad at being servers, but it just seemed like there was really bad management or that they had overbooked or something that night). That left our table feeling ignored and wondering what was going on.

Anyway, I won't be going back because dropping $600 on dinner that leaves a sour taste in everyone's mouth just isn't worth it.
author: Graham H.

description: Overall, the food and ambience were great! I would say 3/5 tapas I tried were tasty. I wish I could've tried the tapas on the prix fixe menu a la carte.
author: Don S.

description:
The trick to getting the best experience you could possibly get here is:

1 - don't have a budget for dinner 
2 - go with good company
3 - sparkling rosé
4 - tip well
5 - the most important - trust the staff to choose the best tasting, freshest variety of foods. I swear to god your palate will be so satisfied, mouthgasm after mouthgasm.

impeccable customer service. Highly recommend. Srslyyyyyyy. Trust.
author: Rosavida C.

description: Great tapas, lovely atmosphere, friendly service. The tapas were very yummy but husband thought we ordered too much chickpeas nevertheless very good. But my favorite of the night is the apple almond tartelette, soooooo good!
author: Ennie L.

description:
Everyone in our party agrees that this is an amazing place. It's pricey but worth every dollar.

We ordered the prix fix tasting menu with seven tapas selected by the chef. $40 per person. Every dish was a surprise for us, with an amazing blend of textures, flavors and aesthetic. Usage of spices and herbs are fantastic.

We had a mind-blowing arroz negro. The tenderness of the squid was complemented the crispiness of rice (at the bottom), which was infused with squid ink, spices, and the just right amount hotness.

Seared Alaskan halibut was flawless. Crispy skin, and the interior was cooked perfectly.

Salad with persimmon, pomegranate, and arugula is very refreshing, and the toasted hazelnuts and pistachio added in a different texture and fragrance.

Chickpea with spinach was nice but a too salty on its own. Would have been nice to go with some naan or rice.

Meatballs in tomato sauce were very flavorful too. The use of different herbs and spices (cumin is particularly interesting) brought the regular meatballs to a totally different level.
author: Ghc H.

description: Order the   charcuterie taste.  Trust me it is worth every dime.  Lots of food for two people.  The pastrami brisket was awesome.
author: Chris S.

description:
This place is pretty good, but it's too expensive. $26 for the Jamon is entirely too much--especially since you're getting about 4oz max. (Our portion was 4 thin slices and like a half a loaf of bread.) The trend continues; with two glasses of wine per person and 5 shared plates, we ended up paying ~$170. 

And then I came home and raided the fridge because I was still hungry.

That all said, it's really nice room, and the staff are attentive--even if they don't know a ton about the pretty decent sherry selection. Standout item on the menu is definitely the xipirons a la plancha--grilled squid--served with a salty anchocress cucumber and caper salad.
author: J B.

description:
Fast food pretending to be TAPAS

Excellent food and service but falls on its face as a tapas bar. The concept of tapas is to enjoy a variety of food with good drink while we enjoyed the drink and 7 round tasting menu as well as desert the owner manager came a few minutes after desert to say they needed the table for waiting customers and basically bum rushed us through desert and our drinks 
This turned the whole experience into a big negative experience the waiter and staff were embarrassed and apologized but the indigestion was unavoidable 
Believe me this is not a repeater at least for me sorry we came here
author: Steve A.

description: A good friend of mine treated me for dinner after I came back from a long vacation, so I cant comment on value for money. But I can say this...the food is pretty good when compared to what I had in Spain. And they have very good set of vegetarian options for my friend. The olive oil was amaaazing. The highlight was the Barca style Xocolata Calenta. Woof woof. Definitely worth going again for the lovely service and excellent food.
author: Balu V.

description:
We managed to get a late reservation based on the recommendation of David Lebovitz. Yes, THE David Lebovitz. We were visiting SFO and had no idea where to eat in the area after his book signing so he recommended Contigo.
We arrived on time but were not seated for about 20 minutes which was really trying because it was already 9 pm and we were starving.
Our server recommended that we do the tasting menu which featured all of the restaurants best dishes. I was skeptical...this late in the evening I was sure we would be served whatever dishes were left over.
However, we weren't.
We were so impressed with our meal at Contigo and we left very satisfied, indeed.
We began with Sardines on toast and all three of us were blown away by the flavours.
Next, were the jamon croquettes. They were perfectly fried and so delicious.
Then the goat cheese salad OH WOW. Strawberries, kumquats, hazelnuts. They all played their parts perfectly in this salad.
Peas on toast...with king mushrooms and manchego..yes please!
We are still debating whether or not the squid with black ink rice and artichokes was the best dish we ate while in San Francisco. We won't forget it soon.
And finally, the meatballs (Albondigas). Every great tapas bar has them, these were the best I've had.

The service was great and, once we were seated, the food came out in a timely manner. It was neither rushed, nor tardy in between dishes. Perfect.
author: Bernice H.

description:
I guess if you are expecting Tapas to be cheap you'll be disappointed pretty much anywhere in San Francisco and this place is no exception. The quality of the food was very good though, as was the service. We ordered enough food for three people (we were actually four, as two adults and two kids) and it came to $141 before tip so it came to $170 in the end including two soft drinks and two Sangrias.

We arrived at opening time but it quickly busied up and the quality of service was consistent throughout. They bring each dish with enough time to eat the prior one so they are not all sitting there getting cold.

We took our kids (six year old twins) and we were the only family there. It is not the sort of place where they bring you coloring and crayons but we were not made to feel unwelcome in any way either so if your kids are well behaved, this place will be fine for them especially as there is a large selection of relatively healthy food, at least some of which should please them.
author: Adrian B.

description: I have two number one's--and this is one of them (mind you, there are no number twos, threes, etc.). This restaurant is filled with some of the nicest individuals I've ever met, and the food is mouth-watering perfection, that I crave on a weekly basis. The menu frequently changes--making the experience that much more exciting each week. The wine is perfection-- and the cava flight is just perfect. This place holds a special place in my heart--it's the go-to restaurant on a Friday night (so long as we plan it right, so that we get a perfect seat). I will eat anything they serve--I even ate barnacles once, apparently they're a Spanish rarity. There is nothing I won't explore here, and it's absolute happiness.
author: Christina L.

description:
This place has very HIGHS and low lowsssssss.Came here with my brother and Dad and Uncle and Cousin , we shared quite a few of things. For those who have not been it's definitely small plates , at times the SMALL is very highlighted. Flavor profiles when on point create an illusion of a very full plate. When it lacks the "ooh dang we paid for that??" sets in.

Highs: Croquetta appetizer
Squid WAS BOMB
Albondigas AWESOME
The herring dish was very tasty
Outstanding wines

Lows:
Ox Tail Hamburgers , NO NO NOOOOO
Sardine and avocado appetizer . We are true blood eastern europeans that love stuff like this and we really did not like it 

If you can , the 40 per person tasting menu makes the most sense . The outdoor seating is very awesome albeit loud the more people are out there. Great attentive staff
author: Lauren V.

description: Over-priced Americanized Spanish food! They're lucky I'm not giving them one star. Having been to Spain several times over the years, I am a Spanish food snob. This place has a mediocre selection of wines that are super expensive, the Jamon Iberico was not all that good for $26! The chocolate con churros is not authentic at all. Its a cup of hot chocolate that you can buy at starbucks. The check for 2 people with drinks and small plates and dessert was almost $200! Ridiculous for the food you get.
author: Nehal M.

description: Oh My God this place is so good!! We had the 7 course tasting menu and there wasn't a single dish we didn't love. Our favorites were the sardine and avocado toast and rice with squid ink. The asparagus with fried egg and jamon was such a simple and satisfying dish. Don't forget to try the churros and salted chocolate too. So decadent! We will definitely come back for paella Tuesday!
author: Sunny C.

description: Enjoyed a late Sunday dinner, in Noe Valley, with a nice ambiance and concrete floors along with light wood benches for their booths.  We decided on the Tapas Tasting dish, along with a great bottle of red wine, which our server recommended.  I enjoyed some of the Tapas selection, not too sure on the others.  But the desert was my fav, a spicy, rich, thick, dark hot chocolate, by local chocolatier, Tcho, along with house made churros for dipping, yummy!
author: Winny S.

description:
We had the tasting menu, worth every penny at a mere $49. My favorite was the squid over black rice and artichokes. So much attention to detail with each dish. Each plate had its own special flavor accents, the order and timing of everything was spot on. We added the papas bravas , which I highly recommend, don't miss them if you're a fan of this traditional dish. Dessert was the almond cake and the hot chocolate with churros. Yum yum yum yum. 

Equally lovely was the service. Prompt and pleasant. I'm pregnant, so of course I have food restrictions. The servers and kitchen were highly accommodating and happily determined which cheeses were pasteurized and which were not (pasteurized blue cheese?! There is a god!!) They swapped my lamb (which I preferred to forgo because of it can't be medium rare why bother) with a small plate of something equally delightful. 

Thank you Contigo for a magical meal and experience I will not soon forget. Truly a gem of a restaurant!!!!
author: Michelle F.

description: Food was yummy, particularly the duck. Also try the tapas with chorizo and the egg on top!
author: Cricri B.

description:
Contigo is one of those restaurants where you stalk Opentable hoping for a prime opening. I finally got a table at 9pm on Friday, but not sure if I'd put in the effort again.

The food was definitely tasty, but nothing amazing beyond belief. The sausage and monchego cheese pizza was the best dish we ordered, perfect crust and flavorful. I felt the Brussels Sprout Leaves and the Pork/Lamb meatballs were just alright. The Churros were very tasty, especially with the melted chocolate. Considering this restaurant is Tapas style, I felt the dishes were very reasonably sized. 

I felt the ambiance was lacking anything really special. I get that simplicity is nice, but it definitely underwhelmed me.

I spent quite some time deciding if Contigo deserves 3 or 4 stars, but in the end I felt 3 was more appropriate. I enjoyed my experience, but doubt I'll put in the effort to come back again
author: Ashwin S.

description:
MODERN (Heath Ceramics), RUSTIC, SIMPLE YET TASTEFUL DECOR. 

Ambiance: We loved the open kitchen counter tables with comfortable chairs with a back. (I dont miss standing up to eat Tapas in Spain). Since we did not make reservations on Friday at 6:45pm, we were able to be seated at the counter immediately. 

After coming back from a vacation in Spain and eating Catalan dishes, we wanted to eat something "SPAIN INSPIRED". 


DISHES WE ORDERED:

Smashed Peas with Pan Tostado ($13). Two slices of bread with this smashed peas topped with Jamon Serrano.  I thought they would've used FAVA beans since they were in season but it was not used.   The side of baby fava greens were refreshing.

Jamon Iberico de Bellota ($17). For $17, 5 to 6 thinly slices of Jamon with bread was served on top of a wooden slab.


Tapas we ordered:

Pulpo and Pimento Pincho.  $2.50. We ordered two.
Sardine and Avocado toast.  $2.50.


I WAS LONGING FOR:

Tinto de Verano drink.  Please consider serving that for the summer.
Sangria - I dont remember seeing this on the menu
Salmorejo - Please consider serving this dish for the months of summer. It's simply divine. 

Minus One Star - Need more selection of tapas. Bigger breads served with your tapas (top it with Sausages, Tuna, etc)


Our 2 Racions and 3 tapas were $55/total. Expect a pricey bill.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Really solid food. Enjoyed the bread with tomato and anchovies as well as the fig and arugula salad. They don't have many non-pork options so if that's a consideration for you I wouldn't go.
author: Yasi N.

description: This review is strictly for the churros. While priced a little too high they were delicious and I still have the TECHO chocolate sauce. They were very close to what I had in Spain, I'd like to try them again and will request that they are not rolled in sugar. I'll be back on Vegetarian Paella night!
author: Josie C.

description: Amazing dinner!!! Really enjoyed the fig salad and salmon the most. The lamb was also delish! For desert the salted vanilla ice cream was heavenly
author: Bobbi R.

description:
I was very happy to come here for their grand opening on Tuesday. The pictures previously posted do a better job of depicting the modern decor, so I won't bother to discuss that. The open kitchen lets you have a view of the food preparation and many of the fresh ingredients, which is very cool. It was a busy night, by the time I left there was a line of people waiting for an open table.

The tapas (hot/cold) are $8 each or 3 for $21. Charcuterie is priced at $9 each or 3 for $24 (the "Jamon Iberico de Bellota" has a $22 supplement cost - Wow! $31 (9+22) for just a few slices of aged ham, I thought). "Bellota" means acorn, so that means ham from acorn fed pigs. Nobody at the table was brave enough to order that. Later I was told that the ham (aka. "pata negra") sells for $90 a pound at Bi-Rite market.

As expected the wait staff was a bit nervous on their first day. The waitresses try to be very friendly and pleasant, but there were a few long waits. At first waiting for someone to take my order, and later she had to check if the kitchen had brewed any cranberry iced tea which was listed on the drinks menu. Much later another waitress was thoughtful enough to bring some bread and olive oil - I used it with the anchovies dish.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c5Pog3vEqmBFOBdL7R3vAg?select=OS1eQ0w8JCBEFK0O3msdLQ

The first tapas dish I tried was the fillets of anchovies. These are canned anchovies, which are salty, so not everyone will like this dish. The fillets are swimming in olive oil, so some of the saltiness is diluted. This simple presentation was a bit disappointing. Would u pay $8 for someone to open a tin can and place a small portion of the contents on a plate, then add olive oil? It would have been a much more interesting dish if they had paired them with red peppers or artichoke hearts, or with olives & cheese over toast, or with chopped tomatoes & egg over toast, like some preparations at bars in spain. Fresh anchovies (Boquerones) would have been a real treat. Sadly, those images were in my head and not on the plate.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c5Pog3vEqmBFOBdL7R3vAg?select=az1xY3irrp9Ogr8F27thJQ

Setas a la plancha, was a very simple dish. Grilled wild mushrooms topped by parsley. Tasty, no complaints.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c5Pog3vEqmBFOBdL7R3vAg?select=lJfp-XTJRt27orjllpkg9A

Sopa de ajo tierno, chicken soup with green garlic, farm egg. "ajo tierno" = young/tender garlic aka. green garlic. I read the dish name in Spanish, so I knew there was no chicken. Customers who read the English part perhaps got confused, "chicken broth" would've been a better description. The soup is served in a shallow bowl, my spoon hit the bottom every time. It would have been easier to eat from a cup. There's a tasty poached egg in the middle and lots of chopped chorizo (item not listed on menu), but not much green garlic (I did see a few slivers of what looked like green onions, which is what green garlic looks like). So the description didn't match and I dislike shallow bowls. But the soup itself was delicious!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/c5Pog3vEqmBFOBdL7R3vAg?select=clW6k6VifY-L-sz0EcBquQ

I was too busy chatting about the bad economy, food trends and SF restaurants, that I just forgot to take any more pics.

Trucha a la Navarra - steelhead trout (tastes like salmon) is served with tender asparagus and marinated onions (resembled the pink ginger you get at sushi places). The fish was perfectly cooked, tender & moist, and it had a thin layer "skin" of crispy Jamon Serrano on one side. I've had a similar dish in other places (salmon with bacon) using applewood smoked bacon instead (the flavor contrast is better). I liked the dish, but it didn't wow me.

The pork belly with ears, feet, & butter beans was a favorite of another person, but I didn't get to taste it.

I was full already, so I didn't order any dessert. But I got to taste someone's blood orange tart with olive oil ice cream, it was very good. Topped with whole blood orange slices. Yummy!

Overall, I saw that the kitchen kept their cool during the rush of orders, and the wait staff did okay for a first day. I expect that the place will be a favorite of many, as they figure out what works or not.
author: Luis C.

description:
Contigo is an excellent little Spanish restaurant nestled into the Noe Valley neighborhood.  I have dined here on several occasions, my favorite being a warm sunny day sitting in their outdoor area nestled amongst their heirloom tomato vines.

The Spanish style tapas plates are great for sharing.  The small plates are fairly priced, and just large enough to give a few great bites to each in a group of 3-4.  They have delicious croquettes- $3-$5 a piece I believe (approx), and they are wonderful.  Jamon is always a hit for me as well.  On my most recent visit we had a delicious white sea bass large plate- excellent!  We also enjoyed their meatballs very much, and a baked, bubbling fava bean dish which vaguely reminded me of cassoulet.  Wine was reasonably priced (heavy on Spanish selections of course), and I also enjoyed their house-made blood orange soda!

Contigo is a relaxing escape- and always a mini-odyssey of food- regardless of the size of my dining group (2 or more), I always seem to have about 5-7 different items (of various sizes) come to table, which is a great way to enjoy a well-balanced meal.  Contigo is highly recommended- reserve in advance or you may get the counter...
author: Andy S.

description:
I wanted to like this place, but I doubt I'll be back. Three of us dined there on a weeknight and ordered about 8 or 9 small plates to share; we wanted to try everything. Sadly, nothing stood out. One dish was bland, another over-salted, another drowning in sauce. None of us had anything scathing to say about the food, but nothing particularly complimentary, either. Seeing as our bill was around $200 (with tip), I was disappointed.
The service was friendly (if a bit stiff) and the patio is lovely. 
The menu item that left the biggest impression on us was a peach-basil champagne cocktail: incredibly delicious.
author: Lynn M.

description: Absolutely terrible customer service. There was a mix-up with OpenTable and the reservation, which was annoying but would have been fine if there was any semblance of trying to make amends. Instead, we were told "You are at the very top of our list! You will get the first table that opens up." We then sat at the bar for an hour and proceeded to watch them seat two of the same size parties ahead of us. I get that 'reservations come first' but do NOT tell us that we are at "the top of the list" and will get "the first table" and then proceed to give the two next tables away ahead of us while we watch and wait. Will definitely not be back, what a waste of our time.
author: Danielle B.

description:
One of the best meals we've had in quite awhile - heartily recommended!

We tried two of the toast tapas - anchovies with a house-made fresh cheese and sardines with avocado and pickled onions. Both were absolutely delicious and well balanced.

For larger plates, we tried a mushroom flatbread (pizza), a squid, chorizo, and black rice dish, sauteed greens, and a braised adobo chicken dish. We'd originally ordered a stewed oxtails as well but the waiter graciously volunteered to cancel it for us when he realized halfway through the meal just how over-stuffed we were going to be. That was much appreciated. The greens were the only dish that was just OK and we wished we'd gotten one of the lighter salads instead, but the mushroom pizza and the squid dish were utterly fantastic. 

We were extremely happy with this meal and will definitely return.

Note that we consider 2 stars to be an average, so 5 stars is reserved for truly exceptional experiences!
author: Amy D.

description:
Came here for a birthday dinner. 

First thing which shined at this restaurant is their service. The lady who attended our table was AMAZING. She gave great recommendations, served our table with great respect. Thank you! 

Food was delicious too. Loved sitting outside in their terrace. The hanging lights create a great atmosphere.
author: M. N.

description: My favorite Spanish restaurant in San Francisco! Great place for groups with their tasting menu which changes often. I got married in Barcelona and Contigo's food and beverages reminds me of Catalan deliciousness. Make a reservation!
author: J A.

description:
I am torn between 2 and 3 stars. There were a few good dishes but truthfully the food wasn't spectacular and was overpriced. 

When we first entered, the hostess desk was unmanned so I figured someone will come over to greet or seat us especially with the restaurant being a quarter full. The hostess/waitress (assumed she was a hostess since she didn't wear the same uniform as everyone else) made eye contact, looked confused as to why were in there, then came over but neither greeted or welcomed us. Eye contact and silence. I dig a showdown when I first enter restaurants. Who wouldn't.  

When we were seated, the table next to us gave us a hard stare. Perhaps I stunk. Perhaps I'm under-dressed. But the hostess had on clogs with patterned socks and jeans so clearly the dress code isn't white tux and black tie kind of fancy. 

I won't lie, our table had some picky eaters. One didn't eat lamb, one didn't like cheese, one was a pescatarian. So we ordered the number of individual tapas according to individual preferences, i.e. we're not going to order a meat item for everyone if only half the party will eat it. We were reminded several times that the tapas was only enough for one, which by the way was already explained on the menu. Once we were done ordering, we were told it wasn't enough. I couldn't pinpoint why the delivery of her responses irked me until I heard her interactions with other tables. As she sat other tables, she first introduced the concept of the menu, explained the number of people each dish is meant for, and the number of dishes she recommended per person. NONE of that was said to our table. We were seated, menus were silently placed on the table, and she silently walked away. Don't get me wrong. It's not that we didn't understand the concept of tapas or raciones, but if she had given that introduction, it wouldn't have felt as judgmental every time her and another waitress kept emphasizing that the tapas are meant only for one.

After we were told we didn't have enough food, we ordered two more dishes like obedient diners. Turns out we didn't even need them. We had to pack the last dish, which they forgot and never packed for us. By that time I could care less. 

If you want your wallet to be gouged, come to Contigo. This is the first tapas place I've been to that only sells sangria by the glass. They do not offer pitchers. Rather than offering churros as a dish and hot chocolate as an additional complement to the dish, it's the other way around. Hot chocolate is $5 and you ADD churros for $4. The churros do not automatically come with the chocolate.The hot chocolate was like the consistency of pudding and is meant for dipping; not the watery hot chocolate you normally drink. I'm asking the same question you are: what would anyone do with just a cup of dipping chocolate??? Of course I'll have to add on $4 churros just so I can use my $5 cup of chocolate. 

The only reason I decided on three stars is because there were two waitresses that were friendly. They also promote sustainability and humane animal farming, and sources their produce from local farmers. Kudos to that and only that.
author: Ivy T.

description:
The food at this restaurant is fantastic. Wow!!  Our server Devon was so warm and offered many helpful suggestions both on the wine list and the dinner menu.  

We had a selection of roughly 7 items and all I would order again.  I chose a white and a red off the list and both were great.  I plan on returning again soon.

Next time I would opt to request seating on the romantic, cute back patio.  The overall space was quite charming.
author: Leslie A.

description:
We sat in the back patio which had heat lamps. the general atmosphere was vivacious and fun. everything we had was delish...
the sangria de cava was peachy and strong. Also the first white on the menu (sounded like xiocolat) was sweet and effervescent.
Started off with Oxtail mini hamburguesas $5 each 
jamon iberico $25
pimientos were tasty though not spicy
local king salmon baked on a fig leaf was perfectly baked, still pink in the center and juicy all through; the corn was nice n sweet $23
Albondigas - Pork & jamon meatballs in tomato sherry sauce $11

Surprisingly the flam/flan dessert was the only thing I didn't love. I usually love flan bc of its smooth and light flavor but it was strong and sweet bc it was Sightglass coffee flan. Not topped w coffeee but made with coffee.  Luckily i was able to sleep :) hubs liked it bc it was super sweet. Maybe i'm just a purist like that with my coffee and my flan! overall loved the experience and it's a place i would bring visitors bc of the atmosphere and location in Noe. It brought me back to the one time i was in barcelona -- good food, wine and memorable atmosphere! The bill was relatively high but it's not compared to a trip to spain...at least that's how i justify it.
author: Emm C.

description:
I came here last weekend to celebrate my birthday with a group of my friends. We had a party of 19 so we were able to reserve the back patio. 

The food was good as usual, but my overall opinion about the restaurant has changed.

1. Our reservation was at 8:30, but the patio had not been setup. It took about 20 minutes for the restaurant to get situated before we could be seated. For such a small place, it's not ideal to have 19 people just hanging around waiting

2. It took another 30-40 minutes for them to bring out the first dish on the chef's menu. They didn't even give us bread while we waited. A few of my guests had to ask for bread, and even then it didn't arrive til after the 1st course.

3. Our waiter was definitely friendly and as helpful as possible so this is definitely not a burn on him, but for a group of 19, how can you only have one waiter serving us? He wasn't even dedicated to our party which made our wait for any requests even longer. It was mind boggling
author: Kristen C.

description:
I went to Contigo during my visit to SF recently and my cousin's bf made reservation for her bday party. The ambiance was trendy and electric, unfortunate it fell short
on the food department.

All 6 of us picked the $40 course tasting menu and I wasn't a bit impressed. I wish I can remember every course we had, but they were unforgettable except for their roasted monterey sardine w/avocado toast that no one seem to like, but I ended up loving it.

I did order oxtail sliders which was the only thing that's exceptional and most likely will come back for. First I thought it was sloppy joes since I'm not a fan of oxtail, but this slider was full of flavor, buttery, and smokey I wish this I had more than half a slider.

Total bill was $400, with 2 orders of wine?!
author: Robin S.

description: Having now eaten here several times, I still consider it a favorite, but honestly, some of the dishes are a bit lacking - the squid was not great and the meatballs were bland. Desserts not very tempting. All that said, still a great place to eat.
author: Antonia T.

description:
Two of my dearest at-home chef friends have been talking up Contigo as one of their favorite spots in town, and I've been looking for a dine-out gem in a neighborhood known more for fun than for food.  We were lucky to score a table in the heated and enclosed patio out back, an oasis ringed with a fragrant herb garden, and to score a playful and relaxed server willing to entertain both serious menu questions and general tomfoolery. 

We opened with one of my favorite Spanish dishes, ajo blanco, a smooth white gazpacho made from Marcona almonds and garnished with pickled cherries and sherry vinegar, a superlative treat.  The little gem salad was gorgeously arrayed with roasted tri-color beets, mint, roasted garlic clips and a tangy sherry mustard vinaigrette, and the charred asparagus with smoked almonds and poached egg was a hearty treat.  

We rolled the dice with two especially unique, bread-based dishes that ended up being the stars of the night.  First, thin slices of toast topped with a creamy smashed pea layer, slices of king trumpet mushrooms and a few crumbles of manchego - my girlfriend's favorite dish.  Next was a beautiful and immensely satisfying coca (Spanish flatbread) covered with an enchanting combination of nettles, caramelized onions, and homemade Catalan cheese.  

The night's encore was provided with gusto by homemade churros dipped in a mug of very thick and rich hot chocolate from the amazing local chocolatier, Tcho.
author: Derek W.

description: Great food and environment. I really  enjoyed this place, great wine and good service, I will be back soon.
author: Douglas C.

description:
I'm a sucker when it comes to churros con chocolat! I would really like to dig into a long story as to why but I won't bore you Yelpers with that.

Came in here on a Friday early dinner expecting to sit at the bar and just order the infamous churros con chocolat. I was expecting the hostess to give us a dirty look because we weren't going to order much ... but she happily sat us at the bar and smiled "The churros con chocolat will be on the way" - I then soooooo had to order a glass of a full bodied wine with our order.
author: Hannah T.

description:
The three stars are for  the food being delicious and the atmosphere was fun without being to loud.

my complaints where that the portions were a bit small, even for tapas and if you are going make sure to get there early, because they were out of many of the items we wanted.

but the major complaint was an incredibly rude server. He wasn't even our server. Our server was very friendly. When we ordered a bottle of wine, some other server brought it to the table,  a fairly tall guy. When he presented the bottle, he mentioned the year...it was different than what we ordered, so my GF asked if he could check our order. He came back with a menu, stood next to my gf, took out a pen and circled the wine he brought and dropped it on the table in front of her saying" see, it is the right year". feeling very proud of himself, he then walked away before we could continue the conversation. 

Long story short, it was the wrong bottle and the server acted like a child.
author: Daniel D.

description:
Came on a stormy rainy night but Contigo provided warm shelter. And what great shelter it was. Our party of 4 had a cozy corner booth where we felt like the center of the restaurant.

Let's dive into the food:
- Sardine & Avocado ($2.50 per piece). Large pieces really sitting on bread. Very tasty with pickled onions to give tang and break the salt. 
- Anchovy ($2 per piece). Also very tasty. Who knew this little 
- Coca ($15), flatbread pizza basically. but it was really good. Simple with arugula, some mild cheese, and other veggies.
- Patates Braves ($8). potatoes were nice and crispy but the sauce was way spicy. 
- Calamaras a la Plancha ($13). with black rice and chorizo, i really enjoyed the textures and flavors of this dish. 
- Brussel Sprouts ($7). A bit over charred. 
- Chicken Tagine. Very tender chicken paired with raisins or grapes for that Mediterranean feel.
-Churros w/ Mexican Hot Chocolate ($9). Honestly the chocolate dipping cup was too much. And the churros were kinda tiny.

Great atmosphere for casual dinner with friends, allowing you to linger and savor multiple dishes.
author: Cindy W.

description: First off, yummy wine selection, and friendly staff. We weren't very hungry so we didn't order the recommended 5 large plates and 2 tasters. We barely made it through 2 plates and 1 taster! Dates, asparagus, and secreto (the pork). Bacon wrapped dates stuffed with blue cheese and marcona almond..... good, but familiar (nothing unique). Asparagus was tender, with a perfectly cooked over easy egg and thin, tasty ham. That may have been my favorite. The pork loin was perfectly cooked with the pink insides and the broccoli rabe was very flavorful. Snaps for that. But like I said, for some reason we were full by this point! We applaud the server's recommendations though and paired with great wine, overall lovely experience.
author: Zara S.

description:
Is really sad actually writte about this review. 
I'm from Spain and toke my friends last night to this place with a lot of expectation about everything. 
But from the very beginning was a mistake. 
The time we support wait was wrong what the girl told us, after wait more time finally we had seat in the bar. The first person who attend us was really great, we spoke in Spanish and I decided order for all in the table. 
The food was really really slow and nothing really good, but our waiters leave early and they change to "another" who never came with the other plates. 
We aske if they can close the windows because was really cold they told us no because the ventilation in the kitchen is poor and need the windows open !!!!! 
Never arrive the other food we finally decided leave this place..
Again ... Is really really sad .... Hope they read this and put a little more effort for next times
author: Guillermo G.

description: Finally got around to this place.  We tried the 7 dish tapas tasting menu.  Not a single dish was not delicious!  Our favorite was the squid over rice.  I am not a squid fan to say the least but I loved the dish.
author: Peter O.

description:
My husband and I celebrated our 8th wedding anniversary with a spontaneous trip to SF and no dinner reservations. When he called Contigo, the hostess was very nice and offered to keep an eye on 2 seats at the wine bar for us, on the wait list.

Our server was Andrew, who was very welcoming, made great conversation and took time to talk to us and answer all our questions about the wine selection & the menu.

We went for the tapas tasting menu and enjoyed it very, very, very much! The sardine and avocado toast, ox tail hamburguesa and the fig leaf wrapped fish with cauliflower and smoked eggplant were the highlight of the evening. 

The wine was perfect with the meal and we enjoyed an amazing dessert wine from Malaga, to wrap it all up.

On our way out, we were pleasantly surprised to have Uze (hope I spelled it right) who was not even our server, follow us to our cab, to thank us for spending our evening there. That was such a sweet added bonus to the whole evening!

Thank you to Andrew, Use and the wonderful staff for the wonderful food & wine and for an overall wonderful experience! Can't wait to come back!
author: anda n.

description:
A very vibrant neighborhood hangout.  Hostess and waitstaff were upbeat, knowledgeable of the menu, and helpful.  Wine list OK, beer list very limited.  As for the food, I'd say it was a cut above average but not exceptional.  There were several good anchovy tapas that I enjoyed and a number of essentially vegetarian selections that worked well.

Seating was close but comfortable, and there is a small, heated patio out back.  Given the exceptionally loud interior noise, that may be a better place to sit..
author: Phil S.

description:
I've been on a search for good Spanish food for a while now ever since I came back from a near month long stint, eating across the northern regions there. After hearing that they were one of two places carrying the illustrious Calcot onion, we had to give it a try. We were about 30 min earlier but they seated us promptly anyways. Bonus.

The rather large spread went as follows:

-Montadito - Cantabrian anchovies, mato cheese, cracked pepper
-Galician pulpo and potato
-Wood overn roasted Monterey sardine with avocado toast
-Marinated olives
-Jamon Iberico
-Roasted asparagus with mojama, pimenton almonds and fried egg
-Calcots
- Catalan style chard
-Calamars a la planxa
-Milk braised pork shoulder
-Rabbit and trumpet mushroom canelon
-Callos  - tripe iwth chorizo and chickpeas

Everything was solid. I like that they tried to represent man regions. They also have a very good wine selection as we had a good Txakoli from Getaria, a muscat form Alicante and a Priorat to boot. I wish this was closer to my home but it's good to see I can at least have one more place out of but a handful that I know of for Spanish style eats. 4.25 stars
author: Kim N.

description:
Contigo is a fairly close walk for me but I don't allow myself to go too often. Otherwise, I'd destroy my already-high monthly restaurant budget. Whenever someone, tourist or local, is willing to come to Noe though, Contigo is my first recommendation. 

The atmosphere is laid back, without pretense. Close tables and an open kitchen, high-quality food, and a variety of wines (glass/carafe/bottle) combine into an excellent experience in a relaxed atmosphere. Looking over the menu is fun for me, just to see new dishes.

Typically I'm a sucker for sharing required of any tapas-based restaurant. And yet my first meal there was a vegetarian prix fixe. In fact, it was the best veggie meal I've ever eaten and one of my favorite meals ever as well. Whatever you choose, bring an appetite. 

Pro Move: Try to arrive ahead of your reservation time in order to be seated on time. Walking in for a table still is possible but no matter the case, people generally wait a bit in the long hallway leading to the hosting stand.
author: Mike H.

description:
Contigo is a hidden gem in a city where it is hard to hide anything. 
We have been here several times now and have never been disappointed. 

On our last two visits, we have had the chef's choice dinner. Excellent pairings of food from the menu, all fantastic dishes, served one after another at a steal of a price for what you get. 

The service has always been exceptional and I look forward to my next dining experience there, soon.
author: Christine H.

description: An excellent, reasonably priced spot in SF.  Probably the best Sangria I've ever had.  The wine list is all Spanish, so ask the waiter for recommendations based on what you normally drink because the names are different.  The food was excellent all the way through--I shared a few small plates with a vegetarian friend, and even as a meat eater the potatoes, spinach and chickpea stew, and tomato bread were all stellar.  Dessert pizza with caramel gelato is a must-have.  Highly recommend.
author: Martin P.

description: Very good service! My boyfriend and I came here for our anniversary and we loved the hot chocolate and churros! We made reservations and they seated is very quickly.
author: Kathy Q.

description: Perfect place for tapas! Had the tasting menu and each dish was a surprise and each one was delicious.  Will definitely return.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place! Every thing we had was tasty and flavorful. The ambiance was quite friendly too. 
Best dishes were squid, meatballs, and the flat bread. Will certainly go back!
author: Shirin E.

description:
This is the tapas restaurant that I had been waiting to find in San Francisco. The location, decor and food were all top notch. You can choose from a large selection of smaller plates to share or have to yourself. They also have the option of a 7-course tasting menu for $40 per person. I believe that everyone at the table must participate if you plan to go this route, but I think it is the way to go.

Each course of the tasting menu is not large but by the end it was the right amount of food for a full dinner. The waiter or waitress will have no problem letting you know which items are on the tasting menu for the night, which takes the guess work out of it. Since the tasting menu is ever-changing you can have a different experience each time you come.

The only negative thing I have to say is that the food came out very quickly. At one time we had three different courses on the table because they brought out 2 back to back before we had finished the previous course. It really wasn't an issue except that it made us feel a little rushed and I like to take my time with dinner.

Overall a great place! I would highly recommend. You are also just a few blocks from the heart of Noe Valley and there are a few bars and lounges close by if you want to go grab a drink or dessert somewhere afterwards.
author: Frank J.

description:
I love this place!

The tapas are very tasty here, and the ambiance really brought me back to Barcelona. They have a Catalonian focus, which is great, and it feels modern instead of that antiquated feel that some tapas places have. Spain has moved into the new millenium, and so can you dear tapas restaurant owners. Witness Contigo.

We liked everything we ordered, from the classic papas bravas (brava sauce only please, hold the mayo), to the gambas, figs and goat cheese, calamari, and everything else. I'm definitely looking forward to coming back.
author: Mike G.

description:
On the south end of Castro Street in charming Noe Valley is a really great Tapas restaurant with an always changing menu. Contigo has so much style and pizazz with it's bright green walls with tons of natural wood accents, hanging lamps hung in all sorts of fashion and a back patio fit for warm entertaining complete with neat stacks of fire wood to add to the casual mood.

Having been to Spain before, you'll taste the true authenticity of Spanish Tapas in every single offering. I highly recommend the tasting menu where the chef picks the 7 of his favorite tapas for the day. There were so many selections to choose from we just made it easy on ourselves and had the chef pick! The price works out if you were to order a la carte and rest assured you won't leave hungry.

Also make sure to save room for dessert. You must try the chocolate churros complete with TCHO hot chocolate for dipping and sipping and perfect for sharing. With an always changing menu, Contigo will have you coming back for more. Let the tapas eating begin!
author: Andrew S.

description:
Great tasting small dishes.  Order a variety and eat your way through the restaurant...that's what I like to do!  
Our wait staff were simply awesome!  They were joking with us, laughing with us and taking great care of us.  
The churros were amazing!
If you order some clams, ask for a little extra bread to soak up the sauce...it's fabulous!
author: Matt V.

description: "I just wanted to cry throughout dinner over how perfect each dish in the tasting menu was."  Contigo gives me a reason to trek over to the land of strollers and NIMBY's.
author: Paul M.

description:
Second time at Contigo and again a bit disappointing. It has the potential to be great, but it isn't. The staff seems pretentious. Not super nice but stuck up. I took my visiting family here and my brother-in-law actually lived in Barcelona for a while. He missed certain essential stuff on the menu and wasn't at all impressed by the knowledge of the staff about the food.

We started dinner at 9pm and at 10:30pm it was clear to us that they wanted us OUT. They opened the door to the outside area which made inside very uncomfortable (cold!). All the staff started eating around us and basically looking at us as to say "please leave". We even got the check on our table, without asking for it. Kinda rude if you ask me. 

The food and wine was very nice, but the attitude of the staff kinda ruined the experience for us. Maybe get some fresh blood in. This crew seems bored with it...
author: Viola M.

description: Intriguing menu of tapas and shareables. No particular dish blew me away, but everything was good. Highly recommended for any foodies in the area.
author: Jason M.

description: Fabulous food, great wine list, excellent service and great desserts. Iberia jam on was great.
author: Fred B.

description:
Came here on a weeknight and the hostess was very accommodating when we had to change the time of our reservation. Even though they were booked solid. There is a warmth and friendliness to all the staff that is sadly wanting at many places in the city. 

But on to the food. We had Little Gem salad, chicken skewers, halibut and lamb chop, all of which are delicious. But the prices for the halibut and lamb chop are beyond ridiculous. $19 for one lamb chop!! $32 for two. And the halibut at $26 for about 3 oz worth is also kind of a rip off. 

SO the food is good, and so is the wine, but be prepared to spend a lot. I think a neighborhood restaurant shouldn't charge such prices. 

I'd go back but avoid the so called entrees.
author: Jay K.

description:
Very good food. Lovely space. We ordered WAY too much for tow people but here's a brief rundown:

Sauteed catalan green beans - delicious, I mean wonderful!
Patatas braves - yummy and just what you expect from Spanish & Catalan cuisine
Seared gulf prawns - amazing, they sold out but our lovely server found a half order for us (which was 2 prawns but small plates, you know)
Serrano hams with melon I think - yummy pretty standard stuff really
Albondigas - HUGE, too much for two people and two people who gorged on like 10 plates before that.  

All in all, great place and I would have given it 5 starts but it's hard when you basically are waiting in line to be seated because they don't take reservations. We waited an hour + and that was a bit rough on a week night.  Definitely worth going to and going again.
author: Lena M.

description:
This is the reason why I hate tapas style dining. Expensive food with small portions. People like to say that it's the quality not quantity but when you eat mediocre food with that high of a price per dish then it's easy to feel cheated. I had something called secreto which was pork, gravy and potatoes. $27 dollars for the dish and it felt like an appetizer. The meat was over cooked and I wasn't blown away by the taste. My girlfriend got something that looked like a pita bread/ pizza. It was the size of a small plate for something around 15 dollars. Honestly i would rather have had domino's or little caesars for that matter. 

As far as service goes it was horrible. The hostess was nice but after that we didn't get much attention from the waiter. To make things worse, the waiter for the next table kept bumping me and putting his ass on my face. Not apologize or anything. Maybe it was because they ordered more plates than me. Never again to this place. Overrated!!
author: Noe R.

description:
All the food and wine were tasty. The Albondigas, patatas bravas, sardines, and churros were standout over other tapas places in recent memory. We also had the olives & almonds, squid, and spinach and chickpeas. Everything was good. I had a very nice glass of the Syrah blend. Total for 2 people came to $100, kind of on the high end even for Noe Valley. 

Not 4 stars because especially for the price, the service was kind of disorganized. They brought our tapas in random order, with long irregular gaps in between, then forgot one, let us order dessert, then brought the last small plate. Not ideal. I would give it another chance, although I see there are other Yelpers who also felt the service was the weak link in an otherwise good experience.
author: Sam Z.

description: I went for valentines dinner meal excited about trying something on check bay area check please. I tried contacting about their valentine menu but never recieved contact about it. It was about $85?? a person for a set meal either a choice of a type  of paella seafood or the brisket meat of some kind with the set apps and salad but u get to pick ur dessert. My bfs meal was delicious melting rip apart meat with mash and some other side veggies but i picked the paella but is the rice supposed to be crunchy? It seemed undercooked i forced it down not really knowing cuz ive never had it but, it was far from delicious. We had mini plates of appetizers of random small items like date wrapped in bacon with a creamy cheese inside and some type salmon and other items i cannot remember. I just didnt want to waste food that was costing my bf so much so i forced it down. The only highlight was the crab salad that was filled of lemon flavored crab. The other thing was the churro and chocolate but it was just heavy for me and to tell u the truth i would have hoped for something more worthwhile than something i can buy anywhere for less than $2. I wanted to try the sorbet but it just didnt seem at all that awesome for what we got. Buying some cheap drinks in order to not go over $200 but we ended up paying with tip a total of almost $230. Even my cider was very wierd tasting for price i could have went to bevmo. It was so disappointing cuz i was looking forward to their regular food options so i do wish we had went somewhere else for valentines but he really wanted to surprise me and this is what we got. I dont wont be back again based on also the very squished tight tables and having no space to breathe. Maybe the food is better when when they DONT have a prefixed menu but,  based on how much we spent and for what we got, I would rather go somehwere else. I have a bad taste in my mouth. He still got Love for me for trying, poor guy.
author: Njellz A.

description:
Came here on a Friday night with a friend, and was delighted by the experience! We ordered quite a bit of food, and everything was delicious! Not one bad thing about the food! Had a great selection of wine, just wish they had cocktails as well. Service was good as well!

The one con of contigo is that their tables sand seats are really squished together.

Overall an awesome place for a relaxing night out. Can't wait to be back!
author: Ashbir C.

description: Depending on when you go, the menu can be better or worse. Overall a solid (but not cheap) experience.
author: Tatyana H.

description: Nice place to eat.  If you have kids their cheese on flatbread is a nice version of cheese pizza.  Big hit with my son.
author: Ronald L.

description: It's pricey, but is a tapas Disneyland. Came here alone after a bad online date, pre-drunk, and hungry as fuck. Got an immediate seat at the bar. Brilliant! Am a jaded native who waits for the hot new restaurant hype to die down. Took me 5 years to get here. Every item I ordered off the appetizers/small plates menu reminded me of why humans evolved tongues and how great that one trip to Barcelona was. Don't remember what I ordered, thanks to whatever excellent, chilled, local white wine I ordered. There were some deep fried breaded balls filled with cheese and something from the ocean, I think. Delectable! Decadent! Raw (or was it smoked?) herring on rustic little toasted things and a tomatoish spread. To die for. Ordered another round of that shizz. A few yummy vegan things, because I like to feel superior when making food choices. And something with that famous Catalan Ham. Oink! Servers were overworked and spread thin because they are dispensing drugs to serious, high-maintenance addicts. Nevertheless, they were affectionate, efficient, and generally awesome. Javier is simply adorable and knows the menu well. He can size up a single, post -manopausal gay man in seconds and suggest just the right comfort tapas with perfect wine pairings. Love the owners' locavore, farm-to-table-organic policy. Contigo: "Cheaper than psychotherapy and more sustainable".
author: Lotion M.

description:
Best restaurant in Noe Valley.

All the food was delicious, and they also have great homemade sodas. Favorites: chickpeas and spinach, toast with ham.

The xurros con xocolate come with a drinkable melted chocolate, yum!

Service was prompt and the decor is warm wood tones, very inviting. They have an outdoor patio.

The check came with a postcard and little piggie paper clips!
author: Anton S.

description:
I really didn't like this place. I felt ripped off.  We spend lots of money on food and restaurants. It's not that the total meal was expensive vis a vis other places in San Francisco, but I left feeling hungry and unsatisfied.  

The meal started off great: with tomato toasts - kind of a liquidy tomato spread with absolutely delicious olive oil on great rustic bread.  It was down hill from there.  

We had anchovy and sardine tapas - the flavors were flat.  Then we had the salad with pomegranate, pear and persimmon (I think it was persimmon.) The fruit was not perfectly ripe, the greens were a little watery (not well dried?) and the whole salad was under-dressed and not cohesive.  The almonds tasted a little stale.

Then there was a really long gap between the starters and the rest of the items.  Really long.

We then had the fried egg plant with mint which was tasty at the time but repeated a bit on me after.  We had the black cod, which was pretty bland and really small.  It came with a pumpkin or squash puree and broccolini, both of which has gotten cold waiting for the fish.  Then we had the albondigas, which were really quite good, but by the time they arrived, there were so many disappointments with the meal that i simply wanted to get out of there.  

If you want similar food, try Duende in Oakland instead.
author: Robert F.

description:
Went to this place on the recommendation of a couple of friends who joined my girlfriend and I for dinner there recently.

First off, we really enjoyed everything that we ordered along with three really nice bottles of a Spanish blended red (I don't remember the name. but it was a great medium bodied wine). Additionally, the atmosphere was good and the service was solid.

Started with the sardine on avocado toast, the dungeness crab croquetta and the duck jamon toast with fried quail egg which were very tasty and a great way to start off the meal. The sardine toast was so good that we ended up ordering a few more throughout the course of the meal.
