For the entrees, we started with the 'pata negra' Spanish ham that was some of the best cured ham that I have ever had the pleasure of tasting. Next was the spinach and chickpeas dish which was delicious and I don't usually like chickpeas. You cannot go here without ordering the amazing pork and jamon meatballls. The crispy fried potatoes were suprisingly good as well as the sauce had a nice spicyness to it. I did have a taste of the calimari with brussel sprouts, but I don't eat brussel sprouts (yeah, I know) although everybody else at the table seemed to enjoy it.

Finally, for dessert we had the caramel flan and lemon tart which were both very good. 

Definitely a place that I would both recommend and would go back to again.
author: Jared C.

description: Great Spanish spot if you're looking for some tapas.  I recall the flatbread being really, really good as well as the Albondigas and the papa bravas.  I really wanted to try the churros but I got too full and so I missed out on those.  I believe the menu changes so while they keep some staples on there some of the items change which would make coming back fun.  The next time I come back I am definitely saving room for those churros.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
The Calamars a la planxa was just perfectly done. I'll give this one 5 stars and will definitely come back just for this alone. We also had:
Croqueta de bacalao 4 stars (pretty darn good & not fishy at all)
Smashed peas on pan tostado 4 stars ( with jamon serrano. great combination)
Galician pulpo and potato pincho 5 stars (octopus was braised for hours so it's not chewy. Pleasantly surprised on how good it was)
Rioja sangria & peach sorbet 3 stars (it was good, just not a big fan)
Xocolata calenta 5 stars (sweet, rich & creamy will get this with the amb xurros next time)

Good service, Good ambiance, Great interior design
author: Chelsea V.

description:
I came to Contigo with two girlfriends for my belated birthday celebration. What a delightful and cozy little restaruant in quaint Noe Valley!

We had a reservation and were promptly seated in their outdoor seating area, which was covered and thus warm and toasty. Noticeably there was a garden area with a plethora of fresh vine veggies and herbs thriving, which we thought were very cute and surely added to the great atmosphere. 

Our waiter/server was friendly and attentive. Upon our request of recommended dishes he quickly highlighted the menu - tomatoes were delicious that day he said. We went along with his suggestions and ordered some dishes to share: pa amb tomaquet, olive oil poached albacore belly, little gem salad, summer corn and pimientos de padron, oxtail croquetas, and coca of cubanelle peppers (add a pastured egg and txistorra sausage).

The pa amb tomaquet was DEELICIOUS and a great starter. the Tomatoes were indeed aromatic, juicy and sweet, and tasted perfect with the olive oil and lightly toasted bread.

Olive oil poached albacore belly was a treat! It came with heirloom tomato slices that were to die for! the albacore belly was moist and lightly olive oil infused. I was trying not to scarf this down but instead take lady-like bites..

Little gem salad was delightful. The beets were fantastic and I am not regularly a beets fan! The garlic chips added a fun crunch and everything worked well together.

The summer corn and pimientos was another hit with me and my girls. What's better than juicy toasted sweet summer corn? Oh, delicious grilled pimientos (not spicy!) with a subtle smoked paprika kick. And the pimientos were the perfect nom nom bite-size.

The oxtail croquetas were really interestingly made with raisins and almonds. I remember they were enjoyable, but I think most likely at this point I was already stuffed.

The coca was surprisingly large in size upon arrival and we were all overwhelmed with it now towards the end of our meal. I forced myself to eat one slice. Good but not as memorable as some earlier dishes.

We finished our meal with Blue Bottle press pot coffee and shared a peach upside down cake with helado. What a wonderful meal with great company. I'd definitely come back to Contigo - a gem in the Noe!
author: Jing D.

description:
I had an outstanding dining experience at Contigo. The environment,  food, and staff were wonderful.

I would recommend the 7-dish course. Several of the dishes were casual snacks (Hamburgers, Pizza, Ham + Beans) yet featured Spanish style and excellent preparation.
author: Steve P.

description:
The service was great and the food was tasty.  Ambience is nice.  Wine pours are a bit small as other Yelpers indicated.  The wait staff really know their dishes and their wines.  Their recommendations were the ones I liked most.  

My fav dishes were the Albacore Crudo and the Roasted Sardine and Avocado Toast.  The Calamari was super tasty but I was a bit disappointed by the Braised Lamb Shoulder as it was mostly fat and very little meat.
author: Yvonne N.

description: Spanish restaurant 24th and Castro. Great atmosphere, warm and welcoming, sorry I had to leave when our meal was over. Great service with very unique and flavorful dishes. Patates Braves, albondigas, tripe, croqueta. coca all were outstanding. Finished off the meal with some churos and thick hot chocolate. Felt like I was in Madrid. I will be back, hope you try out this restaurant, think you will be happy...
author: Dan S.

description:
This is a really unique place.  They specialize in Tapas and Cava (Sparkling white wine)  

We did the tasting menu and split a desert.  The best part about the evening was discussing the wine list with the cava expert.

The food was good, we didn't like the sardine on toast, but I think it takes a special person to like sardines.  The rest of the courses had really great flavors and the timing of each dish was perfect.  The best was the goat cheese on toast with the kale salad.  

We also got the Clementine and Almond Gelat.  Was surprisingly good together and with the champagne.

I will be back for sure...make sure the get a reservation!!!
author: Chad J.

description:
Yum. I was not expecting this place to be as delicious as it was - maybe because we came here on a whim. But it was amazing, a real foodie treat. 

We got the tasting menu which was about 7 items; they were very accommodating in ensuring that all of the items were Pescatarian friendly as well. I tried:

Pimientos de Padron
Anchovy avocado toast 
Goat cheese + fig salad
Patates Braves
Baked Wild King Salmon w/ Corn
Spinach & Chickpeas Andalusian
Seafood stew like dish

My standout favorites were the sardine toast, salmon main dish and the chickpea/spinach main dish. Each of these had great balance but with an unexpected flavor that made the dish amazing. 

Would highly recommend. 

The atmosphere is very inviting, the wine list is great and it seems like a great place to take a date or just go with friends. We had a group of 4, waited 45 minutes with no reservation on  Friday night around 9. 

You Must Try: 

Anchovy Avocado Toast
Wild King Salmon
Spinach/Chickpea Andalusian Style
author: Silva G.

description:
I went to Contigo in a group of 3 for dinner on a weeknight. I'm torn on Contigo because on the one hand the food is fantastic however, on the other hand they only serve tapas here so if you're hungry or have a healthy appetite (like I do) then I'd skip this place. They split the menu between individual portion tapas (1 piece) and medium sized tapas (usually 3 pieces basd on dish). Here's a breakdown of my experience based on my 3 critera: food, service, and environment.

Food - We started with the anchovies and the croquettes. The anchovies and the croquettes are on the individual sized tapas list so we had to place 3 orders of each. Then we had the lamb meatballs and the Halibut. The lamb meatballs and the Halibut were on the medium sized tapas list so we placed 1 order of each and split the it family style. Overall the food was delicious. My only complaint with the food and the restaurant in general is that the tapas are very small (understand that I have a healthy appetite) and they aren't cheap (ranging from approximatley $9 to $30 each) so the tab can get out of hand quickly. 

Service - Our service was excellent. Our waitor was very helpful, friendly, and attentive. No complaints here.

Environment - Contigo has great ambience and is perfect for a date or for a casual meal. They keep the restaurant dimly lit and the noise level is pretty average. You won't need to shout at each other to have a conversation. 

Overall, the food at Contigo is fantastic and they provide excellent service, but don't expect your meal to be filling unless you spend over $100 minimum. I understand that this is a tapas restaurant and honestly Contigo's portions are in line with other tapas bar. Taking this all into consideration and being mindful of my bias, I still give Contigo a 4 star (great) rating.
author: Ken C.

description:
The food here is pretty amazing. Came here tonight with my girlfriends. First off,  we tried to make reservations but they were all booked so we told them to call us if they had an opening.  They called us layer in the day and said they had an opening,  but it was too early so we declined.  They called again later with another time with availability.  I love how they really try to accommodate us. The hostess was friendly. Our server James was attentive,  very nice,  and knowledgeable of the menu and gave us plenty of recommendations. Here were a few dishes we ordered:
- salt cured spanish anchovy montadito (oily fish but great complexity of flavors)
- jamon iberico de bellota (EH, bread & ham (ham is good though) 
- melocoton con jamon (BEST DISH, flavors galore!) *THUMBS UP*
- olive oil fried local halibut (EH, bland fried halibut)
- marin sun lamb rib chops (Good, great yogurt sauce to pair with the lamb)
- albondigas (breaks apart really easily, its OK)

Definitely recommend the melocoton con jamon! Overall, everything is good and i'd come back when back in SF.
author: Tammy L.

description: We did the seven course tasting menu. Six of the seven dishes were fantastic. Only one, the squid, was too oily/slimy for my tastes. But the service, atmosphere, and joyfulness of the entire experience more than made up for it. Also, our server, Deven, was the perfect mix of competence and sweetness. Overall, we will be back, for sure.
author: Morris R.

description:
Phenomenal food, great service, and nice ambiance. What more do you need? 
The highlights were the sardine toast, fig and goat cheese salad, squid (though it was a bit overcharred), and both the churros with hot chocolate and coffee / caramel flan. 

Really liked how the food was seasonal and the farms where the ingredients were sourced were listed on the dessert menu.  

Also, our waitress probably provided the best service I've had in the past year. 
If you can get the patio, do it.
author: Elad C.

description:
What a great place!  High quality food, attentive friendly service, nice ambiance.
I particularly liked the patio area.

Can't have enough:
- The Albondigas (meatballs) were the bomb!  The meatballs were moist, tender, and very well-seasoned, and the sauce - I could not stop eating it, until the last drop.  

Other tasty dishes:
- Calamars a la Planxa - grilled calamari is always good, but here the garnish of corn and chorizo complement the calamari very well.  
- Cantabrian Anchovy Motadito - saw the table next door ordering it... couldn't resist, and it tasted as good as it looked.  

Just OK:
- Jamon Serrano - hard to be disappointed with this, but seriously the quality of the Jamon here does not seem as high as other places I have been to.
- Pulpo and Potato Pincho - just ok.  The octopus wasn't charred or tender enough.

Overall, it was nice place for dinner.  I would definitely come back to try the other dishes.
author: Thomas L.

description: The food is Catalonian, a region of Spain.  With many dishes having a Moorish influence you experience a Middle Eastern flavor.  The result is amazing!  We ordered several tapas (individual servings) and the larger plates that are shared.  You need to experiment when here, a tapas with sardines is amazing, grilled squid, also amazing.  The service is fast.  And you can order in waves, so try some dishes, order more and keep enjoying.  To finish, we had churros with a chocolate sauce, which was amazing.  Good selection of wine and beers.
author: Mike A.

description:
My wife and I had dinner with another couple here a few weeks back and we had a good time.  This had been on my list to try out and I don't venture to this neighborhood very often so it was nice to try something new.  The place is relatively small so I would definitely recommend making a reservation.  The service was good although we sat in the back patio and the ground was very wet with a pretty big puddle so our feet were wet all throughout the meal.  It would have been to have them dry that up before they opened but after a few bottles of wine I don't think anyone noticed.

We had no idea how much or what to get here so we took our waiters advice and got a good amount of various foods.  I would say the standout was definitely the meatballs (enough so that my friend's wife got them again for dessert).  There wasn't anything that we tried that we weren't big fans of though so that's always a good sign.
author: Blake B.

description:
Got the 
- Calamars a La Planxa (the squid w beans)
- Coca (the flatbread)
-  Duck dish

The 7x7 - squid on beans was no bueno. It's literally cooked squid lying on a bed of beans. I wish it was stuffed w cheese or something more exotic, or even..flavorful. 

The coca was surprisingly yummy! good portions, was craving pizza so that hit the spot.

the duck dish was good too. 

The appetizers, especially the anchovy toast was good, but its so tiny, i recommend you save yourself the $2 bite, and use it to pay for your vino.
author: Ami Y.

description: Came with some friends and we had a variety of meat and non meat dishes that were all pretty good - not stellar. I was definitely expecting more from the ham and was disappointed that it was not as rich and salty as i'm used to getting at other upscale tapas/spanish restaurants.  The other dishes were good, but not much to write home about. For the pricing I was expecting more. I prefer B44 over this place.
author: Amy ..

description: Instantly one of my favorite restaurants in the city!  Seriously GREAT!
author: Jerome Z.

description: The food here is so damn good. It makes you want to kiss every person who works here. Everything on the menu is delicious and yes, I tried everything. Highly recommended for any occasion. Foodies' heaven.
author: Mari W.

description: This is hands-down one of SF's best eateries and no doubt the only place worth dining in Noe Valley. I have never been disappointed. The food is interesting, thoughtfully prepared, never over-salted, fresh and delicious every single time. The chef owner is a master.
author: Sandy G.

description:
I had a friend visiting and we were out looking for a place to eat dinner last week.  We had thought about going for Korean BBQ and were across the street, headed for Hahn's, but they were closed.  

My friend smelled the cooking from Contigo, wafting accross Castro Street.  We were entranced.  When we saw there was a special Paella tasting menu, we were hooked.

We ordered the 5 course tasting menu for two.  It was not only creative, but delicious and reasonably priced.  The staff were also very friendly, as were the other patrons seated nearby.  We had an unexpectedly delightful meal.

With one glass of wine each, our meal came to just over $100 sans tax, tip and Health SF Charge.
author: Charles M.

description:
Probably the best tapas place I've had so far in the U.S, Contigo brought back memories of backpacking and eating my way through Spain.

Jamon Iberico was fantastic. Great wine selection to pair with all the delectable delights. My eye is always bigger than my stomach when it comes to small plates. I tried as many plates as my stretched out stomach will allow, and rolled out stuffed to my eyeballs and extremely happy.
author: Bonny B.

description: Solid Spanish food. Recommend the la plancha squid dish and the anchovy and avocado toast.
author: Jake D.

description:
I think the food is a tad overpriced. The restaurant looks great and the staff is friendly, but I was hungry after our tasting menu. It's $42 per person and you get 7 shared plates. 

I recall liking the lamb meatballs, smoked salmon tapas, grilled asparagus. I LOVED the jamon croquetas and the calamari a la plancha. It's just that the portions were tiny and I'm wondering if I'm better off just ordering just the plates I want instead of doing a tasting menu. For example on the asparagus course our table of 3 got 6 pieces of asparagus. 

Oh and the churros are very delicious. But I don't think it's that much better than the ones you get at the park. 

I'm planning to try the place again but this time I'm just ordering 4 plates of the calamari a la plancha. It's so good.
author: Anthony H.

description:
Although we were not seated until 25 minutes past our reservation, we all loved our experience last night.  

THE WINE
All Spanish, which was great because it gave us an opportunity to try something new.  I *think* that we had one of their two ribeiros, which was like a very light Chardonnay.  No heavy oak, slightly acidic, really pleasant.

THE MEAL
I was so looking forward to the pork belly, but they didn't have any!  Damn.  Nothing else mattered after that, so we opted for the evening's tasting menu, which included the following, all served family style:

* Sardine and avocado toast with pickled onions and smoked salt to start us out - OMG, divine.  Get it, lick the toast, smush the sardine on your tongue - so good

* Pork croquettes - you think that you're probably getting a ball of fried pork, right?  Nyet.  It was a dark encrusted fritter with the insides the texture of a mousse, almost - didn't even taste like pork.  Maybe because the pigs are "acorn-fed"?

* Fig salad - oh, the seared goat cheese was heaven.  And the texture balance between the arugula, chestnuts, cheese, and figs was a mouth's wet dream.  So well done.

* The spinach and chickpeas - when I saw it on the menu, I thought immediately of Indian food.  There was no Indian flavor to it at all, but this was the least like dish by anyone in our group of four.  I wouldn't order it again.

* Sausage-stuffed calamari - SO tender, the calamari and so deliciously seasoned the sausage.  Number two behind the sardine toast.

* Salmon on fig leaf - when I first saw the salmon, I thought that it was awfully pink to be cooked all the way through.  But, it did end up being cooked enough and boy was it so soft and melt-in-my mouth delectable.  The vegetables underneath included corn, thin, half moons of squash, and cherry tomatoes.

*The pork and pork meatballs.  I write "pork and pork" because their menu has it as Pork and jamon which is, essentially, the same thing.  They were just okay.  

DESSERT
Despite not having enough room in our bellies, there's always room for a bite of dessert.  And so we shared the churros with thick hot chocolate.  The churros weren't as dark and crispy as I like them, though still good.  And the hot chocolate, without accompaniment from the churros, was super duper rich, of course.  Had about two tablespoons poured over my churro and was totally good to go.
author: Tamar D.

description:
In my quest for eating as much as possible during my last few weeks in San Francisco, I decided to venture outside my normal "comfort zone" all the way to Noe Valley. I can't believe I've lived in this city for over two years and have never been to Noe Valley. My supervisor had high praise for the restaurant  (she's also a foodie), plus it was another chance to check something off the 7X7  100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

My friends and I started to meal off with the little gem salad with roasted beets and garlic chips; goat cheese salad with arugula, apples and hazelnuts; and the jamon iberico de bellota. The salads didn't really impress me much in terms of flavor combinations and they were also small. The jamon was delicious and had a little bit of a smoky flavor.

Hands down the best dish of the night was the coca (flatbread) topped with wild nettles, bacon, caramelized onions and manchego cheese. The flatbread was served PIPING hot. That manchego cheese was like burning hot lava and I totally burned my tongue while trying to eat a piece. It was worth the pain because it was absolutely divine. The caramelized onions were cooked to a pulp and were nice and sweet. Bacon always makes any dish better so I'm not going to comment on the bacon. I also liked how there was a little bit of kick with spicy pepper flakes on top. You have to order this dish if you go!

I was surprised that the calamars a la planxa was on the 7X7 list. The squid had a strange consistency and was softer than any squid I've eaten before. It was served on a bed of squid ink rice with chorizo and artichokes mixed in. The rice was really oily and heavy and the chorizo and artichokes didn't add much. I was disappointed because I like squid ink and the rice really didn't have much flavor. The albondigas were tasty and tender. I only wish that the portion was bigger!

For dessert, we split the churros with "hot chocolate." The hot chocolate was more of a thick, chocolate sauce. It was rich, but not too sweet (though I don't know how you could drink it plain). Is this how Barcelona-style hot chocolate really is? It makes me want to travel to Barcelona and try a fresh cup for myself. The churros were AMAZING. Crispy and fried to perfection and lightly coated in sugar. The combination of churros and hot chocolate pair together perfectly.

Overall, Contigo was an enjoyable meal, but I felt like the portions were a little small. A party of 2-3 people would be perfect. Anything larger and I feel like not everyone would get to have a taste of everything. It was cute to explore Noe Valley a little bit  (it's extremely family-oriented). I don't think it's a restaurant that you need to go out of your way to try, but if you're in the area, Contigo is worth checking out.

Read more reviews and see photos on my blog: http://rbjello.wordpress.com/2012/03/20/spanish-and-catalan-tapas-at-contigo/
author: Jackie T.

description:
Despite the lack of any availability on opentable, we were able to call ahead and get seated at the bar in front of the kitchen ... right next to the door on a cold night.  Actually, it wasn't bad at all, and it was a lot of fun watching the cooks work.

Service, though not always as attentive as we would have liked, was well-informed and very friendly.  We got the catalan wine flight - somehow they charged us $35 instead of the $30 posted on the menu, but it was still not a bad deal for four glasses of interesting wine.  They even substituted the last glass when we chose a relatively sweet chocolate dessert.

The sardine tapa was mild and delicious - even my sardine-hating companion enjoyed it.  Our jamon croqueta, on the other hand, arrived nearly burnt with the creamy insides having but a hint of flavor from the jamon.  We looked at all the properly cooked ones going out of the kitchen that night, and cursed our luck.

Catalan style sauteed greens were excellent, despite being somewhat panned by our server - interesting nuts and dried fruit accompanying swiss chard.  Calamars a la plancha was also very enjoyable.

We had both the lamb tagine and seabass - unremarkable, though the lamb had a nice texture.  With the understanding that this is traditionally a salty cuisine, by the time we got to the tripe dish, we were prepared to declare defeat in the salt wars.

Dessert was an excellent rendition of churros with chocolate - the chocolate much better flavored, though less thick, than that served in Spain.  And they put some flakes of salt on top of the chocolate.

Exuding more sodium from our pores than normal, we stumbled back into the night.  About six blocks straight up hill to where we parked our car.  Decent food, some dishes are a good value and some are not, but we came equipped with a discount coupon, and left satisfied if a little oversalted.
author: Albert H.

description:
I usually love tapas . . . tiny plates of scrumptious morsels, allowing me to sample a variety of delicious plates, what more could I ask for?  Well, I'm not sure what more I could ask for, but whatever it is, Contigo didn't have it.

True, the flavors of each dish were wonderfully paired, but maybe it's my palate, but the flavors didn't wow me, or tease my tongue to want to go back for more.

The Lomo Iberico de Bellota "Pata Negra" was nice.  Reminded me of the meat cone at Baccalone's at the Ferry Building.  The Lomo were small lean not fatty cuts of delcious procured meats.  I enjoyed it, but didn't fall in love.

I also enjoyed the Calamars a la Planxa with chanterelle mushrooms and parsley, but again, eh . . . I liked the strong lemony flavor, but my dining companion did not.  Too much citrusy goodness for her.

Albondigas (AKA Pork and Jamon Meatballs) were okay.  I keep comparing the meatballs and tomato sauce to the one's at Beretta, and no one has been able to come even close to the delectable scumpdiliumptiousness of Beretta.  Worse yet, the meatballs had this slight gamey flavor.

Patatas Bravas were unremarkable.  Fried to perfection with a nice sprinkling of flavors, but the salsa and allioli topping it didn't do it for me.

Overall, I was underwhelmed, and for about $60 (not including tip) for two people, I probably won't come back to try the other dishes.
author: Christina L.

description:
Outstanding. One of the best all-around restaurant experiences I've had in years.

The room is intimate, attractive and lively, without being distracting. The host was very gracious, despite the fact we were late for our reservation. Our waiter was the perfect combination of formality and familiar; professional without being wooden and friendly without being intrusive.  He was knowledgeable and efficient; didn't hover or ask any inane badly-timed questions (e.g., "how is everything" asked 5 seconds after plates set down) and seemed to appear whenever we needed him.

All of the above is sort of beside the point if the food isn't good.  Well, the food at Contigo--every single dish, from start to finish--was excellent.  Looking forward to the next visit...
author: Timothy C.

description:
Why are all Spanish restaurants tapas restaurants? And a Spanish restaurant without paella?? Oh well, it was still pretty good.

We had the following dishes:
-Coca (Flatbread) with roasted potatoes - Flatbread is just a fancy word for pizza. This was really good though! 
-Patatas bravas - pretty much like thick fries with aioili mayo and another red sauce. It's delicious, though, but if you think about it.. you just paid $7 for french fries lol.
-Oxtail Croquetas - Delicious, although it could've been just as good with any other meat. The oxtail tasted like regular ol' shredded beef that comes in burritos!
-Pork Belly Bocadillos - The sweetness of the bread made this thing taste like a Chinese pork bun that you might get at dim sum...
-Fried sardines - This reminds me of Japanese food... oh wait, that's because it is.
-Calamares a la plancha - The squid was very tender, but it could've used more pieces of the squid in this dish overall..
-Marmitako - fish stew.. I prefer my fish not as well-done, but I guess it was good.

The food was all tasty, but my gripe about most of these tapas restaurant still holds true here -- the portions are very small for the amount that you pay. With each dish ranging from $8 to about $14, it adds up quick! I don't think anything on the menu here used expensive ingredients that would justify the price of the dishes.
 
By the way... whoever decided to make ice cream using Blue Bottle Coffee is a GENIUS!
author: Kazu O.

description:
We were set on going for sushi next door. But the sushi place was unable to seat us. So our decision to try Contigo was serendipitous. And you know what? Sometimes that's when you have the most fun. Such was the case with Contigo.

First, I should explain that this restaurant is the type of place that appreciates and normally needs a reservation, as opposed to simply dropping in. We just lucked out getting our group in. You'll be there for an hour, or so.

We were a group of four and we decided to do the 7-course taster. That, along with a bottle of Petalos (Bierzo) was muy excelente.

The chef and cooks are serious here. They're using quality ingredients and are cooking tasty morsels.

Tapas are fun and it's definitely an energetic restaurant. Tables are close to each other so you may end up chatting with the people next to you as well!
author: Greg J.

description: The tasting menu is wonderful! And they let you sub out an item or at least split items if someone in your party doesn't like one. Oh, and the owner -- Elan? (sp?). Is a gem. When service is valued as highly as the cuisine, she puts it over the top with her humble, customer service oriented and expedient manner in which she manages her business. A very smart, savy woman! I wish them continued success and will be back many more times and will recommend to anyone looking for a good night out.
author: Shay M.

description:
UPDATE:
If I could give this place 10 stars I would.
I love this place. Love.

----

The food is delicious and so is the wine.
The outside seating area has a great atmosphere (pardon the pun).
The waitstaff is excellent.
There are no cons to this place, only pros.
author: Fred C.

description:
Contigo is another one of my favorite tapas place.  Their sardine on toast was so delicious.  As a matter of fact, any of their fish on toast was yummy.

I remember their food being so good, but I can't seem to recall specific dishes because I drink a lot when I go to Contigo.  They have a great wine list.  My friend and I would share a bottle and then get dessert wine.  We would easily spend close to 3 hours there.

I have been there during dinner and after dinner.  Seating is very comfortable there.  They serve food until quite late.  The line tends to get pretty long, so it's important to get a reservation.  Price range wise it's hard to gauge because we like our wine, so it's at least 3 if not 4$.
author: Berry R.

description:
Excellent tapas dishes, but make sure you get a reservation, as it seems to book up quite early and walk-ins may be impossible.

To try: white gazpacho with tasty pickled cherries; smashed peas on pan tostado; flatbread with chorizo and squash flowers; albondigas.

The atmosphere is warm, modern, and the menu has a number of more standard fare (patatas bravas) as well as more unique items (the almond white gazpacho). There aren't too many tables, though there is a small outdoor patio area, and there kitchen is mostly open, which lends an intimate feeling to the place.
author: Alexis J.

description:
I have been twice at Contigo now, and I can tell you that even I really wanted to love the place, I couldn't b/c of the "just ok" food.

It is cute place, in a cool neighborhood, a bit noisy, but vibrant.  Service is excellent and the waiters are great.
But, the food is just ok, an for the price you pay (we ended up paying $65/person after tip)  it makes it average.
author: Ardit B.

description: Best, prettiest, and classiest restaurant in Noe.  I love sliding up to the bar, ordering a flight and have tapas.  Sleek service, perfect, interesting food, great Spanish wine. The squid is my go-to Sunday dish now.  Doesn't get any better in the whole Castro/Noe Zip Code.
author: Sam C.

description: This place was great. I really liked the outdoor seating area. The menu has a bunch of options and there truly is something for everyone. The food was delicious, but i was not a fan of the tasting menu being "chef's choice." If the tasting menu was any pick of 7 items it would have been 5 stars from me.
author: Larisa V.

description: This place was fantastic! Came here for dinner and some wine and it did not disappoint. The plates were small, but was expected for spanish style restaurant. I was very satisfied and will recommend my friends to come!
author: Robert R.

description: We were there on a busy Saturday night without reservations.  We were seated within 10 minutes.  The service was excellent and the portions were perfect. I have a restricted diet and they were happy to accommodate me. I look forward to visiting again.
author: Renee W.

description:
We went to Contigo yesterday and at enjoyed our meal and the ambiance of the place. We tried a handful of plates.

Unfortunately about 1-2h after we left the restaurant i started vomiting with horrible diarrhea. It was sadly definitely one of the plates i had and went on all night. Dissapointing as i live so close to the restaurant.

Here's another review of someone who similarly got sick like myself:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/contigo-san-francisco-2#hrid:6oWIFHIR9LezM8J7SZhKgQ
author: G S.

description: I usually leave 400 dollar dinners feeling like I just wasted a lot of money. Not so at Contigo. I especially loved desert. The flam with the chocolate sauce from the churros was the most delicious thing I have ever eaten. I was here with a super fit couple so they ordered uninteresting things  like spinach and salad. The spinach dish was nothing like the disappointing vegetable I was expecting. Order it. Salad was lettuce. ( it was pretty, like if they used it as a garnish I might carefully place it aside to get to the real food.)The tapas are nice too. Quince paste and farmers cheese toasts. Simple so every ingredient had to be perfect. They were so good. Potatoes are the best home fries you've ever had but for me they are just potatoes. I would skip for something more interesting. Service was pretty sucky. Majorly sucky. But your food is that good. I had an empty glass throughout most of the night. I will come back but next time I'll order a few more deserts.
author: Corey Jace W.

description:
another amazing meal.  ordered the whole menu, 21 courses + 2 deserts.  everything is tasty and wine friendly.  can't imaging a potato can taste this good.  pork belly burger OMG. Jamon meal ball, Jamon croqueta, Jaon iberico de bellota, palenta iberica de bellota de jabugo.

Service +++++
author: Linda L.

description: Disappointed with our last meal here. None of the dishes stood out, not even the flatbread, which I loved last time. It's definitely overpriced - something we suspected last time. Would recommend going to a fairer priced and less pretentious Spanish restaurant that probably serves tastier dishes.
author: Y A.

description:
Oh Contigo, how you make my heart smile. I can't say enough amazing things about this restaurant. I like to think it's my little secret spot that no one knows about, a place I can go with my friends and never have to worry about it becoming too hipster, but I think the word is out. Contigo is the place to eat.

I first went here in September for an anniversary dinner with my partner and two friends. We brought a nice bottle of Pinot with us ($20 corkage) and ended up ordering another bottle off the menu (bottles are a little pricey - most are over $40). We started with the anchovies and bocadillos as an amuse bouche to curb our hunger. And then we kept gordering the anchovies and the boquerones. I think we ordered three rounds of those because they were so good! Let's call this Round 1.

Round 2 included the little gem salad, the sauteed greens catalan style, the coca (flatbread), the olives and my personal favorite -the jamon iberico! I first had jamon iberico when I went to Barcelona this summer and this is the only restaurant in SF that has it on the menu. It is so mild, so sweet, so salty. The satiating five pieces linger in my mouth for the rest of the night. I love you, jamon iberico.

Round 3 was meat and seafood - squid, beef and octopus. Dear lord, was it fantastic. I could've sworn they caught the seafood in the morning and brought it to the restaurant for dinner.

Round 4 - dessert. Churros (Xurros) dipped in thick Barcelona-style hot chocolate. I wanted to cry it was so good. I know we had one other thing but I can't remember right now what it was....I just remember everything tasting amazing. There was nothing I didn't like.

I went back here again last Saturday and it was still some of the best food I've had in the city. I really feel like I am in Barcelona for the night at a cool, mellow tapas bar. The ambience is fantastic, the service is friendly and the food is out of this world. California cuisine meets Catalunya. If there is any place you should go with your best friends, it is here. Just make sure I'm not there that night....I want to keep it my little secret.
author: Stephanie P.

description: I have been many times. Excellent food, tapas style of course. Somewhat expensive though. Great friendly service.
author: hans j.

description:
We went to Contigo with a group of 8 and had a fabulous time.  The hostess was adorable. Our server Rafael was well educated and made excellent recommendations and put up with our slightly rowdy birthday boy.

The star here is the food though and it was shining!  We ordered nearly the whole menu.  We started with two types of jamon and olives.  Next up, two wonderful salads, savory gulf shrimp, oxtail croquetas and albondigas.  Finally the ling cod, the lamb - which had the consistency of carnitas - loved it, pork belly (my first time!), two flat breads, brussel sprouts - yum! and patatas bravas.  There was nothing I didn't like or find underwhelming.  I just really loved every little bite.  We also enjoyed a couple wines, tried some sherry and finished with cava.  We had a meal to remember.

Thanks Contigo!  Can't wait to go back.
author: Mac M.

description: My favorite restaurant in SF.  Yes, lots to chose from but none have the passion, creativity and the consistent wow effect of Contigo.  6 visits and each time the menu has been unique and amazing.  To keep it fresh and changing the Chef actually closes down the restaurant to go to Spain and travel the country to find new recipes to bring back to Contigo.  Service is always amazing as its a team focus on all the tables so you are never left wanting.  Great wine list as well.  Overall Contigo has everything I want in a restaurant 1) Amazing food 2) great atmosphere (not too loud) 3) Attentive service 4) Reasonably priced for the high quality food
author: Dave L.

description:
My business partner and I came here on the recommendation of a colleague. Aside from the crab cake, which was amazing, nothing else we ordered was that tasty though not terrible, with the exception of the short ribs...it was totally tough like jerky. I wanted to love Contigo, it's a cute neighborhood place and the service was excellent, but the food was just not up to par. And for me taste is the most important thing. 

This was on company expense so we didn't even pay for the meal, but for $25 for small portion of short rib, another $25 for the small portion of sole, $7 for a dash of olives, etc, they had better be damn good. And they weren't. 

As my business partner said, "You come here if you want to have a drink and snack for $60 per person."
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I live literally a 15 second run from my door to Contigo.  I was thrilled to hear of it coming--really wanted it to be great--but sadly, it's just medicore.

I've been three times.  I found it very subpar compared to any other tapas restaurant in the Bay Area (and I've lived in Madrid).  The service is ok.  But the food is incredibly salty.  We had squid, ham, patatas brava, anchovys--we took what the waiter recommended as it was close to the type of tapas I usually order anyway. Nothing to write home about.  I've had better at Andalu, Cha Cha Cha, Ramblas back in the day. There are just too many other tapas and other restaurants in the same price range that are loads better (Bar Jules, Bar Bambino...).  Next door to Contigo are a variety of ok neighborhood eateries.  If you made me choose between Contigo and them, I'd definitely prefer:  Hamano Sushi, Barney's Burgers, Lupe Italian, and Incanto.  If I had to choose between Basso and Contigo, I'd just go to the Whole Food Salad Bar instead.

Yet whenever I walk by, it's somewhat crowded.  So, just like with Mission Chinese, there are just some things I don't get in life.  

I don't really based my Yelp stars on service.  I try to focus on the food.  If the soup nazi were in SF, I'd be okay with patronizing that place and putting up with the abuse.  In the past, the service has been passable/fine.  But for whatever reason, one winter evening, my date and I were the first people at the restaurant at 530 pm.  The host seated us at the one worst table possible.  We were dressed nice--we were attractive.  But why give us the patio table with the strong freezing draft (billowing then freezing my hair into sheets) when NO ONE ELSE was there?  we requested a change of tables, and they really struggled with that request for 10 minutes.  Let me repeat, we were the only people in the restaurant, and we were still wearing our heavy coats at our tables.  When I told them we needed to leave or die of exposure, they begrudgingly gave us another table--not even inside.  30 minutes later, finally more customers showed up (25% full).  But by then we were done and gone. 

If your date knows food, men, you won't get a second date after taking her there.  If it were my prediction alone--I'd say this place would be closed by early 2013.  But I understand that other people have different tastes from me.  Just so you can callibrate with me, if you had to ask my favorite last five restaurants i ate at in sf were:

1.  benu
2.  delfina (but not locanda as much)
3.  umami burger
4.  amphawa thai on geary--surprisingly good for thai
5.  pizetta 211

Outside of SF, I've had wonderful meals, expensive and cheap at:

1. Olivetos
2. Summer Kitchen
3. B Side BBQ
4. Pizzaiola
5. Kirala Sushi

All these places I've mentioned above are 8 or 10s/ out of 10.  Contigo is a 4.
author: Philip L.

description:
Contigo was great. Friendly staff, nice atmosphere, and delicious food. Our reservations were set for 8pm.  We were a bit concerned about being seated at a table in the back patio because it was pretty cold and windy walking to the restaurant. The table worked out great because it was a bit quieter than the main restaurant and the back patio has heat lamps and a plastic roof to keep out the cold but allowed for a nice view of the night sky.

Our server was friendly, helpful, and attentive without disrupting our special anniversary dinner celebration. We ordered the 7 course tasting menu which was dry filling and allowed us to try many of the dishes we were interested in.  We especially enjoyed the Squid dish and the meatballs. We also enjoyed two desserts (churros and hot chocolate and the butterscotch flan) not included in the tasting menu, but definitely worth it.  We had a great time and look forward to coming back.
author: Alex L.

description:
Calamars a la planxa!  Tender squid over black rice with fava beans and chorizo!  What a pleasant surprise that little tapas was!  I need to go back just for that.  All the small plates we ordered were great.  I did find most of the dishes to be a little over salted (that doesn't stop me as I like salt a lot, but it could be off putting to other diners).   I thought the prices of the dishes were fair for the quality of food which is all fresh and all locally resourced.    Cute space, very cozy.  Great date spot.  Plus the waitstaff was awesome.   Very enjoyable.

(Edit:  While discussing Contigo with friends I was told that one friend had a celebrity chef Michael Chiarello sighting there.  I won't go into the salacious details, and they were pretty salacious...anyway, always fun to spot a celebrity chef!  Foodie street cred).
author: Kari S.

description:
Want bang for your buck, do not come here..if you are looking for bang even regardless of the buck do not come here. I do not often treat myself to dinner as these but I had seen some fantastic photos and write up of this place. I decided to give this place a try. What a DISAPPOINTMENT. Ridiculously priced tapas done completely mediocre. Although the description on the menus will have your pallette saying yes please, once you actually get your tiny morsel to your pallette will still be begging as almost all the dishes missed the mark. 

Salted Cod with melted leeks and wood mushrooms was so terribly bland and was plated awfully, it looked like mush with the smallest piece of cod for $23

Little gem salad was so tiny and was $11 although it was tasty the dressing left us quiet puckered. 

Our flat bread was 2 types of cheeeses with calf fatted bacon, this bacon was so greasy it was like dripping everytime you bit into the now soggied flat bread. 


SERIOUSLY: How can you mess up Patas Bravas and call yourself tapas place.
These tasted like the the paprika jar fell into the potatoes. Awful, salt less, bitter. 

The best dish was the the snap peas with ham..but come on I go out to eat to savor creative cooking that I cannot accomplish myself. Since, this was a splurge for me I left a little irate paying $200 with wine for such unsavory fare. 

I say save $$$ go to fair priced tapas place such PIcaro where you not only get what you pay for. You pallette and YOUR WALLET will be so so grateful.
author: Deandra B.

description:
Wohoo!   An easy breath of fresh air.

And it's right down my street!  I love it when the hood is good to me. 

I really enjoyed Contigo.  Nothing spectacular.  Just a super simple menu, a nice wine list, simple clean decor.  When I walked in, it was deja vous!  I thought I was in Flour + Water for a hot minute.  In fact, I was so taken by the similarity that I had to ask....and NO, they are not related.  Thank goodness ;)  

Contigo's cuisine is Spanish.  Delightful flavors.  Satisfying portions.   Splendid service.  Cool prices.  Oh how lovely it would be to enjoy their outdoor seating on a nice day.  My menu recommendation:  patatas bravas (take it from someone who normally doesn't eat potatos!).  

All of that adds up to five stars in my book.  :)
author: Angella S.

description:
Small neighborhood restaurant on Castro was an excellent and surprising find during a business trip.  Parking was a bit of a challenge to find an open spot on the street.  

Once in the place you're greeted with the kitchen on the left with bar seats facing the action.  Once I saw this that was where I wanted to be.  Service never faltered as I was waiting on by several from the moment I stepped up to the hostess to the time I left.  

Crab croqueta, wood roasted sardine and avocado toast, calamars a la planxa, and ablondigas...each had a unique and flavorful combination.  I would order these again but there were so many other dishes that looked worthy of a try as well.  

Go here...you won't be disappointed.
author: Daniel V.

description:
I LOVE CONTIGO!

I cannot even count how many times I have been here. This place is SO good. I have never left disappointed. Great wine selections, too.

As for dessert, you MUST have the coffee flan! MUST.

Also, for groups: make sure to order the Tapas Tasting Menu. It's definitely worth it!
author: MJ T.

description:
I can get past the so-so food and the douchbag startup atmosphere, but for a somewhat costly meal, I would hope our waitress wouldn't be a total snatch.
Basics when we're eating at a "decent" sf restaurant include: refilling our water glasses, topping off our wine glasses from our bottle, asking how our food is, checking in on us other than delivering the check...yeah our grumpy waitress took our food order then basically disappeared for the rest of the night. So if you're coming here for an experience, or for the food (because it wasn't great), I would pass.
author: H.S. G.

description:
We wondered into Contigo on a random weeknight and they sat us at the bar. The restaurant was very trendy, I liked the decor, and the service was above average. The food was delicious, but seemed less attended to that I would have liked. For example, we got the flatbread and it just wasn't cooked long enough. I can doughy pizza crust anywhere and pay a lot less. 

Try the dungeness crab croqueta--it was delicious.
author: Bradley B.

description:
You really cannot go wrong here.  

We had:  all of the 5 tapas (double order), the pimientos de padron (those little Spanish peppers grilled to perfection - here, the portion was very generous).  In addition, we had the calamars a la planxa (with black rice and artichokes) and the wood oven roasted lamb riblets (a misnomer, since the ribs are big).  They are very good.  

Do NOT miss the dessert of Spanish chocolate with churros, we also loved the fabulous sorbets (sweet corn, strawberry) served with an Alfajor cookie - wonderful.

Large selection of Spanish wines, complemented with a brief but good beer list.
author: Thor T.

description: I have been very fortunate to eat an many amazing restaurants in San Francisco and Contigo is on of my absolute favorites. Do not miss the sardine and avocado toast, flatbread, meatballs, or the squid. I have never had a dish that I didn't enjoy. I love the atmosphere. Try to sit on the outside patio in the back. Choose from their selection of delicious spanish wines and order xurros and chocolate for dessert!
author: Meghan B.

description:
A great  spot  

2004 Jumilla gran reserva was acidic and tanniny. My friend drank isastegi, a natural cider, which was very bitter but he enjoyed it. 

We shared the Marin sun lamb that was the perfect amount of fat and falling off the bone served over ginger saffron couscous with sweet roasted quince and purple broccoli. 

The papas brava con allioli was delicous. The papas were perfectly crispy and the salsa brava rich with tomato and acid. The allioli was a nice spicy surprise to a usually non spicy dish. 

Overall  the food was great. Nice atmosphere and service was top-notch. The meal was a bit expensive ($70 for everything) but I think an interesting place that served dynamic food and I would def be back!
author: Jade W.

description:
Great modern decor with a back patio area. Service was nothing to write home about but wasn't bad either.

Okay, on to the main attraction, the food. The patatas bravas were the best I've had - crispy, with two sauces a spicy tomato sauce and an aioli.

The semi-firm goat cheese was just all right with a very small portion.

The flat-iron steak was cooked well but lacked any significant flavor to speak of.

Finally, the scallops were awesome! Served with roasted artichokes and I believe some sort of thinly sliced smoked ham. Too bad again, the portions were so tiny. Just THREE scallops for $18?! As good as it was, that's not a good value at all.

This place has the so much potential...It's too bad they fall in with every other tapas joint by serving incredibly small portions.
author: Art O.

description:
I started out giving Contigo a 5 star rating for both the great tapas and great service. Dropped to a 3.0 rating due to the entrees. 

We went with our server's recommendations for the tapas of imported Spanish Serrano ham, chicken liver pate, tripe, and the meatballs. All four were a 5 star rating. We also had the La Quercia prosciutto from Iowa which was acceptable if not compared to the Serrano. 

The fried potato side dish with allioli and salsa came to the table hot and the potatoes were crispy on the outside. The salsa had a little kick to it.  Definitely order this dish.

Entrees were weak compared to the tapas.  Of the four entrees offered, we had three - the prawns, the chicken, and the oxtail cannoli.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I can honestly say this is my favorite restaurant in SF. 

 I'm always in the mood to go to Contigo, and have never had a single bad thing here. The food is amazing the service is great (but we're bias since we go here so often they know us), and the restaurant it's self is beautiful. 

Another perk is the area; we've never had a problem finding parking within a block or so (which in SF terms is great).
author: Rose L.

description:
We were in the city with some friends from out of town this weekend and made last minute reservations at Contigo having done little research on the place beforehand.  What a pleasant surprise!!

From the service, to the wine, to the food - everything was great.  Rave reviews all around.  There were so many enticing items on the menu and we were all tired from traveling, so we just decided to go with the chef's tasting menu.  7 dishes to share between 4 people for $40/person.  The flow of the meal was perfect and the portions were generous.  For many of the dishes (#5-7 below), they even brought out two portions, which was more than enough!  

Individual dish reviews: (must-haves are written in ALL CAPS)
1. Wood oven roasted monterey sardine and avocado toast - the pickled onions balanced the slightly fishy sardine.  Good flavors and the avocado was deliciously cool and creamy on the crispy toast

2. Jamon iberico de bellota - Jamon...mmm...enough said.

3. LITTLE GEM SALAD - my obsession with beets continues!

4. Pimientos de padron - an assortment of bite sized peppers (some spicy, some not) roasted to perfection with sea salt

5. Patates braves - I'm not sure what Allioli and Salsa Brava are but they give fried potatoes a whole new life!  If this is Catalan's version of home fries, I'm sold.

6. CALAMARS A LA PLANXA - my favorite dish of the night!  Perfectly tender squid served over flavorful black rice with chorizo and artichokes.  

7. The last dish I can't find on the menu online but it was their version of a braised pork belly.  Also amazing and my 2nd favorite dish of the night.

For dessert, we ordered the vanilla gelat with california olive ranch arbequina olive oil and sea salt.  The perfect ending to a pretty perfect meal.

We left completely stuffed and completely happy.
author: Carolyn P.

description:
A lovely friend of mine suggested this place for dinner and it provided a settling for a perfectly enchanted evening.

First we got there a little early and they offered us water & wine while we waited for our table to be free. Extra point for attentiveness.

When we sat down we were having a bit of trouble selecting a wine and asked the waiter for a recommendation, and he knew how to ask us what we liked without making us feel stupid for not being able to respond like oenophiles. Definitely ask for a suggestion!

The dishes are tapas size but they are really fit for sharing. If you dont come in with a fred flintstone appetite id say 3-4 dishes max are ideal for two people. Highlights:

-Asparagus
-Calamare
-Lamb 

Id say the only real minus point was a lack of a wide coffee selection (they only had french press, which was fine but if you're sort of picky or insistent on having an espresso or latte you might be annoyed). 

Atmosphere was also tasteful, avoided tapas bar cliches, and wasnt so noisy that you have to shout at your dining companion.
author: Ash S.

description:
Bad attitude from the minute we stepped into the restaurant. Okay we didn't dress up, but you said "Casual attire" and that's why we didn't bother to get changed after being outdoor and hungry the whole day. The hostess gave us a head to toe look, told us that since we don't have a reservation we'd need to wait for 20 mins (totally fine) and added "are you sure you want to wait?" HUH!?! Did that mean she didn't want us to be in there? 

The one star is for the food - we had the tasting menu and they had interesting flavors. The other star was for our server - who was very nice and tried her best to compromise.
author: Emily C.

description: A few of the selections were good flavor but overall a disappointing. $13 for a glass of wine that was filled way below an average pour was a major flaw. The lamb chops should have been labeled gristle chops as it was a piece of fat on a bone. Staff was friendly.
author: Steve C.

description:
We had a reservation for a table for two at 9pm on Friday. Now it is acceptable that patrons may have to wait 5-10 mins even if they have a reservation for the table to clear. We were there for 25minutes, and a couple was seated before we did. When we asked how much longer we had to wait we were told that a large group had paid their bill but had not left. After giving them another couple of minutes we left our menus at the concierge and left. The waiting staff did not seem apologetic nor did they offer us a drink or anything to win our heart.

I have been here before, and their food is not bad at all, but definitely not worth being humiliated the way they expect us to.
author: Bulent K.

description:
I'm a sucker for spanish tapas for a number of reasons. Perfectly portioned bite-sized morsels of heaven in my mouth. I like that I can order 7-10 different dishes and practically try every dish on the menu and still have room for dessert. Also wine pairings... This was definitely the case at Contigo. 

     The bf and I dropped in for dinner without reservations @7:30 on a Sunday night and scored a seat after a 30 minute wait. The decor was fresh and clean, an atrium made up for the lack of art and everything seemed centered around the kitchen. Service was relaxed and friendly. Food was on point.

What we had from what I could remember were:
     Pork Sliders: hefty slice of pork belly sandwiched between mini burger buns served with pickled red onion 
     Crab Croquettes with cheese: gone so fast I don't remember them
     Golden Beet Salad: Sweet roasted beets as well as pickled beets, delish!
     Grilled Octopus: Good, but probably the weakest link 
     Albondigas: nicely balanced with a good marinara and not too large in size
     Braised Short Ribs: melt-in-your-mouth goodness
     Churros with Hot Chocolate: super thick chocolate

     All in all, a successful date night.
author: Laney L.

description:
During our weekend as SF residents, J and I strolled on over to Contigo on the recommendation of JHL.  He explained that it was a favorite neighborhood eatery of his, so in an effort to do as the natives do, I made reservations for dinner at 5:30PM on a Sunday.

AMBIANCE: Cute decor/ambiance.  Although the dining space isn't very large, the open kitchen and abundance of natural light makes it seem slightly larger than it is.  I will say that seating was somewhat cramped... and why they would seat us next to the only other diners in the entire restaurant when there was plenty of open space elsewhere was a mystery.

SERVICE: Friendly.  A little bit scattered at time, but overall they did a good job.

FOOD: Eeehhhh... nothing stood out to me.  We ordered a few items:
- Sardine + avocado toast ($3): Good pairing of oily fish and fatty avocado, with the pickled onion to cut through the fat.  I think I would've enjoyed this bite more if the avocado had been sliced instead of mashed to a thin paste.
- Little gem salad ($12): Light & refreshing.  I wish there were more beets and that the garlic chips were more flavorful.  It was not worth $12.
- Coca (flatbread; $15): The version we had had chantarelle mushrooms and some porky product, along with a divine cheese.  My fave of the items we ordered, it was essentially a fancy pizza.  The crust was delicious, with a slightly smoky flavor from the wood-fired oven (?) they baked it in.  The flavors were bold yet harmonious, and I had to stop myself from inhaling the entire thing.
- Local xipirons (squid) a la Planxa ($14): very tender squid, but slightly bland in flavor.  J didn't care for the beans in this dish, and thought the sauce was too watery.
- Tripe with chorizo & chickpeas ($9): VERY tender tripe.  The sauce was basically a ragout, chunky and yummy.  I wish I had some bread to eat with this dish. 
- Molasses cake ($9): basically a spiced gingerbread-y cake.  I was expecting moist decadence based on the description, so imagine my disappointment when I took a bite of extremely crumb-y DRY cake! :( BOOFACE.  However, the salted caramel sauce was a delightful pairing with the cake flavor.

OVERALL: I wasn't wowed by the food, but if I lived in the neighborhood, I could see this restaurant entering my weekly rotation.  However, its not something I'd drive all the way up from the south bay for.  Dinner sans drinks for two came out to over $70 (including tax + tip)
author: Susanna W.

description:
Yummmyyyy.  Super fresh food. 

Run down of what we got:

the tomato bread (forgot the official name): SO good and fresh. It felt like they smashed the tomatoes 2 minutes before. SO good. 

the jamon iberico plate: YUM. I would come back for this. PERFECTLY salted and the bread they served it with went well.  The only change I would make is if they had the option to get it with some cheese. That would take it over the top

lamb tagine: I thought this was good.  the lamb was super tender and only needed a fork to eat it.  I just thought it could have had more flavor/spice.

Halibut: DELICIOUS. easily the best thing we had. SO so good and fresh. 

really great service as well, and the ambiance outside was super cute with the wood piled up, heaters and greenery all around. I would definitely go back.
author: Megha A.

description:
If Charlie Sheen were Contigo's chef and yelping his menu:

The pork and ham meatballs: "I got magic and I got poetry in my fingertips."

The roasted cauliflower: "I am on a drug. If you try it once, you will die. Your face will melt off and your children will weep over your exploded body."

The calamari with oranges: "I'm bi-winning. I win here and I win there."

The whole trout: "Every day is just filled with just wins. All we do is put wins in the record books. We win so radically in our underwear before our first cup of coffee, it's scary."

The caramel flan with Blue Bottle coffee: "I'm proud of what I created. It was radical. I exposed people to magic. I exposed them to something they're never going to see in their boring normal lives."

The above were awesome. Other dishes from our feast (the chef's selection of seven dishes at $40/person plus a few others) included the sardine and avocado toast (good), fried potatoes (no Cha Cha Cha) and pork belly bocadillo (lacking a burst of flavor).

Loved the energetic, vibrant decor and buzz from the crowd. Service was nice if not overly memorable. Priced just about right with wine by the glass on the high side.

A very strong four stars, just a notch below five. Or as Charlie Sheen might say, almost winning.

Quotes courtesy of http://goo.gl/vHOv3
author: Jason B.

description:
Unbelievably good. Had probably the best Salmon of my life. 

Went with my wife, my brother-in-law is famous there and has been trying to get us to go for years. I see why now!

The sommeliers also know their shit.
author: JP F.

description:
I really love this place. More of a high-end, nose-in-the-air Spanish affair, but somehow I did not hate it. Both the tapas and wine were great, albeit a bit on the pricey side. The modern twist applied was quite nice, though I do have to say, if you want a Spanish mommy's cooking, I'd still go to Alegrias. 

Recommend going there through Savored.com, take the 30% off and suddenly, this restaurant gains another half star ;)
author: Fiona S.

description:
One of the better examples of a cozy, casual and delicious tapas spot in the Bay Area. The vibe is energetic yet comfortable. The seating leans towards bar stools or small tables - so perhaps better suited for date nights or as a place to meet up with a smaller group of friends. There is a patio area which looks like it would be gorgeous in the warmer months. 

The menu is well-prepared, interesting and consistent (although I did find certain items leaned a bit to the salty side). But for the most part, all of our food was very tasty and catered to a wide spectrum of preferences - from small plates and finger foods to larger, heartier dishes. They also offer a fairly broad wine list - including a nice selection of imported beers, authentic cavas and traditional sherries. 

A definite recommendation for anyone interested in exploring Spanish tapas with good energy in a great San Francisco neighborhood.
author: Gigi G.

description:
Went to Contigo this Saturday with my wife and had a great meal. The Albondigas meetballs, calamari stuffed with sausage and bacalao (salt cod) were really great and made us excited to go to Spain next year. The pamb tomaquet was OK  - nothing spectacular.n 

The bottle of wine we had was very good and was reasonably priced (as were many bottles on the list). 

Overall though, the bill was pretty steep - not somewhere you would go every week.
author: Mark L.

description:
Excellent tapas in a  lively atmosphere. The inside feels trendy and fun but not hipster.  The dishes aren't hit or miss--every one is well-thought out and well executed.  Good for dates and groups.  

My only complaint is that they schedule reservations too close together; I've frequently had to wait 10-15 minutes as the folks who're at the table that's ostensibly reserved for my party finish.
author: Jen R.

description:
Came here to celebrate new beginnings and was not disappointed.   Ambiance was laid-back and sophisticated.  The casual atmosphere and great lighting made me feel like I was in the chef's home.  

In terms of food, neither my friend or myself was in the mood for meat so we had our waiter pick out some great vegeterian tapas - could not have been more happy with what we got.  Typically Spanish food is very meat (Pork) heavy, but there are some great options on Contigo's menu for those who don't want to venture down that path. 

Go!
author: Aasim K.

description: Lively atmosphere, delicious food and great wine. Pan con tomate, chard, and cauliflower were favorites, as was the hot chocolate and churros. Not an expert with spanish wines- staff recommendations were spot on.
author: Andria B.

description: Came here for a weeknight dinner with some friends, had a wonderful experience. Service was friendly and attentive, and we were seated right away. Every dish was perfect. I recommend the pork shoulder! Everything was flavorful, fresh and served at the right temperature. We left satisfied, but not stuffed, at about $40 dollars a person.
author: Kyle S.

description: A friend and I tried the tasting menu.  Every item was absolutely delicious!  Of course,  we favored some dishes over others, but is was nice way to be introduced to the food at Contigo.  I will definitely be back.  The service was great,  the environment nice and most importantly, wonderful food!
author: mi m.

description:
Wonderful food, beautiful atmosphere, great service.  

Definitely try the cantabrian anchovy montadito, the wood oven roasted sardine and avocado toast, the croqueta de jamon iberico de bellota, and the baradad de bacalla.  The sight glass coffee caramel flam and the vanilla gelat with carlifornia olive ranch arberquina olive oil and sea salt were also amazing.
author: Kayla H.

description:
I picked up the wife from her hair stylist (Glamarama) and being late and not having much to eat that day, well... i was Mr. Cranky Pants.

also... driving in mission district traffic was not helping.

We park across the street no problem and they seat us at the Cava bar

Big daddy IPA on tap

36 month aged/acorn fed serrano ham (FUCKING ROCKS!)

fried goat cheese with strawberries and arugula and hazelnuts

oxtail croquette

patatas bravas

albandigas

churros con chocolate

all winners...

2 tables away, Traci des jardins is having dinner.

life is good...
author: erik H.

description:
Last night I asked my grandmother to have dinner with me.  She said, "I'll have dinner contigo".  

I've heard great things about this place, but haven't had the chance to visit until last night.  What a pleasant surprise!  

Simple, yet modern ambiance.  Open kitchen and small bar.  Granie and I dined in the outside (covered) patio, which enhanced our experience.  It was very well lit and warm.  The menu is short, yet comprised of plenty of options of delicious Spanish tapas that wow'd me.

Our meal started off with the dungeness crab croquetas..O.M.G!  Soooo good!!  Shaped like golf balls (maybe slightly larger), fried on the outside, and warm creamy crab on the inside.  Heavenly!

We ordered the beet salad, which was tasty, not the best I've ever had, but quite good.  The tangerine slices were a refreshing addition.

I'm not a huge fan of potatoes, but granie is, so we ordered the patatas bravas.  Spicy potato wedges with salsa and sour cream on top.  They were good, but not something I would order again.

My favorite tapa was the short ribs.  WHOA!!  So tender and juicy!  The meat was served over delicious whipped potatoes with toasted almonds and gravy.  Seriously a divine dish.  THIS IS A MUST HAVE!

All of my senses along with my appetite had been satisfied by my visit to Contigo.  I will definitely return.  Probably this weekend!  YUM!
author: Taña Marie R.

description: Went to this little gem with a few friends. We had all the tapas and they were ALL GOOD! My favorite was the flatbread and the albondigas. They do not have a full bar but plenty of good wines and beer:)
author: Adri H.

description:
First of all, I know my review is long overdue. But, I felt like I had to write it down anyway. I decided to try out Contigo because of it was a Michelin Bib Gourmand pick...basically, great food for an awesome bargain price. 

Overall, I really like the atmosphere. I think that our waiter was really great and he suggested some very tasty wines. It was a comfortable space, but after leaving the table the BF and I both agreed that there was nothing memorable.

Everything was executed well...just not...well, mind blowing. And even though it was supposed to be a "budget" price, if we had a choice we would have opted for another budget meal. The octopus dish that we had was a little heavy, and we could have done without the oxtail and beans. 

If you're looking for a cozy atmosphere and nice service - definitely give this place a shot. I would be interested in trying it out again, but would actually recommend any visitor hankering for Barcelona style tapas to head over to Bocadillos instead.
author: Shay F.

description:
Very impressed by this beautiful spot. We were recommended to this little haunt from a executive chef who I completely trust and wow! were we happy we asked him!

We were sat on the back patio - which was covered in heatlamps and tarps for the cold SF weather months - but was lush with all the herbs growing in the gardens around you.

Our waiter Raphael was perfect with his Madrid accent and very knowledgeable understanding of the wines & menus. He even gave us input on where regions where, why it made it special etc!  (+1 Bonus star for him!

We decided to try our hand at several of their dishes and didn't know where to start so we told our waiter that we were hungry and the ones we liked and allowed him to bring them out at his discretion as we were in no major rush.

Timing was well executed, and loved each and every dish with the small  exception of 2.

HUEVOS ESTRELLADOS - Loved the crunchy scrambled fried egg with txistorra sausage. Just the perfect amount of blend & flavor.

CALAMARAS A LA PLANXA - Wow! My husband had never tried Pimentos whole before and was so happy with the juxtaposition of squid & romesco sauce! Perfection!

ALBONDIGAS - Pork & Jamon Meatballs - DELICIOUS! More please!

LOCAL KING SALMON BAKED ON FIG LEAF - Salmon was very soft and tender under the Cava Butter and the green beans & Peas were cooked to the perfect moment with full flavor.

GAMBES A LA PLANXA - The jumbo prawns were huge, however the amount of work to get the shell off made it a bit annoying. Now I can myself a pretty good desheller of shrimp, however this was way too difficult for the satisfaction factor. The bed of sea salt made it flavorful and beautiful but I wish it would have been just a bit easier to enjoy the meat. (-1/2 Star)

PORK SHOULDER - Slow Roasted - Taste was a bit off, there was too much of a portion for a small plate, and the Pork itself had too much fattiness on it. Not our favorite. (-1/2 star)

We could have just shared 4 or 5 plates, but we wanted to try they all.


Dessert - FIG Tarte with Ginger Gelato was as I could only describe it after the first bite...as this dessert was making a memory! 

It was memorable, one of those desserts that you would always just remember with a good night, a great moment and the end to a fantastic meal. Kudo's to the chef & staff for a well enjoyed night out!
author: Danie G.

description:
I didn't know much about Contigo when I went there for dinner this past Saturday but I do love tapas and Catalan cuisine so I was definitely excited to go.  Sadly, I should have left my excitement at home.  To call Contigo a big disappointment is unfair so we'll just leave it at . . . disappointment.

When trying a new restaurant I like to experience as much of its cuisine as I can.  In that vein, my table and I opted for the chef's tasting menu.  For $40 per person we purportedly got the seven best dishes of the night.  If we ate the top seven, I feel bad for other patrons who ate the dishes in the bottom seventy-five percent of the menu.  I will say though that $40 per person for a comprehensive tasting menu is a good deal.

Our meal started out with the arugula and strawberry salad.  The salad was balanced and tasty if you got all of the ingredients in your mouth in one bite.  If you didn't, the salad was unbalanced, a bit tart, and the strawberry flavor was misplaced.  In a continuing theme throughout the evening, or next course, the Monterey sardine on avocado toast, was brought out before we had finished our prior course (this happened with every single course).  The Monterey sardines were good if you like salty fish (which I do).  Our next dish was the beet salad which was nothing special.  The beets could have been roasted and pickled a bit more (a la Chez Panisse).   

Next, we were served the Calamari with squid ink rice.  The Calamari was good but lacked a "wow" factor.  Following the squid was the Albondigas (pork meatballs).  These were dry and bland.  How you screw up Albondigas is beyond me but then again Contigo messed up Patatas Bravas (more on that later).  

Our next course was the seared halibut which was overcooked and dry.  The sauce served with it was good but the errors in cooking the fish ruined the dish.  By this point in time our table was pretty full.  We'd had salads and we'd had proteins . . . yet strangely enough, it was at this point in time that the chef thought it was a good idea to cap our meal with a big plate of sauteed greens.  Needless to say, given that they weren't very good, all the table did was pick at it.

One of the patrons in my party, being informed that the patatas bravas was not part of our seven course meal, ordered it separately as she is a huge fan.  Unfortunately, she regretted her additional order.  The patatas bravas were cooked poorly (didn't really get the crispy exterior) and were served with an aioli more similar to sour cream and a bland romesco sauce.  Needless to say, neither she nor I was pleased with the dish.

For all you Yelpers who don't live in Noe Valley, you aren't missing anything if you don't make it to Contigo.  And for all you Yelpers who do live in Noe Valley, I'm sorry that Contigo is taking up valuable restaurant real estate in your neighborhood.
author: Oski B.

description: San frans, you should try this place and the amazing wine!
author: Kevser T.

description:
Food 2.5 stars

I really wanted to like Contigo, but I left without that satisfied feeling from a place that leaves you full and happy. The service was impeccable, but the prices were high, and 2 raciones per person + a coupla bites were not quite enough to fill our bellies, but was plenty to empty our wallets. Most of the dishes were quite tasty, but portions were small. I'd rather go to the Mission for a place with a larger menu selection. 

This place is great if you want Noe ambiance and have a smaller party (since the menu only had about a dozen options).
author: christine l.

description:
Very authentic, good staff, good price, nicely designed space, food is spot on.

Will be back.
author: Raul D.

description: This is a good example of how service can really influence a restaurant experience.  Ours was quite good - in addition to being nice as could be, every recommendation he made (on the wine and several of the vegetarian choices) panned out.  Although we had a mix of meat, fish and vegetables, the vegetable dishes are what really stood out: they were all quite good but the potato dishes were the best in my view.
author: S M.

description:
Parking was easy to find (we had an early Saturday reservation). 

We were seated right away (place was half empty at the time). 

We spent approx. $100 per person including kids. You'd expect a better attitude from the staff if you spent that kind of money at this kind of restaurant ... but once we paid the bill the hostess and waiters started making circles around our table showing they wanted us to leave ASAP, then in a couple of minutes one of the waiters came to our table saying something like "thank you for coming, come again" obviously meaning "you've paid your bill and now we want you to leave". 

And now - the food. It was mediocre, not bad and not something special (as correctly pointed out one of the reviewers you could get this kind of food at a local Whole Foods buffet). Size of all portions ... like for little babies. First we ordered sampler ($40 per person, 7 tiny micro dishes per person), well they were so tiny that even kids complained they were still hungry, then we ordered more - again very small portions although little bigger then 7-course samplers, same size of tiny micro-baby-burgers though (diameter of a large overcoat button). We've been to Spain and we know Spanish cuisine, well this food is not exactly Spanish cuisine, a Californian version of Spanish food, twice smaller portion.

Wine is just okay, nothing special except the prices, nothing from Spain you cannot find at a local Safeway or a local Lucky's. 
Watch out for what they bring because one of our guests ordered a glass of quite expensive dessert wine which he didn't get, instead a guy faking Spanish accent brought a glass of some kind of Porto which was obvious, but no apologies, just kept insisting it was the wine that was ordered even though our guest is a wine expert, so he would know the difference. 

Dessert - just okay, nothing spectacular. Oh, wait. They brought anchovies we ordered earlier (and forgot about) at the same time they brought the dessert, quite a touch, isn't it.

The bottom line - never again. The food is mediocre. The place is extremely overpriced given the food quality and portions sizes. The service is just a bit below average and the place is somewhat cramped.
author: John C.

description:
Maybe I'm a sucker for tapas-style dining since I can try way more deliciousness in one sitting. 

Or maybe it's cause I went here on a foggy SF night, and when I walked in, it reminded me of the delightfully warm beaches of Barcelona. 

Or maybe it's the fact that they have Jamon Iberico de Bellota. Ok yeah, that's it.
