Seriously, where else can you get this stuff? They gotta start serving in not-so-fancy places cause I feel like an asshat when I'm sitting there drooling over my beloved pork goodness while the couple next to me is trying to profess their love for each other.

Everything else was tasty as well. 
- sardines - just yummy. but i like sardines.
- cana de oveja cheese a la planxa - single-handedly responsible for my lovefest with the hazelnut/arugula combo 
- coca with wild nettles and bacon - yummy pork fat tamed by the earthiness of the nettles? yes, please!
- albondigas - the tomato-sherry sauce is delish

But, dear Jamon Iberico de Bellota, nothing compares 2 u.
author: Monica C.

description:
My mouth is still quivering with the ecstasy of their sardines on toast with avocado and carmelized onions. Yeah man... 

Last night we dined from the small plates of the gods and it was good people! 

So you say you're a fan of tapas and that Cha Cha Cha is your favorite, well expand your horizons, come here and taste something far more authentic with fabulous variety and a wonderful wine selection.

In addition to the aforementioned sardine on toast I could also recommend the ever popular patatas brava, the oxtail croquettes whith pine nuts and this screaming good pork belly on grilled small roll with spicy chips made of deep fried cured meat... Insane huh? You hungry yet?

Salad was nice, the zucchini salad that is. The olive plate with pickled carrots and cauliflower was tasty and the deserts divine. The churros with a cup of chocolate sauce, did you actually think you were not going to like that? 

Major points for serving small individual presses of blue bottle coffee, the crack of all coffee... I'm really looking forward to going back... mmmm mmmm mmmm oh yeah... get there early cause it gets filled fast...
author: Len S.

description:
I had been meaning to check out this place for a long time. when we tried to make a reservation around 5:30 which is the time they open, we couldn't get any until 8:30 and it wasnt an option. so instead, I called them to see if it'd be okay to walk in around 5:30 and the person reluctantly said yes. when we got there, we were told we have the table until 7. I guess they had the right to tell us this, but i elt a little uncomfortable.

anyways, now for the business-

we tried their tasting menu (40$/person), it was very yummy. it came with 1 or 2 small sized tapas and other larger items. 

my favorites were the black cod and the pork belly sliders.

they were cooked and seasoned to perfection. 

the only thing I would say about the course is that the order of the plates was a bit questionable. we thought that pork belly should have been on the appetizer side rather than after the "entrees" as it was very delicious and a little heavy at the same time; by the time we got to try it, we were already full.

the overall experience was very satisfying!

would be happy to try it again!
author: Sung C.

description:
The food? Good at best, below average if I'm being totally honest. I wanted to like this place but I've had way better tapas with much better service elsewhere. 

We had to wait 45 minutes past our reservation which had us dining at almost 10 p.m. After a day of packing and flying into the city, the last thing I wanted was to be eating that late. It was also quite unfair for our friends who had driven in from San Jose to meet us at the restaurant. The staff kept apologizing and telling us the people at the table reserved for us weren't getting up and assured us that we would be "taken care of," whatever that meant. 

I know it's fine line when restaurants have reservations lined up and a table won't leave. It can be a delicate situation but what bothered me about the way Contigo handled it was they made empty promises of us being "taken care of" and their inconsistency in dealing with these matters. We had to wait for our table because the restaurant couldn't/wouldn't ask the people to leave but we heard from two other friends who had dined there on separate occasions that they were asked to leave when they weren't ready to go because there were people "waiting" for their table. 

As far as being "taken care of" we received a complimentary dish of Pa amb tomàquet but that was pretty much it. When we received our bill, every single dish and drink was accounted for. Not that we were expecting them to comp our entire meal or anything but after waiting that long for our table and the sub par food we had, the whole experience really didn't seem worth it.
author: Bora K.

description:
I have been to Contigo three times now, and really enjoy it because it is within walking distance from my house and the food is very good.  Traditional tapas style plates from the Catalan region of Spain are their staple, and they are excellent.  The service is good and the ambiance is very nice.

What is lacking is their drink menu.  They have a nice selection of Spanish wines from regions known for their vineyards...lots from La Rioja.  Unfortunately, that is about it.  They have no liquor license, which is not uncommon in this city, although nevertheless disappointing.  The least a restaurant can do is make up for this shortcoming with other great beer options and maybe some sangria.  Plus, they could take advantage of the Spanish edge they're going for to serve claras, tintos de verano, and calimocho...albeit that would be far more Andalucian than Catalan ;) 

We tried their sidra...which in Spain is typically from Asturias, and actually quite good, even though I am not normally a fan of cider.  This sidra was from Chapel Hill, North Carolina and it was not good at all...flavorless and kind of gross, not to mention 12 bucks, and totally not worth it.  They only have two other non-wine options: a pilsner and an IPA.  And their pilsner was all tapped out.

If you have been to Spain it is very possible you have only had Mahou or Cruz Campo, and know that neither is much better than a Bud.  However, La Alhambra, a brewery in Granada makes 1925, a pilsner style lager and La Mezquita, a stronger malty beer with over 6% alcohol content.  I'm not saying they should pay the prices to import these beers from Spain, but they could certainly offer a more extensive selection without compromising their authenticity...if that's what they are striving to maintain.  

I will definitely continue to enjoy eating at this restaurant, and hope they acquire a liquor license and improve their beer selection.
author: Leah R.

description:
We had reservations for 8:15pm on a Friday night.  We got there on time, maybe a little early, and there was a line of people inside along the wall in front of the hostess stand.  We made our way up to the front and checked in with the hostess who told us the people at our table were paying their bill and it would be a couple of minutes.  So, we joined the line of people along the wall as we waited.

The couple of minutes extended to about 20 minutes.  I usually eat dinner at 6pm.  8:15pm is already late for me to eat.  So I was totally starving by the time we were seated.  However, I did like where we were seated.  Our table was all the way in the back next to the window to the outdoor patio.  Not in the outdoor patio.  Inside, next to the outdoor patio.  I liked it.

The restaurant is tapas style, so each dish is not very big.

We started with the small sized Jamon Iberico de Bellota.  It was really a small portion.  The ham was good and it came with little pieces of toast.  We also had the Patatas Bravas and the Tripe with chorizo and chickpeas.  I think we also ordered something else with fried eggs over potatoes.  They were all tasty, but nothing over the top.  I found it a very average eating experience.

We didn't finish until about 10:30pm, so it was quite a long meal for not too much food.

The bill for the three of us was about $35/each person.  Not too bad, but I probably could've eaten more.
author: Kris L.

description:
I have been looking forward to visiting Contigo for a year!  Ever since I discovered and started following the chef's blog - "In Praise of Sardines" (http://inpraiseofsardines.com/).  After weeks of trying to get my friends over to contigo from the East Bay, I treated myself between Frameline Film Festival presentations on Saturday night and boy was I happy!

Brett promised there are vegan options nightly among the flatbread specials - but I couldn't get past the small plates and ordered four:  olives & almonds, a delicious arugula & zucchini salad, patatas bravas and Catalan style spinach with a glass of Portuguese sparkling wine at the Cava bar.

The food was fantastic and the restaurant is just beautiful and elegant - the photos do not do it justice!  I'm looking forward to going back with friends to try more items on the menu - thanks for all your hard work, Brett!
author: Jenn C.

description:
There's been such a buzz about Contigo, we highly recommend making reservations like we did. 

Got seated promptly and were dazzled by the traditional Spanish dishes.
And started things off right with several glasses of Cava.

Way too many dishes to list, but my favorites were the Pa amb tomaquet, Anchoas and Arugula salad to start.
And with the other selections we had the two tripe dishes. Amazingly delicious. Especially the tripe with chorizo and chickpeas. 

The wine selection is superb. Traditional Spanish wines, and our waiter was very helpful in steering us towards the best choices.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Mickey A.

description: It reminded me of my dining experiences in Madrid. Great vibe and service.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Very overpriced. The portions are TINY and expensive. The server recommended that if we want to share we just order a bunch of small/medium plates, but otherwise the more expensive plates ($27) should be enough for one person as an entry. Yeah... we ordered a bunch of small plates to share AND ordered the more expensive plates.... and then ordered more small plates and still left hungry. The more expensive plates are definitely not enough for a one person entry. And the food wasn't even great, nothing to write home about.

At some point, we decided its time to stop throwing money at them for bringing us tiny little portions and just go home hungry and unsatisfied. Very overrated restaurant.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description:
Great place to get some classic, as well as unusual tapas.

We started with the Wood Oven Roasted Monterey Sardine and Avocado Toast.  Good balance of flavors between the fishiness of the sardines and the creaminess of the avocado.  

We also got the Jamon Iberico.  High quality and a great way to start the meal.

The Sauteed Greens Catalan Style includes a slightly bitter chard which is balanced with the sweetness of raisins and almonds.  

The Calamars a la Planxa is calamari of course on a bed of squid ink rice.  Reminded us of Barcelona.

If you've never had Tripe before, the Tripe with Chorizo and Chickpeas is a good dish to try it for the first time.  

The place is kind of small, so be sure to make reservations.
author: Brent S.

description: It was OK.  We generally enjoy the food but the service was not up to par.  Very slow and verging on arrogant.  We wanted desert but decided against it as a) no one came for so long to ask us and b) even if we had have been asked, judging on length of time it took to get the rest of the food, we didn't want to wait that long...we won't go back.    The Patatas Bravas was not near spicy enough for this dish..
author: Jenny G.

description:
If price weren't a consideration, I'd say the food was ok to good.  However, given the prices, I was underwhelmed by the food.

More importantly for this review, though, was the absurd time it took for the restaurant to serve us the food we ordered.  I was in a group of 6 people who placed orders around 8:10 pm on a Wed. night.  It took them over an hour and a half to deliver the last of the orders we placed, even after our request (around the hour mark) that our orders be sped up.  Admittedly, Contigo is a "tapas" restaurant and because of that, we were ok with the food being delivered in a staggered manner.  However, one hour and half is way too long for the last of our orders to be delivered.  To be clear, the restaurant was pretty busy at the time we placed our orders but I would expect any serious restaurant to anticipate spikes in activity around that hour and to manage those spikes accordingly.  The restaurant offered us two complimentary desserts to make up for their delay in serving us our food, but everyone in my party felt like that offer was too little too late.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Excellent service. Good wine selection.
Must haves include the meatballs (albondigas), jamon, patates braves.
author: Ashvin V.

description:
I wanted to like Contigo. It was written up in one of the local mags.  I love tapas. I like the name.  So I asked my man to take me there for my birthday.
The ambience is spot-on; gorgeous wood tables, mason jars, everything looked sleek with a touch of granola. Cozy seating where you almost are beside your neighbor.  Great for a date. Totally San Francisco the way I like it. All of the stars go to this element alone.
Sadly, the food was so bland. The corn dish was ordinary.  The pork bellies were literally a bite and a half in puffy bread. People rave about that belly, but I've had plenty of wonderful pork belly in my life, and this aint it.  Everything else was even more forgettable.
author: teray g.

description: I actually like Contigo a lot. I've been there several times since its in my neighborhood. I always enjoy the ambiance, drinks and food. But tonight I met there with 3 friends and was pretty bitterly disappointed by the service. In short, we were there for a little over two hours and were talking for about 10 minutes after we got the check when the hostess came over and politely asked us to hurry up and leave. I don't consider two hours an overly long dinner, nor have I ever been asked to hurry up before at a restaurant. I was very surprised, taken aback and, as I said, disappointed. Also, they sat us in the enclosed patio where, despite heat lamps, it was freezing cold half the time. We were all very cold and had our coats on. Patio is awesome in the other three seasons, not so much in the winter! Overall, an old standby made me kind of sad tonight.
author: Mstar P.

description: I recently celebrated my birthday in their private dining space, the outdoor patio/garden in the back of the restaurant. The area was perfect for our 22 person group. When we arrived at the spot, we were cheerfully greeted by one of the owners who had help me put the menu together. She also assisted me with the wine pairings, kicking the night off with nice bottles of cava and sangrias for those who wanted something sweeter. Everyone left that night raving about the food and the service. Highlights for me: the seasonal salad, the oxtail sliders and flatbread with squash blossoms. We had a few vegetarians and food allergies which they accommodated quite nicely. One of our friends was like "Yeah, I'm a vegetarian for the attention." Really though, the service was spot on. Only one server for our party and she didn't miss a beat. The inside of the restaurant is quaint and charming. I look forward to my return to try more of their thoughtfully prepared dishes. Hope to see you there.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Contigo gets a solid 4 stars!  This is a fairly new restaurant in Noe Valley (5 months or so old) -- upon meeting my friend, I neglected to write down the address.  I must've asked 5-6 people who lived in the area where it was, and they didn't know where Contigo was yet.  A friendly homeless woman of all the people I asked knew exactly where it was!  ;D  Thank you!  

They take reservations if your party is over 6 people only so my friend and I made sure to meet early enough to beat the dinner crowd.  We had nice seats by the window and it was a warmish San Francisco night - so it was perfect!  

I had a glass of Spanish wine - yum!  And we started out with lightly fried (kind of like tempura batter) eggplant dipped in a bell peppery sauce - thumbs up!  Then we had albacore belly over sea beans - thumbs up too!  Next, we had the lamb over cous cous and vegetables - this was our favorite!  So flavorful and tender!  

We shared a strawberry dessert called "Dirty Girl Strawberry" something or other that was served over a melt-in-your-mouth cookie - heaven!  

Over the course of our tasty meal with excellent service, we caught up on our girly chat.  Good times!  I'd definitely come back!!

Dinner+one glass of wine+tax+tip = $48
author: Maile N.

description: great for sharing. i really enjoyed sampling a variety of the menu. of what we had i particularly enjoyed the seared goat cheese with arugula, figs and hazelnuts, the oxtail sliders and the coffee flan. most people would opt for the churros for dessert (we got both) which come with a thiiiiiick chocolate meant for sippin and dippin, but the coffee flan was the winner as it was surprisingly verrry coffee in flavor.
author: Regina C.

description:
Deven provided fabulous service and the food was just good.  We always have a great time here thanks!

The "loud" rating is only because of large groups that have been there recently when we have, but it is not unbearable.
author: Kasi S.

description: Nice atmosphere (tables are a bit close though), extensive Spanish wine list (red & white), knowledgeable staff, delicious food with a roatating menu. Oh and thier bread is delicious!! I have been here twice now; once with a friend, and once with my mother. Both times were equally pleasent. There is also a small patio for al fresco dining.
author: Kelli G.

description: Last weekend, I took my boyfriend up to SF to mingle with my folks - we ventured out for dinner the first night in town and were pleasantly surprised by how effing amazing Contigo was!  From the chic ambiance to the friendly wait-staff and right on down to their amazing selection of Tapas and Wine, Contigo is should be on everyones "Must-Eat" list.  We started off with my first anchovies ever and a light and savory salad; slowly but surely, we made our way to some lamb chops and squid.  Every bite was amazing and left you wanting more - pretty much exactly what a great Tapas place does, right?  I will definitely be coming back to enjoy everything their exotic menu has to offer (and hopefully, I'll get a chance to enjoy the outdoor seating area - it was adorable!
author: Amanda G.

description: I LOVE tapas, I LOVE Contigo. I've eaten here four times, and the food is always amazing. The first time we went we had a large party and we sat at one of the long tables outside. We were probably there at least two hours and I'm pretty sure we ate everything on the menu. The wine selection is also quite good. Make a reservation, you won't be sorry. Mmmm risotto balls!
author: Staci B.

description: Everything on the menu is so tasty you can't go wrong with anything and they have a great wine selection to pair with their food.
author: Mary W.

description:
I have heard about this place from my neighbors for month. Dropped in without reservations, last minute with a friend visiting from the UK and SO happy we did. The place is scrumptious!!!

Gorgeous tapas.

Wonderful start with olives/almonds. Lovely sauteed greens. Beautiful cauliflower cooked to perfection. Shared a lovely halibut. Recommended glass of Rioja brought it all together.

Mmmmmmmm - highly recommend.
author: Mark M.

description:
In a newly renovated contemporary space, Contigo brings a little of Barcelona to Noe Valley.  

The menu starts with a selection of "pica-pica" (appetizers), including salads, patatas bravas, fried smelt, squid a la plancha, oxtail croquetas, and chard and beet greens with garbanzos. There is a selection of jamóns (including the muy expensive jamón Ibérico de Bellota) as well as some entree-sized dishes, including Catalan flatbread and fisherman's stew.  The reasonably priced wine list is mainly Spanish with some Portuguese thrown in for good measure, and it includes quite a few wines by the glass or carafe.

The wait staff are still working out the kinks (a little slow on picking up used plates), and the kitchen is not quite hitting on all cylinders (ordered items appeared somewhat sporadically and they sent out a sand dab entree that was woefully under-cooked), but both the vibe and the food are good.

With a line leading out the door, Contigo is good and certainly popular, but personally I will take my dinero to Laiola for Spanish tapas.
author: CJ G.

description: Contigo is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. My Spanish husband has also given it the seal of approval! We've been there multiple times and have never been disappointed. Our favorite dishes include the patatas bravas, sauteed greens Catalan style, pan con tomate, fig salad, and flatbread. The ambiance is great, especially if you can get a table on their terrace in the back. I've always been very happy with the service there, too.
author: Julia B.

description: While each of the dishes of the tasting menu was tasty, I think the $46 per person was way overpriced given what was served. The potatoes were good but Plow serves far better potatoes as a side dish to their breakfast menu. The paella was spiced well but very skimpy on the shrimp and seafood given that there were three of us and we each ordered the tasting menu, The little gem salad again was fresh and tasty but the size was barely adequate for 2 people,  not 3.  We appreciated the sourcing of the menu from farms at the Ferry Building Farmers' Market and really enjoyed the freshness. However, I really think this is a great place for someone who  thinks the food isn't good unless it's overpriced. We are not budget shoppers and have no problem paying for high quality, but this restaurant sadly tries to pass skimpiness off in a "small dish" format. In addition, we really felt rushed. Because we paused between the main meal and deciding on dessert, the waiters, hostess and others kept coming by to ask "is everything alright?" implying that we should get moving. because they had already cleared the table. There were a few empty tables around us so we were not holding up a big crowd. I was hoping to find another nice neighborhood place, but sadly, I don't think this is it.
author: junona j.

description:
The sardine toast was heavenly: perfect mix of salty, smoky, crunchy.  I had to order a second one.
Flatbread w/ nettles - delicious, though the nettles didn't add much.
Tripe stew w/ chickpeas - tasty and filling.
Fried eggs with potatoes - sounded boring (not my choice) but was delicious.
Albondigas were unexceptional.
Churros with chocolate were disappointing: the chocolate needed to be thicker, and the churros less salty.  The same dish at Lolinda is better.

Overall, excellent food, and I'll return for that sardine toast and to try other dishes.
author: Sumomo O.

description:
Consistent with a few other reviews, Contigo is a restaurant that offer some good and average/below average dishes.  Noise level can be good at the patio but is dependent on who is sitting at the next table. Service was friendly and prompt.

3.5 to 4 star food:
-wood oven-roasted local sardine and avocado toast
-croqueta de jamon serrano
-jamon iberico de bellota
Monterey xipirons a la planxa (x is pronounced ch)

3 star food or less:
-Gilda
-charred asparagus
-albondigas
-tripe with chorizo and chickpeas

For my experience, this is a 3.5 star rating wherein it is good to try once but may not be compelling enough to go back.
author: Rx C.

description:
I'll be honest.  Contigo would be a four star place but for the salt.  Oh!  The salt!  Everything was oversalted.  Not sure if that's typical or we had a salty cook in the kitchen the night we visited.  It snuck up on us, for sure.  We realized it was highly seasoned, but on the walk home, I consulted with my co-diners.  I thought it was just me, but they encountered the salt lick situation as well.

We were really bummed out that the sardines were sold out for the night.  But, no biggie.  The flat bread was tasty, the halibut was cooked perfectly.   The two salads that we had were really good, dressed to perfection and great combinations of flavors.  

The servers were all really nice and helpful with the menu and other suggestions.  

The weak point for me was dessert, we ordered the churros and chocolate.  Both were adequate, but not earth shattering.  

We ordered 2 salads, 1 flatbread, 1 small plate and 2 large plates and one dessert to share among the three of us.  We also enjoyed a glass of wine/cava each.  The bill was a very reasonable $117 before tip.  

I'd like to go back in hopes of a non-salty adventure.
author: Gayle G.

description: First visit here, had great food and service. Getting a table on a Sunday evening was easy. A featured dessert, a coffee caramel flam (flan), was outstanding. -- best flan I've ever tasted. If you're visiting from out of town, take a Muni subway to Castro station, and then the #24 bus south on Castro. It's about a mile from Market St.
author: Craig R.

description: This was one of the most disappointing meals I've had in a while.  I ate here for NYE it was $75 per person for mediocre food!  It was advertised as a "6 course meal". But really it was a trio of hors d'oeuvres, crab salad, entree and dessert.  We still left hungry too.  Not worth it.
author: hannah t.

description:
Great tapas and great wine list in mod settings. Our party of three ordered just the right amount of small plates, and the service and recommendations were fantastic. We had reservations, and, since the place was pretty full the whole time we were there, it's probably a good idea to have 'em.

The noms: padron peppers, arugula salad taken over the top with Medjool dates, albondigas, pa amb tomaquet (Catalan appetizer of bread, tomato, and olive oil), and a summer squash flatbread (coca). Our favorite and most expensive (coincidence?) item was pata negra, the damned tastiest pork I've had in a while. Paprika-rubbed loin! 

Dessert: hot chocolate (not the drink, but actually hot, melted chocolate) with churros. I had this in Madrid and it tasted and was served just the same.

The little plates, plus glasses of Cava to start, and a bottle of Rioja for dinner-dinner, came out to ~$60 per person.
author: Tara R.

description:
A note on their reservation policy. At 7pm on a holiday weekend, we should not expect a table to be waiting for us and do not ..but, three of their 10 or so walk in stools were open. Our hopes began to rise.. " Can we sit here?" we ask the hostess.   NO. "We are holding them for a couple who called." How nice. It's good to be nice.  My suggestion to Contigo is that if you are way popular and way small (all of which is the case here) and you only  have 10 or so spots for neighborhood walk-ins... then keep them from the walk ins.  
So, now you all know the little secret....call ahead 15 minutes for these cute counter seats, ask for Samayijah.
author: Robert B.

description:
I have been there on friday night, and even if i had reservation, i waited for at least 25 minutes standing infront of chef and analyzing all plates of menu he made in the while. (good strategy before ordering!).
once seated in, we had several plates and they were all perfect! someone was amazing like chicken en adobo and sardins toasted bread.

staff was co cute and friendly, even if sometimes they forgot to close door and we felt cold, but just for few minutes. :-)

average of prices is honest, probably some plate is a bit expensive considering the quantity of food, but the quality is so high!

if i'd like to come back? OF COURSE.
author: Davide milidolo R.

description:
I was surprised to find that you need to make reservations to eat here on a Wednesday night! It's kinda out there, off the main strip of 24th...I guess it's the only decent place to eat in the hood.

Inside, the decor is your typical mission hipster does fancy modern open kitchen reclaimed wood super dim bathroom etc. Very nice. It is however very crowded and very loud. We sat on the back patio, which in my opinion is more pleasant than the inside -- entirely enclosed with clear plastic tent roofing, heat lamps and chard growing in planters. 

The food was tasty, but not enough to justify the price. Loved the calamari salad, but it was the kind of dish that left you mentally calculating the dollar value of each tiny tentacle ~ $1.75/piece in my estimation.

I know, it's tapas. But rather than encouraging sharing among your group of friends, this place will have you fighting over paltry slivers of anchovies. *Sigh* I'll probably be back, but next time I'll bring my waify, eating disorder friends.
author: Lauren H.

description: very nice little place in Noe. The back is pretty fun since it is very cozy and has a little herb/vegetable garden. food is made with care and I recommend the tasting menu, the portions are good and you get to sample a great variety.  definitely a neighborhood favorite.
author: Charles L.

description:
This review should be 5 stars for the service! I went in to Contigo early on a Wednesday evening to grab a couple of tapas and a glass of wine with a friend. The server that we had was awesome! He was this adorable Spanish man complete with Euro-mullet and mustache - he knew all about the wine selection, the Iberico ham, and was super friendly! 

We had the Patatas Bravas, of which I am a sort of connoisseur! The taters were very well done although I wished that the sofrito sauce had more of a kick to it, and they could have been a tiny bit crispier.

My friend had the Croquetas de Jamon, which she adored! 

So why only 3 stars? Because there was a woman (hostess? owner?) in a nice springy dress standing by the door who started glaring at us after we had only been sitting for 30 minutes! I know that look as a member of the service industry myself and it says "get out! you are not spending enough money to occupy that table for any longer" - We ordered food AND wine, arrived early to avoid the dinner rush, and were seated at a tiny 2-top table adjacent to the bar (not the most desirable although we were fine with it), and then forced out with nasty looks.

Again, the food was delicious and the service charming but the owners need to find a better balance between turning over the tables quickly enough and turning away business by glaring at their guests!
author: Emma B.

description:
Food is quite good. A few recommendation if you want to pick chef's tasting menu ($40 per person):
- Make sure you have the arroz negro (with squid and chorizo). I had it twice, the second time I had it was not as good because the rice was too soft, but the flavor is good nonetheless.
- Make sure you have the cod
- Croquetas de jamon (it really is very very good)
- Albondigas (the meatballs are really good)
- Salad, the version with pomegranate, persimmon and hazelnut chunks (not the beets salad!)
- Make sure not to have the chicken skewer (it's fine but you can get that anywhere else)

They also have  a very friendly wait staff!
author: T H.

description:
Jaw-droppingly tasty food. If you're going to cheat on your diet, this is the place to do it.

The artisanal hams are not to be missed, but be sure to also try the tripe with chickpeas. And the fried chicken. And the oxtail-stuffed peppers. And everything else on the menu.

Contigo used to have a no-reservations policy (except for groups of 6 or more), but recently (FINALLY!) started taking reservations for parties of all sizes. You no longer have any excuse not to eat here.
author: Henry F.

description:
I'm pretty embarrassed for our group of 4. When the server says "I'm impressed" about the amount of food you have consumed, and assumes that you don't even want to see the dessert menu (which we did), you know you have done some serious work. 

The first thing you will notice is how cool the space is. Not just the decor, but the creative use of the space, like the fact the refrigerator is actually the back wall. 

Our server was great, the Spanish wines he recommended were spot-on, but the food was really the standout. 

The grilled sardines, over avocado on crispy toast was superb. The pork and jamon meatballs were so delicious we had to order more. I loved the flavor combination of the olives/almonds/pickled veggies dish. The brussel sprout sauteed leaf dish (with hazelnuts & fried capers) was really unusual, but worked well. We threw all the add-ons onto the flatbread and were not disappointed. And the last stand-out (as if that isn't enough?!) was the black cod dish, which was delicious. The squash puree with other goodies was good enough to cause fork battles between the 4 of us. 

It seems absurd to not give the meal 5 stars after that description, but there were a few dishes that were forgettable. We had a ceviche dish which was not very good, and I have to be honest, I didn't really get the expensive pile of shaved "jamon". For $29, to have a small pile of shaved, cured ham, served with plain, ungrilled bread, seemed...odd. It didn't do it for me at all. Maybe my ham palette is not developed enough at this point.... (/sarcasm) 

Other than that, the meal was absolutely fantastic. I can't wait to go back, and have a feeling on subsequent trips, I may change this to 5 stars.
author: Andrew M.

description: Really extraordinary. Service was amazing and the food was fantastic.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Whine about wine!
The saying goes that billionaires only look at the left side of a wine list, if you are a middle class person like me; you look at the right side, see which prices are in your affordable range, then look left and see if it's a wine you like. My wine affordability is about $50-$60 maximum. My dilemma is that I recently started dating a really nice girl and she only drinks white wine, while I mostly only drink red. I know we should dump each other and get our money back from EHarmony, how could they a match red wine person with a white wine person.  Everything else is in harmony so we will soldier on with this difficult relationship. Okay back to my whine.  Now that we have to order wine by the glass, I noticed how many different restaurants measure the amount they serve in a typical glass of wine.  A bottle of wine holds 750ml, most bars and restaurants serve four glasses of 175ml per bottle (the other 5ml for testing the wine by you or the Sommelier).  Restaurants are in the business to make a profit and the mark up on wine sometimes seems excessive, but rents in San Francisco are not cheap and they have to pay all the overheads etc. so a bottle of wine that retails in your local supermarket for $15 is now $60 in a restaurant.  Okay I agree with mark up, BUT what I don't agree with is the stingy restaurants that pour 125ml glasses of wine instead of the usual 175ml, and thus get six glasses out of a bottle instead of the usual four.  We had a fantastic dinner at Contigo, but they are one of the "Stingy" restaurants and serve 125ml of wine per glass. So we have decided never to return to a "Stingy" restaurant.
author: Peter H.

description:
my birthday dinner from my amazing bf. i told him tapas style would be my choice. i wanted to be able to taste lots, and boy did we..15 dishes later = stuffed & happy!!
must haves: national snack Pa amb tomaquet, lomo iberico de bellota "pata negra", prawns, summer corn w/ chanterelle, chard, oven roasted sardine w/ avocado toasts.. these were my top top favorites. 

other delicious dishes: jamon iberico de bellota "pata negra", little gem salad, tombet (needed a dash of salt), albondigas (perfect balanced lamb and spices), tripe, coca flatbread w/ wild nettles

not on my list to get again: riblets- nothing special about them, little meat. patatas bravas- ragu had a nice smokiness and some strange allioli on them, sauce didn't seem to go with potatoes. dessert- churros- chocolate sauce was lovely but the churros were hard and dried. 

looking at the dessert menu we instantly said to each other "chef here, but no pastry chef". nothing popped out that said wow let's try this!

i mean out of 15 dishes and two not into and one eh, thats amazing. 
we really enjoyed it here, our server took care of us, wine choice that was perfect Arzuaga- dry and fruity, slightly chilled. we had a bottle of Cava in the beginning but can't remember which. 

national snack and the prawns were seriously perfect. THOSE are definitely a must have everytime you come.
author: Abigail W.

description: Did the Paella Tuesday Tasting Menu, and everything was fabulous-- flavors colorful and well-paired. The restaurant has a laid-back atmosphere with a kick of class. It was nice for a date night. The staff was very friendly and attentive. We sat on the back patio and enjoyed the whole experience.
author: Kat T.

description:
Once upon a late-night, I was waiting for the bus at 24th and Castro when I spotted a very modern and pleasant, wood-and-green-lettering sign for a restaurant called "Contigo." Instantly intrigued, I made a mental note to return (which I did two Fridays later).

Design: I mention the sign because it encapsulates Contigo perfectly: the restaurant is a little rustic, modern without being pretentious, no-frills, soothing. You'll wind up sitting very close to your neighbors -- very NYC-esque in that regard. 

Cuisine - what's awesome: Brussel sprouts, crab salad, meatballs. Dining there in December gave us the rare opportunity to try LATKES. So good! Between two people, you may want to order, say, 5 dishes to share. Menu changes daily (read: go back for new tastes!).

Cuisine - special note: Unless you're gaga for typically "blech"-inducing dishes like sardines and anchovies, you'll need to check your gustatory inhibitions at the door. Contigo could make a root canal taste good.

Booze: No hard stuff, just beer and wine. But they have a lovely, curated collection of both.

Service: Loved our waiter. We all but invited him to dine with us. Cool guy without being a "cool guy."

When to go: Contigo is perfect for a Friday night date, even on one of those Friday nights when you just want to do the post-work week flop. Take friends who you like talking to.

I can't wait for Contigo take two. So very recommended!
author: Mary v.

description:
I'd give it 3 1/2 stars, if I could, but it so easily could have been 5!  

Once we got past the self-important maitre'd who chided me for not making reservations (they didn't take reservations the last time I tried to eat there), it was a rather nice dining experience.  I don't like to be greeted with an attitude that suggests I should feel honored that they let me through the door (as had also happened last time).  

We were seated outside in an enclosed patio, which was a bit too warm even on a cool San Francisco evening.  Just the same, the setting was cozy but still comfortable.  Our server was lovely, attentive and knowledgeable.  

Appetizers include olives which almonds and pickled vegetables (nice), croquettes (really nice), patatas bravas (perfect) and sardines (I'm not the one to ask).  

Our server guided us to a very nice bottle of wine, the name of which I don't recall.  I might have to drop in and refresh my memory -- it was that nice and not horribly pricey.

For our mains my two friends had steak and fries, and I had coca (flatbread) with fresh summer squash and bacon.  I didn't taste the steak, but it looked excellent.  My flatbread was very tasty, nicely seasoned, somewhat delicate but filling just the same.  Only one of us didn't completely finish our meal, which must be a good sign since the portions were certainly adequate.

Desert was shared -- thick hot chocolate and churros and some sort of blueberry tart with a dollop of ice cream.  Very nice but by then I knew I had eaten a bit more than my fill.  

I'll most likely try Contigo again.
author: Jens H.

description:
Almost one year later and one of my dearest friends and I are back for another fabulous dinner at Contigo. There is an upside to not finding your Sufjan tickets in the form of a coca flatbread of heirloom potatoes! But our dinner began with a salad of shaved brussels sprouts, followed by calamars a la plaxa, albondigas and classic patatas bravas!

We opted for dessert at a nearby Bi-Rite but again the churros con chocolate are a must for any first time visitors :)
author: Penelope B.

description:
Share with your friends - share lots too! Cute little place that packs you in tightly - a little too tightly - so tightly it was sweaty warm when we were there! Ahh, but the food...

Flatbread with sausage - a must. Pork meatballs - get two orders! 

Excellent wine list too!
author: David S.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up to 4 for good service.

I've been on a Tapas kick lately, love the variety!

Great: Sardines w guac on toast, Iberico ham.

Good: Albondigas (Bocadillos better), Oxtail croquette, Gem salad, Tripe.

Dessert: Blue Bottle ice cream! Churros y chocolate just ok

Service was very friendly. Wine was pretty good.
author: Derrick V.

description:
We have been coming to contigo since it opened.  But we have not eaten there in about 9 months. We went last night and It is still as good as it was when it first opened.  Fabulously tended greens and vegetables, excellent ham and little treats of goodness in all the plates we ordered.  They let us taste wine till we got the right one.  Uzie our server was fabulous, friendly and helpful and just the right speed. 

A really nice experience
author: Cheryl T.

description: Had a fantastic meal here tonight. Great energy, and service. Uze was our waitress and was nothing short of charming. Always liked tapas, because you get to sample a bunch of delicious meals, and they did not disappoint. We used open table to book, so that made things easy. Top favorites - the roasted corn and mushroom dish, the roasted squid dish, and the chocolate caramel flan.
author: Marc R.

description: Perfection, from start to finish. Amazing flavors, charming space, and our server Uzie was delightful. Hands down, the best Spanish food I have had. And whatever you do, save room for the flan. It's life-changing.
author: Michael M.

description:
The food was really good, though we were much happier with the flavors of the sardine on toast and the sliders than we were with any of the other half dozen dishes we got. 

The nice thing is that these 2 dishes were the least expensive on the menu. When we go again, we'll probably just order a bunch of those, wine and maybe one or two other dishes.
author: Aaron N.

description:
On a whim we decided to return to Contigo, where we had eaten two years before on a previous trip to San Francisco. We were lucky enough to call ahead and score two seats at the bar, where we grazed the menu while the wall behind us filled steadily with walk-ins.

Standout tapas were the pulpo and potato pincho and the sardine and avocado toast. Pork shoulder and tripe were also fantastic. Bar seating means a close-up view of the desserts, and we went with an apple-blackberry tart. Don't miss the dessert wines here -- our waiter gave great recommendations.
author: Kevin D.

description:
I don't get out much lately, admittedly, but this place was a nice experience, and pretty dang yummy.

Standouts to me were the calamari with squash, hazelnuts, preserved lemon and mint and the appetizer of lomo. Don't hesitate. Get the full plate. You won't be sorry.

I didn't give it 5 stars pretty much only because it was a bit pricey.

Nice atmosphere, both inside and outside on the back patio.
author: S M.

description:
Love this tucked in Tapas place in Noe Valley.  Had the pleasure of dining with some friends here for a early Sat dinner before catching a flight back to LA, and I must say I very much enjoyed myself. 

Although we coudln't grab a table on the little garden patio, it may have been a blessing in disguise as it was a rather chilly night and the hostess graciously moved us to a table right next to the glass doors, so we got the best of both worlds.  

The decor is just to my taste, simple, clean, neat and grainy hardwoods with stainless steel accents abound and a bright light green colors cleveryly placed throughout.  The restaurant itself seems like it could have been a former house that was gutted and remodeled to form a long restaurant space.  The patio in back looks like exactly that, a quaint small yard with wood beams holding up heaters and a nice canopy for a feeling of being outdoors without being exposed to the elemets.

The food was outstanding!  The platas bravas was amazing with cripsy potatoes, a salsa sauce with some zing, and a wonderfully creamy aiolo.  The tripe and garbanzo is flavored perfectly and perfect with some crusy bread.  The lamb with couscous is also amazing tender and braised just right.

All in all a great meal, while a bit pricey for tapas, we found the portions to be perfect to share between 4 people, with enough in portions for everyone to have a taste.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I would like to give Contigo 4 stars, and I may do that in the future. But after the first visit it wasn't exactly a 4 star experience. 

The food overall was quite good, well executed. Though, there were not alot of standouts for me to mention, the sliced meats were good, Lomo and proscuitto presented on a board and thinly sliced which was good. The patatas bravas were excellent, nice heat and crispy. The croquetas were a bit wet and sploogy, I am used to them being a bit more firm and the pork belly was a disappointment, with the meat being dry and the fat not quite rendered enough (our server highly recommended it which made it more of a dissappointment). 

The burnt caramel flan was delicious, but the churros and chocolate missed the mark. The churros were really crispy almost like some sort of cracker stick and the chocolate was very thin, not an authentic Barcelona experience sadly.

Finally, while our server was excellent, made good recommendations on the wine and made sure we were happy, the small plates all came out at once overcrowding the table and making for a truly strange and incongruous eating experience. A place whose main focus is small plates Spanish tapas should really know better...the idea is to have a leisurely meal with the specific plates that go together being served together. The hot brussel sprouts should not come out with the cold sliced meats board..it just messes up your palate. And our busboy seemed to be really anxious to move us along even though there were empty tables and nobody waiting and it was quite early...one of my biggest pet peeves is a busboy removing a plate while there is still food on it. When the plates are so small to begin with one bite is almost a third of the plate....why would you try and take that way! 

In the end we felt rushed and confused. I will definitely go back because I love Spanish food, the atmosphere was nice and there are so few places in San Francisco where you can get quality tapas. But next time I will be specific about the order of the plates and hope that the bus boy situation was fluke.
author: Kai H.

description:
Been here a few times and now it warrants a review. Took a bunch of out of towners here on Tuesday and had a blast. Waiter was awesome and was very attentive even though he was run off his feet with the load of other tables. Everyone else staff wise is always friendly with a hello, how you doing or seeya next time. Good wine selection with an emphasis on Spanish offerings.

Food is consistently good with their signature pork and ham meatballs as an anchor to their ever changing menu. The sauce on the meatballs...let me get that last drop with a piece of bread. We had ordered the lamb with couscous as well, very tender and tasty. The salads and the flatbread/pizza were very memorable.

If you have left room for dessert, their signature xurros (that's Spanish for Churros I clarified the change in spelling from last time) served with dark cup of warm chocolate is a nice  finish a great meal. Other desserts are great as well, but they change like the rest of the menu.

Definitely worthy of your time and money, won't be disappointed.
author: Jack D.

description:
A group of us met here last Saturday for dinner.  
The pros:
Beautiful seating outside
Large variety of tapas
Wait staff courteous

The Cons:
If you have a large group you MUST do the chefs choice menu
We were limited on the time we could stay to 2 hours
Wine selection lacked and was slightly over priced

All in all it was a good experience. I am a vegetarian and there was a pescetarian in our group and the staff/chef were very accommodating. Each time a dish was brought out that had either alternates were brought to us that I was very happy with. I did not hear any complaints from the meat eaters other than a few who were not big on the sardine tapa dish that was served.
author: Tuesday C.

description:
I loved this place!  The decor is minimal but very cute.  The service was attentive.  And, most importantly, the food was yummy.  We loved the Montadito, fried cheese, Asparagus (with a fried egg!), and meatballs.

The patatas bravas was just ok and the saffron rice was not good.  For dessert we shared the orange pistachio cake.  I liked it, but love chocolate more so regretted not ordering something else.

One drawback- they only serve beer and wine.  However, the glass of red wine the server recommended was really good.  Unfortunately, I cannot remember the name of it.

I'll be back.
author: K V.

description:
Awesome and I will definitely be back!

Me and my partner are picky when it comes to dining out. We want great food, attentive friendly service, and an atmosphere conducive to enjoying a great meal. Contigo fits our bill.

Goat Chops, delicious!
Flatbread, very well done!
Wine selection, yum!
Service, pretty damn good.
Hot chocolate with churros, mmmmmm!
Cheese plate, interesting and flavorful!
author: Foodie F.

description:
I already know as I start this review that it will be four stars. Now for you, I must discern why.

My overall feeling was that I had fun - we all seemed to have fun. Several glasses of wine made the evening fly by.  I ate too much.

We had lots of good food (approximately 16 separate dishes "tapas" between 4 of us) with a few great food moments and no bad food moments. The standouts were the brussel sprouts - yes...brussel sprouts.  They were chopped and stir fried with nuts and spices - mmmmmm.

Also outstanding was the Jamon Iberico de Bellota and at $29 per two ounce serving it ought to be.  It was a great tasting having that served side by side with a more traditional Serrano Prosciutto from Iowa (at $9 per 2oz.). I preferred the Iberico, but others felt the opposite.

Also good was the swordfish and orange on orange salad. I didn't like the chicken so much and the flat bread was a touch flat.

The staff was very accommodating and did a great job of keeping the multiple servings straight and sequenced in a way the kept us all engaged and enjoying the meal.

Wine list is all Spanish and we were pleased especially with the Fume Blanc equivalent. Plus we had a small complimentary tasting to narrow the field of choices.

Cool contemporary atmosphere with the kitchen right up front and out in the open. They were quite busy but we didn't feel rushed. With a little refinement of the menu I believe Contigo will move into the "greater than 4 star average" range.
author: J T.

description:
I've been meaning to write a review about this place for several months...but you know when something is THAT good that you want to wait for the muse of inspiration & genius to hit you so that you can fully express how much you loved this place?!  

Well, it hasn't hit me...but I can't resist telling you how fabulous this place is.

I came here this past summer with my best friend who lives in Italy and her husband to meet up with some of her food blogging friends who live in San Francisco.  We were escorted to a table near the back and introductions were made.  Soon after cava was brought out.  It was my first time having cava and it was really delicious.  Perfect for a warm, summer evening.  I longingly looked out at the covered patio...it looked like a wonderful place to sit on a beautiful evening...saved for next time.

The menus were perused and since a few of our party knew the restaurant well (as well as the owners) they gave us suggestions.  What ended up happening was that we pretty much ordered the whole menu - and were brought some extra specials along the way.

It's been too long for me to remember every single dish we had but what I do remember was this: everything was delicious.  If you like tapas, you'll love the food here.  The ingredients were fresh, the dishes were innovative and the service was impeccable.  This seriously may be the most perfect restaurant in SF.

It may sound like I'm over-exaggerating but I don't ever say anything like this.  Seriously...get down to this place as soon as you can.
author: Melanie N.

description:
The food was 'good'...not exceptional, just good.  Again, as with my last experience there, it just isn't a friendly place (with the exception of that waiter we had last  time, but he wasn't there)....when spending $40 per person the least you can do is make it a friendly, warm experience.  I give up on this place...simply not worth the price

Just because the staff doesn't smile doesn't mean it makes the experience full of substance and grace...it just makes it unfriendly.
author: Blake J.

description:
Super duper f'ing delicious.  

Yes, we came with my sister who is friends with Brett Emerson but I think we would've had an awesome meal if we had come in anonymously.  Our group of seven came on a Saturday night a few weeks ago after nabbing a reservation for one of the two large tables.  After perusing the menu, we decided to go whole hog and order EVERY ITEM on the menu.  

All our dishes were phenomenal but we especially loved the fried chicken, the oxtail stuffed piquillo peppers, fried potatoes, and flatbread with nettles.  The salads were also really yummy - well-composed and balanced.  We had the most adorable Spanish waiter who was attentive, prompt, professional, and did I already mention that he was really cute?

I certainly felt like I ate more than my stomach could handle but this time it was definitely worth it.  Afterwards, Brett told us that the only other party that has ordered everything off the menu was Alice Waters and the crew from Chez Panisse.  It's nice to know that she's a fellow glutton!

I spied quite a few families with tots in high chair so I will definitely bring the rugrats the next time we're in the neighborhood.  I can't wait to return!
author: Michelle T.

description:
Who even knew that brussel sprouts had leaves, let alone that they would taste amazing sauteed in brown butter?  

This was one of a series of outstanding dishes I had during a recent visit here.  While the brussel sprout leaves would be the highlight of most meals, we had an even better dish too!  The first entree was a fresh salad with dungeness crab.  The avocado and olive oil melded perfectly with a bit of heat to bring out the flavors in this dish.  We also had a quite tasty rabbit with bacon and chestnuts, which was served as a roulade (although not described that way on the menu).  Dessert was a rather tasty persimmon cheesecake, which I could have sworn tasted exactly like pumpkin.

Overall, Contigo produced one of the best meal experiences I've had recently featuring fresh, delicious produce.  Service was generally good.   The only odd thing was the hostess...when we wanted to get a table, she must have pushed about 200 buttons (no exaggeration), then walked away twice without saying anything and finally gave us a time of about 30 minutes (which in reality was 10). Maybe she was new?  

Oh, and the funniest thing of the visit.  We sat watching the open kitchen and what was the chef, who was surrounded by all this delicious food eating?  Nothing less than Mike and Ike's candy...to each his own.
author: Ian P.

description:
I found myself going to this place for the 3rd time last night (in a year). Its not spectacular but you get what you want. A little of everything (since its Tapas).

The place is pretty. I like the crowd too. Its not too noisy even if tables are close together. 

Their tapas are just OK. But their halibut was good and their churros :)
author: RED C.

description:
Definitely a fan of this Noe Valley spot! We were immediately impressed by the service which was a constant positive throughout our dinner, 5 stars for that alone!

We began with anchoas del cantabrico, basically cured anchovies in olive oil that has been stripped of all the salt of its can - should be cheaper, but  still a good appetizer; we followed with a pulpo (octopus) salad which was excellent, sprinkled with really soft and delicious pieces of a poor little octopus - thank you, o awesomely soft and delicious brother octopus!
We were in the middle of taking apart these delicacies that the first course arrived, a nice flatbread with leeks, a couple of odd cheeses and caramelized onions to which we had them add anchovies on one half and sausage on the other - very savory - but probably wouldn't order it again as I can likely replicate it by adding some of the good stuff to a Trader Joe's ready-made flatbread. We were not even done with that, that the main course arrived, a truly delicious lamb shank soooo good!!!

alas, or, good thing, the menu changes often....what surprises await me for the next time I will visit, hopefully sooner than later?
author: Paolo D.

description:
Loved... Freshest food, great service, lovely atmosphere, and interesting tastes. 
Overall great experience.
author: Ken H.

description:
This place is great! I went in last night on a first date, off his recommendation. First off the fact that I enjoyed this place on a first date is huge, they can be a bit uncomfortable in the wrong environment. The place itself is quaint, on the smaller side but not so much that you feel you're eating over the people next to you. They have an outdoor patio that has a great feel to it on a nice day, and the decor is very well done wood benches and accents with lime green and beige walls so the pop color isn't too much but you still feel like it's spring. 
The wine and beer selections were good, all Spanish and the waiter was able to suggest what works well for my pallet. Now as for the food, first off my date learned very quickly to ask before ordering someone else food, because I am a vegetarian. With that being said there was not a single issue with he and I sharing multiple tapas and thoroughly enjoy them all. They were all able to suit our taste buds, while feeling hearty enough to fill us, without either of us leaving dinner with overly stuffed belly's. 
I would definitely go back again, date or not!
author: Mandi S.

description:
There are a number of good restaurants in Noe Valley, I like many of them, but Contigo is not "like"...... it is "love!"

The constantly changing menus are magnificent, high quality ingredients, simply prepared, fantastic outcomes. Each meal must be finished with a chocolate caliente. Just skip the usual espresso and drink this instead, not sweet, just beautiful chocolate. 

Service is excellent, particularly Rafael, extremely well versed and very polite.
author: Nicolas E.

description: I'm quite excited about this place. Finally a restaurant where you don't get a cocoa powder when you ask for hot chocolate. This is a real deal. Coffee flan is also quite good. Tempted to give it a five star rating but wouldn't be true to myself, as beer and gelato were nothing special (particularly, gelato) but everything else is quite classy and quality food. Will definitely come back and recommend to everyone! If you're a group of 2+, I suggest you call ahead and make a reservation
author: Nick R.

description:
Yum! Almost felt like we were back in Spain! We didn't have reservations, but thought we should wing it anyway and see if we could get a table. The restaurant was really full (this is around 7pm), but they were able to accommodate us in less than 10 minutes wait, awesome! The waiters are really friendly and ready to explain everything on the menu. They have a great wine list of everything from Spain. 
This is one of the few places that serves Jamon Iberico, just like how we remembered it, except we wish there was more of it and its not sliced so thinly! For tapas, we had oxtail coquette and pulpo. Its not clear on the menu, but we expected there to be more than 1 each per order, especially for the price of it! Regardless, it was really tasty, the pulpo was nice and smokey, soft and not chewy. The oxtail had a rich flavor and really nicely fried on the outside. Happy! For Raciones we had the calamares with squid ink rice, and the beet salad. The calamares were really amazing, full flavored, lots of spices. The beet salad was very refreshing, but seems more californian than spanish to me. Then we also had the hot chocolate with churros for dessert. Overall, all the dishes were very well prepared and flavors were very well balanced. The portions are very small and prices pretty steep. Last but not least, they support local small businesses and farmers. On the reverse side of the dessert menu, they list out all the sources for their ingredients that evening, they even have their very own small garden that they harvest from. I really have to give them props for that. Its great to know where my meal came from and that they didn't have to travel very far to get to my plate. Yum!!!
author: Lai T.

description:
In honor of quite a positive experience here, I will write this review in the best Spanish I can muster.

Muy excelente!  Me gusta las tapas.  Estan muy bien.  Mi favoritas son las albondigas, las calamars stuffado con lobster champinones, y los tomatos heirloomos.

Tambien, mi novia y yo pensamos que el servicio fue muy bien.  Podemos ganar dos seatos a la bar @ 9:30 pm cuando otras reservaciones estan cancelado.  Pero, la cena fue un poquito demasiado expensivo.

Cuatro estrellas!  Gracias.
author: Albert L.

description:
Oh, little gem salad, you are so simple, yet so delectable. Albondigas!  Albondigas!  Without you is such sweet sorrow. And flatbeard, a wonderful surprise, everytime. 

A little pricey and sticky on warm days.
author: Cynthia G.

description: I've tried this place twice now and just do not see the appeal of over-priced, under-whelming tapas food where you could get a majority of the items from Whole Foods.
author: Anne D.

description:
I had high expectations for this place so was quite disappointed.

My main critique was that our waitress was condescending ("This is a tapas restaurant, tapas mean small plates." Really?) and didn't like that we weren't dot-com millionaires hoping to drop a lot of money. It was still a $50/person meal, so I wouldn't say that we skimped too much. 

The wine list was among the pricier that I have seen lately, so we elected for one of the more economical options--sherry. More condescending comments from our waitress--"were we sure what we were ordering?" Yes, we were sure.  Turned out the menu was wrong and the list price was for a 1/2 bottle, so we changed our order and got a wine in the end. A good restaurant might have honored their mistaken pricing, but not Contigo.

The food was good. The churros were great--the chocolate could have have had a thicker consistency if they really were going for true Spanish-style churros con chocolate.

We're a well-traveled, well-cultured foodie lot and there are enough tapas restaurants in the city that I probably won't come here again. Esperpento, for instance, serves up the classic Spanish dishes at a fraction of the cost and I've always had good service there. If I'm going to splurge, I'd go to State Bird Provisions (great service, amazing food) for unique tapas any day over Contigo.
author: J L.

description:
This is the first Spanish restaurant we went to after our return from Spain in September '09.  Based on the reviews and reputation we had high expectations.

However, nothing we had was very good or seemed very authentic.  There was a prevalent suspicion that every dish was made with local ingredients that weren't especially suited to the dish.

That's almost forgivable.  Maybe their supply chain was out of whack because the suppliers in Spain were on Vacation in August.  But if that was the case, then they should have either truncated the menu or developed dishes that would've worked better with local ingredients.   

I'm all for locally farmed produce, but you have to use the right produce.  Although we ate here 2 months ago, the current menu lists a great variety of Spanish sourced items (notably the pata negra jamon and lomo), so maybe everything is back on track. 

The service was also pretty bad.  2 dishes were forgotten, and had to be re-ordered.  And drinks were delivered to the wrong table.  And I'm still waiting for my second glass of wine.

If there was even a kernel of promise in what we experienced the first time I'd say I owe it a return visit.  But there wasn't, and I don't.
author: Michael F.

description: I love tapas and I love Spanish cuisine. I had high hopes for this restaurant, after reviewing the menu and looking at the pictures. The high point of the dining experience was the service. Our server was very professional and very attentive. We were never waiting for something and the food came out rather quickly. The food, however, was not as noteworthy. We tried the anchovies with goat cheese, the jamon iberico, the olives, the empanadas, and about four other plates. With a party of four, we were stuffed, but individually, the plates were rather small and bland. Nothing really stood out for me, save for the flat bread which was the highlight.
author: Shawn H.

description:
Fun scene, great food. I'm not typically a fan of tapas b/c I know what I like and I don't want to share!  I went with a group of friends, so I had to mind my manners. Next time, I'm going with my husband and he'll have to order his own damn dish of delish if it wants a bite!  Mine, mine, mine!

Anyhoo, the food was fantastic.  The meats in particular.  Fun, super smart and cute staff.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Contigo is a little hot spot that serves little plates at a relatively big price.  My past experience with places that specialize in tapas is that they serve food that packs a punch, big taste on a little plate.  Not so Contigo where I found the food muted.  

For example the little gems in a salad of that name were not so sprightly as I have had elsewhere.   Yes the beets, garlic chips and mint were all there but the salad was tame.  Similarly, oxtail stuffed pequillo peppers with pine nuts, raisins and rice was surprisingly bland with most of the taste coming from the sweet peppers.   Calamari with mushrooms and pea shoots read better than it tasted.  The squid were chewy and most of the taste came from the small serving of mushroom.

Day boat scallops were OK, the artichokes that came with them were tasteless mush, although the squid ink blackened rice under the scallops was tasty.  

I  left thinking that I should return to Zarzuela on Hyde Street soon.
author: David D.

description: We ordered the tasting menu and loved it!  Great flavors, perfect timing, clean and contemporary décor.  We will be back!
author: j h.

description: Delicious and pricey but that's because we ordered a ton of dishes to try :)  One of the better tapas places in the city.  Love the ambiance and patio dining.
author: Francine T.

description: Food was awesome. Seriously, everything we had tasted great. Got the Paella, meatballs, squid, and a couple of salads. The strawberry lemonade is great as well. The service a little off, but nothing terrible. It was one of the best tasting meals I've had in SF.
author: Keith O.

description:
Five of us ate here Friday night, and -- short and sweet -- we had great food, great wine list, and a great time!

/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

OK, longer review . . . 

We started off with a bottle of Raventos CAVA while we perused the menu.  Then, we ordered a half-bottle of Manzanilla and the "pa amb tomàquet" (the Catalan version of bruschetta); the anchoas del cantábrino (yes, cured anchovy fillets from Cantábria); a plate of jamón serrano from Salamanca and one of "la querica organic Berkshire 'prosciutto' from Iowa" -- both very different, but equally delicious; and some pimentos de padrón . . . 

Moving on to a bottle of Lanzarote Vino Tinto Carbónico, we had the arugala salad (with Medjool dates, Valdeón blue cheese and bacon), the shaved brussels sprout salad (with almonds, preserved lemon and idiazabal) -- who knew?!? a true delight; some garden peas with pea tendrils (let's not forget the tendrils!) and cipollini onions; and some romano beans with chorizo.

Finally, we had a 200 La Rioja Alta Reserva with some albóndigas (pork and jambón ham -- wouldn't that be pork + pork? -- meatballs served with a tomato and sherry sauce); tripe with chorizo and sofregit; and coca (flatbread) with carmelized onions, olives, arugula, manchego, farm egg, and some txistorra sausage.

A wonderful meal indeed!
author: Jason L.

description: Pretty good for a city where authentic Spanish food (let alone Catalan food) is seriously missing. Very pricey (four tapas and four drinks over $120)!
author: Nena G.

description: Ok so I love tapas I've been wanting to try a place here in the Bay Area for awhile .SO I did some yelp researching and thought we give this place a try - well the place is trendy reminds me of some place in the meat packing district back home BUT the tapas although good are overpriced - as for the tapas I really would have liked to see some more traditional tapas - the soo called medium plates are small - would we go here again uhhhh NO - hopefully I can find a good traditional Spanish restaurant in the Bay Area and not have to wait until I go back home to NYC to have some good tapas !
author: michelle r.

description: Have been living in Noe for a while and finally made it over to Contigo-- by far the hippest, has a jolt of contemporary energy that the other family oriented places that close at 9 pm around here lack.  The fried goat cheese cake w/ green figs, basil and arugula was incredible- wish I could find a way to replicate it at home.  Also tried lobster mushrooms, which were pretty good.  We sat at a mini bar, which was very intimate and it's a great place for catching up w/ a close friend or going on a date.  The service was outstanding -knew a ton about wine and not overbearing. Definitely will be back.
author: Elana R.

description:
Wowee wow wow.

Dinner for one at the bar. Nice glass of cava. Albacore belly on heirloom tomato salad. Sardines and avocado on toast. Jamon iberico croquetas. Hot chocolate with churros.

This was my farewell meal to San Francisco. Five days in the city, first time visiting, first adult vacation, and I was directed to Contigo for dinner before my 11pm flight. Blown away. Absolutely gobsmacked by the meal. If you're a resident of SF, please, dear god, go to Contigo.
author: emily h.

description:
Reserved a 5:30pm Sat using Open Table was quick and easy.  Found free street parking only a couple blocks away was great.
   We didn't know what to expect being first timers, we got to eat on the semioutdoor area felt like eating outside, an over head heater kept people warm, viewing the sky while you eat is a seldom enjoyed practice.
    7 dishes for $40 was a steal!  I'm not going to remember everything but will try:
   The dishes came quickly starting off with (not in exact order)
1) Sardine on hardtoast with special salt tasted the minerals in the salt was unique.  Be prepared for the strong salty taste, the avocado was like butter.
2)hard toast with hamon, cheese, and a pea puree was an interesting combo
3)asparagus with almond crumbs
4)whole shrimp tasted like lobster
5)ox tail meatballs with raisins and nuts
6)pork meatballs with beans
7)king salmon with rice with squid ink was just pure heart heaven

had to order the extra churro and hot chocolate, a bit too heavy to drink but great bitter sweet chocolate dip with the crunchy warm churro was sooooo great I'm salivating.
  
Only 2 beer selection was fine, got the Pilsner was average, they also have IPA choice and about 20-30 different wines, they have bring your own with corkage fee I believe.

great, I would come again try the wood fired pizza, everything on the menu looked great,

Service with clean plates were changed and unobtrusive.  Perfect evening, was so happy left decent tip.  I liked how a different server dropped of each dish to explain what they were was very good and informative touch for first timers like us.


Well done!
author: David K.

description:
The Albondigas.  How can they be so soft and still retain their shape?  They were heavenly.  Pulpo salad is octopus.  Really!  So tender.  Would like to go back with a dining partner who is not small-oily-fish averse.  

The highlight, however was hostess Samiya.  We were told 35 minute wait and decided to try elsewhere.  Half a block away the cell phone rang:  Samiya, informing us there was a cancelation and we could be seated in 5 minutes.  That's customer service.
author: cheryl f.

description:
Patatas bravas were okay.

Coca was okay.

Jamon iberico was amazing.

Chocolate con churros was decent.

Wouldn't go back.
author: Catherine H.

description:
Meh.  I've experienced better.  Came here with a party of 3 and got to try more than a handful of the dishes and none of the dishes popped -- flavors lacked...it was kind of boring actually.  I've been wanting to come here since last year after spending a couple weeks in Barcelona and I really wanted to like this place. But alas, the food definitely did not feel authentic.

Service was terse and not very warm, but they got the job done I suppose.

Ah well.
author: ML ..

description:
Outstanding! Definitely one of the best tapas restaurants I've been to in awhile.

Love the casual atmosphere and zen simplicity of the decor. Get's a little loud inside but probably because everyone is enjoying the food so much.

The service was excellent. We were greeted promptly by the host and told our table would be ready in a few minutes - and it was. Everyone from the server to the food runners were friendly and efficient.

The menu seems a bit more adventurous on paper than it is in reality. However, the items we tried were very fresh and extremely well prepared.  The halibut crudo was very fresh and zingy with oranges and radish. The Coca Flatbread was rich and earthy from the mushrooms.  Finally you can't go wrong with a thick, rich cup of hot chocolate and a side of churros. Yum!

Portion size and price is more than comparable to other tapas restaurants that I've been to before.  Let's face it those small plates are not cheap and can add up quickly.

Bottom line though is that the quality of the food here makes it worthwhile.
author: Jeff S.

description: unique, inventive dishes - great attention to flavor and spice when complimenting meats and seafoods with veggies and spices. The garden they're growing around the tables is a nice touch and adds to the aromas and overall experience.
author: Ken F.

description: It was our first time and won't be our last! Interesting and creative menu to entertain the palate! The service was excellent and many different members of the staff made sure we were enjoying the meal.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Went with a friend who knows tapas and Spain! I also love tapas. 

We got lucky (only waited 30 minutes, they take no reservations) and were seated in great tables (and not on the bar, like others).

Definitely worth considering!
a. patatas bravas: 5 stars
b. jamon serrano: 5 stars
c. free water, either sparking or mineral, nice touch. 4 stars
d. great service and very cool ambiance: 4 stars
e. beer very tasty: 4 stars

Just okay, nothing to scream about.
a. little gem salad: 3 stars
b. oxtail:  3 1/2 stars
c. meatballs: 3 1/2 stars

1 or 2 stars:
a. every plate of bread = $2
come on now, really, charge for bread? (there's nothing special about this bread)
b. tapas that are 3 1/2 stars: 
way too overpriced!! $8-9 dollars for 2-3 tiny pieces, is this serious?

bottom line:
would we come back? hmmm.... we talked about this at end of dinner.
***if they added more food to the tapas plates, to be more realistic, then yes we would come back.... otherwise, nahhh....we are not coming back.
author: mario c.

description: Over the last few years Contigo had become one of my go-to places. I ate there at least once a month. Over the last six to twelve months it's deteriorated. The two sizes of the Jamon Iberico plate have been condensed to a single size (too small). My favorite dish, the croquettas, are rarely on the menu now it seems. The wine list, always full of underaged, undistinguished bottles has remained lifeless. There's just not enough here to keep me coming back. the patatas bravas are almost, but not quite enough.
author: Gary C.

description:
The food is good enough but it was hard to judge.

The three of us ordered about $150 dollars worth of food and, with the exception of dessert and serrano ham, it arrived all at once. It completely ruined the meal. Everything was cold by the time we got to it. Why the feck would I want my flatbread, calamari, croquettas, potatos bravas, duck breast, artichokes, anchovies and meatballs all at once? It's fecking TAPAS! I really don't know what they were thinking but it made us feel very rushed. And the fact that they were trying to clear our plates before we had finished them didn't help either. 

I would have given them two stars but the butterscotch flan was amazing, easily one of the best desserts I've had in the last year.
author: Jack M.

description:
Had the crispy pork belly which was tender and crispy in a delightful broth filled with butter beans and strands of pig's trotters. The Swordfish also excellent came in a very nice base of saffron onion and dabs of delicious black olive  with some artichoke. The side of mariquita chard with pine nuts was more ordinary tasting.

Highlight of the meal for me was chocolate caliente (thick barcelona chocolate) with churros. The chocolate had a very interesting salty flavor but tasted heavenly with a dipping of the sugared churros.

3 stars in view of price/portion/quality of food. Also, there is a weird service charge in the bill.
author: M Y.

description:
Bottom Line: Yummy tapas.  Reservations come relatively easy so its a great last minute choice.

Ambiance: What you expect of a typical San Francisco restaurant: modern and unpretentious.  

Food: There are some tasty dishes on their menu.  We pretty much loved every dish we ordered, which included: stuffed peppers, sardine toast, arugula salad, clams.   And of course, don't miss the ham selection.  They also had a great selection of Spanish wines that aren't easily found outside of Spain.

Service: Good.  I ordered the melon soda, which had an odd taste.  When they noticed I wasn't drinking it, they immediately took it away and replaced it with an iced tea.
author: Annie T.

description: Really disappointed. I've been a neighbor and have been coming here for the past years since they've first opened.
