Menu was overpriced, room very loud, staff really unaccomodating (we had a family dinner planned with six arriving for a reservation for five). After 30 minutes of the cold shoulder we just left.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Went with my roommate who kept gushing about how good this place was.  Um, NOT!

Service was horrible! Our server was beyond unattentive, and yeah, we know that you forgot our dessert order and finally re-entered it into the system 10 minutes later, jerk!  You should have just fessed up! It's kind of obvious when the same dessert has gone to all the surrounding tables even though they ordered it 10 minutes after we did!

The food was good - just good - nothing amazing. The little fried fish was greasy, the bocadillos were a little dry, and the churros were funky. The cured meats were tasty, and I really can't remember anything else we ate (and we had a lot more).  That just goes to show why this place only deserves 2 stars.  Sorry.
author: Vicente G.

description:
Whoa, did they have an off-night or is it overrated?

Ordered about $200 of take-out for 5 people. It was ready within 30 minutes and packaged well (though wastefully).

- Autumn Salad was delicious...then it all went downhill fast. 

- Didn't like the meatballs or the pulpo (octopus) salad - the flavors were just off.  The pulpo salad was left unfinished by our party after everyone tasted it.

-Calamari was way too salty. Also left unfinished by our party after everyone tasted it.

-The nettle flatbread pizza was awful and it came back to haunt us for the next 18 hrs if you know what I mean. Also left unfinished by our party after everyone tasted it.

-Besides the autumn salad, the one thing I'd eat again is the oxtail croquettes but half of our party didn't like them.

It seems like the best thing to do if you eat here is to enjoy the relaxing ambiance and order something very very simple like bread and cheese.

Btw, reservations only for 6+.
author: Marina N.

description:
We had the pata negra to start, followed by the little gem salad, wood oven roasted sardines, greens sauteed catalan style, crispy pork belly, and finished with the burnt caramel flam.

Everything was great: the service, the recommendations, the atmosphere & the food.

The most memorable was the crispy pork belly.  It came with trotters and ears which I'd never had and was very impressed by! The flam was also insanely good. 

Highly recommended.
author: Heather M.

description: I went here with family for my birthday last year and it was outstanding. The food is amazing and the wine is incredible. The oxtail hamburguesas were moist and tender. The Calmars with squid ink is a MUST have  as well as the potatoes and meatballs. Every course at Contigo I had was concise, playful and delicious. If you haven't tried this place, you're definitely missing out ! Go as soon as you can!
author: Reuben R.

description:
Contigo is a welcome and much-needed addition to Noe Valley.  The space is beautifully designed and everything has been considered - from the drinking glasses to the mini-garden in the patio area.

My dinner date and I dined there with the intention of ordering just a few appetizers and some glasses of wine. We had the albondigas, flatbread, calamari, and churros, all of which were great. It was pricier than I had expected, but I still enjoyed my time there.
author: ML P.

description: I have a really bad habit of only writing reviews when I have a bad dining experience, so, I decided to break the cycle.  Contigo is deserving of my first mindful 5 star rating.  A very cool neighborhood restaurant introduced to us by friends who live in Noe Valley.  We had plans on going to the Mission and seeking out one of the many great restaurants in that neighborhood for a special dinner and made an adjustment as our 'foodie' friends said Contigo in Noe was their favorite restaurant in the city.  We were not disappointed!  Absolutely amazing service, food, environment, etc.  Loved everything about it.   The Coca (flat bread) is a must, but everything we ordered was excellent.  The city is loaded with really good restaurants, this is one of them!  Worth making the trek to Noe if you live on the other side of town.
author: Lisa T.

description: We went early, right after they opened for dinner, as we'd heard it was crowded and noisy later, and were the 3rd table filled. The kitchen was busy with activity, our waiter was prompt and knew the menu, and every single dish we ordered was fantastic. Iberian ham, say it with me, is the dish to start with, maybe a nice glass of wine to start, and before you know it, there's olives and potatoes and the best damn squid and another glass of a different wine...and then dessert and sherry and what a lovely evening. When did all these folks arrive, all the tables are full and the noise level is up there. Soft furnishings, i.e. drapes, rugs, tapestries sure would help to soak up some of the sound in a very loud room, but other than that winge, no complaints. Lovely food, good service, enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
The food at Contigo was very delicious. I had a salad and some shared dishes with my husband. I thought it was healthy and tasted great. It's no wonder there's always a line outside to get in. I tried coming here once before and they didn't have a table so I made a reservation this second time. 

Ambiance is great. We were seated in the back outside where they had home grown herbs. A little pricey, otherwise, I'd go back more often.
author: Tai M.

description:
Wine: delicious, though $14/glass.

Atmosphere: great! We sat in the back patio that felt rustic, comfortable, yet warm (heat lamps were right above us and on full force - aaahhh. The chairs are metal and therefore COLD until your body warms them up.) Noise level was quite fine.

Waitstaff: on it - friendly, knowledgeable, not too in your face but there enough to keep the water glass full (complimentary sparkling or still).

Food: and this is why I am only giving Contigo 3 stars: just ok. While the hot chocolate was like liquid pudding, the coffee caramel was way too sweet. The tagine and albondigas (meatballs) were incredibly salty - and I love salt! The sauce on the patatas bravas was also incredibly salty, though tasty, while the potatoes were cut too big so they were crispy on the outside but mealy on the inside. The sardines were $1.50 each (really?!) and overpoweringly strong to enjoy the rest of the flavors available. The asparagus soup on its own was kinda bland though the mushroom pate in the center was ridiculously delicious. Mixed together, the soup was good.

So, would I go back? maybe just for wine an the hot chocolate.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
My wife and I  dined at Contigo twice in 3 months! That's a record-breaker for us. Both times we were seated outside, which I recommend (the garden setting seems quieter and a bit more peaceful than indoors). The staff is extremely helpful and kind in their explanations of the dishes. And what dishes they are! Great menu, tasty offerings, and it's all fresh fresh fresh! Love it! 

Larry
author: laurence c.

description:
Love this place. Although I haven't been to Basque country in Spain, I enjoy their food and see many different flavors to regular Spanish cuisine. 

Good ambiance, the dining room is spacey for a small neighborhood place -- the tables aren't crowded too close to each other the staff is knowledgeable and friendly. 

Food: I recommend everything we ate =)
Anchovies- Yes they are salty, but aren't they suppose to be? Eat it with some bread to balance the flavor out and make sure you dip in the olive oil its sitting in! 

Oxtail Croquettes: Filled with meat and you don't get the greasy feeling like when you have oxtail soup etc. perfect! 

Pork Meatballs: I didn't think you could make meatballs to come out so fluffy and soft. I have a new found respect for meatballs! 

Crispy Pork belly: I started the night thinking I was going to eat healthy, but I could not pass up on this one. The pork belly was braised and baked (i think)- so it was tender but also crispy on the top and it came with almost a small casserole with white beans and smoked meats which gave the sauce great flavor. I think this is a must try at this place. 

The only con is that they do not take reservations for small parties- so we had to wait about 45mins for a table on a Thursday night. But for me, it was worth the wait.
author: Nini D.

description: Can I just have a big bowl of croquetas?  Side of Goat cheese fig salad.  Double order of calamars ala plancha.  Bottle of wine.  Super size it please.
author: Mark A.

description:
First two visits deserve 3 stars.  Third visit would have been  laughable-if it were someone else.  Sat out back in the "outdoor" seating which is parcel surrounded by 4 walls and no views of anything outdoors. 12 minutes before our first interaction with a waiter and 26 minutes until our drinks arrived.  We were then brought the wrong appetizers.  Dinner finally occured without a hitch .  Then after our dinner was cleared a server brough us salads- after dinner, that we hadn't ordered.  After splitting desert we waited just under 20 minutes for a waiter fly by so we could pay the bill and escape this comic trajedy.  It wasn't just the waiter.  There seemd to by a revolving cadre of inepitude.

The food was very good as usual but really not 4-star level given the sparse portions.
author: John D.

description: This place never fails; it's simple and elegant inside, lovely hip and friendly wait staff, great wine list, and DELISH food.  Meatballs, anything with squid ink, the ham sides are devine.  Sit at the bar for a date with the family; well behaved kids are welcome.
author: rebecca g.

description: Little gem in Noe Valley. My fav is the smashed pea tostada.  Sadly it is no longer on the menu! :(
author: Anna Y.

description:
We moved to Noe Valley this past summer and Contigo has quickly become our go-to spot. 

Whenever we go, I know that I'll have a good meal...and every third or fourth meal I know that I'll have a FANTASTIC meal. In other words, they're reliable good and occasionally great. Their menu changes a lot because it's based on seasonal ingredients, which is obviously good but you're never quite sure what you're going to get or whether your favorite thing from last time will still be on the menu. 

We just did their New Years Eve set menu on Friday. The food fell in the "good" category but their dessert fell in the "make-a-'mmmm'-sound-after-every-bite" category. I'm not a huge dessert person or ice cream person, but this orange sorbet of theirs was out of this world. Imagine the best clementine you've ever eaten and then make it into a soft, somehow fluffy sorbet. It blew me away. Yes, a sorbet blew me away.
author: Laurel A.

description:
2 dollars for 4 pieces of bread.

They served only 4 small pieces of bread with a lot of cheese and ham meant to be shared between 5 people. And then charged $2 everytime we asked for more bread. Without mentioning the charge, which just sneakily turned up on the bill.

I would avoid this overcrowded, overcharging, overrated Noe establishment.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Having missed the churros con chocolat in Barcelona due to bad timing and the Spanish need for siesta, as well as the lack of quality Spanish food in the city, it was great to read that Contigo opened up their doors in Noe Valley.  The place is vibrant with the packed tables and the great use of space, including the bar style seating where you can see the cooks have their way with the procuitto.  

The menu is primarily tapas style that can satisfy both the meat eater and the seafood lover.  Albeit the Jamon Iberico is expensive, it is worth every bite of its soft texture and slightly salty finish.  If you enjoy beef, then consider the (ox tail) croquetas and if you rather pass on the meat then the calamares and gambas will serve you well. The Cocas (flatbread) is a nice compliment to any meal, especially with the addition of egg and/or anchovies.  

Eventhough we stuffed ourselves with our usual "over-ordering", we still made room for what I really came for, the curros con chocolat was worth the extra calories,  as my dissapointment from a couple of years ago was erased with every thick chocolate dip and bite.  The only drawback is the food is over priced, but if you are looking for quality versus quantity then you won't have a problem here. 

FYI: If you do order coffee with the churros, try mixing in the extra chocolate with your coffee for a nice mocha mix!  ;)
author: Jason A.

description: Good quality, seasonal food in a pleasant, trendy atmosphere.  Good wine list and food is good for sharing.  Menu isn't incredible accessible, however - not as many meat dishes as I expected, but the veggie dishes are delicious.
author: Mitchell F.

description:
Having only been open for 3 weeks, Contigo has everything running so smoothly it seems like it's been open for 3 years! Opened by a former Chez Panisse chef, this small contemporary tapas bar is the most happening spot in Noe Valley right now. Friends and I had been dying to have dinner here since they opened, and we finally did last night. Luckily, I was able to secure a reservation for 6 (they don't take reservations for parties less than that), because on a Tuesday night, the place was packed.

We decided to request for the chef's choices, and had them send over 2 of each dish (the portions are definitely small) to us until we wanted to stop. This was a great way to go, because we got a taste of all the favorites, including:
- patatas bravas (the red sauce had a great kick)
- beets and clementines (super fresh)
- asparagus, jamon chips, egg (we fought for that one piece of bacon)
- octopus and fingerling potatoes (cooked to perfection, not chewy at all)
- lengua (I didn't even know I was eating beef tongue until someone told me afterwards)
- lamb and pork meatballs (yummy)
- bacon, asparagus and tronchon flatbread (my favorite of the two flatbreads)
- jamon, arugula and manchego flatbread (a bit too salty for me)

After the flatbreads, we decided to move on to dessert -- this time, we selected three that we wanted to try: chocolate sauce with churros, pear tart and vanilla flan with salted caramel. The desserts did not disappoint! All this plus a bottle of Martin Berdugo tinto del pais? $37 per person!

If these are the flavors of Barcelona, I've got to book a trip there asap! Want to go conmigo?
author: Connie C.

description:
this is a good place to come share some small bites.  4 of us ordered a bunch of stuff.  i loved the salt cod brandade, the flatbread, sauteed greens, and sardine and avocado pintxo.  we also got the beet salad and grilled asparagus, which were good too.  

for dessert, we shared the churros and the apple walnut cake.  the churros were nice and hot, but i wish the chocolate sauce was thicker.  

to drink, they have a lot of spanish wines, and i had a nice rioja.
author: Helen T.

description:
I've never been to Barcelona, but I think I got close tonight at Contigo! The place was poppin' serving upscale tapas for a downscale crowd in quiet Noe Valley.

We decided to go for it and had the chef send out his favorites. Good choice! The potatoes bravas came first, and judging from their spicy, crunchy deliciousness I knew we could expect good things from the rest of the menu. The octopus and the beef tongue with lentils were the clear stand-outs... yum! Our party of 6 ended the meal happily stuffed after spending only $40 each. 

Don't forget to indulge in dessert! It would be a crime to ignore the sweet side of this menu. The flan is made with salted caramel and the churros are hot, crispy and golden with a dark and sultry chocolate dipping sauce. We couldn't get enough of the pear pastry's addictive almond filling. Ah... the perfect antidote to this never ending sweet tooth o' mine.

Okay, we've got a winner. Va a Contigo conmigo?
author: Nicole G.

description:
Exceptionally good food and gorgeous place.
It is not cheap, but worth the moneys and the wait.
author: Fred A.

description:
Contigo has only been open a few short weeks but if the crowd on a Tuesday night is any indication, it's already one of the hottest tables in town. Easiest way to nab a table? Invite five friends along and make a reservation, which is exactly what we did last night.

We decided to let the chef send out his favorite dishes, which was a brave decision but ultimately a great way to try some standards. Out of the smaller plates, my clear favorites were the octopus, patatas bravas (some of the best I've had) and the lamb and pork meatballs.

The asparagus, jamon chips, egg had one tiny piece of incredible bacon but the rest of the dish was kind of just eh. Beets, clementines and ricotta sounded great but again, didn't move me at all. And the 
lengua was fine but lacked flavor (kind of ironic considering it's tongue) My main issue with all of the small plates (or as they call them, Pica-Pica) is the fact that the portion size is incredibly small at $8 a pop.

We tried two different flatbreads from the woodburning oven and I enjoyed both of them, the jamon version probably a bit more than the bacon one. 

We shared three desserts: the hot chocolate con churros was a decadent treat - super rich chocolate and tasty, sweet churros paired well together. I'm not a big phan flan but was satisfied with my one bite. And the pear tart had a crispy crust that was difficult to cut through with our forks - again, fine but nothing special.

I guess beauty is in the eye of the beholder - I thought our dinner good albeit overpriced given the portion size but most of my dining companions raved about the meal. Despite my waifish figure, I can eat...and I left Contigo hungry. I would probably come back and order some flatbread and a glass of wine, but definitely not for a full meal on an empty stomach.
author: phil h.

description: Very good food! excellent service and suggestions. Tastes like the food in Spain!
author: AJ S.

description:
I wish i had remembered to write a review of this place right after i went because i am forgetting important details...so forgive me for the lack of content...but...

Went here a few months back with my aunt, uncle and boyfriend and we sat at the "bar" overlooking the kitchen which was nice to be able to watch them cook our food. ; ) 

-The sparkling was tasty, i tried a couple including the red or rose colored one and they have a sweet sparking i tried for dessert! i enjoyed all of them. 
-I remember loving the brussel sprouts, they we picked apart (all of the leaves separated) and sautéed in butter with garlic......oh my. =]
-The Sole was wonderful from the puree to the greens to it being cooked perfectly.
-Patatas Bravas were good, especially the sauce!
-Crab Salad good
-Octopus good
The one negative thing i remember was having an Oxtail fritter sort of thing and it came uncooked/cold in the middle twice...so that was kind of a bummer...but we enjoyed everything else. 

ooooooooo & the Blue Bottle ice cream.... sooo tasty!
author: Sarah F.

description:
i'm still on my roast chicken obsession these days. after trying zuni, umbria and now contigo, my favorite is actually the half chicken at contigo with zuni's version as a very close second.

i also enjoyed the sauteed greens dish with raisins and pine nuts. it reminds of the one at boccadillos, actually. next time, i'm going to try one of the flat breads. you can see the wood fire brick oven as you walk by the front door window. the restaurant decor is awesome!
author: Helen Y.

description:
Not impressed. At all. I've wanted to try this place for so long, and finally got the chance with a group of friends. Each time a tiny, overpriced dish came to the table, we just had to laugh! Considering each dish is an average of $8 or more, it's ridiculous. And trust me  - if the food tasted awesome, I wouldn't complain as much, but it was okay at best. I've definitely had better, similar food at other restaurants. The shrimp were bland, the burger unmemorable; the meatballs were decent but overwhelmed by the addition of mint. Probably the best thing I ate was the simplest dish: bread covered in tomatoes and olive oil. 

I'm kind of bummed I waited for an hour and a half to dine here. But I'm glad the food was subpar because it gave me an excuse to go to Mitchell's Ice Cream afterward and fill my still-hungry belly with a giant cone.
author: Beth T.

description: Contigo has been one of my go-to places for many years and I'm sad to see how bad the service has become. I went there last week, and was totally ignored for about 30 minutes. I tried to make eye contact with each server, and none of them would even look at me. It was as though I was invisible. Finally, I got the woman taking calls at the front desk to take my order. Then, about 15 minutes after that, some ridiculous server who had a personality full of fake smiles (felt like she'd overdosed on Prozac) stops by to ask me how I'm doing and tell me that she noticed I placed an order. WTF?!?! It's unacceptable to completely ignore guests. Every waitperson should have noticed me sitting there being ignored for so long and one of them should have done something - either talk to me, or get someone to talk to me.
author: Eater S.

description: Just had dinner at Contigo with a large party.  We ordered quite a bit, and the food was okay.  Typical tapas... nothing that stood out as spectacular. The service, unfortunately, left much to be desired.  The server seemed like he would rather be somewhere else, was curt and trite when anyone asked a question about the menu, and he seemed to be rushing us out (even though the restaurant had several empty tables!).  The ambiance was nice, but the temperature inside the restaurant was uncomfortably hot.  With all the great reviews, I had high hopes for more...
author: Z K.

description:
A nice relaxed atmosphere with fresh, quality ingredients prepared in interesting ways/combinations. It was really hot the evening we went, and the strawberry gazpacho was just perfect to pique our tastebuds and cool us down. Along with the various adult beverages hehehe. 

Oxtail croquetas were super-yummy, crispy on the outside and almost machaca-like on the inside! Sardines w/ avocados on little slivers of toast were delicious, and on the house as the waitress was concerened we had waited a bit. That was ok, not necessary as we are not impatient diners. But it was really nice!

We were seated super-promptly, though it was crowded. I understand that they don't take reservations, that is fine with me. I can't think of a tapas place in Spain that I have ever made a reservation at. Can you?

Oh! And Elan gave me a sample of this DELICIOUS fresh CA olive oil. YOW! So fresh it BURNED! Thank you Elan! (Come back to dance class!).

It seemed to be a loudish place, but I usually like that. People enjoying themselves because the atmosphere is conducive to such things! They did a really nice job on the decor: warm, natural, relaxed yet modern.
author: Jackie P.

description:
Sade says, "it's never as good as the first time" which is usually true for everything except losing your virginity. Last March, I was invited by my sister to travel to Spain. We stayed in Madrid and Barcelona and since then, I've been missing the orange juice, cafe con leche, and the pan con tomate. Contigo has none of these things but I still had a great time because they most certainly have have tapas!

We were celebrating one of my sister's birthdays in December and here is how it went down:

-They don't take reservations but I think you can call a few minutes beforehand and they can try to hold a table for you
-It's a small restaurant, got kind of cramped waiting for a table because it was pretty crackin', so you can put your name down with the host and wait outside
-For a party of 3 on a Wednesday night, we waited for about 20 minutes
-Sat outside but it wasn't so bad, they have heat lamps
-Our server was the best! Knowledgeable of the menu (he lived in Spain for a few years) and witty as hell...it's a shame I forgot his name
-We ordered Cava (german gilabert which was pretty good and had nice font on the bottle...PLUS!)
-For the 3 of us gals, we shared 6 tapas, they suggest 2 per person, we went crazy on the patatas bravas and ordered 2, 1 is enough though
-we had flan & the churros w/chocolate for dessert, if you tell them you're celebrating a birthday, they'll put a candle in one of your desserts
-the bill came out to about $160 for 3 people, 6 tapas, 1 bottle of cava, and desserts...not bad

I automatically like this place because it makes me think of Spain but there are a few other tapas I'd like to try. Hell I'll come back just for the service!
author: Tatiana D.

description:
Only good things to say about Contigo.  Nice menu with lots of options for tapas and some larger entree sized portions.  Our waiter Rafael was seriously great - friendly, funny and right on with food and wine recommendations. They don't rush you here, which I appreciate. 

Like the last time I got to sit out in the Patio (best site of the house) with my friends who wanted to try Contigo after all my great review and it was pretty nice! They love it.

P.S. Owner, you should be very proud of your staff.
author: Kubrick T.

description: I loved how they asked if we wanted the egg on the flatbread, to which our answer was of course, why not?, and what came was a delicious pizza with an egg over-easy style right in the middle! The mini-pork sandwich was yummy, as was the sardine on toast with a light avocado spread. The space was comfortable and fun, and the staff very nice, no snooty-ness. (Maybe though in this economy nobody is snooty anymore?) Complimentary fuzzy water for the table is a nice touch.
author: Christine C.

description:
Don't eat here if you're actually hungry!  

Oftentimes tapas presents with the dilemma: which one would you want to have after you're done eating - full wallet or full stomach 'cause you can't have both!  Contigo is not an exception.  The portions were very small. And, frankly there are better places for much cheaper.  The amuse-bushe was a tiny 1/2 radish that was no bigger than a thimble.  The shrimp were annoyingly still in their shells.  The flank steak was good and the accompanying onion rings good too - just wish there was more!  The tagine lamb was also decent but Aziza on Geary is much, much better.  And the much-touted 'house-filtered' tap water served with our meal initially had a bug in it!

The atmosphere is hip and sheik with a cozy up-scale/causal feel. 
The wait staff is good-looking, but could do less with the up-sale pitches.  By the end of the meal we had the anticipated churros, which were good, but Cosco does better.  (For the best churros, if it's still around - The Churro Station in San Rafael is it!).  And, afterwards my dining party all started to talk about other restaurants we loved - telling isn't it?   That and the fact that I'm having some ramen now...
author: Kevin H.

description:
Yay! What a great addition to the neighborhood!

This isn't a tapas bar exactly, you wanna know why...because the food fills you up!  The plates are mostly shared, but they are pretty hardy. The menu changes frequently, which will keep me coming back often! Oxtail fritters are mostly meat, not fritter (imagine!), cod salad is interesting and tasty, lamb/couscous dish is amazing (my fav from the night) with unique spices,plenty o' tender meat and delish couscous.  The pork meatballs were also hardy and moist and came with flatbread.

The hostess was friendly, gave an accurate wait time, and called a few mins before our turn. The server was friendly and gave a good wine recommendation. 

Wines are all Spanish.

Decor is warm and contemporary. A lot of clean wood and metal. Outside garden area (they're growing some of their own produce!). They support local farmers/fisherman/ranchers/creameries, etc.

Dessert (yogurt/apple cake) not fab but changes often so that doesn't matter. Also, their coffee is Blue Bottle and comes in a mini press.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
Wow. I'll definitely be back here.

Took a friend for a birthday dinner here but it would be a fantastic date night. 

Pros:

The menu is varied but not overwhelming. They have jamon iberico, which is some crazy rare black pig who was fed on acorns and lead the posh life...until he wound up on the board with quince jam, delicious cheese, and hazelnuts.

The definite high point is that the service, or at least our waiter, was fanfuckingtastic. He had great recommendations for food, and I told him that he was the boss of my wine, and he took it and ran with it. 
Everything we tried we loved: the ham, the anchovies, the tomato bread, the pimentos and fleur de sel, the pork belly, and the flat iron steak. Churros y chocolate and fig rasberry tart.

Everything they have is sustainable organic local  bla bla. Even the sparkling water is made there, not from bottles.

Cons: not a goddam thing except that they don't take reservations...but even this turns out to be a plus because they take your number so you can go for a walk around or get a drink and they'll call you when the table is ready.

Even the host was super cute and nice. 

The amience and decor is nice and cozy and not annoying in any way.

Go here.
author: Andrea S.

description:
I disagree w/ Rafael.

Good for groups (there were several there who seemed happy)
Good after 7pm (went in Tues 9ish and no wait)
Good for nice days (patio was loverly)

Delicious food, freshingly different than the ubiquitous Cal-Italian in SF.
- Anchovies were great. 3 of them served in grassy olive oil.
- Sardines w/ avocado puree & pickled red onion on crostini were amazing. Salty, creamy, acidy, crunchy, mushy.
- Albondigas - pork / ham meatballs were scrumptious.
- Grilled peach, fried pig ear, wild arugula salad was pretty good; a little soggy.

Nice wines and nice beers from Spain.

Kind of bitchy server though...
author: Melanie C.

description:
Delicioso! Every dish was filled with unique flavor. The first dish we had an array of jamon. The best of the trio was the jamon iberico de bellota. Other favorites of mine were the albondigas (pork & jamon meatballs with a tomato sherry sauce), local calamars a la planxa, escarole salad, and the olive oil poached artichoke hearts. The oxtail croquetas were simply divine. 

Every bottle of wine that was recommended was amazing. 'Menuante' carinena and 'Odysessus' priorat was our group's picks of the night.

The desserts: Blue Bottle coffee helado and chocolate caliente con churros were delightful.

Great and friendly service!
author: Lisa C.

description: I will keep this short and sweet everything i had was awsome.  I will be back I want to eat the whole menu. The ox tail little burger is soo good.
author: Steven M.

description: Very very good! The flat bread is great and the chickpeas and spinach are a must! The people I came with couldn't stop raving about the Currox and hot chocolate.
author: Amaya W.

description:
Contigo is great. I'm a little confused by my reviewers beneath me, but maybe things at Contigo have changed in the past 3 days. Ya neva know.

There were 7 in my party last night, which consisted of 6 "I eat everything and anything that's put in front of me as long as it tastes good" diners, and then me. I'm more of the "I don't eat shellfish or pork for religious reason, red meat and cooked milk for digestive reasons, and can't eat bread products for 2 more days for Passover reasons." And I gotta say, even I left Contigo a happy camper. 

Our waitress seemed to know everything in great detail on the menu and was more than happy to space out the seemingly endless tapas we ordered. Mind you, I didn't try all of them. I didn't take part in the oxtail, jamon, pork belly, and toast. However, I was a big fan of the snap peas, fried potatoes, and cheese platter. My boyfriend and I split the chicken entree, and thank goodness we did, because there's no way I could have eaten the entire portion. (And I can eat.) The wine selection pleased our birthday boy, a sommelier  at a popular San Fran restaurant. Dessert was again something I didn't try, but even if I did eat pork and it wasn't Passover, I wouldn't try bacon peanut butter cookies. Nasty. 

Beware of one thing: there is a slight decline on the way to the bathroom, which I almost fell down in front of my newly acquainted dining mates. Coulda been hilarious, but disaster averted. This time.

The food + the wine + the service +the super cute restaurant = 4 stars.
author: Lindsay W.

description:
What a fantastic experience! My boyfriend and I went there last night for the first time. We were seated on the heated/covered patio, which was nice although a bit chilly. We split three of their tapas, then he enjoyed some of the jamon serrano and we split one of the flatbreads. I enjoyed a glass of tempranillo, which was tasty but reasonably priced at $7, and he had a beer. We topped off the meal with churros con chocolate, which was INCREDIBLE. 

It was even cooler to enjoy the meal and know that it was sustainably produced.
author: Jenn G.

description:
I can't believe I am reviewing a restaurant so quickly after I went to it just a week ago.  I guess it is because I am so eager to want this place to be great so I can make it a regular spot for myself.   

It wasn't as crazy as the last time, a week and a half after they opened.  I was a little firm and not wanting that seat right behind the door.  I understood the hostess wanting me to enjoy the kitchen and see the "show", much like I do at Boulevard.  I was by myself after all and she wanted me to have the best experience.  Guess what I did have the best experience!   

I sat at the same bar I did the first time and was a little concerned because the original guy was there behind the bar. He was kind and nice but spent far too much time with each customer and therefore neglected the others.  I have been in the restaurant scene and I know you just want to acknowledge the new customer who has been seated in your station.  That never happened until I started eyeballing him again just like the first time.  Don't get me wrong he just needs to find that happy medium of great customer service.

Enough of me let me tell you about what BRETT did for me tonight.  The Monterey Bay Calamari was over the top yummy and I think it needs to be the signature dish!  BRETT already serves peas and kosher salt as their "shtick" so why not carry it over to this Calamari.  The simplicity of the dish with the peas and the touch of mint just worked.

I will be back. And certainly watching as your progress into one of Noe Valley's best.  Shit, you own a restaurant in Noe Valley and we are talking about it on Yelp in a good way.  I say it already is a success.

Later dudes and thanks for coming to Noe Valley.
author: Scott P.

description: SERVICE SUCKS! FOOD IS NOT WORTH IT! If I could give this restaurant 0 stars I would. I was with a group of people mostly my age range one younger and was the only one carded(and the only one who didn't bring ID). Not a problem, I didn't really want to drink. My cousin who is younger than I am said to her that he was younger and she just laughed, didn't ask for ID. So I got pissed and was being and spoke my mind, at this point I was not being a bitch. She was a total bitch to me which started an argument. At this point I was at her level of bitchiness. I gave up and she left but kept coming back eavesdropping on my conversation asking me if I wanted to talk to the manager and explaining her actions and how I looked young and she learned in school to ID the young ones. She still only ID'd me and my younger cousin, not the other young people I was with(we are all over 21. Her name is Carissa, ask if your server is Carissa, and if it is ask for another server. I hear the meat and fish is good but I'm a vegetarian. Vegetarians beware!
author: L N.

description: Really wonderful. Great service. Everything was very good but the stars were the lamb shoulder and the hot chocolate. Fantastic!  I have been back numerous times and it always makes me happy.
author: Torbin B.

description:
Took the family here for a weekday dinner and these are the items we tried,

Tapas (pica-pica)

*Patatas Bravas
*Sardine and avacado toasts
*Pork belly bocadillo
*Oxtail croquetas

Serrano Ham (Cold cut)

Platillos
*Coca with Jamon (Ham)
*Wood oven roasted Lamb
*Salmon

I found the Patatas bravas and the Oxtail croquetas to be quite good. Pork belly was decent. Salmon was poor in execution, slightly frozen when cooked and flavorless. The remainder of the dinner items, uninspiring. 

The recommended glasses of Cava were pretty decent.

May I suggest Paella be a crucial part of your menu?! Paella might not be a fancy item but there sat the Patatas bravas. I like my slightly crisp on the bottom, PLEASE.

=)
author: DAVID N.

description: Went here for the first time after hearing people rave about it. The menu was a nice cross-section of favorite regional specialties from around Spain and small (but not too small) plates made with fine seasonal ingredients from nearby. The oxtail hamburguesita (slider) was delicious as was the delightfully buttery summer corn with chanterelle mushrooms. I also enjoyed my Calamars a la Planxa (a Catalan dish). Dessert was wonderful -- a tart made with Pink Pearl apples and blackberries served warm with a nugget of ice cream. It is a great place to dine alone although the idea of coming back with a group and ordering the sampler ($40 a person) is very enticing. Service was good without being overly solicitous and the maitre d' was very professional.
author: Keith R.

description: If you are looking to play a little Contigo, you're totally in the wrong spot. These guys have killer Tapas and wine to boot.  Love the sardine and avocado toast, and the little gem salad is a gem.  The Paella is no Carajillo.  No kick, just a dry, boring, and bland dish.  Still a place to go with.
author: Joe B.

description: Get the Calamari, and stop there.  The place serves ok food in a beautiful space.  I think most spaniards would be a bit disappointed though.
author: Sallie J.

description:
If I could give half-stars, this would be a 2.5 star review.  Mostly because I think Yelpers are too generous.  Are most businessed really worthy of 3-stars or above?  Contigo is new and deserves some slack...that's why I give it 3 not 2 stars.  

Let's recount:
Friday night:  
New dining option is Noe!  Awesome!  Menu on line looks intriguing.
A bit of a wait and no place to sit, but you can order wine while you stand around and watch the action in the open kitchen.  Life could be worse.  

As a budding female chef, I am delighted by the diversity on the line.  Women grilling not just plating cold apps and desserts.  Props.  

We sit in the back-- a charming little enclosed patio with heat lamps and an herb garden.  Good call.  

This is a tapas bar.  The plates are, as they should be, small.  So don't expect midwestern portions.  We got a range of cold and hot appetizers and one of the wood-oven pizzas.

The menu changes frequently so I won't bother going through each dish.  Lets just say that they batted around 60 percent.--not inedible but nothing to write home about.  Several of the dishes were under-seasoned.  And the egg-add-on to the pizza was way overcooked.  No yolk to ooze.  The waitress was apologetic and promised to get it taken off our bill.  A new restaurant should at least be this accomodating.  BUT BEWARE of EMPTY PROMISES.  The bill did not reflect her words.  Read carefully.  

Growing pains?  I hope.  Noe can use all the dining options.  But I'm not likely to head back anytime soon.  Food & service: So-So.  Which would be ok (perhaps) if the prices matched...but our bill topped out over $110 for 2.  You can get damn fine food around the corner at Firefly for less than that.
author: Meadow L.

description:
I've never had a serving of anything on the menu I didn't like. The chefs here have a way of making things that you might not think you'd like taste like the most amazing thing on Earth.

Delicious, juicy, crispy pork belly that melts at your touch. Enough said!
author: Farm S.

description: Their patatas bravas taste like crack, the seafood is always superb and the coca is awesome. I always get a thrill whenever I dine here.
author: Tami Y.

description: Booked the babysitter and took my wife out! I surprised my wife and she loved this place. She studied at university of Madrid so the bar is high when it comes to unique / traditional Spanish food. The people were really nice and the food was perfect. My only ding is that they place the tables really close to one another and you end up being part of everyone's conversation. Yes I would go back!
author: glenn w.

description:
There was nothing wrong with this meal, everything was right, but nothing was amazing. It was good food, with a good atmosphere, good service, adding up to a good night.

Solid. Just not over the top.

Maybe I'm just bored with this sort of food.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Take a trip to Contigo and you'll feel like you're stepping into one of the best tapas restaurants in Barcelona.  All you'll be missing is the Gaudi architecture outside and the rambunctious Catalans inside.  I'm hoping Contigo finds a way to import the latter along with their spectacular Spanish delicacies.

The atmosphere is cozy, without being too cramped.  The night I went, which happened to be their 2nd week anniversary, there was a line leading to the door.  I've heard of 2 hours waits, but lets chalk that up to only being one of the most anticipated openings in SF, people!

I was able to sneak in and sit at the bar.  This is probably the best seat in the house because you get to see all the action in the open kitchen.  From the sizzling flat breads in the wood-fired oven, to the flat top with pork belly griddling, to the skillful plating and service of the staff at the bar, you'll be treated to stunning visuals as you anticipate your meal.

Ordering a trio of what chef Emerson has dubbed "pica-pica", or tapas to the layperson, is probably the best deal on the menu (3/$21).  This was plenty to serve one person, and provided the best opportunity to sample a range of traditional (and slightly fanciful) takes on Catalan cuisine.

Tortilla de Hongos - having been to Barcelona many times, this is one of my staples and the way i judge a tapas restaurant.  its like going to a thai restaurant and ordering Pad Thai.  its a simple dish, but tells a lot about a place if they can make it well.  Simply put, one of the best tortillas i've ever had.  Great ratio of egg to potato to mushroom.  Soft without being mushy, perfectly seasoned and a wonderful blend of earthy & creamy tastes.

Croquetas de Bacalao - i believe its illegal to call yourself a Catalan restaurant and not serve salt cod, or bacalao.  If it isn't, it should be.  Because in the right hands, bacalao is one of the greatest foods on the planet.  It the wrong hands, though, it can be a salty mess.  Originally used as the way to preserve the massive quantities of fish needed to feed pre-refrigeration Spain, salt cod has been elevated to the status of an icon for Spanish cuisine.  The croquetas at Contigo kept the legacy of this ingredient alive and strong.  With a crispy exterior hiding an intensely creamy and vibrantly fishy interior without the over abundance of that salt once used to cure it, these croquetas are subtle and lovely.

Bocadillo de Cerdo - Ah, and the climax of the trio, the bocadillo de cerdo.  Served on the softest mini-bun, this amalgamation of pork belly, onions and harissa aioli is just like biting into a piece of heaven, if heaven is made of pork belly.  And let me tell you, my heaven is. :)  The perfect blending of flavors between creamy, smoky pork belly, the slightly sweet onions and the subtle spiciness of the aioli.  I only wish i would have just ordered 5 of these on a plate for dinner!

To match the cerdo, I paired one of my favorite and up-and-coming wines.  The Dev Patel (see Slumdog Millionaire) of wines, if you will: Bierzo, from a small district in Spain.  Lovely fruit and richness to match with the pork, but a little overpowering for the other two dishes.

Sadly, the only downside of the whole meal was the dessert.  The Flam (no, not spelled Flan, as I was told by the knowledgeable wait staff), was good but not amazing.  A nice way to end the meal, but didn't match the deliciousness of its predecessors.  I'm kicking myself for not having the chocolate and churros, but I'll rectify that next time. ;)

And this review would not be complete if I didn't mention the attention paid by the wait staff.  Clearly, they know they're under the microscope, but this knowledge did not stop them from being approachable and incredibly pleasant on a night where they were clearly over-subscribed.  The hostess Elan, and my waitress, Norma, were both so sweet, coming by every 10 mins to see how i was doing and to chat with me about the food & drinks.  They even sent over chef Emerson to thank me for coming by at the end of the evening.  Nice touch, and i applaud them for their attentiveness.

Now, you might wonder, with all this praise, why not a 5-star rating?  Well, let me tell you dear reader, 5-stars are hard to come by.  They are reserved for the places that hold a special piece of my heart.  Whether by circumstance (an amazing birthday meal) or by simple perfection (everything exceeded expectations, from food, to wine to service), they are not given out willy-nilly.  While this place could certainly deserve 5-stars, I'm going to reserve that last star for a future visit to see if they maintain their quality and dedication to service.  So stay tuned for the next installment of this review ...
author: Brian F.

description:
I've been to Contigo several times, beginning one of the first weekends they opened and the most recent for Valentines Day, and I'm consistently impressed. 

The service has always been great - greeted warmly, friendly, knowledgeable waiters. We sat at the Cava bar once for dinner and the bartender was a riot. 

The food! A lot of people go to Contigo and are surprised - because it's Catalan, which is slightly different from many of the popular tapas bars here in SF. It's still amazing. They've been one of the only Spanish restaurants to carry the real-deal Jamon Iberico - if you've ever been to Spain and had the real thing, you *KNOW* what I'm talkin' about. Not to mention the oxtail croquettes - I'm not a huge fan of weird eats, but you gotta try these things if they're on the menu. Incredibly tender and flavorful. 

The ambiance is great, too, I love the neutrals + one-color (green) scheme they got goin' on. It may not be authentic old-world Spain, but it still has a great feel - a little formal-ish, good for a first (or second) date.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Been wanting to go here for a while, seemed like Monday was the day I could usually make it, but no luck since it is closed on Mondays.

Ordered just small plates and enjoyed every morsel.  Oven roasted sardines with avocado were awesome!  Will go back, even though the busboy spilled a glass of water down my back.

And even though it is in Noe Valley, leave the kiddos at home.
author: Mickey D.

description: Something to be said about unhurried meals between friends and consistently good food coming out of the kitchen. A friend celebrated a milestone birthday, since 3 of the four had been to Barcelona, I wanted to evoke the good vibe/memories. Our wait staff suggested a very good complimentary wine to all of the appetizers we ordered, and it stacked. We relished every dish and agreed someday, all four will make a trek to Barcelona once again.... If you heart squid and sardines, this is the place
author: One P.

description: Writing this from a month or so out, but still remember this as being a good place for tapas. We tried a variety of dishes, and all were good. The seafood and veggie dishes were the best (and this is coming from a non-vegetarian). I also left there wanting to go back and try more of the dishes - I think you'd need ~3-4 visits for a party of 3-4 in order to try everything.
author: Dave L.

description: Good food, expensive!  Like the atmosphere & crowd, great staff.  Give it a try for sure when in Noe Valley.
author: John F.

description:
Contigo really exceeded my expectations -- and I came here for the first time with some hefty ones!!

I matched up with a close girlfriend of mine for dinner and wine, as it had been awhile since we last caught up.  First up, I was immediately taken aback at the decor.  It was the perfect convergence of modern Californian with a minimalist yet cozy flare.  The setting eminated a very warm ambiance with cedar-colored wood varnishes and stainless steel touches.  

As for our server, Rodolfo, he was eager and exceptionally knowledgeable about the best picks on the menu.  [As a quick aside: I couldn't help but notice that he bore a very striking resemblance to Jim Caviezel of "Passion of the Christ" and "Angel Eyes" fame.]  He wound up making some favorable recommendations for wine and for the dishes we ultimately wound up selecting.

The *only* thing that might knock this experience down a star was that we ordered the Halibut Crudo, but it never came to our table.  In retrospect, it's fine, for my girlfriend and I were satisfied with what did come out of the kitchen and one more plate might've pushed us over the edge.

Beautiful space, great location nestled away in the uberly-charming neighborhood of Noe Valley, and great staff on hand to attend to all of your needs.  I'll be coming back....
author: Katie C.

description: Went to Contigo last Tues and had a fabulous time!!! Waiter was great, helpful, recommended great wine and overall a great experience. The food was AWESOME!!!! Recommend the calamari, the crab, the pork belly, anchovy toast and the best thing in the world-their fried goat cheese salad!!!! BOMB!!!! Best thing i've ever had! So good!!! Dessert was good too but the entrees were the highlights!!!
author: Mary C.

description:
OK. So-so. Some highlights (restaurant decor, beet salad, water options) but now "get" why yelpers feel price and quality/quantity of food do not match. Service was fair but maybe when you forget to put the order in for the egg on our flatbread, make it up to us somehow...right? 'Cuz it would have been a world better with it - I suspect. Seated right away but it was 5:45.

$120 (with tip) for six small plates, flatbread, chicken entree, two wine, one beer, dessert and coffee. Sounds like a lot of food, right? Well, walking home, husband threatened to stop at Firefly for a "real" meal. Overall, the food was fair. Two salads (beet, chickory) were excellent if not a tad overdressed for such fine food. Calamari was not as tender as I would like but had great flavor. Sardines were not my cup of tea. Mussels were fair - better options in SF so I would not order again. The crudo tasting plate of "mar" options was our fave - beautifully executed and fun to look at. Flatbread was dull (we had the vegetarian as don't eat pork). Chicken was quite good although somewhat boring and uninspired on the plate with just a few mushrooms and some greens. Loved the BB coffee in the french press and our scoop of coffee ice cream was great.

Probably the most annoying part was the first-date couple sitting a mere six inches away from us. This is why one hates when tables are crowded together - any more of their "why do I have to work so hard....I need six months off" and "what is called here? No-eat Valley? Stroller Valley?" and there might have been some words. Oh yeah, and the co-ed bathroom was filthy...concrete floors display where anyone splashed liquids and clearly some have not been aiming well at all.

Doubt we'll be back soon even though it's a five minute stroll away. If were to do so, would sit at the bar and go for a glass of wine and a cheese plate pre-"real" meal.
author: Karin S.

description:
While many of the businesses along the main 24th St. corridor of Noe Valley shutter, Contigo is on fire with popularity. They clearly set the stage for this hype well within the foodie community through connections, but that's as it should be because I found my experience lived up to the current buzz. Contigo, in my opinion, joins a short list of perpetually popular, quality restaurants (Zuni, Town Hall, Slanted Door, Destino, Range, etc.)

The food: 
Delicious, seasonal, high-quality. Everything was very well prepared and perfectly seasoned. I'm in culinary school, so I'm picky. Sometimes the simplest things tell the most about a place, and here the potatas bravas (fried potatoes) were one of my favorite things just for their spicing and the two accompanying sauces. I overheard someone saying the menu changes daily to accommodate the whims of the season. I have deep respect for places that are truly seasonal like this. 

The decor: Gorgeous. They took a space that used to be a computer store (!!) and turned it into one of the most stunningly light, modern and welcoming spaces. The back patio, somewhat enclosed and with space heaters, is a gem. 

The service: Very professional and thoughtful, despite being busy. They provided helpful recommendations, and I loved the complimentary filtered water (flat or sparkly) bottles they provide for your table. 

The cost: Extremely reasonable for what this place is. We didn't drink much (one glass of wine and an iced tea), had four small plates and a side of bread. But for the two of us it was plenty (I was stuffed enough I didn't have room for dessert). With tip, under $30/person. 

I think most peoples complaints are simply the difficulty of getting in. We went early (6:15 on a Monday) and sat right down. If you go later, you should realize it is going to be a challenge to sit down, especially if you have a large party, and be willing to wait. They also have two bars (one in front of the kitchen and one the actual bar) that you can eat at (also adding this to my list of places where you can eat watching the kitchen, love that!). So if you are just a party of one or two those areas up your odds.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
i haven't been here in about 2 years, sorry, but noe is a bit out there for me, 1/2 way on the J line there and i was like, wait, are we still in SF? but two plus years later and i still really love this place. the spanish wine list alone sends me into fits of rapture. i seriously would love to drink my way thru this whole list. 

overall i love love love the food here, but yes, the portion sizes can be a bit too small, and it is pricey for what you get in some cases. the lamb tagine was kind of a joke it was so teeny. delicious yes, but still a bit small. the coca (flatbread) might be one of the best i have had--hello fatted calf bacon, so nice to eat you. carmelized onions and arugua help round out the saltiness and it's a good value for $14. the meatballs here are super good, and i am picky about my meatballs. i was also IN LOVE with the calamars a la planxa--with blood oranges, black olives an pickled onions it was such an interesting and fun combination of sweet with salty with ocean. i also loved the motaditos with anchovies and avocado, but you gotta like anchovies. which pretty much applies to all dishes with anchovies. 

i was there with 3 girlfriends and we ordered 6 dishes and split a dessert and were stuffed. with a bottle of wine it came out to around $35 a person. the portion sizes are great for dining with your girls, but if you eat here with a boy, you might end up spending more since he's goin to need more to fill up.
author: rachel p.

description:
Very impressed with this place.  Decor is very contemporary -- open kitchen, outdoor space, and nice cava bar in the middle.  Every dish was prepared with the highest quality ingredients and the kitchen staff was on top of everything.  You had the sense that the entire crew was comprised with all trained chefs.

The highlight of the menu was Jamon Iberico.  This is god's food.  Acorn fed wild boar aged 36-months.  This is the finest of foods and expensive, but for the purveyors of fine cuisine, it is well worth it.

Service was very nice and the wine selection is also smart.  There's nothing negative to say about this place except that it is not cheap.  Fun restaurant but only go with people who are willing to pay for the "good stuff"
author: Laurence H.

description:
Came here the other night with my boyfriend to celebrate. We made a reservation, although when we walked in at 6, the place was pretty empty. Upon first walking in, I noticed the decor. I'm a big fan of the long narrow dining room and the simplistic set-up with an open kitchen so that was a plus. The wait staff was attentive and friendly. 

I had a glass of Rose that was delicious, my only issue was that I didn't know where any of the wines were from and none seemed to be local. This seemed weird to me because even though I know it is a Spanish style tapas bar, the waiter did brag about the fact that they tried to buy locally (the back of the dessert menu even showed all their local providers).

We decided to order the Tapas tasting menu. A little pricey (at 40 per person) but what the heck? When in Rome... My favorites were the calamari and black rice and the salmon. The sardine crostini was also really good. They gave us Iberian ham wrapped around manchengo cheese which wasn't on the menu but was kind of disappointing be cause it didn't highlight the ham enough.

Overall, good place to go for a night out. Great atmosphere (although a little loud/ bad acoustics) and really tasty food! Not to mention, the part of SF is really cute and fun place to walk around.
author: Caroline A.

description: Delicious! Contigo always comes through!
author: Neil W.

description:
Service was impecible.  If this were based on service alone, it would definitely be a 5 and if I could give this place an additional .5 star I would as it's definitely a 3.5.

Cute restaurant, it's kind of loud inside though.  The outdoor seating is covered with a clear top so the temperature out there is perfect.  They have a cute little outdoor garden, which is a great thought and really nice to see as you're sitting outside, but, there are far too many Nat's out there to enjoy yourself or your meal.

Speaking of meals, the small dishes were terrific.  
 - Oxtail croguetas
 - Calamares and Pimientos de padron a la plancha, lemon.
 - Bread rubbed with tomatoes Catlan Olive oil and flor de sal

The beef rib was recommended so we decided to try it.  As my boyfriend was cutting the rib, we noticed that the rib was completely cold.  So cold that the marbling was white.  Our server apologized and brought it back to the kitchen and they warmed it right up.  When we finally got to eat it, it was indead delicious.  :)

Overall, I give it a 3/3.5 though.  I don't think I'll be rushing back any time soon.
author: Delilah B.

description:
I was one of the lucky ones that was able to get a preview dinner, and it was divine!  

The atmosphere is unpretentious and you just ease in to a comfortable table with friends.  They have very cool water glasses that are old wine bottles.  

Service was great.

But the real story was the food.  Very innovative menu and combinations.  The salads were divine--so fresh and full of flavor.  Loved the oxtail croquetas and the papas bravas.  Wine was excellent.  Deserts were good too--a nice change of pace from the typical.  Blue Bottle coffee to boot!

Can't wait for the official opening!
author: Caren H.

description:
I had an amazing first experience at Contigo last weekend.  It was a Friday night and there was a 30-45 min wait, so we just walked to the Valley Tavern waiting to receive a call.  With just enough time to down a starting cocktail, we walked back over to grab a fantastic seat at the front "bar" in front of the open kitchen.
I've been trying to check dishes off my list of things that I have never tried, so we started with the Sardine toasts with avocado spread and pickled onions.  They were delightful- crunchy, and creamy, a great blend of textures and flavors.  This dish also paired nicely with the manzanilla sherry.  I love sherry.
The next dish was the Rabbit and chanterelle canelons with nettle pasta, with beixamel and manchego cheese.  This beautiful dish was very rich and creamy, but certainly well thought out and unique.  I'm glad it was a small serving, otherwise I would have felt much more guilty.
Hello Oloroso sherry!! I think we had a few of these :)
One of the guys in the kitchen was able to sneak us some delicious little green peppers that I want more of next time.  He also informed us that most people at making out by the end of dinner in the area that we were sitting in, so I would say it's a sexy place. 
Can't wait to come back...
author: Laura P.

description: Great food - I feel like SF doesn't have that many tapas places, and this is definitely a good one. We shared the albondigas, the avocado and sardine toasts, the croquetas, a spinach and chickpea dish and the figs with goats cheese. Everything was really tasty. The service was a bit slow but I think that was just the bar staff - our waitress was very nice and friendly.
author: Olivia B.

description: 4 of us went for dinner there two weeks ago on a Wednesday and it was bustling with a packed restaurant and table turnarounds. We had the family style 7 course tasting menu which apparently is made up of the chef's best dishes and all dishes were just ok with the only exceptional dish being the squid stew which was v.g. In lieu of dessert, we had the Catalan hot choc and must say that i enjoyed that and the squid dish the best from the menu. We also had a spanish red which was said to be the most full-bodied red on the list and it was just ok. Loved the layout and the vibe of the restaurant though which reminded me of the bustling tapas restaurants in Barcelona.
author: Renuka V.

description:
The décor was exactly the style I love: reclaimed wood counters/tables, warm with simple design and great ambiance.  These are the things I love.

The food: I dare say excellent.  I am not much of a sardine aficionado myself, however the sardine crustini was delicious.  It tasted of the sea, freshly caught when I bit into it.  The calamars a la planxa was great and cooked to perfection, I.E. not rubbery, with a great sauce, perfect for dipping bread in (we'll get to the bread in a second below.).  The goat was good, halibut was seasoned well, though I could have done without the breading.  The churros... Come on.  How bad can it be dipped in a decadent chocolate?

The service: Left a lot to be desired.  A couple of waiters seemed to shine, but the one I had was apathetic, slow, uninterested and aloof.  I had to ask three times for a basket of bread.  Come on.  It took much too long to even come by for our orders.  I hate having to ask for water, but that was common place.  I'm not terribly picky, but I know good service when I see it, and it's important.  It was seriously lacking, at least from my waiter.  

I had a wonderful time with my partner, who's birthday it was, however, the waiter really was not good.  I wanted to give the restaurant four stars, but based on the service, it deserves three.  I hope they can improve upon this with our particular server.
author: Chris Y.

description:
Living in San Francisco for over 3 years, I've patronized quite a few purveyors of Spanish style Tapas.  My experiences have been at best disappointing.  I take my Tapas eating very serious so I am often overly critical, but as a review this is to your benefit. 

Contigo is a long awaited answer to a culinary prayer.  If you are a fan of tapas and in general delicious savory dishes I would recommend very highly CONTIGO.   If you can, try to get a patio seat, you might notice the herb garden that has been cultivated, now where do you see that.
author: michael h.

description:
We tried and failed to eat here Monday as they are still closed on Monday nights.  I did learn however that they are now opening 7 nights/week.  Yeah!

On 2nd attempt we succeeded on a Tuesday night around 7:30 p.m. we arrived and a table for 2 took about 20 minutes to get seated.  We sat at the wine bar, which was a little crowded but we got drinks quick!  As we were waiting we got to observe all the plates coming out of the kitchen and help decide which we must have...the list was growing long!

It's a wine and beer bar, the wine selection is predominantly Spanish and Portuguese wines with a nice selection.  We enjoyed the beet salad with goat cheese and mandarin oranges, incredibly fresh asparagus, delicious sardines and the coca jamon (it's like a small pizzette).  We saved room for dessert and had a small cup of melted chocolate with sugary churros and the Ros cheese which is similar to an aged Manchego one of my favorites.  It was all perfectly portioned and delicious!

The staff was incredibly friendly and helpful and I will definitely be back!
author: Lara L.

description:
Just wrote the review for chocolateria San Gines Madrid so I figure I give this place its credit for having chocolate similar to a typical Spanish cup of chocolate.  I am not sure if the churros are made in the restaurant however the sugar that the churros have isn't typical.  

I've been here a bit of times and I typically go here just for the chocolate.  The place is great for something different, the food is freshly made.  The last time I went I enjoyed watching the cooks.  I sat at the front bar in front of the kitchen, I remember the interesting egg basket where the eggs are kept, it was shaped like a chicken.    I would suggest you walk here from the BART station.  Will give you nice conversation time if you have a date.  Over all a great place for conversation over a cup of chocolate.
author: The Wing Man V.

description:
I'd been hearing about Contigo since it opened and was excited to go with a friend for a nice mid-day dinner.  We arrived and was told there was a 20 minute wait, so we went to the dive bar next door for a cocktail.  Halfway through our drink I got a call that our table was ready, so we drank up and headed over.  

We started with a carafe of a great Albarino, Bodegas as Laxas ($22) along with a few small plates.  The simple and incredibly delicious Pa Amb Tomatquet (Catalunya's national snack of toasted bread, tomato and olive oil) and the Jamon Serrano Reserva board.  The tomato bread was $4 and came with two pieces, and the Serrano came with 10 or so pieces of the paper thin cured meat and some accoutrement and cost $9.

Our next course we ordered another carafe of Albarino (guess we should've just gotten the bottle in the first place!), the Pulpo Salad ($9) and the Sardine and Roasted Eggplant Escalivada Toasts ($8).  I really loved the Pulpo Salad with was tender pieces of octopus, cucumbers, pickled lipstick peppers, onions, capers and mint.  Simple clean flavors with great textures.  The sardine toasts were good, if you like sardines (which I do), and had a nice smokiness from the eggplant... it came with 3 toasts each with a sardine fillet laying atop the eggplant.

For our last course we got a carafe of a Mencia from D Ventura ($28), a delicious red, and ordered the Coca with Gypsy and Red Lipstick Peppers ($14) and the Tripe with Chorizo and Chickpeas ($8).  I loved the tripe dish and had never had tripe before.  The tripe was soft and tender without feeling mushy, the chorizo added a great smokiness and the chickpeas gave it body and depth.  it was a great portion and paired well with the Coca (flatbread) that was delicious and great for sopping up the sauce in the tripe dish.  We added the egg to the flatbread, which is one of my favorite things.  The tripe dish was definitely the best value and portion and was hearty and homey.  Oh, we also ordered another tomato toast with this course, because it was so tasty!

Our server, Andrew was great and made our dining experience so much better more enjoyable.  He was helpful and seemed excited by our selections, was knowledgeable about the menu and wine list and just had a great relaxed presence.

Contigo may be delicious, but it definitely isn't cheap.  I know we ordered a lot of dishes, but the portions are small and we wanted to sample as much as possible.  Before tip, our meal was $140.  I will definitely go back to Contigo, but it may be a better destination if you aren't really hungry!!!
author: Ariel D.

description:
We LOVE coming to Contigo. Having recently moved to the area, it has quickly become a tried and true favorite. While pricey if you are looking to enjoy a full dinner with multiple courses; this place is exquisite if your looking for an amazing culinary experience. My significant other and I regularly share a couple of tapas, an entree and dessert (average bill including tip is around $80)... Having said that, we have never been disappointed. The menu changes daily while still maintaining the popular favorites (the Arugula Salad, Albondigas meatballs, and Marinated Spanish Olives are some of ours). 

My only qualm is the seating. While set up to encourage community, we find it difficult to hold a conversation due to the noise level and close proximity to other diners. We have learned to set up a reservation on-line because they frequently have a wait list at the door. The waitstaff are great- very friendly and attentive, and always eager to please. All said and done? It's TOTALLY worth it.
author: Nani M.

description:
OK, i use the term underwhelming alot when I give a poor review, but this place is the definition of underwhelm - fails to excite, stimulate or impress - I'm really surprised there are so many good reviews here.  

Sardine appetizer was good, not too fishy or salty, but should have come with bread or crackers so the taste didn't linger into your next course.  Their chicken dish was a leg and thigh of chicken with slightly oily and rubbery skin on a tiny portion of parsnip potato mash.  For the most expensive item on the menu, I was surprised how small and unsatisfying this dish was.  Overall the prices here were high, for Noe Valley and the portions.

Even the folks next to us were disappointed with their flatbread and sausage. And by the way, half the restaurant is effectively outside under a clear awning in the backyard with several heat lamps - if you are next to the heat lamp, its fine, but otherwise, you are going to be wearing your coat most nights...
author: Ron W.

description:
Contigo is really trying to bring some hipster coolness to stroller-laden Noe Valley.  We wandered in here after a somewhat unsatisfying trip to Radio Shack and cheered ourselves up with sidra and 2 plates of Pimientos de Padron. (I so love pimientos de padron; they are like a box of chocolates, except that you don't typically double over in pain over a chocolate.  Well.)   

No wait on a school night here, and the service was pleasant and unobtrusive.  For some reason, the waitstaff here all look like they are auditioning for http://thesartorialist.blogspot.com/.  Great eye candy, but I felt I had wondered back stage at an Arctic Monkeys show.
author: Lorin Y.

description:
Great food and service here! Some of the dishes were smaller than other tapas place I've been to but not so small that it wasn't worth trying.  All the dishes my friends and I had were fantastic! 

Our waiter was very friendly and helpful. They don't take reservations for a party of less than 6 so come early if you don't want to wait.  We went on a Monday night and surprisingly it was almost full so I would expect it to be even more busy on a weekend.  

Definately planning on coming here again soon.  With several dishes and a bottle of wine for 4 of us, it came out to only less than $40/person. Not bad!!
author: sidney c.

description:
As we approached Contigo, we were startled by a pierce shrieking that sounded like a parrot with its knickers in a twist.  We opened the door to see a petite woman (who, as it turns out was one of the owners Elan) panic stricken on the phone while she punched buttons on a console. "I'm sorry," she mouthed.  We were sorry too and stepped outside to protect our ear drums from being shattered.  

Anthony was bummed; he'd been looking forward to trying out the new place in his 'hood as he'd been to Beretta one too many times of late.  I encouraged him to wait.  By the time calmness descended we pretty much had our pick of the place.  We chose a table at the back next to the windows, which we discovered opened, so we enjoyed a nice balmy breeze.  Our waiter Andrew was very patient and helpful as I tried to find a wine to my liking.  I was not a fan of the Alfrocheiro Blend, but think it would probably go down nicely with some cheese and jamon.  The Cabernet was smooth, but nothing special, and while the Tempranillo was fine, $9.50 is too much for a glass.  The Carinena Blend, Montsant, 2004, was perfect... yeah, I had three of them!

We loved the Beets and Will's Pixit Tangerine salad.  The Fava Greens Catalan Style were on the bland side.  The Asparagus with mojama was yummy - could have used a bit more green garlic. The fried little fish were a little on the large side, but delicious nonetheless, and on the opposite side the fava pods were so small I thought they were green beans; also could have used a bit more lemon in the mix.  The patatas bravas were outstanding - hands down beats Cha Cha Cha any day!  The lamb and pork meatballs were original and delicious.  The flatbread with wild morels was tasty enough but lacking zing... it could have used a smidge of grated cheese, but Andrew explained it was the only item on the menu that was 100% vegan... 

They gave us a small discount, presumably for either our inconvenience or patience...

All in all, we give it a solid 2 thumbs up... allowing some room for improvement.  

By the way, the interior is lovely and I wouldn't mind propping up the bar on a busy night with a glass of wine and some cheese.  Wish it was in my 'hood!
author: Lorraine F.

description:
We had dinner there last night, and while it was okay, it was neither totally wonderful, nor even a place I would make a point of going back to.  It may have been said elsewhere, but the textures and/or tastes of much of what we ordered just didn't work well together.  For instance, the patatas bravas (sp?) featured both a white and a red sauce on them.  Maybe it's my own peculiar sense of order, but wouldn't it have made more sense to have the sauces on the side?  We also had a small plate that was a combination of pickled carrots, almonds, and pickled onions.  Odd mix of textures, no?  One taste combo that actually did work, at least for me, was the flatiron steak with bleu cheese, but the cheese just formed into little balls and sort of rolled around on the steak without truly achieving any kind of unity with it.  And the small plate of clams had sand in it.

I will say that the service was outstanding.  But at the somewhat steep prices at Contigo, I'd ignore the current buzz and go somewhere else, at least until they have the kinks worked out.  For right now, I'd say 2.5 stars..
author: moosedog i.

description: Very delicious tapas, in particular the jamom iberico is my favorite. Only been once and I'm excited to go again sometime soon.
author: Zachary S.

description:
Loved the food. But knocked it down to two stars based on being terribly over-priced, much too loud, and uncomfortable setting.

We were seated at a table with the sun in our eyes, but no curtain available so finally we were moved to another table. We really liked the food, but for the three of us with 2 glasses of wine and one iced tea, and six plates to share (mostly appetizers) it came to $94.  Plus it was so loud we had to shout at each other and even then couldn't hear each other.
author: Jane M.

description: I went here yesterday for dinner.  We had an early reservation at 6 pm and were seated promptly.  I thought the decor was quite lovely, modern and fresh.  Our waitress was nice and attentive but could have been a bit more helpful with suggestions.  There were 2 of us and we got 6 plates to share.  Nothing was excellent nor was anything horrible.  I thought for what you get it wasn't a great value for your dollar.  You will have to order quite a bit to get full.  The wines by the glass seemed to be nice and a normal ($9/glass) price range.  With so many great places to go in this neighborhood and city I don't know if I would choose to go back.  It was a bit expensive for the amount of food.
author: Karen C.

description:
Pretty good.  Worth $100 bucks for 2 people - probably not. 

For the Corkage Fee, go to www.SFCorkageFees.com!
author: Brittney B.

description:
I am new to Noe Valley.  Just moved here from Boston.  The area is great but what addition to the neighborhood Contigo has added.  While I am not a fan of Spanish/tapas style food I still give this place 5 stars. 

Each dish was prepared with tremendous skill and were extremely flavorful. The back patio is going to be amazing come summer.  A perfect place to grab a glass of wine with friends and have a few taps.  

Classy, different and fun I am so glad that is opened in Noe Valley.  My only gripe is that the prices were on the higher side.  Not too high but high enough to make me think twice about going back weekly.  

Noe Valley is going to be killing it in 2009/2010...  you just wait!
author: Ryan B.

description: We had dinner here back in November. We had to wait a bit (started our bottle of wine while standing in the "cozy" entryway!) but the wait was worth it. Our waitress Erica made excellent recommendations and we had an amazing meal!
author: Kevin C.

description:
I came here with a small group (6) for a friend's birthday. I was easily able to make a reservation, but had to put my credit card number on file in case I didn't show up without canceling or the number of my party decreased without notice. Although I thought that was a little annoying, I was okay with it. 

First impression of the restaurant was that it was modern, tasteful and welcoming. It didn't feel like the cookie-cutter restaurants that are continuously popping up, which was a breath of fresh air. After ordering enough food for what seemed like an army, we started on a bottle of wine we ordered. The tapas came out sporadically, giving us plenty of time and table space to enjoy the different flavors. Although nothing blew me away, the food was consistently enjoyable, something not all too common. I went with two people who had actually grown up in Spain, and informed me that the food wasn't necessarily authentic. Some close, others something they'd never heard of until that evening. 

After about two hours we were ready to pay and leave. It was a bit of a shock when the check came -- none of us were really full, but the total well surpassed $300. I guess that goes to show that things add up quickly. 

Even with the overpriced bill, I do see myself going back sometime. For me, it seems like the perfect place to bring friends or family who are visiting, because it's the perfect example of San Francisco culture. I appreciated that my server was from Argentina and knew a lot about the food.
author: William d.

description:
I really got in touch with those Catalunyan flavors, bold and so earthly refined.
