Patatas bravas were kinda re-invented but the aioli was just perfect. Can't say the same of the tomato sauce. Also had the brisket fritters, a radicchio salad, tuna conserva, asparagus and a terrific grilled squid dish.
Probably the best tapas place I've been in the city. 
I've never paid $135 in Barcelona though, that must be a San Francisco twist.
author: Dario B.

description: The atmosphere is nice. But I didn't really enjoy the food. The price was too much for a 7 course meal. The meal was not filling. This isn't a good place for a big party, might be better for two people.
author: SF S.

description: This place is dope.  They have fresh, seasonal food, which is a real highlight.  The calamari dish is probably my favorite dish in the world right now.  They have great service and a laid back vibe.  It's spendy, but won't break the bank.  Great date night, or larger group spot.  Cool back patio.
author: Dan N.

description:
We are definitely excited to have Contigo in the neighborhood. We ordered a variety of dishes including the following which were our favs:

1. The coques
2. Pulpo salad
3. Summer green bean salad
4. Oxtail croquetas
5. Albondigas (amazing sauce...have to buy bread to soak it all up, more on this later)

The greens sauteed catalan style would have been perfect were they not over salted...(we love salt we swear, but too much can just ruin a good thing).

Charging for a plate of ordinary bread is a bit much even if the olive oil that accompanies it is good. 

Service was excellent.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Overrated again. This place prides itself with ecclectic spanish food. what if you wanted paella? Its not a paella joint according to the snooty waiter. A can of sardines do not cost $12.95.here it does. Want spanish? Go to Patio Espanol in Alemany. Great food portions in a real spanish setting. Maybe we'll give it another shot.. Maybe.
author: Jorydude r.

description:
Maybe it's because I'm on a small plates revival kick.  Maybe it's because I'm trying to stick to eating only local food and all their produce is grown in the very garden where I had dinner.  Maybe it's because the service was excellent and our wine choices were spot on.  Or maybe it's just because each and every dish was damn good in its unique way and I was stuffed after 2 solid hours of nibbling.  

I do try to limit my 5-star reviews so they really mean something, but this one deserves it.  And no, I'm not local to the neighborhood...the cab ride from across town will be worth it every time.
author: Jeanne J.

description:
This place lives up to all the rave reviews and hype - it is really excellent.  

They don't take reservations - so get there early if you go on a Fri night - or really late so you don't have to wait.  We ended up waiting 1 1/2 hrs arriving at 8pm on a Friday night, but just went next door for a few drinks so it wasn't that bad.  

The food was definitely worth the wait.  My favorite was the calamari and burger - it was simply delicious.  

The service and ambiance is also A+.  Will definitely go again - might try the weeknight and get there a bit earlier to avoid the long wait.
author: Gina C.

description:
Great vibe, delicious food, all around good stuff!  We shared a carafe of Albarino, which was crisp and light.

Patatas bravas were a must order.  Little gem salad also was yum - my friend said it was the best lettuce she has ever eaten. Jamon serrano was legit (i did not sample but it went fast). I wasn't as crazy about the oxtail croquettes as others but they were fine. Their version of bruscetta is awesome - not sure what they call it but I could have eaten a loaf.

Friendly service and nice ambiance made it even better.  We waited about 15 minutes on a sunday evening.  I'd say only go in groups of 4 or fewer.  If 6 or more they take reservations.
author: Aaron T.

description:
As much as I use Yelp, I have not added a review in a long time, partially due to time constraints, partially because very little has excited me of late.  Contigo is exciting.  It inspired me to add a review.  For anyone living in Noe, Bernal, the Castro, Mission, you've got yourself an amazing tapas style restaurant close by.  For everyone else, this is absolutely destination restaurant quality food.  Without a doubt. If they were in Oakland (I live, w/o a car, in Bernal Heights), I'd still go several times a year.

Just to give you an idea of the quality and authenticity of the food, this ranks right up there with places like Batali's Casa Mono in New York, and the multiple terrific local spots in San Sebastian and Barcelona.  The food, I believe, is on that level.  

Three types of ham are served:  serrano, iberico de bellota and Iowa's excellent La Quercia prosciutto.  On a busy Friday night, my fellow diners and I enjoyed a number of 'pica picas':  setas a la plancha (sauteed mushrooms with a parsley pesto); tortilla de hongos (Spanish omelette with black trumpets); croquetas de buey (fried balls of savory, pimenton inflected brisket - delicious, especially with a squirt of the accompanying lemon); a perfectly dressed, piquant chicory salad and a wood fire roasted coca (Catalan flatbread) with radicchio and house made Basque chorizo.

For a platillo (entree) I had fried skate served over a red pepper sauce.  Tasty but slightly overcooked and stringy.  I love skate, have eaten and cooked it on several occasions, and never have experienced this type of texture.  Anyway, good flavors though.

Desserts looked delicious.  We just had some ice cream - olive oil and chocolate cardamom - the former tasty and the latter a bit gritty from cardamom and cocoa and also a tad icy.

A few other non-food related observations and comments on others' reviews.  To reiterate others' comments, this is a brand new restaurant - be patient.  Timing may be a bit off (ours was perfect up until the entree, where things proceeded to lag).  Servers may not yet know all their stuff (ours did just fine, and was quite personable as well).  Regarding the price, it should not cost you $125/person as one reviewer suggested.  Four of us ate several small plates, had three platillos, shared a bottle of reasonably priced wine and ordered one dessert and tea.  Total including tax and tip was about $50/person.  Even if we had indulged a bit more with food and wine it would have been about $70.  For tapas (especially of this caliber) that's a bargain.  Sorry, when you factor in the currency exchange it's not much cheaper in the best spots in Spain right now.  It's 2009, not 1999.

One last comment - not a wine geek's wine list.  You're not going to see LdH, wines from Ribera Sacra, multiple types of palo cortado,  Not yet anyway.

If you are a fan of tapas, check this place out.  You'll probably like it a lot.
author: joe m.

description: The tapas are great for sharing and quite tasty.  A few are on the oily side though.  I was disappointed by the tasting menu - it seemed to have all of the staples that I could order at any tapas restaurant.  I'd prefer less quantity and more quality.  The service is also ok.  On my last visit the server forgot to order one of our dishes, which was fine since we were full at the end.  Lastly, the tables are just a tad too close together.  It's a real challenge to squeeze out if you're trapped inside.  I'm embarrassed to say that I knocked over someone's water at the next table while trying to maneuver out.  If I return, it would only be to casually dine at the counter.
author: Nicole G.

description: Can't believe this restaurant is around the corner from our house - dangerous! We've been to Contigo four or five times now and have never been disappointed.  We love the sardine and avodado toast, the squid ink risotto, and the yummy cava wines.  Service is professional and warm.  One of the best restaurants in SF for sure.
author: allison s.

description:
Great food, cozy space, BUT only so-so service.  Time is of the essence, you cannot relax and enjoy your meal before people start staring daggers at you to get up and go.  Also, they kept forgetting to serve drinks we ordered and would ask "oh do you still want it?"  

I doubt I will go back and I doubt they would care.
author: Lisa G.

description: came here based on my other friend'd recommendation for dinner, with my BFF after a spa day @ Bliss and since neither of us had tapas before we opted for the $42 pp 7-plate menu plus a 1/2 order of the fried potato with aioli and the cake with blood orange for dessert - it was the perfect portion dinner for the two of us - everything was delicious - my friend wants to bring her BF there on their next date when she is in the City
author: Mia C.

description:
Upgraded to five stars. Two recent experiences at Contigo have been excellent.

*************************************

It was our first time at Contigo tonight after having walked by many, many times on our way to some place else.

Service was excellent - efficient, friendly, and helpful. The food was great, too - we enjoyed every bite.

But some portion sizes were small given the prices. The albondigas were excellent, but 3 small meatballs for $8 is too steep. Ditto for the olives and almonds - a tiny dish of each for $6. The chard, which was excellent, was a tiny little plateful. C'mon Contigo - chard is cheap!

Our dinner, with tax and tip (no drinks), came to $75. Had it been $65, this would be a five star review (and we'd be enjoying Contigo at least every other week). But hey, 4 stars isn't bad. This is a lovely, lovely place and a great addition to Noe Valley.
author: David G.

description:
New Spanish/Catalan joint? It immediately went to the top of my must-try list. Ever since my first visit to Barcelona two years ago (since followed up by an extended vacation through Spain and another trip to Barcelona just to visit my favorite resto-bar in the world, Cuines Santa Caterina), I have been absolutely in love with Barca's approach to food - simple, fresh, delicious.

I had very high hopes for Contigo and they were mostly met...but I wasn't absolutely wowed by the food. I did love the decor and layout - the multi-level dining room makes the space look bigger and more complex than it really is - basically one large rectangle.

What we had:

Asparagus with sieved egg and crispy pancetta: by far the best thing we ate - the asparagus is just barely blanched so you get crunchiness and a burst of fresh flavor.

Bacalao fritters: our least favorite of the dishes...just a bit too heavy, a bit too fishy and not that appetizing overall.

Kurobota pork bocadillo: a generous slice of ultra-fatty pork and pickled onions on a teeny brioche bun - the buttery savoriness of the pork, the slight tartness of the onions and the slight sweetness of the brioche bun worked really well together. But if you consider the fact that you are paying $7 or $8 for this laughably small "burger"....it's just a bit overpriced for what you are getting.

Spanish tortilla with black trumpet mushrooms: as far as Spanish tortillas go, this was a decent version but again...the tiny sized portion compared to the price is disproportionate. Tortilla is essentially poor man's food made of five ingredients: eggs, potatoes, onions, salt and oil. $7-8 for a teeny wedge of this is a bit unjustified. Make your portions bigger Contigo!

Calamari a la plancha: another teeny portion of calamari on a bed of arugula with a red sauce (reminded me of enchilada sauce). Not great, not bad. 

Pescaditos fritos - when I am in Spain, these tiny fried fish, which I've found in Spain called "boquerones" are my favorite tapa. Ducca, although an Italian restaurant, does a very very good version. Contigo's was ok...the fish they use are really a bit too large to be eating whole - you can feel the bones of the fish in your throat which is not entirely pleasant. Usually in Spain the fish are about half the size and the portion is 2 - 3 times as large.

Flatbread with benton bacon and asparagus: Great smoky bacon sliced paper thin, nice chewy flatbread.

Contigo is a great addition to the SF dining scene - I'm all for more Catalan or Basque places in the city. However...please make your portions bigger as they are ridiculously, laughably small.
author: Deb I.

description:
My new fave neighborhood restaurant.

Loved the Oxtail Crouquettes, Butter Beans and the dessert...
HOT CHOCOLATE AND CHURROS

Service was nice, atmosphere was friendly and hip.  I'll be back!
author: Keika L.

description:
Nice. the Beretta of Noe Valley. Hip, minimalist space, cool outdoor seating, and better food than the surrounding places (e.g. Le Zinc.)
Portions are small and you'll end up spending a bit, but it's worth it.
Get the jamon, the abondigas are good but smallish, and the grapefruit-olive-octupus thing actually works.
Skip the dessert--get cheese instead.
Good selection of Spanish wines, and the wine guy is incredibly knowledgeable, forthcoming, and accommodating with both vino and sherry samples, and a healthy sized pour.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
The wind blew me into Contigo, charmingly situated a few steps away from the corner of Castro X 24th.

We ordered a ton of food: cured anchovies, spanish olives with fried marcona almonds and pickled vegetables, a little gem salad with roasted beets, tomato salad with anchovies and olives, greens sauteed catalan style with pine nuts, raisins and garlic, wild lobster mushrooms and corn, albondigas, and coca flatbread with wild nettles.

Of all the dishes, a special place in my heart is reserved for the cured anchovies, the tomato salad with anchovies and olives and the coca flatbread with wild nettles.  My friend raved about the coca flatbread, and after having ordered it I can see why!

We ended the meal with the dirty girl strawberries in the almond meringue nest and the chocolate caliente con churros.  I loved the meringue as I'm partial to the texture, and was not that impressed with the chocolate dessert, which was surprising because chocolate is an obsession of mine.

Will I come again?  Yes, definitely!
author: Janet L.

description: My girlfriends and I shared about 7 of the tapas and some wine and it was really great! The service was a little slow and there was a crying baby sitting right next to us which put a wrinkle in the night, but everyone was friendly and the food was great so I'm still excited about coming back to this restaurant;0)
author: Veronika O.

description:
The food and service we very good at this little Noe Valley Joint.
A very nice addition to the foodie scene in the Neighborhood.

Is it worth a trip out of your way?  Probably not, but it is certainly a nice place if you are near.

Plates are small, so be prepared to spend more than you are expecting.
author: David R.

description: Love it! My new favorite restaurant. Try the flatbread...enjoy!!
author: Nicki B.

description:
The space is beautiful, simultaneously contemporary and cozy. It's not large, but it feels expansive thanks to five distinct dining zones: chef's counter, lower dining room, cava bar, upper dining room, and a heated, covered outdoor patio surrounded by herb gardens.

There's jamón from Spain (and Iowa), alongside meat and vegetables from the usual assortment of local farms. Contigo offers an assortment of small pica-pica plates ($8 each, or $21 for three). Hot tapas like crisp patatas bravas and marinated sardines take their place alongside an assortment of Spanish-accented cold small plates like the remojón: salt cod, oranges, and olives atop white radicchio.

We tried a couple of larger platillos as well: juidones a la segovia, a dreamy assortment of pork parts atop creamy butter beans. The chorizo-y txistorra burger was fabulous but very rich; be ready to share it with a friend. For dessert, we made short work of the not-too-sweet almond cake, filled with a dollop of pastry cream and a schmear of olallieberry preserves.
author: anita c.

description: I'm very upset to have to write this.  What has happened to the prices over there?  $24 for three slices of Jamon and 3 half slices of toast?  That equates to $9 each for dry toast and a thin piece of ham while squeezed into tables like sardines, ($2.50 each) shouting at your guest in front of you; right after you've waited in line for the only bathroom for 10 min.  Jes, it was delicious but come on!  $11 for 3 small meatballs? I know it's tapas but we could take a trip to Barcelona for what it would cost to attend nightly.  Not that anyone is viewing this but at least bring the prices down to reality and I wouldn't mind sitting on top of one another shouting (just like the old days...).  Even tho I've written all of this I'll still go back.  It's a great local place with good fresh food and an incredible wine list.
author: Allen V.

description:
We're fortunate to live about 2 blocks from Contigo, so we're able to eat here pretty often.  Having had a chance to sample alot of what this place has to offer, I'm in a pretty good position to say that the food is amazing.  Contigo isn't your standard Tapas place.  You could come here just for the cured meats, which range in saltiness/fattiness -- but they're all fantastic.  The restaurant's heart and soul, however, is its wood fired oven, which is used not just for delicious flatbreads, but also to import smoky deliciousness into -- among other things -- tripe with chorizo and chickpeas (not for everyone, but I love it), the pimientos de padron with sea salt, and octopus salad.  There are typical only 3 or 4 "second" plates on the menu, but you can't go wrong with any of them. Last night we shared the seared sea bass with summer vegetable safaina, ancho cress and black olive sauce.  This was sophisticated Spanish comfort food --  tremendous depth, multiple levels of flavor.  The olive sauce really balanced out the sweetness that came through the red peppers and tomatoes in the safaina, and the fish was melt-in-your mouth perfect.  
Contigo has an all-Spanish wine list, with lots of stuff by the glass.  If you don't know Spanish wines, don't worry. In addition to being generally excellent servers with a thorough knowledge of the menu, the waitstaff also knows their wines.  

Save room for dessert. You can never go wrong with any of their warm chocolate/churro combinations, but they also do wonders with whatever fruit is in season.  Last night we had an unreal fig-wrapped sweetened ricotta cake (cooked in the wood-fired oven) with local honey and fresh figs.  Light and decadent at the same time.  

Contigo is typically pretty packed with Noe/Mission/Glen Park/Casto residents, but I wonder when the rest of the City is going to catch on.  It is not just a neighborhood restaurant -- it's worth getting in the car and making a night of it.
author: Andrew E.

description:
My dad and I ate here the other night on a whim. He'd been once before and enjoyed it. I loved it. The design is great. Very welcoming, clean and bright. I like the counter by the door that looks on the tiny but effective kitchen. We ate on the back patio, covered with heat lamps - nice. 

The food was great. We had the lomo Iberico (thinly sliced ham that was devine), little gem salad (amazing dressing, light, acidic, fresh), the pizza like coca (nettles and sausage) and the salt cod fritters.  Each dish was so tasty - pleasant mix of salt, spice and crunch.

Highly recommend for friends or a date night. Great wine selection too. Our waiter, Javier, was very friendly and helpful.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Personally I love everything about this place. The wait staff are tremendous, the atmosphere is low key and laid back and the ambiance is just right.
The food really shines. Very unique dishes with a wide variety of intriquing tastes.
Check them out.
author: J A.

description: Beef cheeks were tender and delicious. And for desert, try the churros with chocolate sauce. Overall, good but not special enough to earn a 4th star.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Been trying to go here for awhile now... read a review about in the paper and was interested.. we were in the neighborhood and starving and decided to stroll on in..(so did everyone else...hence there was a wait) i love the open kitchen (everything looked so clean and sleek), they also have an outside patio, the whole restaurant layout was pretty sweet.  The service was attentive.  

We shared a little gem salad, it was quite good, the gems were crisp and the beets were perfectly cooked and seasoned.  We also had the sea scallops, the bf loved the scallops, i'm not really a scallop fan but i must say they were perfectly cook and fresh, i did love the bed of veggies it came with, nicely seasoned.  The albondigas however were a bit disappointing, the meatballs lack seasoning and tasted a bit on the bland side, the sauce that it came with however was quite tasty......last but not least....dessert... we had the Blue Bottle coffee helado...so yummy.. it was a bit pricey but hey you pay for what you get and you're also paying for the ambiance!
author: Tara B.

description:
My sweetie and I have been looking forward to Contigo's opening for some time, and it was well worth the wait!

The Tortilla de Ortigas (Spanish omelet with nettles) was muy sabrosa (very delicious), as were the Remojón and the Calamares.  The Suquet de Peix (fish stew) was fantastic, and after devouring it, we decided we had room for another dish. Enter the Coca de Alcachofas (flatbread with artichokes, spinach, and a couple of other ingredients).  Absolutely superb!  However full you might find yourself after your meal, the Churros y Chocolate is a MUST HAVE (after dipping and eating the churros, you must drink the chocolate -- don't be shy). And if you know what's good for you, you will also order the Blood Orange Tart.

Service was a bit slow, but not in a deal-breaker way.  They're still getting their sea legs, and everyone was incredibly friendly.

Note that they only take reservations for parties of six or more. We stopped in and asked how long the wait would be, and they said it would be about an hour.  They took our name and phone number and said they'd call us when a table was ready -- so we didn't have to stand around waiting.  Very professional and accommodating, I would say!

¡Bienvenidos al barrio, Contigo!
author: Jessica L.

description: decent at best, though it is unfair that i came back from Spain shortly before trying this place.  I found the food mediocre and slightly over priced for what you got.
author: Wayne L.

description:
I've eaten here twice now. The first time was just with my wife- great meal. We tried various tapas and had some wonderful Spanish wines-- definitely made us feel like we were back in Spain.

Last night, I had a birthday celebration at Contigo. There were 7 of us and we had the tapas tasting-- very generous portions and wonderful selection of food. The piquillo peppers stuffed with crab, albondigas, and goat tagine really stood out. The pork belly bocadillos as always were delish. The service was fantastic and we sat out on the back patio. It was warm and not too loud and we were able to have a great meal and conversation. 

Definitely recommend this pace for parties of all sizes.
author: Kevin H.

description:
There's a lot to love about Contigo. 

The food's great, the decor is superb and it's located off charming 24st in Noe.

Prices tend to run a little higher and portions tend to run a little smaller. The mantra here is quality not quantity. That mantra also translates into good service.

One thing I have noticed is that the estimates they give you on wait times are really liberal. Both times the actual wait time was about half what they said. This is something I really appreciated because they can get quite busy and I hate places that tell you one thing and the actual wait time is 2x longer. That's a sure fire way to start a meal angry.

I've only eaten here once but I can see it happening again and again, budget permitting. I'll withhold final verdict until I've tried this place a few times but I'm very grateful that a place like this has opened up in the neighborhood.
author: Pete C.

description: Awesome tapas place! I had dinner here with friends and we ordered a bunch of dishes to share. The crowd favorite of the night was the coca flatbread with bacon, caramelized onions and manchego cheese. It was the perfect combination of sweet and salty. Also the patates braves were really good along with their albondigas. The sauteed greens were just alright - nothing special. Definitely save room for dessert. Their churros are spectacular and if I knew it wouldn't all go to my thighs, I would have drank all of the hot chocolate it came with. Will be back for sure!
author: Amy N.

description: Was there with two girls on a Friday night.  After trying the authentic Spanish tapas in Spain during this Summer, I think I was little too picky about Tapas now.  Overall, the food were too salty.  We choose the 7 course family style among three of us.  The best among all was the sardine served on avocado toast because they didn't over seasoned it.   We like the decor and the friendly services.  Other than that, the restaurant was ok.  Thanks
author: Jade P.

description: Exceptional food in this little Noe Valley restaurant! Don't take my word for it - Alice Waters recently dished to the Financial Times that Contigo is all the hotness in San Francisco.
author: Alaina I.

description:
This place only gets two stars from me. Though the restaurant is well decorated the food in terms of flavor and portions were disappointing. 

Misses= pretty much every entrée since they were meant to be eaten by dwarfs
-sardines
-abodogitas
-fact you have to pay for bread

Things that were ok
-bocadillo pork belly
-wine list
- tart with icecream

I'm not coming back
author: Christian S.

description: It was alright but I definitely expected more and left somewhat disappointed. I wouldn't really recommend someone go out of their way to eat at Contigo. It's a good looking restaurant with a nice vibe. We got the tasting menu. At first the courses were coming out pretty fast but slowed down once the server realized we weren't keeping up. Everything was okay. I was surprised the items we received were considered to be the best on the menu that night. Also the chronology of the meal seemed weird. We received seven courses and the last two were super heavy - like patatas bravas with cheese and egg-- and then meatballs. Not an easy way to finish off the meal. So! Cute place, alright food, not exciting.
author: m t.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed a long and lovely meal here. We had the tasting menu which was excellent value. Tapas places always feel a bit overpriced once you've ordered enough plates, but with the tasting menu I felt we had a really good and reasonably priced - for the quality - meal.

Very friendly but not too attentive (I like being left alone to eat) staff and really good wine.
author: Anna M.

description:
Really nice neighborhood place. Great, friendly (and funny) servers. Wish there was a full bar, that's all.

Been there twice now. Will definitely be back.
author: Shiny D.

description: Waiting for over one hour in between appetizer and main dish is just wrong. Food is good but expensive. There are better quality Spanish food for lower price in SF.
author: Chris C.

description: Personally, I think I'm just not a tapas person, but for a tapas restaurant, Contigo wasn't bad. I was surprisingly full when the meal was finished, but nothing really wowed me. The atmosphere and decor were charming, but nothing incredible enough to bump Contigo up to a 4 star restaurant. The food is pricey, as should be expected of tapas, but everything felt slightly oversalted. Definitely had higher expectations.
author: Selena K.

description:
We had very helpful friendly service here and really enjoyed the pleasant atmosphere on a relatively quiet Sunday evening. 

The highlights for us were traditional Catalan tapas including acorn fed jamon, olives, almonds, cheeses, etc. We especially enjoyed the Coca - a pizza-like flat bread baked in a brick oven.  

Another memorable dish was the Churros and Chocolate dessert. The churros were hot and served with intensely flavored hot chocolate.
author: Pete Z.

description:
I have eaten at Contigo a few times, and generally liked their food.  However I won't be going back anytime soon, nor taking my friends there.  About 45 minutes after eating dinner there last night, I was horribly,violently ill. 

That would be bad enough and cause me to steer clear for a while, but when I called to inform them today two things left me with an even worse taste in my mouth.  (pun intended)

First, the woman who answered didn't ask what I had eaten - I.e. she was so sure it had nothing to do with *her* restaurant that she wasn't even thinking of doing a safety double-check on their food handling and safety.  Second, when I politely said I would like a refund of the money spent on dinner, she said she "couldn't do that.".  When I said that I would like to speak to a supervisor, she hummed and hawed and then offered me a gift certificate.  Now why on earth would I want to go back to somewhere that made me horrible ill? I explained this and said if she did not have authority to offer a refund I would like to speak to someone who did and could I talk to her supervisor. (In case you are wondering, we are only talking about $35.  Not a lot of money.)  At this she started to get an annoyed tone, told me no, I couldn't talk to her supervisor, and that if I didn't want a refund she was going ton hang up on me.  One more round on this, where she accused me of being rude even though I was talking in a perfectly pleasant manner and simply repeating that what I wanted was to talk to whoever did have the "power" to refund my money and she ffinally admitted that she herself was the owner!
  
Enough said.  Do you want to go somewhere that stands behind their work and will give you a refund if you have any problems, or somewhere that the owner will pretend she is a lowly employee just following orders so that she can keep your money and yet dodge responsibility.

(And for those of you who will want to jump in and say I could have gotten sick off something else, I have been perfectly healthy recently, the only other things I ate yesterday were cold cereal and toast, prepared at home and consumed about 8 hours earlier.  Had felt fine all day.  Started getting nauseous within 30 min of getting home.  After the rest of Contigo's food abruptly exited my body, within ten minutes I was back to feeling fine again.)
author: G T.

description:
Translating the word "Contigo" essentially means "Going with you", however, at Contigo in Noe Valley, it often seens that pretty much everything is against you.

Don't go expecting (very) efficient service: Empty water bottles sit on ones tables for prolonged periods of time without a refill as do dirty dishes

Don't go is you have a movie date at the Castro Theatre the same evening or any other scheduled plans: Long waits in between small plate courses can be painfully slow.

Don't agree to sit at the bar, unless you like to be punished.  It is located in the small corridor to the front door of the restaurant where hungry diners waiting to be seated crowd and bump seated patrons.

Don't go after 7 pm: Unless you like a punishing wait, arrive early.  The Great Recession?  Not in the country of Contigo.

Don't go when the temperature rises above 80 in San Francisco, because that means that in Noe Valley, it will be over 90 and at Contigo, over 130 degrees. The place becomes a oven worthy of cooking flat bread on the floor.

Do go to be seated in the outdoor patio: The cute back dining area, enclosed in a 1970's "Boy In The Bubble" plastic covering to protect diners from the fierce evening winds that blow all the street trash into The Mission is a nice addition, but don't steal the vegetables growing in the garden.

Do go with a group, but make sure the entire party is present, otherwise you won't be seated: The more people in your party, the more small plate courses you can try.

Do go expecting reasonable prices and delicious food: We might have loads of restaurants in Noe Valley, but 98% of them are mediocre and it takes a going out of business sale to allow a new one in the neighborhood. Contigo is a welcome addition to Noe Valley, even with all of the drawbacks to this new establishment.
author: Rafael R.

description:
The oxtail fritters and octopus are worth the trip. I ilked the Tennessee ham, too. The wine list needs work, but they just hired a new wine person and he said that's going to happen over the next couple of months.

Easy street parking later in the evening since area residents don't park overnight in metered spaces.
author: Robert L.

description:
Last night we headed over to Contigo. Contigo, which means "with you" in Spanish, offers a strictly Spanish wine list, and an array of Spanish style small plates, flatbreads and entrees.

We started with two different Cava's, my favorite was the rose, the Mont Marcal Reserva Brut Rosado 2005. It was tart with a slightly bitter undertone which reminded me a bit of Campari. I'm always a sucker for the pink fizzy drinks, let's be honest. The Sanstrave "e", Gran Reserva was also sampled. Not pink, but a bit less dry than the first. Both unique and refreshing.

Onto the small plates. Starting with the Esparragos-Asparagus with Jamon chips, green garlic and sieved egg, the Octopus, and the potatoes with chorizo and onion. We also ordered a flatbread with asparagus, crispy bacon and a farm egg on top for good measure. The flatbread was the highlight of the meal for me. They have a large wood-fired oven in the front of the restaurant, and the flatbread and egg on top were cooked to perfection. The asparagus was still brightly verdant and the bacon was delightfully salty and crisp. 

The octopus was good, though could have used a bit more acid (that seems to be my normal complaint) some sort of citrus or vinaigrette to compliment the flavors. We ended with the sheep's milk cheese which was extraordinarily soft, stinky and went very well with the hazelnuts it was served with.

All in all this is a fun place with the friendliest service I've encountered in San Francisco. My friend and I remarked to each of the staff members we came in contact with that they were all a pleasure and made us feel very welcome. I'd be more than happy to come back for a glass of wine at the bar or to split small plates and flatbread with a few friends. Especially with a pink and bubbly glass of rose!
author: Elissa D.

description:
So, waffling between a 3 and a 4 here.  Food was pretty good, not great though.  Service was really good.  Atmosphere, vibe, look was all very good.  A little bit on the expensive side for even high-end tapas.  Anyway, on with the review.

This is basically a fancy tapas place.  Went with my friend George and we were both starving after workouts and ready to eat a LOT.

We started off with a taste test between jamon serrano ($9) and jamon iberico ($21).  OK, $21 is a lot for a couple of slices of cured ham.  But it sure is delicious.  The iberico is more like a ribeye or kobe, super fatty and melt in your mouth.  The serrano is more like a ny strip, much meatier taste.  Both are great.  George preferred serrano, I preferred iberico.  But I'll prob get my iberico from Bi-rite next time.

The small tapas are $7 if you get 3 or more.  We got, in order of deliciousness:

2 orders of oxtail croquettas (these are AMAZING rich croquettes, DELICIOUS)
snap peas and mushrooms (delicious, but you know, peas and mushrooms...)
patatas bravas (delicious fried potatoes with OK sauce)
butter beans w/ chorizo/pig's ear/trotter (basically fancy pork and beans, except with a FRIED PIG EAR ON TOP, pretty solid)
and the only real letdown
albondigas - very bland meatballs that were lukewarm, not seasoned, and a little undercooked

So, including the jamons, that was 8 total small items.  6 small or 4 small + 1 large is probably the right amount for 2 people.

Plenty of good by the glass wine selections, and knowledgeable servers on both food and wine.

For dessert we had churros con chocolate (thick hot chocolate).  Delicious.  One order is definitely plenty for two.  George of course forgot the size of the order and insisted that we had to get two orders.  I suspected something was up when the waiter said in a very surprised voice, TWO ORDERS!?  The chocolate is great, the churros are pretty good, but not great.  A little too much sugar caked on them for me, but maybe I'm biased because I had to stuff down four of them.

We ordered way too much, but normal dinner here with a couple of glasses of wine each and dessert/coffee will prob run about $60.  A little on the pricey side for what you get, but not too bad.  Overall, I'd say I'm pretty neutral on this place.  I'd be happy to go again, but it's not high on my list of places I feel like I need to go back to real soon.
author: Deva H.

description:
Cute and very solid neighborhood tapas joint. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I lived in the neighborhood it would definitely be one of my local joints. The food was good, but didn't totally impress me. We had the fresh grilled calamari and it was a little bland. The fried sardines were really good though. The lamb tagine was not memorable, but the skate with a spicy sauce on the side was somewhat memorable. You get some good and you get some just ok, that's what makes this place just 3 stars.  

The wine director seemed a little stand offish or maybe snotty. We were asking for wine advice, but he didn't seem to be recommending anything just spewing out characteristics of the wine.
author: Karen C.

description:
Our party of four showed up with no reservation on a Sunday night. We were quickly seated at the bar, which in most circumstances is not ideal for sharing 'small plates,' but the bar was more than wide enough and we had a great view of the kitchen. 

The food was terrific. We shared six plates and raved about each of them. A couple of highlights are:
- Shaved Asparagus (served as a salad)
- Calamares (not fried) and
- Albondigas (lamb and pork meatballs).

The wine was good, and seemed reasonably priced. 

The staff was nice, knowledgeable and brought our food out at a leisurely pace allowing us to enjoy the meal. 

On the whole I was very impressed that this new restaurant seemed to run like they had been open for years. Bring friends so you can try as many plates as possible, and expect to have to wait for a table. From what I have heard, this place has been very popular and there's usually a wait. 

Enjoy.
author: Kemp M.

description: I probably need to go back to Contigo during my next SF visit, since I wasn't feeling awesome and wasn't super hungry when we dined here.  In any case, I thought it was a good Spanish-inspired restaurant (wines by the glass were particularly impressive).  The food was good, though there were only a couple of things that really jumped out at me as being amazing (the sardine-avocado toast with pickled onions, and the fabulous churros).  Service was a little distracted, and I cannot believe there is only ONE toilet for all of those people - it's not a huge place, but there are enough seats in the restaurant to justify a little more bathroom space, methinks.
author: Betty R.

description:
Hmmmm.

Good, though we weren't blown away. 
Overall verdict: fine, good staff, overpriced, better tapas elsewhere in the city.

A beautiful space -- we had good first impressions, the place was bustling at 9pm on a Thursday. Granted it's still semi-new, so we were exepcting it to be full, but the wait turned out to be only a quick minute or two.

We were promptly greeted by a knowledgable server who helped us with our wine and food selections. 

Once we ordered, food arrived very quickly--perhaps too quickly--but still coursed nicely. Tried the beet & clementine salad (good), tortilla de hongos (bland and boring), lamb croquettes (very good; our server's recommendation) and calamari (fine).

Then the halbut (we were all underwhelmed) and a flatbread w/ jamon and (good though incredibly light).

After those first six dishes, the three of us were still hungry and had to go for some heartier dishes -- patatas bravas (the old standard) and another order of lamb croquettes.

We ended up paying ~$50/person with tip, including a bottle of wine split three ways, and weren't incredibly full but content enough.

Overall, I liked the space but the food was nothing spectacular. Having recently dined at Zarzuela in Russian Hill, and with all the buzz with Contigo's opening, I had high expectations... not sure I'll be back, though, unless someone else is paying. 

They should definitely consider weekend brunch service, given the location and great space.
author: Daniel P.

description:
One of the things I love about living in San Francisco is occasionally finding a hidden gem restaurant every once in a while. Contigo is definitely one of them. 

I wouldn't even have heard about this place had my friend from culinary school not tipped us off about the place. Our party of four former classmates sat down and asked the waitress to have the chef send out whatever he thought we should eat (I love ordering this way). 

Highlights that stuck in my mind were baby squid cooked on 'la plancha': the most tender, juicy squid I can recall having topped with a lovely harissa sauce. There was a wooden board covered with mounds of earthy, piggy, delicious Iberian ham shaved on a racing car red imported meat slicer. There was the opulent crispy pork belly over white beans. Pork and beans have never been so happy together. There was the fried skate wing with artichokes. The skate wing was breaded and fried perfectly and lightly. The artichokes were lemony and had a wonderful caramelization.

And then the churros. Anyone who has churros on the dessert menu automatically gets points with me. Freshly fried and served with a Barcelona style hot chocolate... What on this great earth could be better?

The venue was also very modern, cozy, and 'earthy'. I'm definitely a fan
author: Terry N.

description:
Delicioso!  Very good tapas.    Can't think of one dish we did not like.  Waiter was fun.  Good crowd...mix of the Castro Hip and the Noe Yup.  But it's very popular, so expect crowds.  Worth the wait.  Also, very nicely designed space.

We left fat and happy!
author: Gary H.

description: Definitely the best restaurant in Noe Valley. Absolutely delicious!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Gorgeous interior -- and when they open the back patio, it'll be fabulous. I love having an open kitchen where you can watch the staff at work.  The environment was very pleasant for a nice dinner with a friend. 

Food was good, as per Bay Area tapas standards, with some nice twists. We had a tortilla with nettles, the asparagus, chickpeas and spinach with mint and sauteed mushrooms. All were shockingly filling for 2 people, even at the tapas sizes. There was plenty for lacto-ovo vegetarians, so I was happy.

We dined here the second night they were open and they were still a little slow on things like water, which was necessary given the salty nature of a lot of the food we had ordered.  In general, service was not only slow, but inattentive. The wait staff still needed to learn about various items on the menu (e.g. what is this random ingredient listed here?), but that will hopefully come in time.

I will caution, tables are *extremely* close together. I'm a small person (5', and thin) and so was the unknown woman next to me and we still had to squeeze through to get to our seats. 

I look forward to going back and seeing them iron out their opening week kinks and having a lovely meal.
author: Carla B.

description:
Went here tonight -- had high expectations and were excited about a new addition to our 'hood. Overall, the food was good - not amazing and lifechanging. The biggest issue was the service -- host was friendly, accommodating, but it pretty much went downhill as soon as we were seated. At any one time, we had no idea 1) who our server was and 2) where they were. 4 of our tapas came out at once, and then one took quite awhile longer -- we were left with scraps of bread and dregs of wine -- not a pretty sight. When we asked a passing waiter where our final dish was he said "Oh, we don't want too many things on the table". Umm....ok. On top of that, the table next to us seemed to be friends of the chef or owner or something -- waiters/waitresses were super attentive to their party. 
Anyway, here's the run down on the dishes we had: 

1) Lamb skewers: well seasoned, juicy, but way too small - I know, tapas are supposed to be bite size, but this was not worth it.
2) Jamon serrano reserva: Good, but hard to screw up. With no accompaniments, it left us feeling unsatisfied. We had to ask twice for a few slices of bread.
3) Pescaditos: delicious, crunchy little fish -- this was probably the best part. 
4) Lengua: good, but it took forrrrrrrrever and it was a cold dish. 

Wine list was good - interesting variety. 

Overall, they need to step up their service and figure out how to pace dishes a bit better.
author: Kate T.

description: This place was super cute and the service was great!  The Chocolate Churro dessert was amazing!  Fancy Tapas and worth the price.  Definitely would come back here again.
author: Sonia M.

description:
Cuisine: Kinda like a tapas place, but some new combinations and ingredients I've not seen elsewhere. Maybe it's some super-regional specialties they focus on? It's definitely a place to share plates (so come with a lot of people to taste everything).

Menu: The type of menu that immediately makes you want to try everything. Dishes are well-described and the combination of ingredients is really tempting.

Service: Knowledgeable, polite, just-right. Complimentary sparkling water brought to the table, great recommendations about dishes to try and amount of food. Top-notch.

Decor: Cool! Lots of cool touches everywhere. Uber-modern, but lots of warmth from natural wood and natural light from the backyard (covered) patio. They make a lot from a small space. Great little touches like the tableware, the open kitchen, even the restroom.

Food: Delicious. (Note that I didn't say mind-bending or earth-moving, but pretty darn tasty across the board.) Everything pretty much lived up to the expectations set by the server and the menu. A few items I remember:
-Sardine toasts: huge winner
-Asparagus soup: very nice, but not the end-all
-Goat cheese salad: tasty
-Roasted cauliflower: as good as anyplace I've tried
-Salt-cod fritters: tasty
-Imported ham: superb - the real deal, but crazy $$$$.
-Housemade orange soda: skip it

Wines: Spanish-only. I needed a lot of help deciphering the list! Thankfully our server was pretty well-versed in the different regions, varietals, etc. The wine we got was quite good, but by-the-glass prices are too high.

Value: OK. We left not-quite-full at $50/person (and only half of us drank wine). Quality and decor were suited to the prices, but portion sizes were too small. I think the tasting menu would have been a better value.

Overall: We had a very nice time and we'll definitely come back.
author: Al M.

description: Overall nice restaurant.  It is pricey for the portions.  The waiter, although a bit strange, nailed our request for a dry and spicy red wine.  All the waiters covered for each other - nice team work.  If one waiter was busy another waiter would help his table out.  Food was full of flavor.  Really loved the pan tostado of jamon!  Down side was the fish in our suquet was a little undercooked.
author: B c.

description: Flippin' delicious. Go for the nettle pizza and make sure to finish it up with the Blue Bottle flan.
author: Jeph F.

description: We had a large group and lots of tapas to share.We sat outside in the back. Both the food and ambiance were great. Highly recommended!
author: O'Brien J.

description:
Solid on all fronts.  Authenticallly Spanish/Catalan in the "innovative sense" - a very cool place to dine that combines food, decor, atmosphere to create a good experience.  

Waiters were very much in the know about the menu and wine list, and our experience was quite nice and worth a return visit.  Well done!
author: Jason H.

description:
While tapas are ubiquitous in Spain, the food here in this SF hideaway is generally a good try at something authentic.. but we left this restaurant thinking it does not know what it wants to be... more about the staff being overly shallow and really missing how a true Spanish Tapas restaurant works than anything else. I would have given more stars on account of the food but as an overall experience I just give it a 3.
First of all the greeters/Maitre d's need to lighten up both times they have been overly rude with their needless grandiosity/overly fake interest in you, and you feel like your going through a vetting process to come in, and surprisingly this happened on two occasions with two different people.
When you sit down and see the menu in Catalan, Castilian and English.... where are we going with this we wondered, we all know two of those dont mix :)....
Back to the food with wafer thin slices of the ruby red wonder which is jamón ibérico de bellota, arguably the greatest item of food in the world to the albóndigas, fideuà with txistorra, and chocolate con churros all very very good, but this is a Spanish restaurant and yes we like bread with our food and we don't want to be rushed and we want you to bring the food in the right way.  As we sat finishing, we thought on a cold foggy SF morning, Chocolate con Churros would be the perfect treat but this place is only open in the evening. We will go back hoping the staff get better but last time we left before being seated because of the attitude we were being given by the maitre d while waiting for a table.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Great food !! Good service.  The pork/meat balls with the spicy tomato sauce was very good. The flatbread pork broccoli dish (fancy way of saying thin crust pizza) was very tasty !!! The asparagus dish was great too !  We'd order these three again for sure !!! Except there are more dishes that sound great, to try next time !

The beet salad was 'ok', as was the calamari dish. The former wasn't bad, the later was much saltier than I prefer. This may just be a personal preference though.
author: Andy W.

description:
I have been waiting for a long time for the opening of this place.Every morning on my way to work I wondered what was behind "contigo" . Now, after 3 days of its opening, I know! 

They just accept reservations for parties of 6 or more, so we just walked in. It was around 8.30 when we got there and there was a big line.

The hostess was really nice. She took our number and she called back as soon as she had seating available for us. She said the wait would be 40 min, so as the place was crowded we went to a bar nearby. After 20 min she called us.

We sat at the bar, perfect for us as we love to watch people cooking.

We did only tapas - that have good size -(as we wanted to have room for dessert):

 remojón (salad of salted cod and oranges) - loved it! Olives , salt cod and oranges with frisee make a perfect combination! The cod was perfect, not too salty...

tortilla de ortigas - it was OK. I am still trying to figure out what was missing. Maybe a little bit of salt, a little less olive oil...

calamares a la plancha - DELICIOUS! Really... Cooked to the perfect texture and with a really tasty spicy sauce.

croquetas de rabo de toro - Our favorites! 

We also asked for bread and olive oil. 

For wine we went with a "garrafa" of Portuguese Touriga Nacional. Very good!  

For dessert we shared the bread pudding with dates, that was a little bit on the sweet side but delicious.

We enjoyed the space. Not pretentious , not too loud,  simple but very elegant decoration, cool silverware and other little details...

The service was good, with exception with the water, that took a little bit to come to the table.  

5 stars to the hostess : She made sure she spelled my name right. When I told her that was with "f" and not "ph" she made the point of correcting it. I know is a little detail, and even if I am use to people write down my name on a confident manner but wrong, I appreciated a lot her effort to take it right!

As this is in the neighborhood I hope to go back many times and I am sure they will get even better!

P.S.: I have to mention that I LOVED the map in the restroom... Ok, besides food and wine, I like maps!
PS2: And the little paper clip with a pig shape that holds the check and the cute postcard.
author: Sofia S.

description:
The young friendly Spanish waiter who patiently explained the menu made us feel like we were transported to Spain. Contigo is a very stylish place with a nice covered outside space at the rear. A modern restaurant with many pleasing touches. The two of us  shared three tasty small plates (pica-pica) at $7 each and a more elaborate larger fish dish (platillo) for $18. All tasted fresh, were well prepared and artfully presented. Our choice of  spanish vino blanco and a portuguese vino tinto complemented the food well. (The latter at $6 a glass was great value.) The catalan-style vanilla custard (flam) with salty caramel completed the satisfying meal. 

Contigo was a very pleasant experience and is a great addition to Noe Valley. We will be back!
author: Geoff L.

description:
I stopped in here for dinner with my boyfriend early on Saturday night. We sat at the bar. 

The run down - 

- The bar was nice and all the guys working in the kitchen were nice to look at!
- The food was tasty. I really loved the wine I had. I also ordered brussel sprouts and the chicken. The brussel sprouts were nothing special. The chicken was very tender, but the gravy was a bit salty. 
- the hostess was extremely nice
- Not sure about the decor past the bar area. It seemed to give me a picnic-table impression. Maybe if i sat in the dining room I'd have a different feeling. Looks like they had a heated outdoor area in the back
- A bit expensive for the small portions. Chicken: $21, Brussels: $7, wine: $10 glass
- Limited beer selection
- Fast service. 

I gave 3 stars because even though it was tasty, I probably wouldn't go back.
author: M E.

description:
Food was mediocre. 
Flatbread might have been good, but was WAY oversalted. 
Beef with french fries...mediocre, although cooked medium rare as we asked it to be.
Salads were teeny, tiny.  
Service was earnest, yet unenthusiastic.
Deserts were better than salad/entree. We wished we had skipped the salads and entrees.
Coffee was yummy. 
The one child in the restaurant was only around 3 years old, but was playing with an iPod, not knowing what he was doing with it, but the bright screen kept him engaged while Mommy and Daddy attempted to decipher Contigo's menu. 
Very Noe Valley. (No substance.)
Caveat emptor.
But, perhaps this is the "new" San Francisco.
author: Adam K.

description: How I love this little Spanish spot!  Welcoming space, beautifully made food and a lovely neighborhood vibe.  Casual yet classy, great use of local ingredients, pig to tail philosophy (which is the best), incredible flavors and a fabulous wine list.  I really do not understand the negative reviews.  Contigo is a warm, innovative, sustainable, fresh, seasonable restaurant run by a wonderful family.
author: Jo A.

description:
Contigo is my new favorite neighborhood restaurant.  The oxtail croquettes was the best oxtail preparation I've had since I can remember.  The serrano ham was fantastic as were the patatas bravas and the pork belly.

The chocolate and churros are definitely worth the calories for desert.  Good wine list as well!
author: Joe S.

description: This is arguably the best restaurant in Noe (along with Incanto and La Ciccia).  Great staff and consistently delicious food.  Love what they do with interesting vegetables (fig greens) and cocas and adore the brussel sprouts: please keep that on the menu!  Desserts are not as strong as the regular menu, and I miss that they got rid of blue bottle coffee in favor of sightglass (not as yummy in my opinion).
author: Mala K.

description: Excellent tapas, reasonably priced, beautiful, delicious, and very Catalan in style. Good service, but I swear it took FOREVER to get our bill, fortunately we were very relaxed and in no hurry. Definitely a must repeat.
author: J B.

description: I see that a lot of people have not been happy with the pricing at this restaurant.  I dined here on Wednesday night and tried the menu of the day.  It is a four course tasting menu with great selections.  It costs $35 per person and I felt VERY well worth it.  Fresh delicious vegetables, great desserts, many main dishes to choose from.  I lived in Spain for 4 mos. a few years ago and the aromas and offerings definitely brought me back.  My bill was a little higher because I indulged in 2 glasses of cava (Spanish sparkling wine), which were deeelicious ($8 - $10 per glass).  So, if you'd like good value I'd suggest their seasonal menu of the day.  Loved every second :o)
author: Julie L.

description:
Warm attentive service.  Tasty, well executed food.  Highly recommend.

Recently hosted a bday party for my girlfriend here for 15 people.  Restaurant managers helped craft a seven course pre-fixe menu.  Service and food were excellent throughout the night.  We all had a blast.
author: David C.

description: I had my birthday dinner here last week. The food, wine, and service couldn't have been better. They were extremely accommodating to our group of 15, and somehow we all managed to sit together in a way that was both comfortable and still intimate. My favorites were the pork belly sliders, sardine tapas, crab pasta, calimari a la plancha and churros con chocolate - I guess that is everything we tried! :)
author: Clara S.

description: So I have to say, I've always loved the idea of tapas but no one in SF really does it that well.  It's been more about the concept of little dishes and less about execution of good food.  Contigo however does it right.  Deliciousness.  We had a nice sampling of everything, sardine toast, croquettas (yum!), clams, jamon iberico, salads...all were so good.  The staff was also amazing.  Our server Rafa was a doll.  Great recommendations of food & wine with a side of cute stories from his childhood growing up in Spain.  Made us feel like we were hanging out at a neighborhood restaurant in Spain.  So welcoming and fun!  Nothing wrong with that on a Friday night after a long week in the office.  Thanks Rafa!
author: Carol W.

description:
Fabulous! The food was amazing. I went with a group so we ordered one of almost everything on the menu. Highlights were the smashed peas on toast, little gem salad with beets and mint, the halibut entree and the pork entree. We had an apricot upside down cake with heavenly ice cream for dessert.
I agree that the prices are a little steep for some of the small servings, but it was such high quality food.
I would like to take off 1/2 star for our server who seemed rather snobby and not very friendly.
author: W D.

description:
Alirght....I live right down the street and I'm Spanish so of course I was thrilled when this place opened and went right away. I took my cousin and we reveled in the Spanishness of it all. 

Kudos to the restaurant for picking a region and sticking to the cuisine, flavors, and culture! Too often restaurants try to envelope an entire county's cuisine in one menu! 

If you want a true taste of Catalonian culture and cuisine hit this place up. Even the atmosphere and decor resonate my home country. No tacky yellow and red emblazoned all over the place, instead you find the bright colors, clean lines, and open space common to Catalonia. 

The food was good (Not AMAZING), the menu is well balanced, our cava was delicious, but the service was spectacular. Very attentive, friendly and kind. We sat at the bar and we looking at the on-goings when one of the sous chefs even stopped to ask if we needed anything or had any questions. Def try the place. Best with a small group of friends.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
Really great tapas and amazing desserts. Just try it. I loved the homemade lemon soda (did they use a Meyer lemon? Cuz those class of lemons cost $$$). 

They recommend 2-3 tapas a person. My favorite dish was the chorizo and tripe. I also tried the beef stew, but the chorizo and tripe is such an unusual combination. Potatoes, something-roons, and calamari-type salad were all really good too. 

if you are overwhelmed, just try the chorizo and tripe, lemonade and churros and hot chocolate. I did like the ice cream served with honey and  almond cake was good. I really like the candied lemon peel, which added a nice touch.
author: A H.

description:
I love everything about this place - appetizers, mains, sherry selection...

... except the wait for a table. Are they taking reservations yet?
author: Colin D.

description:
We have visited Contigo twice now.  Once on a weeknight when it was not crowded and the staff was attentive and the food better than average. At that point, we thought it was a solid three stars with a potential for a fourth if it could maintain consistency in future visits. The wine list Includes some unusual choices and we found an inexpebsive gem from Portugal that we now stock at home as well. 
That brought us to our second visit in the hopes that Contigo would become a neighborhood gem and earn it's fourth star.  We came around 9 on a Saturday night with a reservation. The place was packed but we were seated right away -- a big plus in my book.  Then things began to go a bit sideways.  The waitress informed us that the kitchen was out of both rabbit legs and octopus (two of the most appetizing choices on the menu).  OK, regrettable but it happens.  So we order two appetizers and two main courses.  The Jamon Iberica is delicious but of course the same as the one I order on line and not a tribute to the kitchen. The crab salad included good size chunks of crab and was well dressed.  So far so good. The trout skin was crispy and the seasonal Brussel sprouts and hazelnuts as a bed to the trout were tasty and well prepared. Then one of the staff stopped by to tell us that they ran out of the mushroom entree we had ordered an hour ago!  There was a vague sort of apology but nothing approaching the level of contrition I would have expected.  No offer to comp a different entree or anythingfor that matter.  These are the momenta that make or break restaurants, especially small neighborhood restaurants in a highly competitive environment.  And here Contigo's management failed miserably. There wasn't another main course worth ordering.  So I just asked for a big helping of the cheese course. Out came a meager offering of cheese and insuffficient bread -- not even warm bread at that.  Goodbye extra star and no choice but to drop Contigo down to two stars despite better than average food. 
Unless Contigo gets a better handle on customer service in a business that is not just about food but about how you make people feel when they eat that food, I would joy expect them to last another year. 
We won't be back.
author: Sweet B.

description:
I have been waiting for months for this place to open in my hood and it finally has.  In the two weeks that it as been open I have gone twice, both with pleasant experiences. 

1st time was with the parents from out of town on 13-March. We got there at 6:30pm and had to wait about an hour. By the time we sat down we were quite hungry so it was perfect. My parents are sooooo picky on going out to eat cauz they are excellent cooks and they really liked it.  We got the Pica-pica (sardinas fritas, patatas a la riojana y callos madrilenos), coques (coca amb pernil), and judiones a la segoviana. This was plenty for three and quite delicioso. The callos reminded me of my grandma's tripe...yumm. The chorizo in the patatas, El Palacios, was also very good. Also de judiones were perfect.  the wine steward was extremely helpful and patient with us trying to find a nice bottle of wine.  We ordered dessert (three helados: bittersweet choco cardomon, olive oil and tangelo) which were OK. 

2nd time was just last night with a dear friend and we sat at the 4-seat bar in the middle of the room with our host Andrew, nice knowledgeable helpful guy.  We pretty much had the same menu as my last visit, it was just sooo good, Pica-Pica (patatas a la riojana, callos madrilenos and the bocadillo de cerdo), and a coques (coca amb seco). This was enough for two and with a couple glasses of wine and cava for dessert.......this was a perfect amount of food , not to pricey, and also very yummy.

The dessert menu is not too appealing to me for some reason but I will one day try the hot chocolate and churro though.  The wine list I like. Diverse enough for all taste and the prices are reasonable. 

The atmosphere and wait staff is great. The wait to be seated though can get crazy so go early or be ready to put your name down and go somewhere else for drinks, they will call you when your table is ready. I can't wait to have better weather to try the outside but this will definitely be a stop on my way home for a glass of vino and a pica pica for chow. 

CONTIGO bienvenido a NV....we have been waiting for a new, NOT Italian, place here.  I am recommending it to all even my Spanish/ Barcelona boss and all my friends that ask me for a new place to eat.
author: Jacqueline A.

description: I'd like to write a review, but apparently business is so good here they will not take a reservation for 11 people.  Sad, in this economy or maybe they are doing so well they don't need 11 professional individuals dining at the restaurant.  Cheers, we found another place to host us.
author: Darren I.

description:
I took my whole family here to celebrate my mom's birthday (this was my second visit) and we all had a fabulous time. It's perfect for an intimate dinner for 2-4 - definitly feel like I could spend hours here sipping wine and chatting away. As for the food, I have a soft spot for all things spanish/barcelona and not to mention anywhere that serves whole griled anchovies and sardines (drool) so I was especially excited to make a return visit here.

Highlights were the pulpo salad with fennel and citrus (i love octopus and this tapa was refreshing and perfectly seasoned), the artichoke and carmalized onion "coca" (the carmalized onions melted in my mouth), the sardine toasts. I got the chocolate y churros for dessert (naturally) but I have to say my dad's apricot tart was what really blew me away. The service is excellent, the atmosphere is warm, and you will certainly leave this place stuffed.
author: Nikki L.

description:
The lamb tagine was delicious... best lamb I've had in a long time.  couscous was perfect and the miniature turnips with greens were a nice addition.

pork belly slider, salt cod fritters, spanish omelet... all good.  for desert, a pear tart with olive oil ice cream (a pleasant surprise) and flan with burnt sugar and a hint of seville orange.  with a glass of pedro ximenez, a perfect meal.

nothing risky on the menu.  perfect for noe valley!

service was excellent.  prices reasonable, good spanish wine selection.
author: Greg H.

description:
Some dear friends recently returned from Maui happily engaged. Before the napkin selection and save-the-date project overtake them completely, we thought to toast over a stream of great food and a bottle of bubbly. Enter Contigo.
The space is perfect for this sort of thing, vibrant but not loud, intimate but not pretentious. We were sat within just a few minutes of our reservation and service shined thru-out. Never rushed, but plates were cleared efficiently and the meal kept moving.
We ordered all kindsa things and left more than saited. I felt the standouts were the veggies-- the asparagus had a tangy, delicious romanesco and the artichokes nicely done, left delicate. I didn't love the Oxtail, but others did, so it may be operator error on my part (just a gamey meat to me..), and i liked the esthetic-- presented in the stuffed peppers. 
-the sardines were flavorful, if salty, and the soft subtle of avocado balanced that well.
-dessert of choc and churros was a little meh on my end, but i seek a dark, bitter chocolate flavor and this was more milky.
A lovely spot for toasting reckless love.. now let the pragmatics begin! i'll be on their Maui dance floor in October to be sure.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Nice vibe, intimate and laid back.

Innovative and tasty menu. be sure to try the asparagus salad, calamari with ink and braised oxtail.

well done Contigo!
author: Carrie F.

description:
We first went to Contigo only a week after they opened. It was our first taste of tapas in a long time, and it was a fabulous, table-pounding experience (not that we actually pounded the table). I always thought tapas were small plates that left you hungry. Contigo's tapas are small, but they are quite satisfying (unless you're a glutton). The secret is their freshness: the flavors seep out of every bite; their apparent simplicity belies their skillful execution. They date the menu, too, so you know it's not a predictable list.

Contigo is popular, so get there early if you want a table without waiting for it. On our first visit, on a Saturday around 8 PM, the wait for a table was 40 minutes but the counter was free, so we took it. On our second visit, on a Tuesday at 6, we specifically asked for the counter even though we could have sat anywhere. If you're just two people, by all means opt for the counter: the kitchen is right there and so much fun to watch -- not because it's chaotic but because it's so quiet. Your food is prepared calmly right in front of you -- and handed to you right over the glass partition. Such service!

As you can see from glancing at the kitchen, and the menu, the ingredients are local and very fresh. The (red and golden) Beets and Pixie Tangerines were a juicy combination, complemented by chopped almonds, arugula, and a dab of smooth ricotta. The Sardine and Avocado Toasts from their wood oven were a revelation: mouthwatering fish atop smooth, buttery avocado (which I normally dislike) and crisp toasts that did not completely fall apart when bitten. Gambas al Ajilloo were garlicky and generously sized Florida white shrimp, whose sauce was worth the price of another order of artisanal bread just for dipping into. Albondigas were tender lamb and pork meatballs served on a delicious puree of almond garlic ajo blanco. 

These four "pica-pica" dishes ($8 each or $7 when ordering three or more) and two glasses of Cava (the complex Raventlos i Blanc, $9, and the rose-colored Mont Marcal, $8) were enough to fill us without denting our wallet too much -- and still left room for two desserts: Barcelona-style hot chocolate with crisp churros and a tangy lemon tart with caramelized sugar on the top.

The tab came to $62 -- steep, yes, but it was really delicious food served with attentiveness and care. Although we noticed on our recent trip to Barcelona that Cava is much less expensive in Spain, we didn't find any tapas dishes there that compare to the quality, fresh local produce, and meats that create the tapas at Contigo. Contigo serves up special, tasty plates using locally sourced ingredients in a relaxed atmosphere. Plus, any restaurant that says on its menu that it's closed May 1st in observance of International Workers' Day knows how to treat its workers right.
author: Stefan G.

description:
my partners in dine, ingrid m. and sonia m., came here to celebrate a bday on a rare and delightfully warm evening in september. seated on the patio next to a mini veggie garden we enjoyed the lomo, padron peppers, gem salad, patatas bravas, anchovies on toast, albondigas, and the flatbread. the only dish that fell flat for us was the dessert, next time i'm getting the churros!

the ambiance is really nice, the open kitchen is super cool, the bathroom is gorgeous, and the service was excellent. the only downside, is that the dining room seemed really loud. thankfully we were seated on the patio!
author: Wanda D.

description: We have been here several times now and each time we have really enjoyed it. The ambiance is great. We have had a variety of the dishes and have enjoyed them. We especially liked the paella, the potatoes bravas and their baked ricotta cheese dish.
author: Nima K.

description: Frankly never really understood what the big deal was about Spanish food before eating here. Flawlessly executed dishes, extensive list of sherry, and artisanal cured hams. The service is professional, but warm. The arroz negre with calamar is otherworldly. Not to be missed.
author: Ben R.

description:
The food was good but not exceptional in any way.

I was annoyed coz they kept running out of the good stuff. ....they ran out of patatas bravas!!!!! 
By the time we were ready to order dessert, they ran out of the dessert special (bread pudding) which was praised to us earlier and we were so looking forward to trying. 
We half heartedly ordered the apple tart  from the menu instead, which the waitress came back and informed they that ran out of  as well :(

I am giving them 2 stars for not being better prepared on a Friday night.
author: Insi L.

description: This place is excellent as long as you're in the mood for some pretentious dining.
author: Matthew B.

description: This is my new favorite casual resto.  Love the space, the food, the atmosphere.  You cannot go wrong with the Spanish acorn-fed ham to start.  The meatballs are a wonder, as are the flatbreads, and, basically, everything else I tried.  The service is friendly and knowledgeable and they are happy to pour you tastes of wines you aren't sure about.  Best of all, the atmosphere is so convivial you cannot help but enjoy yourself.  Just the right level of energy, noise, etc.  Happy, happy, happy, yum, yum, yum.
author: Laura W.

description:
Thought the food was pretty good, even though we froze our butts outside waiting for a table.  What's up with no reservations?  

Ham was great, but couldn't taste any chorizo in the chorizo oil (in the squid ink dish) - somewhat disappointing.  The service was slow, but not a big deal.   May go back.
author: Ellen R.

description: Modern take on tapas, great quality but a little pricey IMO.  Beware the hard-pumping yuppy clientele.
author: Alex M.

description: Food was not bad, but not memorable and did not justify a bill of $150 for two. Wine pours were small and the wine was forgettable as well. If this is the best Spanish restaurant in SF, there's an opening for someone to do better.
author: Mike O.

description:
Visit on a weekday.
Calamari & Flatbread great.
Enjoyed the pickled vegetables & roasted almonds.
Pass on the desert.
author: Kaan E.

description:
Delightful addition to my neighborhood! 

I ate at Contigo Saturday night with a couple of friends; wonderful, but they're still working out some kinks as is expected with new restaurants... 

Thumbs up on everything we ate ~ delicious ~ we even ordered the Croquetas de Jamon twice. The luscious little treats were so crispy on the outside, and when you cut into them, the Mahon just ooozes out. YUM!! I absolutely adored the Sardinas Fritas presentation in the little sardine tin. Fantastic Chocolate Caliente con Churros for dessert. The sea salt was a nice touch! 

Thumbs tilting downward on the seating/no reservations. I stopped by at 7:45 while walking my dog to put our name in and was told 45 minutes to an hour (they had just seated three parties of six). I said I'd be back at 8:45. At 8:45, friends in tow, we were told another 30 minutes. Left a cell number and went home for a glass of wine. We called at 9:30 to check in and were told another 20 to 30 minutes. Walked back and were seated close to 10pm. Thoughtfully, they gave us a glass of Cava to pass the last 15 minutes, and swore they'd never seat three large parties simultaneously again. 

Like I said, they're still working out the kinks, but I am sure they'll successfully figure it out. I hope so, so I can be a happy regular and update my review and rating!
author: Steffanie L.

description:
Okay, I finally went back to Contigo with a friend.  She got stuck on BART and when I arrived there were 4 men outside the bar next door smoking.  I groaned inwardly, it was like deja vu - I was expecting them to tell me I'd have to wait outside.  BUT, I was happily proved WRONG!!   I was greeted and seated without hesitation.  I had my glass of wine while I waited.  When my friend arrived, we had delicious tapas and a lot more wine and had a wonderful time.   So, I'm changing my rating.  Clearly the policy has changed. 



[previous post} Can't say how the food or wine was because "according to policy" one cannot be seated until the entire party has arrived.  I planned to meet a friend for an early meal on a weeknight - the tables were empty.  I had arrived 10 minutes early because parking can be unpredictable and was looking forward to a glass of wine while I waited.  Instead of a cozy seat and a glass of wine at one of the many empty tables, I was given a menu to look at while standing in the doorway.  I waited long enough for my friend to show up and we went elsewhere.  

If you decide to go here, DON'T tell them you are meeting someone.
author: Lexi -.

description: Came here for friend's birthday and sat outside which was a great atmosphere and since it was covered, it was warm without needing heat lamp.  All the dishes were great.  We ordered one round first of probably 10 dishes and then ordered more of the ones we liked.  The churros/chocolate dessert, parfait with grilled peaches, and blue bottle ice cream were all delicious.  (Not many restaurants do both entrees and dessert well.)  Will definitely go back again!
author: Irene C.

description:
WOW!  that's basically all i can say.  We ordered the 7 course tasting menu and absolutely loved it.  It's rare to get a tasting menu this intricate and extensive (7 courses)  for only 40 bucks, but Contigo does it.  The food tastes like it took all day to make and each dish builds on the one before it.

They even switched out one of the courses because my date doesn't eat eggs.  Whereas most places would throw in a cheapy salad when you ask them to switch things up, Contigo have us one of the best courses we had all night.  Smoke pasilla stuffed with braised ox tail.  The ambiance is wonderful and I will be back for a future special occasion.

Thank you for a wonderful evening Contigo y todavia somos contigo.
author: John H.

description: OK - I'm a foodie so a fresh sardine over avocado cream w/a sliver of red onion sends me. As did the anchovy bruschetta, the fresh watercress salad w/warm goat cheese and even the plate of amazing olives/blanched almonds and pickled vegetables. But paying $10+ for a glass of wine that comes w/4 oz (or less) really pushes up the bill. With only $50 in food we ended up spending $60 each (2 of us, out on a girlfriend date) - just to have what amounted to about one and a half glasses of wine. Service was lovely - and food is really scrumptious.
author: joan g.

description:
