I had a lovely time and delicious meal at Contigo last week. The staff is fantastic, warm, welcoming, thoughtful and plain ole friendly. Since it was their first week everyone was eager to solicit feedback about their guests' experience and it was easy to see that they sincerely cared.

The food was delicious. The wine was tasty and the ambiance was great too. Its a bit loud in there though and be prepared to sit very close the neighboring tables. 

This is a nice choice for a date with that special someone when you're looking for something with personality and sabor.
author: Jessica Y.

description: The tuna and tomatoes were a little bizarre together. Definitely order the meatballs...to die for! Great service too.
author: Ryan S.

description:
I was looking forward to the opening of this place since Spanish Tapas is one of my favorite foods. went with a friend and was very dissapointed.
The place looks great, portions were very small and expensive , specially the pico pico's, could hardly find the octopus in the octopus salad, the spanish Tortilla, was only a little bite, hard to share with anyone .Most of the dishes were just ok, specially for the price...not going again soon $100 for 2 ppl and left hungry.Wise up guys...!
author: Daniel G.

description: I love Contigo!  It's a little more expensive than most places I go to, but totally worth it.  I always get the prix fixe menu and share things with friends.  Can't go wrong with the date cake!  It is so amazing.  The staff here is super friendly and lovely.  They also know all the dishes really well, so ask them for tips, they're always happy to chat.
author: Julia D.

description: Everything we tried was amazing. I totally recommend the prawns in Ajo Blanco sauce.
author: Nazanin S.

description:
Bocadillo de Cerdo, a.k.a. pork belly slider - this might be the most perfect food in the world. If you cannot make it to Contigo to eat one of these perfect little sandwiches, your life is simply not as rich as it could be. Unless, of course, you are vegetarian, vegan or kosher, in which case you should let it slide just this once to eat a Bocadillo de Cerdo. 
Sitting at the bar, the service was fantastic and I especially appreciate their policy on water - you get it still or bubbly, warm or cold, just how you like it, and they give you a whole bottle of it from their in house filtration system, read: free. Great beer and wine selection and servers are ready and willing to help you pick something out if it's all Greek to you. 
Splitting 3 tapas, 1 small plate, 2 drinks, 2 deserts with a friend ran us $40 each, incl. tip. Not bad for great food.
author: Stefanie F.

description: Nice small plates collection in a Spanish style - waiter says is primarily Catalan. Love the fishes and the veggies alike. Nice wine selection as well. Too bad the place has so few tables. Will certainly return again.
author: Joey D.

description:
The food was great - - -very tasty, unique.  We called on a Friday early evening and they were kind to reserve a table for 4 on the patio (for a short period).  The server was also pleasant and knowledgeable.  
However:

Slow Delivery of the Small Plates:

The timing of the delivery of the food was incredibly slow - - -it took 50 min for a pizza to be delivered to my daughter.  All but the cured meats were lagging on their delivery.  We were there for over 2 hours and only 8-9 plates (and two kids).

Portions were small:

I know Tapas are small plates.  However, the portions were very scant. I'd either keep the price and increase the volume of food or decrease the price and maintain the volume.   We left hungary.

If the portions and service remain,  I will not return.
author: Nancy L.

description: I am friends with the chef/owner and manager, but don't ignore my rave review because of that. This is my favorite restaurant in SF, barring some of the classics like Zuni. By a large margin, the best Spanish cooking, tapas or otherwise, I have eaten in this city. The patatas bravas are the stuff of legend. It's my go-to place for birthdays, out-of-town visitors, and just a plain excellent excuse for a great meal out.
author: Catherine S.

description: The interior design at Contigo is slick but most of the food is pretty average, especially compared to other tapas places in the city.  For what you get, my opinion is that it is significantly overpriced.  Also, while I don't like sangria personally, I found it odd that a tapas place wouldn't have it on the menu.  That said, the churros are amazing and probably the only thing I'll ever go back for.
author: Joseph S.

description:
I came here for a mid-week celebration dinner.  It was all around fantastic.

The server was nice and really knowledgable about the Spanish wines.  T

The brussel sprouts side was amazing!  As was all the food.  We ordered 5 dishes between the three of us and it was just right.  Every dish that was walked by our table smelled amazing.  We will definitely be going back to try more!

I give it four stars because the dishes were a bit expensive for being one the very small side.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
I would give it a higher rating if:

1) it wasn't so expensive
2) had better food
3) we didn't get kicked out after spending more than $400

So, we didn't have reservations, but ended up at a large table in the back, outdoor area.  There were about 5 of us at the beginning, and about an hour later, we had about 8 or 9 people.  We weren't being loud or rude.  In fact, we were still ordering bottles of wine, cocktails, and tapas for the table, when we were told it was time for us to leave. 

And, I was so wishing I would have had a pleasant experience! The place is down the street, but given the amount we spent and then getting kicked out, I don't think I'll be going back.
author: Nadia T.

description: The food was excellent, but we had a Saturday 9:15 reservation, and they were out of at least a third of their dishes--so our selections were very limited, and their menu was not very large to begin with for a tapas-type place.  We got their goat cheese salad (very good), pumpkin dish (excellent), their meatballs (also excellent) and their chickpea spinach dish (unremarkable).  We loved the wine suggestion.
author: Samantha W.

description: We went to Contigo for my bf birthday and we were not disappointed.  Well, we were a little bit, hence the lack of a star.  We ordered the $40 per person chef's selection menu, which I highly recommend.  You get 7 tapas for the entire table of medium size portions.  If it were 4 men, it would not have been enough food.  Everything was really tasty.  The stand outs to me were the ham flatbread, and the stuffed calamari.  Both of these were so delectable.  The halibut and the asparagus dishes were mediocre.  I loved the food and the ambiance, but what left me with a little bit of a disappointed feeling was the service.  The server seemed, for lack of a better definition, full of himself and overly familiar.  I'm all for a friendly server, but it was the consensus that we felt that our server had us feeling that he was doing us a favor by waiting on us.  Also, every food server would dump the plate on our table and barely tell us what the food was.  I remember asking one of them what the tapas were before he ran off.  Granted, it was a busy Saturday night, but the service could have been better.
author: Stacy M.

description: 3.5 stars - The food ranged in quality from excellent to mediocre.  We ordered a bevy of plates.  I recalled fondly the clams and the super fresh peas that came with the excessively dry lamb. Some of the food was somewhat over salted. Service was ok - acceptable but not particularly attentive and rather smug, though our server did recommend a really good wine.  Decor is modern, stylish, and warm.
author: Eric C.

description: Went here for New Years Eve dinner. Food was good. A bit pricey - but tapas generally is. The service was good. The neighborhood is nice and its easy to find parking.  The ambiance of the place was a 9/10 (sat out in the patio, but they had heaters).
author: Saquib P.

description:
We went to Contigo last weekend for a special treat, and boy was that a mistake!  We checked in at 8:30PM and were told the wait would be an hour.  We went to a nearby bar where we were called at 9:45PM and told that our table was ready.  When we got there, it was actually a bar seat available (there were 3 of us) so we waited for a table (another 15+ minutes).  Okay, no big deal, this place is beautiful inside and we were excited for the experience! 

But, as soon as we sat down our waiter came over and asked us to order right away because the kitchen would be closing at 10.  Um, excuse me?  First of all, it was now 10:05 PM, and we just waited well over an hour for a seat!  Our evening was just starting!! If they couldn't accommodate us in the time their kitchen was open, they should have told us to dine elsewhere as opposed to taking our name and having us wait!

Additionally, because the menu is tapas, its nice to order over the course of your meal as opposed to all at once.  Anyway, we did not cop any attitude, and did some ordering.  The food was generally good.  I would say the shrimp special was a bit bland, the gem salad just fair but the arugala salad, the albondigas, the vegetarian ratatouille and the duck was very good.  The portions were too small. I mean really.  I did appreciate the sparkling water on tap! That was nice.

However, even very good food and nice water cannot increase my star rating.     

After our food came OUR WAITER NEVER CAME BACK TO OUR TABLE.  EVER.  We saw him take a seat at the bar, eat his dinner and talk and laugh with the other staff.  Mind you, the restaurant was still FULL of patrons, so it wasn't like we were the last people there.  We had finished a bottle of wine, finished all of our food and NO ONE came to check on us.  We had intended to order more food, more wine, but literally it was like we weren't even in the restaurant!

I finally flagged (after a number of attempts) a bus-boy and asked him for another salad and my friend ordered another drink.  Twenty minutes after that, we flagged someone else down to ask for dessert menus.  

To top all of this off, two of the owner and/or managers (they seemed like a couple) came to sit at the table next to us and have their dinner.  They kept looking around the restaurant, seemingly oblivious to the horrible service we were receiving. I nearly leaned over and said something!

During the time we were attempting to order dessert, we saw our waiter put on his sweater, and leave the restaurant.  He did walk right by our table when he did this, and did say goodbye to the owner/managers sitting next to us.  He never once came over to tell us he was leaving, or that someone else would be finishing serving us.  

Maybe for some folks, a $150 dinner is no big deal - a weekly thing.  For us, going to Contigo was a special treat.  We went to celebrate a happy occasion.  We don't appreciate being treated so poorly at a place that, at this point, should be far more attentive and geared toward patron service. 

Although its not upscale food, we get better service across the street at Hahn's Hibachi for a fraction of the price.  Or, if we want something nicer, FireFly is tried and true. 

I am a loyal Noe resident who loves to support my local spots but will NEVER go back to this restaurant again!
author: L S.

description: An exceptional new Spanish restaurant featuring cuisine from Catalonia, the northern part of Spain.  My date and I were seated in the outdoor patio, which was covered and well equipped with heat lamps, creating a nice romantic setting.  We shared a bottle of a tempranillo rose that was crisp, fruity, and perfect for a sunny day.  Our meal consisted of the patatas bravas, tortilla de hongos, mussels, mushrooms, and the flatbread with jamon, arugula, and manchego.  All dishes were tasty, especially the flatbread and tortilla de hongos, which is a frittata of potatoes.  We also enjoyed the churro for dessert, dipping it in the chocolate sauce.  But, dipping was not enough for my date, so she indulged the chocolate with a spoon instead.  I would really like to return to try all the other dishes on the menu and to have another gratifying dining experience in this charming restaurant.
author: Linda P.

description:
wasn't fabulous, but I dig it.

be sure to make a reservation, at least on sunday nights. We had to wait about 30/45 mins around peak time.
author: L R.

description: Very decent neighborhood tapas place. My friend and I sampled many different aspects of the menu and found each to be flavorful and with decent portioning. On the warm day we went in, the Serrano ham, cheeses, and chilled gazpacho were big hits. The decor is what you would expect these days... modern and clean. The seating is pretty hard and not expecially comfortable for long visits. Service was pleasant and helpful but not especially attentive; we often waited awhile to get items refilled or to get our next course. All in all tho, the food is definitely winning and worth going back for.
author: Aaron L.

description: the small plate mecca for noe,fun for four or more with an outside heated area take friends to empress without breaking the bank .i've found the staff always attentive and friendly,a wide range of food so you can please a picky friend too,enjoy it all with a nice bottle and have fun.
author: wilma m.

description: We had a party of 6 and did the tasting menu which turned out to be a very special and took the option to be surprised with each of the 7 courses. Each one was hand selected by chef that night. We are all still talking about the smashed peas on pan tostado and actually ordered another piece per person they were so good! Nice selection of Spanish wines and I actually love a tasting menu that does include dessert.  I would give it 5 stars but 2 of the courses were just average.
author: John F.

description: Interesting basque-like cuisine.  Tapas style.   A little too pricey for the amount of food you get, though.  They should have larger portions. Some of the $8 tapas plates are ridiculously small.  The food was pretty good, though.
author: Dan P.

description:
Had an awful experience with the staff. First I registered on the waiting list (30' minute wait) and explained I would be waiting for a friend on the curb right in front of the restaurant. Friend arrived and when we came back in 30' minute later as expected, it was only to see that our spot (and many others) have been given to other people in the meantime. We were rudely told to re-wait for an other 20' ! Not a word from anyone while I was waiting outside, right in front of the door.

Generally speaking, they have a "we are popular" attitude but should be more cautious about what will happen once the initial hype will be gone.
author: Sacha A.

description:
I live close by so I had to try Contigo.  Got there last night about 8:30 and was told the wait would be 30 to 40 minutes.  After hearing all the great news about the place I decided to wait.  I stepped next store to The Peaks for a quick cocktail (as they serve only beer and wine) I came back in about 20 minutes and was told it would be another 20 or 30 minutes.  Still decide to wait.  After 40 minutes making my total wait time a little over an hour I was finally seated. Note, I was by myself and they were obviously more interested in seating the numerous couples waiting as a couple who entered after I did was seated before me.  The hostess was very pleasant but as I said to her I know you have only been open a week and I am sure your working out the kinks but you need to be more realistic about your seating wait times.  She did at one point during my wait give me some toasted Almonds to chew on while I waited however, a glass of house wine might have made the wait a little more bearable.  Well now I am finally seated and having read the menu about 20 times front to back had decided on my food selection.  I had originally planned to do a few small plates but since it was now near 10 o'clock I opted to just have a glass of wine and one large plate as I thought it would arrive pretty quickly as it was getting late and the restaurant was now beginning to empty.  I chose the judiones a la segoviana for my entrée which was pork belly, ears, feet with butter beans and the waiters wine recommendation of a rosé from Spain.  It was quite delicious!  I am not a big rosé fan but it paired very well with the saltiness of the pork and the soft texture of the beans.   All in all the food was excellent but the wait extreme.

I will go back, but will probably wait till the initial hype dies down but once again the food was very very good!
author: Pat C.

description: Good ambience & friendly waiter. The halibut was excellent, especially the sauce. Prawns were good but only gives you 3 - which is kind of awkward to share with a date. Don't order the artichoke salad. The papas (potatoes) were ok ... Came with a salsa type of topping. Definitely need a carb dish to fill you up because the portions are small. I would suggest 5-6 dishes for a party of 2. Beware: Prices are steep.
author: esther j.

description:
we keep going back with large groups of friends and our recent visit was good, but not as memorable as past visits. 
the menu had changed since they last time we went. 

removed were the OXTAIL CROQUETS.  they were replaced with STUFFED PEPPERS WITH PULLED OXTAIL. WHAT A BUMMER!!  we really hope the croquets are brought back. out of 8 people, no one at our table even finished a pepper. they were not special at all. 1/5

JAMON SERRANO- always a hit 4/5

PATATAS BRAVAS- super yum 5/5 (it is hard to walk away from these and not fill up)

RAW ARTICHOKE AND ORANGE SALAD- super vibrant, zesty & delicious. 5/5

COCA OF CHANTERELLES (1 w/bacon, 1 w/egg) easy going and kinda boring. 3/5

we will still come back. other mentionables in the past were the whole duck & sauteed squid. we did not see them this time around- maybe they were specials. 

Here is my old review:

great ambiance and service. the back patio is lovely- especially when dining with a group. 

here are our votes (out of 5 stars):

shaved asparagus 5/5
pulpo salad 3/5 (tough)
local halibut crudo 5/5 (like ceviche) 
sardine and avocado toasts 4/5
oxtail croquets 5/5 (best thing we tried!!)
albondigas 2/5 (boring)
la quercia organic berkshire prosciutto pared with ros (sheeps cheese) a very nice paring 5/5
liberty ranch duck leg tangine 5/5 (amazing)
wood oven baked firebrand bread 4/5
chocolate caliente 3/5 (non memorable)
meyer lemon tart 4/5
author: SF U.

description: Had a really enjoyable night at Contigo. The wine was excellent.  We ordered the anchovies which were truly great and the olive oil they were sitting in was good for dipping bread.  Sardines were equally awesome.  My least favorite thing surprisingly was the pork belly sandwich.  It was way too small and I must have got the side with all fat.  Just not that great.  The potatoes were my favorite thing, well, maybe that and the brussel sprouts or the ice cream dessert, or wait, maybe the churro?  OK, so yes, we ordered almost everything on the menu which is why I am writing this with a pang of guilt for all the overindulging I did last night!!  Great atmosphere, beautiful space with an outdoor area.  Nice work Contigo.
author: Andrea R.

description:
been here a couple times with my good friend lentz!
great small plates!
outdoor seating and big wine list
in noe valley
author: Kate R.

description: Once again, we on 4/1.  Great service, deliciously prepared food. But after almost a $100 bill (it did include a few glasses of wine) we left kinda hungry and contemplating getting a burger on the way home. I know that it's about quality rather than quantity, but come on.  The portions are too small!
author: Anthony C.

description: The food is here is delicious, however, the portions are so small that I don't want to go here anymore cuz I'll still be hungry after (or super poor from having to order a ton of dishes...its not cheap!)  Love the piggy paperclips that come with the check!
author: Maureen K.

description: Yay!  Finally a tapas place that looks, feels and tastes like the ones I encountered in Barcelona!  The summer squash coca was excellent, as was the cucumber salad and sardines.  And I'm impressed by the seasonality - pink pearl apple and piel de sapo desserts in mid August!  Mmmmm!
author: Elaine U.

description: I really liked this place.  They're doing everything right... great location, great space.  It's a small place but I like the set up.  There are 2 small bar-seating areas and little nooks for normal tables.  There's a bigger table area in the back and also an outdoor area.  Everything is clean and bright and open.  Service was excellent:  very friendly and helpful and on point.  Food was pretty good.  I really loved the flatbread and egg/potato/sausage  dishes and all the pork dishes (jamon serrano, albondigas, etc).  I definitely want to try the dishes we didn't order, so maybe next time!  The one negative was the dessert.... the xocolata calenta was described as "thick" but it was kinda watery and thin... we used it to dip our xurros in it.  But then again, it IS hot chocolate, maybe we were supposed to drink the rest?  It gets pricy when you order a lot, but looking at it, the prices are fair and the portions are fitting.
author: Easter E.

description: Yummmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!! Who the heck would not give this place five stars!? My girlfriend and I showed up at 8:30pm, and they said they wouldn't have a table till 9pm. While we went next door for a glass of wine, they called us at 9 exactly and held a table for us. Wow! Later on, after absolutely delicious food and exotic wine, a third girlfriend joined us, and no one said a word about her simply joining us at a two-person table. She was instantly welcome, with no fuss. FOOD: the flat bread with nettles is to die for. Being from NYC, I am extremely picky about my pizza, which is really what this bread is, and it was spectacular. Their huevos estrellados and moorish lamb tagine were exquisite. Very flavorful and well-balanced. Btw, the olive oil that comes with the bread is phenomenal. Although, I may have to say that the bread could be better. That's the only little 'but' I can come up with for this place, but I wouldn't take even a half star off for that as it's just a nuance I'm sure they'll eventually improve. I think you may have to ask for bread, though. I didn't see the check, so not sure if one has to pay for it. A major plus also is their very knowledgeable wine guy/bartender. Now, I know my wine, and he was able to carry an intelligent discussion about Spanish wine, and most sommeliers miserably fail at Rioja/Priorat-Garnacha/Tempranillo task. All in all, a fun-filled delicious experience in this cozy place with great service. Can't wait to return!
author: Marina S.

description:
What a great addition to the neighborhood.  Every meal we've ever had here has been fantastic, with friendly, attentive service to match.

The oxtail croquettas and the corn with mushrooms are consistent standouts.  Many of the desserts are good, but the churros with chocolate are the safest bet.

The plates split best with groups of three or four.  With two people you don't get to try as many things; five or six is fine but you need to get double orders of everything.
author: George O.

description: Fig salad with goat cheese is unbelievable. Calamari was out of the world. The 7 course tasting originally had me concerned that it would be insufficient, but, I was stuffed out of my gourd by the last dish. However, I still had dessert and the churros wih chocolate is not to be missed. Friendly staff who made sure water was filled every few minutes. A place not to be missed.
author: Richard G.

description: This spot has become my go-to tapas restaurant.  I haven't had a bad meal here yet.  The service is great (the bartender is super knowledgeable about Spanish wine, and friendly and cute, too!).  The wine selection is exciting, and the foods have all been delicious.  The menu changes frequently, so I never get bored.  There is a small outdoor patio out back, with heat lamp things.  It's a great date spot.
author: Erika B.

description: Good food, fun/classy/wine-bar ambiance, great wine list. I don't generally love Spanish meat dishes so it's not my fave - but all the seafood and veggie dishes are generally solid.
author: E T.

description:
I realize things happen in the world, however, for a restaurant town like San Francisco, some things are really not that excusable.

1.  We entered the restaurant, no hostess at the door.
2.  She finally came over, sat us and brought over water.

That is where it ended as we sat there and there was no server who came to the table.  I spotted a friend, went over to say hello, my friend and I reviewed the menu and chatted.  We waited for about 15 minutes.

Being someone who works with the industry I saw there was trouble.  Five tables with menus open, people looking at the kitchen wondering if food was coming and a service staff that did not look like they had it together.  We decided to leave.

Having read reviews (and really wanting to try this restaurant) I knew who the owner was as he was in the kitchen.  I went up to him and told him we were leaving and why.  Of course he apologized, and his excuse was "we are short staffed."

Restaurant management 101:  If you are short staffed, close off a section.  If the kitchen is running behind, have your hostess stop seating until you catch up.  Restraurant psychology 101...a server should appear at a table within 3-5 minutes of a table being seated, even if it is to say, "Hi there...we are really busy this evening.  I will be with you in just a few minutes."

Also, on a hot summer day, if you have a patio, open up the plastic...that is why there is a patio.

As we were leaving, there was a line.  People were walking in, and of course, there was no hostess to be found.

It's a shame the evening turned out the way it did as I was looking forward to dining at Contigo.  We wound up going next door to Hamano and service/food was lovely.  I also noticed 2 other parties from Contigo were also at Hamano.
author: Eli B.

description: Should be 3.5 stars...the food lives up to its billing- that is to say, it is dang tasty, and for tapas, great serving sizes, even if the price per plate is high. The wines were good, but again, their price point was too high on the Cavas. All in all, a good experience...just seems they missed the point of tapas, which should be an affordable way to meander through good flavors...
author: franco m.

description: First visit to Contigo back when they first opened was really disappointing.  Really pricey and really small portions, meh!  But we decided to give it another try 6 mos later, this time with reinforcement - my in-laws!  We LOVED it!  We tried most of the stuff on their menu, and they were all SOO good!!!   I dunno, they changed their menu a lot, and were a bit more generous with their portions too.  I know, I know, it's tapas, but we've also been to Spain, and I don't think even their kids' menu was as small as the prtions we first had at Contigo.  SO, any improvement is significant!  The sardine on toast is my fave.  Yeah, I can live on that.  Everyday.  Screw mercury-poisoning.  Bring it on.
author: Grace K.

description: just great. good wine good food. the tasting menu for $42 is a steal
author: Guy S.

description: First, let me say I was a huge fan of Contigo but my experience there last night completely turned me off the place! .First- unnecessary attitude from the servers. My friend asked for a diet coke with his meal and was told "We're too classy for that" by the waiter. *rolls eyes* The food arrived, it was great, as was the wine. I've been here multiple times and my favorites on the menu are the charred asparagus with poached egg, the tostadas and of course the jam on iberico! The food yesterday was the only saving grace. We were seated outside and they don't have any ability to regulate the heating- it was either freezing or we felt like we were sitting in a sauna. Towards the end, as we were finishing our meal, we saw a RAT scuttling around near our table! For the last 15 mins of our meal, the rat kept us company near our table. We complained to our server and he coolly told us "We are aware of the issue" Well- a heads up would have been nice. When I go to a restaurant and pay $40 a head (at least) a rat is not what I expect! Total buzzkill!
author: Sreejita D.

description: Everything was very tasty and fun to share. Attentive service, though I wish they did not swoop to pick up "nearly" empty place so quickly... frankly, I like to dredge the sauces and eat the last crumbs of potatoes and stray mushroom or chive. Quite stuffed, so got my money's worth. I would hope you could also enjoy just a couple of dishes if on a budget or if you desire a snack instead of a big meal.
author: T G.

description: Only good things to say about Contigo.  Nice menu with lots of options for tapas and some larger entree sized portions.  Our waiter was seriously great - friendly, funny and right on with food and drink recommendations. They don't rush you here, which I appreciate.  The back patio looked like a nice spot and I loved the simple vibe of the decor.
author: Lena J.

description: Superb. Hate to say it, but those who gave this place1-3 stars must have deficient palates. Food is as simple and elegantly composed as it is flavorful. They use excellent, seasonal ingredients and know how to combine them to complement their flavors and create culinary bliss by the bite. Thinly sliced dry-cured ham, grilled peaches and mint leaves. Three ingredients -- perfection. Beef and pork meatballs in sherry sauce -- warm, rich, savory, delicious. Menu changes daily, so there's always a reason to return. Not all the dishes may be your thing, but I guarantee you will find some that wow you.
author: nathan l.

description:
I was set to like this place because I love tapas, especially Catalonian tapas, but it was utterly forgettable and therefore disappointing.

I've tried all day to remember what we ate last night, but it was so unremarkable, that I can't. I couldn't even remember when I threw it back up a few hours later. I wish I could because then I would know what made me sick! That said, the flan was pretty good. Can you screw up flan though really? All in all, it was a small amount of unremarkable food for pretty high prices.

I wanted to give it 3 stars, but I had to knock one off for the service. It was hipster crap. I swear, I think they might have hired their servers from the Hipster Olympics rejects. They seemed to be more concerned with fostering their "ironic" facial hair than anything else. And their "ironic" choice of music was utter crap. It was the sort of stuff that has been turned into instrumental versions and was played on my grandmother's radio station in the early 90's. Madonna's "Take a Bow?" Really? That's not even ironic, it's just bad, especially for a supposedly new, wanna-be-hip restaurant. When I asked about it, one of the hipster bartenders just gave me a long dirty look. By the way, are you really a bartender if you just open wine? Just asking.

Anyway, like I said, I really wanted to like this place, but I'd rather head over the bridge to Barlata in Oakland for better Catalonian tapas, larger portions, lower prices, and just a better experience all around.
author: Alex D.

description:
Celebrated a much anticipated interview with dinner at Contigo during its opening week. We arrived around 10pm and waited in the entryway with glasses of the Pares Balta brut cava. If you know me at all, you are probably aware that trying new restaurants and drinking cava are a few of my favorite things. The clean lines, cool green tones, and quaint size of the dining room give it the perfect eco-chic balance of a room that would be at home in Sunset, me gusta.

A group vacated some seats at the back bar for us where we ordered a spritzy dry white Txakolina (a great Basque wine) and an assortment of small dishes. We started with the simple and earthy setas a la plancha (grilled wild mushrooms) with pounded parsley. These were soon ignored when the patatas a la riojana (potatoes stewed with chorizo) arrived. Although we had thought about ordering the more typical patatas bravas, these soft and silky potatoes were served with a lucious sauce that we guarded to dip our flatbread crusts in. The sauce had the broken-down starch of the patatas, the richness of the chorizo fat, and a hint of sweetness that was quite delicious. Next up was a jamon coca (flatbread with serrano ham and cheese). This was also a simple combination of top notch ingredients that we mainly ordered to add some heft to our meal, but were happy to have the crusts to dip in the aforementioned sauce. Jamon Serrano is always delicious, no?

And b/c it wouldn't be fair to leave without trying a large plate, we also got the pork belly, trotters, and ears with white beans. I have a special fondness for pork belly and trotters and for white beans. That being said, the large plate portion did not seem generous for the price (b/c we all know how much the feet and ears cost). I wasn't really into the ears either, the cartilage was crunchy in a mildly off-putting way. The tiny trotter bites (there were only a few of them) and belly meat were savory and worth battling over with our forks.

We closed out with the chocolate con churros which were merely ok, but we felt like getting a good grasp of the menu and we were celebrating after all. Service made a good effort despite it being the opening week with eager crowds of late night diners. Contigo is a much needed and perfect addition for a neighborhood that is somewhat barren of reliable yet interesting dining choices.
author: Candice L.

description: Great food no doubt. Expensive for small portions. Sure its a fancy place and its tappas so I get that the portions are smaller. BUT they are still cheap to me because they skimp on the actual food on the dish. For example the fig salad had  one fig cut up into 4 pieces. It was not enough to add to the flavor overall. Skimpy in the ingredients itself which provided less of a balance for the dishes overall.
author: M. C.

description: I have been waiting and waiting to check this place out and maybe I hyped it up too much in my own head because it didn't live up to my expectations.  Don't get me wrong though, the food was tasty!  Our server was friendly and authentic with his Spanish accent.  The gambas were disappointing, but the calamari, meatballs, and desserts were great!  The atmosphere was casual and lively and I will definitely give it another try!
author: Carolyn D.

description: Was there for the first time with friends who live nearby. We were there on a Friday night at around 9pm, and had to wait for more than 30 mins. But that is a good sign in the sense that the place is popular. Good wine selection, great flatbread dish (has chantarelles, add sausage, and it is very good). Nice patio. 3+
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description: My wife, who is 9 months pregnant, and I had an 5:30 pm dinner reservation at Contigo.   We arrived a few moments early but were told we needed to leave the restaurant because the staff was having a meeting.  They didn't offer my wife a seat but rather told her to wait outside.  The restaurant then opened at 5:40 and, without any apology, had us wait several more minutes before seating us.  The food was fine and our waiter was friendly, but overall Contigo was incredibly classless.  Certainty will never go back.
author: MTR M.

description:
So a friend recently suggested we go eat at Contigo and the first thing I did was come to Yelp to check it out. 
I only became confused! There was alot of love and alot of non-love in the reviews. Since the reviews seemed to cancel each other out, I decided to throw caution to the wind and try it myself. So this is what happened:

Got there not long after they started service
Was greeted and seated immediately
Our waiter was charming, informative and attentive
Yes, they charge $2 for each plate of bread- not great, but who needs the carbs?
Fizzy water is free!
After it filled up, service slowed down, but not too bad
The food was delicious- yummy sardines, 

I would dine there again, but would get there early for an optimum experience
Even better if someone else is picking up the bill!
author: peggi j.

description: Eh.  I've been to better tapas places.  The servings are smaller than most tapas places, but the prices are about the same.  The jamon plate was good.  The wine that our server helped us select, however, was not good.  I also thought it was odd that we had to ask for bread and then they only gave us one piece each.  Huh.  Bread shortage?  The decor is interesting -- a lot of pieces of wood were from a farmhouse or something and they reused it.
author: Mitzi C.

description: We really enjoyed our dinner here Friday night. As Gina C. says we ended up waiting quite a while, but with the bar next door, it's not such a bad deal. If you don't want to wait though, I'd recommend going with just one other person and sitting at the bar - although half the fun is going with enough people that you can try a bunch of things. Seriously everything we had was fabulous. The jamon serrano reserva, olives, pickled vegetables and marcona almonds, patatas bravas, sardine and avocado toasts, stuffed calimari, anchovies on tomato toast, meatballs, burger and manchego flatbread. All delicioso! Looking forward to going back! Also gotta give a shout-out to the great service, and lovely decor.
author: Sarah R.

description:
this place was good. there were lots of good veggie options and the service was crisp and friendly.

we had the fried potatoes, the spinach, the stuffed pepper, the mushroom salad, and some other things i can't remember. 

the only thing that i did not like was the sticky table. that was kind of gross. and took away one whole star. but everything else was nice. great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Kenna T.

description:
don't go when they (are supposed to) open!

went the other night - they were supposed to be open - they hadn't gotten it together - person at front of house said to "leave" and "come back in 5-10 min" - incredibly stupid attitude - could have said "free to wait in the bar area" or "free to sit down at table and wait until we're ready" - why is it that business establishments can't get their doors open on time - a time around which prospective patrons just might be planning their own lives! - won't return until person at front of house has been replaced
author: S K.

description:
Honestly, what is the big deal here!!! 5 Star not!!! It's the new restaurant on the block in Noe Valley and sadly misses the mark. I've tried it twice now and gave it a few months from my first experience in hopes it would improve. 

I thought it was expensive for the teeny portions served, visually unappealing presentations and overall just unforgettable food. The menu was not well rounded and most of the small plates contained starchy lower end vegetables (potatoes) or flat breads (thin crust pizza) with scant toppings. Where's the tasty little meat, poultry and fish platters?? 

I can't even tell you what I ordered because nothing was a standout. Oh yeah, the sample of wine they served me when I ordered a glass of wine. I thought our waitress had brought a generous taste for my approval but in reality, this was the smidgen of wine they served for $10/glass. Three of us ate for about $105 (without tip including the glass of wine) but departed hungry and uninspired. I doubt if I will return. I don't know what my dinner companions thought of the place because none of us discussed our experience. This leads me to believe that no one else gave the this restaurant their stamp of approval. 

They are plenty of other tapas restaurants in SF that excel well beyond this eatery. If you have to go here, I suggest it as a springboard to start your evening but not for a night out to impress anyone.
author: t r.

description: Despite having stopped on here for a couple quick snacks, I never attempted a full meal here until last night. I was prepared to be slightly underwhelmed, but the opposite came true. Everything we tried, about ten plates, was fantastic. There seems to be a sort of prefix deal sun-thurs nights that make the overall prices less intimidating.
author: e w.

description: Fun place, liked all the small plates especially the potatoes, and nice Spanish wines too.
author: Peter H.

description:
I think I may have liked this dinner better than everyone else at our table. But honestly, considering most of my dining companions were fresh off a day of wine tasting and could hardly see straight, I'm not sure how much that should change things. 
There was something about Contigo that was just successful. Each dish was well assembled and executed, and managed to feel unfussy without being too simple. 
With a large group, we managed to try a huge portion of the menu. My favorites were the toasted bread with tomato (really addictive), the patatas bravas with delicious aioli and salsa, and the flatbread with squash. There were also several fun salad combinations, including one with fig, another with cucumbers. The cheeses, olives and pickled vegetables made for diverting nibbles. 
And finally, the desserts were fantastic - the intense chocolate and churros, and a perfect fruit tart. 
Would like to visit again when fully sober.
author: Purnima M.

description: I ate here for the first time and I think this restaurant is just ok. It is very cozy and the service is nice. Make sure you make reservations because the wait list is an hour long at nights and there is no waiting area. I have eaten spanish dishes before. Comparing to the other spanish restaurants, this restaurant served the smallest plates I have ever seen. For example a clementine salads involved a small clementine cut up in 5 pieces and little bit of raisins and garnish. I spent 40 dollars on 3 tapas. I thought it was not worth. Some of the dishes were tasty but not all of them. I have been to better restaurants!
author: Zara L.

description: Fun neighborhoody-type place to go.  Sleek  decor. Suggest the Pulpo salad (I could have eaten three orders); sardine and avocado toasts(ditto), clams, soft shell crab, and lamb. Innovative wine list and the service was  great.
author: WK C.

description:
Contigo delivers great food and great service in a lovely space. I particularly want to single out our server, Elisa, for helping us put together a meal that was nothing short of spectacular (every dish was good, and I have yet to wrong with jamon serrano, but the chicory salad, the croquetas,and the flatbread with bacon, manchego cheese, and asparagus still rose to the top of the six or seven items we ordered).

It was a very busy weekend night, but Alanna (sp?), one of the owners, still made a point of coming by to check in, a nice touch we appreciated. 

Will be back next time I'm in town!
author: Anne C.

description:
Went to Contigo last Friday night with 2 friends -- awesome experience overall.  Very friendly, accommodating staff from the host to the wait staff to the bartender to the wine expert -- all were welcoming and accommodating.  The restaurant was popular that night necessitating a one-hour and thirty minute wait, however, we were able to order wine and excellent goats milk cheese and a rare jamon Iberico for our appetizers to cushion our wait.

Upon getting seated, the wine expert continued to offer his spot-on recommendations for the type of wine I was looking for.  He knew his Spanish wines well and was able to articulate the subtle nuances between the different vinyards.

We shared food items like quail, sand dabs, steak, calamari and butter beans among other dishes.  All were delicious and the staff and kitchen were completely accommodating of my allergy to nuts -- they altered whatever dishes they could for my special request.  I appreciate their efforts in recommending alternative ways to prepare the dishes in order to avoid contact with nuts or nut oils without jeopardizing quality or taste.  

We concluded the evening with cappacinos and chocolate torte -- the torte was phenomenal.  

In my opinion, Contigo scored on all counts -- taste, quality, unique offer and impeccable service that was relaxed and neighborly.
author: Scott H.

description:
In the interest of full disclosure, I do know the owners of this restaurant; I'm the supplier of the handmade salt bowls for their tables.

That said: I came here a few days after they opened. They are still working out a few kinks (the outdoor patio was open, but they warned people that it wasn't 100% complete; I think they're still getting more heat lamps and doing some work on the flooring?) but wow! The space looks so gorgeous already. It has a modern design, but somehow, the kitchen, visible from most of the restaurant, manages to feel like someone's kitchen in their home. I was also really impressed with the friendly, knowledgeable waiter.

Their menu changes daily. Here's what the 2 of us had that day:
--Oxtail fritters--these are AMAZING. I could have had a big plate of these as an entree.
--Razor clams--I didn't really care for these, but I'm not sure if it was the clams themselves (I've never had this kind before--I usually like the little tiny bite-size ones) or the preparation.
--Wild mushrooms with pressed parsley--A minimalist dish, perfectly presented to bring out the mushrooms' flavor.
--Jamon, arugula, and manchego flatbread pizza--I loved this. The flatbread was so crispy, and the jamon had great flavor. Next time I would order one with more veggie toppings on it, though.
--Asparagus with egg--Perfectly cooked asparagus. I've never had it this good before.
--Pork belly, feet and ears with butter beans--I could have done with a bit more pork belly in this, but it was otherwise totally delicious. Those beans are freakin' amazing.
--Chocolate gelato--The flavor of this was more complicated than just chocolate, but I can't remember what else was in it. I liked this but I'm not a huge chocolate fan so I wasn't bowled over.
--Hazelnut browned butter cake--This was the winner for me. Delicate but dense texture, great flavor.

Their menu is really quite affordable for the quality of the food, as well.
author: Lynae Z.

description: Very mixed. Fun atmosphere, but very uneven food. a few great dishes, a few really pretty bad. great: potatoes with chorizo, flatbread with ham and cheese. pretty bad: broccoli rabe (limp and overcooked), ricotta tart (VERY dry). i didnt love the pork belly slider, but i think that's more on me than them - i didnt pick it and i dont like stuff that fatty. but i can see how some would love it.
author: Erica W.

description: Very good wine selection and tasty food, especially the gazpacho and anchoas. Iberico jamon was good but the chorizo was even better. Service was spotty, waiter forgot a couple of our orders and had to remind him after some wait. Overall food was good and fresh but the bill is overkill. I might be back if someone else is paying.
author: Alex B.

description: What a joke??  Honestly, if you like the whole 'tapas' thing then head towards russian hill and go to Zarzuella.  I left Contigo hungrier than when I went in.  The food tastes good, but in no way is it worth the amount of money they charge.  The mushroom plate ($9) was simply one mushroom cut in 6 pieces.  AND, the SF chronicle food critic needs his or her credibility checked as this place will be out of buisness in less than a year.  Seriously, the best thing about the dinner was the absolutely adorable & knowledgable waiter.
author: richard c.

description: Mmm. Noe is stepping up it's game. This place is legit and I don't mean just-another-neighborhood-restaurant-kinda legit. Everything we tried was right on. They have a great patio with shelter from the elements. The atmosphere is top notch. Maybe the only rub is that there's no bar for waiting, but they will bring you a beer/wine while you stand in the entry... Here's a tip for walk-ins: the wait seems to be not as long as advertised by the host/hostess and (best of all) they will call you on the cell phone when your table is ready, if you want to stroll the hood.
author: Jason Y.

description: Love, love love this place.  Food to service to decor......it's all good.  Been three times and haven't been disappointed yet.  Keep up the good work Comtigo!
author: Vincent C.

description: Two words YUM MEE. Nice location, nice inside, delicious food, great bar.  Win Win...win.  Yeah, love the Tapas.  I like variety.  Great local place.  Check it out!
author: Karen J.

description:
a new(ish) destination spot in noe valley.  a welcome, sit-down interpretation of a tapas bar in a neighborhood in desperate need of some new spots to eat.

very good, reasonably priced spanish wines.  consistently solid, interesting takes on authentic spanish dishes that make sometimes hard-to-approach rustic cuisine (read:  pig's feet) much more accessible.  well-portioned plates, and a well-balanced, tasty menu.  save room for the chocolate & churros. seriously.

service is much improved since several visits opening month.  nice (but small) outdoor space, and well designed and implemented interior, with a small counter by the door.  kitchen's open relatively late, and i was pleased to see a decent size crowd dining at 10pm on a random tuesday in june.
author: Matt G.

description:
Mediocre at best.
The layout and design are super-cool.
The food is good (not amazing, but certainly not bad).
The portions are tiny.
The prices are high.

All things considered, I would still even go to Ramblas in the mission before this place....much bigger selection at a much more reasonable price and not as much of a scene.

Hoping this place picks up on some of the cues in due time and maybe give it another shot down the road...

But, on the good side, there is definitely plenty of room for improvement here :-)
author: Michael K.

description: Other reviewers are right on: this is a 3.5 star place right now.  Since it has 4 currently, I'll give it 3 and aid the regression to the mean.  Service was a little rough around the edges, food was fine but pricey.  Has a lot of potential though.  They'll be inventive and perhaps make the cost worth it over time.  But as it stands it was about $80 for a mix of ok and very good dishes supplemented by ok service.
author: Brian D.

description: Best tapas in the city.  Jamon y queso simply marvellous with the tempranillo.  Great atmosphere.  They made meatballs a gourmand entree!  Meatballs! The owners Brett and Elon are very warm and welcoming and their taste is exquisite.  Plus, my waiter was from Spain and gave me recommendations and compared the food to places in Barcelona.   Authentic, made me want to hop on a place to Andalusia!   Everything locally grown and organic, but they don't overhype it.  Contigo is my favorite new restaurant in SF!
author: Rob W.

description: Good food and service. I really liked the flatbread.
author: Jason K.

description:
Been here twice now and really enjoyed it both times.  Good ambiance and the waiters really seemed to know their wine. Oh and the hostess is also so sweet.  

You can't really go wrong with anything on the menu but our favorites were the chard, alobondigas and the Jamon appetizers.
author: steph T.

description:
Really liked the setting of this restaurant: great design, open kitchen and lovely staff. Went with 4 friend and we ordered a lot of small plates to share. 

Every single one of the dishes was great - cured hams, oxtail meatballs, Spanish pizza type-thing (?), patatas bravas, salads, churros with melted chocolate (awesome), Blue Bottle coffee ice cream and Blue Bottle drip coffee.

Will be going back with other groups of friends.
author: Simon J.

description: Loved it.  Great ambiance.  Outstanding service.  Delicious meal and wine.  Waiter was cute and fun -- let us try a bunch of white wines before picking one for a carafe.  Same when we switched to red.  Delicious jamon and cheese plate w/ quince and roasted/salted hazelnuts.  Scrumptious salad of winter squash, onions and pomegranate.  Great broccolini, caramelized onion and machego flatbread.  Pork/beef meatballs and olive oil fried chicken with brussel sprouts and bacon topped it all off.  I would have finished with churros y chocolate if I had room.  Read about it on nosaladasmeal blog, and my high expectations were entirely met!
author: Kelly J.

description:
I was there with my boyfriend last tuesday.
Great service , excellent food. The wine sepling was just right.
Finding a parking is problematic but well worth the trouble.
Defently one of my top 5 resturants to visit agin this year.
author: shirly b.

description: We have been waiting for a special occasion to go to Contigo for a while now.  The atmosphere from looking in off the street alone make it look very comfortable, Green and hip.  Our server was Rodolfo and he was a package.  First, after we decided the wine that the host suggested was too much of a Rose for our taste, he helped us find what we were looking for and even added in a great story about the history of the winery.  Rodolfo had a solid Sommmelier-like knowledge that truly make the experience.  That is only the wine!  The tapas were extraordinary!  I recommend olive plate, croquetas and the calamari.  Will definitely return.
author: J J.

description: My hubby and I decided to try the mushroom appetizer.  Listed as sauteed mushrooms with garlic and parsley.  They were very, very  spicy.  I asked the waitress what was in it besides the garlic and parsley listed and she informs us that there's cayenne pepper in them.  So I'm wondering why wasn't that listed on the menu.  For the entree the waitress said it was a combo of shrimp and scallops.  I asked to doubt check because I'm allergic to fish.  Well. we found out that the dish has "shrimp and tiliapa" not "shrimp and scallops" as the waitress thought....so we decided to go with the Shrimp Ceviche.  This was even spicier than the mushroomsl.  Again, I asked the waitress and she said the "owner" said there was vinegar and garlic.  Sorry.  I've tried many different cuisines and found some spicy and some not.  The menu didn't reveal what it had in it.  Now to be fair, my husband can eat East Indian cuisine and i cannot. I  find it hot, whereas he doesn't.  By the same token, I can eat Thai,  no problem and my husband finds it very spicy.  To each his own, I guess.  Bottom line, i think they should be up front about the ingredients in their food and their patrons decide if they want to try something "hot".  Expanding on that, if there are people with allergies.......are they taking that into consideration?
author: Cleo B.

description: What a great experience.  We didn't have reservations, so they seated us at the bar until a table was available for 5 of us.  Fantastic wine paired with amazing appetizers.  I went about two months ago, so I don't remember the exact dishes.  We later got moved to our table seamlessly.  The interior of the establishment was contemporary, yet comfortable.  It is always a great time, when you have great wine and food, and everyone at the table is saying "Try this, no this!"
author: Scot B.

description: Contigo has promise. They're a new restaurant that's still working out the kinks of opening. I went there with a friend the other night and the food was pretty good, but the service needed a little bit of help. I think in a couple more weeks they'll be running smoothly.
author: Dan M.

description:
The jury is still out on this one, but Contigo is definitely more than a 3 star establishment. 
     We arrived right upon opening so we had the choice of seating areas and I was instantly drawn to the lovely garden area. The decor reminds me a lot of La Mar; simple but bold colors. I chose the indoor area but, on one of those random warm nights in SF, the patio area would be the place to be. Since I had just finished a midday Bikram yoga class, I was ravenous! I had a hard time deciding because my stomach wanted something... anything... Upon the suggestion of my friend, we ordered 2 of the pork belly sliders (so good you don't wan to share) and the potatoes with chorizo. The sliders were awesome. I had a bad run in with thick cut pork belly at Burma Superstar so I was hesitant to try it again. Contigo set me straight. It was the perfect balance of pork belly, onions, and bread. The next item we ordered were the  potatoes and chorizo. It was tasty, not fabulous, and I would probably pick another menu item over it on future visits. 
For the main entree we had the soupy rice which was awesome. It seems as if lately sunny side up eggs are finding there way into more and more dishes and the soupy rice is no exception. The egg married perfectly with the rice, fresh veggies and broth. It was a simple dish, but it was well made and tasty. I enjoyed my visit to Contigo but since I was in a hunger induced stupor, I need to give it another visit to see if it earns the illustrious five stars...
author: chelsea b.

description:
Went here with my husband for our anniversary on a monday night. I'll separate this review into 3 sections-

1) Service- Was excellent. Water/wine glasses were kept full, orders were taken promptly, waiter/bussboys were very pleasant.

2)Aptsmosphere- Very cozy and intimate. We sat on the back patio and the ambiance was very inviting.

3)Food- Ummm. I really wanted to be impressed after all the great reviews, but I just wasn't. the standout for me was the flatbread with summer squash, onions and olives. I also really liked the salt-cod croquette. 
                 The cheese plate was ok. there were these preserved fruit cubes on the side that were very good, but they were soooo tiny..barely enough for one person to spread on their bread. The oxtail croquette was a little odd, not sure about the flavor combination. Finally- the patatas bravas. Im sorry but it seemed like homefries that would be served on a plate of huevos rancheros, with salsa, sour cream and everything. They were just disappointing after all these rave reviews.

Not sure if I'll go back, because the food is the most important thing to me in a restaurant. There's so many other places I want to try...
author: melinda g.

description: I havent had this great of tapas experience since New York. What a great addition to the neighborhood. I am a veghead (pescatarian if you will) and was pleased with the selection of veghead friendly items, my favs include the beet & clementine mixture, the clams, and the croquetas. We ended with the churros (!) and chocolate. Ambiance was great, my two girlfriends and I sat in the back patio garden adjacent the fresh herb garden, and were able to carry on our chatty/catty convo amongst others without it being too loud or too quiet for that matter. Make reservations if going on a weekend. Original wait time estimate was 1 hour, but we ended up waiting about 40minutes - totally worth it.
author: Jordan V.

description: Non-pretentious yet energetic atmosphere.  The service was attentive but not obtrusive.  Food came out FAST.  Overall, I liked the food.  The mixed olives small plate was yummy, as was the olive oil/artisanal bread side (the olive oil was incredibly smooth and flavorful).  Pork belly with alioli was tasty but not incredible.  Herbed chicken was respectable.  Lots of other good stuff was on the menu that I'd like to try.  It's a bit crowded so you might have to wait outside since the waiting area is a narrow hallway that fills fast.  And this place doesn't take reservations for small parties (less than 6).
author: Michelle F.

description:
whoa, i didn't realize this place just opened....i asked the waitress how long this place has been around, and she said something like a week, and i thought she was being a smartass....whew, lucky i didn't stiff her on the tip because of that!

so, had the croquettes.....fried stuff...are you kidding me?  i'll always get that.  this was made with oxtail...oxtail a bit on the dry side, but it was good overall.  patatas bravas....again...fried stuff?  yeah, and it was good.  salad (does this offset the fried stuff?) with kumquats and almonds....excellent...the fish dish (steelhead) was decent...maybe a tad overcooked, but they made up for it by slapping a thin slice of ham on top of it....

now that i know that they just opened, i can forgive them for some of the lapses in the services...like it took 30 min or more for us to get our last dish....so i had to skip dessert, since we needed to leave.  they were super pleasant though, so no big deal.  i read another reviewer write that you can get bread on request...what's up with that?  i was kinda wondering why some got bread while we didn't....but i just landed on the idea that maybe they just gave pretty people the bread.  

i will definitely come back again.....
author: Miss P.

description: Have eaten here 3 times and Contigo has been really good each time.  Overcrowded: yes.  But that's because it's good.
author: Drew H.

description: was so good...we loved the service .. the food was very unique flavors came together so well...the squid mmmm!  loved the tripe...the flatbread...had buddha's hand ice cream and prickly pear sorbet and lemon cookies..love this restaurant...gonna make it back sometime soon
author: Amanda J.

description:
I've been meaning to try Contigo for a while now - last I tried they told me it would be a 2 hour wait.  On a whim my bf and I decided to swing by on our way home for work.  We got there right as they opened and surprisingly were the only ones there for quite some time.

I really love the decor - always a plus - specifically the lights that were draped at different heights.  I wasn't a fan of the fabric on the banquettes however, but on to more important things...

We were only planning to have a drink and a small plate or two, but of course became overly excited when we saw the menu and ordered 4 different plates.  We started with one of the sheep's milk cheeses.  We were both impressed by the substantial serving size and enjoyed the bit of quince jam and hazelnuts served alongside.  Very good cheese at that.  We then had the little gem salad served with yummy, sweet, pinkish beets and fried garlic.  The combo of the beets, garlic and a really vinegary-lemony dressing was delicious.  Next was the calamari served with padron peppers.  For some reason I didn't read the menu carefully and thought it was served on some form of bread, but it wasn't - it was just marinated, possibly slightly grilled calamari served with the peppers but the combination of flavors was delicious, and the calamari was cooked perfectly.  Again, the lemony-olive oil sauce was a great addition.  Finally, we got the pork meatballs.  I don't eat pork typically, but I've been feeling adventurous lately and tried some.  They were much more subdued in flavor compared to the rest of the meal, and at first I wasn't blown away.  I almost even gave my meatball to my bf.  However, as I continued to eat it really grew on me - it was almost a soothing, warm sort of comfort food that became more appealing the more I ate.

All in all a great little meal/snack.  I was full enough not to have dinner, but the boy definitely is ready for a second dinner now.  Also had a nice Rose with my meal.  The server was super friendly and didn't push more food on us when we told him we only wanted a few appetizers.  

One last note - check out the bathroom - my grandma always said you could tell the quality of a restaurant by the cleanliness/design of the bathroom.  Contigo certainly wins on this point.   It may even deserve 5 stars, but I think I need to try some more of their food before I can make that call!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Stopped in here on a whim last night; had a really good meal. We enjoyed the bread with Arbequina olive oil (good olive flavor), Porcini mushrooms and potatoes roasted in duck fat (aaahhh, duck fat!), fried artichokes, meatballs and olive oil fried chicken. The plates are fairly simple but taste great. The artichokes with a bit of fresh squeezed lemon really had a good flavor, and the chicken was super moist.
Dessert was the apple tart and ricotta with honey, fig spread and jam. Both were good, but the ricotta was pretty rich. Like most places these days they were a bit heavy on the salt, but overall flavors came through.
author: Ana M.

description: I was invited to try Contigo this weekend and was blown away.  We've been anticipating the opening for quite a while, and the food and the restaurant delivered beyond any expectations.  I'm drooling on my keyboard thinking about Contigo's squid and the hot chocolate dessert.  We are in for quite a treat once this opens on Mar 3.  The menu is reasonably priced (kind of set up in the SPQR model - with small plates priced at 3 for $21 and then some entrees around $20).  The spot is really gorgeous and every detail is well considered.
author: J M.

description:
Finally made it to Contigo after arranging for baby sitter, we stroll by this place every day in our walking course. There was no queue on a Sunday night.

Waiter let us taste each of the wine they have on carafe, we decide on a medium bobied red which goes well with varieties of dishes.

Each dish is quite small, which is the fun part as even a couple can taste a lot of different dishes. We ordered about 6. All are excellent.

Although expensive, but Iberico ham is a must. The flat bread with cheese and nettles is also excellent.

Seating area is cramped and noise level is high, but that atmosphere works for Contigo.

If you are hungry like us, the bill can be expensive.

Have to go back and try other dishes.
author: Yi S.

description: I love the neighborhood and I love this place.  The atmosphere is great, a bit loud but none the less great.  They have dishes that sound so interesting and taste wonderful.  Definetly a great addition to an already great area.  Will most certainly go back.
author: Josh L.

description:
gorgeous interior, friendly hostess and servers (although being less than a week old the service needs improvement) and yummy food.

nice selection of wines by the glass.

we just did tapas

spanish omelet (yummy) 
bikini (like a grilled cheese sandwich but with quince jam, so good)
patatas bravas (fried potatoes, totally skippable)
croquetas de rabo de toro (yummy oxtail croquettes, maybe the best thing we had)
zanahorias (roasted carrot salad, second best thing we ate)
razor clams (AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE) the couple next to us complained about them too.  the server warned us they might have sand inside and we were prepared for that but they just tasted so OFF.  it was actually an embarassment compared to the many other lovely items.

bread upon request

i had hot chocolate and churros for dessert with a little mini press of blue bottle.  the chocolate is thick and intense.  the churros tasty.

my gf had brown butter cake with whipped cream and apples.

once the servers get a little more used to things it will be even better.  tonight slightly annoying things happened like not bringing coffee until way after dessert was served and then no milk and when the milk came the dessert dishes were gone so we were without spoons, waiting fifteen minutes for the bill, that sort of stuff wasn't good but still the food was tasty, everyone was nice and the price wasn't too bad.  

note to cold girls, don't sit by the door in the back.
author: Poppy C.

description: overpriced, unimaginative oily tapas. our wine selection, thankfully, was good. the service good. being originally from Madrid and growing up with my grandmother's cooking, this place lacks the quality while emphasizing class and atmosphere. the first experience was good, the second and third were so disappointing that i'll not likely return.
author: John M.

description: This place takes me right back to the wonderful, simple food that I have enjoyed the few times I've journeyed to Barcelona... ridiculously fresh ingredients, simply prepared, with a heavy seafood tilt.  This is very much a Catalan experience - so please leave your visions of Madrid-style tapas firmly at the door.  The menu changes very often, so it is a little hard to predict your experience.  But, every experience I've had here has been pretty darn amazing, with only the odd dish or two not completely living up to the expectations set by others.  Service is brilliant with the plates timed perfectly to ensure you're not overwhelmed with food at your table (the danger of tapas-style dining).  The albondigas (meatballs in tomato sauce) are almost always on the menu and excellent every time, although there is sometimes a variation in the spicing of the sauce (likely to match the current season).  There is a great collection of either house cured or imported premium hams and salumi for that true Spanish touch.  Any of the cured or cooked seafood specialities have been to die for, in my opinion.  They also have a great, reasonable wine list, but definitely ask for help in navigating it as there are few on the list that are familiar to most wine drinkers.  I love eating at the bar in front of the kitchen because you get to watch the action - it is amazing what they turn out of that relatively tiny kitchen area!
author: Chris P.

description: Gorgeous food and the best staff ever. Everyone here is knowledgeable and nice, and perfectly match the laid back/modern decor. I have been here 3 times and the food never disappoints. And yes, the 36mo aged Spanish ham is worth $22.  My only issue is that either the plates are a bit too small or a bit overprices, but the bill at the end of the night is just a hair more than the experience. That said, I love these guys.
author: senator t.

description: I loved the food. Halibut crudo was amazing and the fried artichokes with freshly madreaoli were some of the best I've had. The only bummer was the patio was crawling with kids but I guess that's what you get in Noe valley.
author: melissa o.

description:
We went on the opening night, and while the place is cute, and the owners seem really nice, the food was really not up to snuff.  I will, however, handicap this review since they just opened and are probably working out some kinks.

Each of the small dishes is $8, $21 for 3 dishes. You can also order main dishes which are between $12-$19. Here's what we ordered:

- Calamares - portion was very small, a bit of spicy red sauce and it seemed very fresh
- Oxtail croquette - nice presentation for 2 croquettes but the flavor of the oxtail itself was bland, it didn't seem to have any spices to make it taste interesting
- Chicken soup - after being told that there is actually no chicken meat in the soup, I decided to order it anyway. There were bits of chorizo or sausage in the soup which tasted quite nice, but I literally only had about 1/2 cup of soup which was lukewarm. again a very small portion.
- Sausage hamburger - the hamburger was small (see the theme?) and burnt. There was not much flavor since the meat was overcooked. For the price of around $12 it was unsatisfying
- Flatbread with manchego, arugula and ham. the portion size was small again, i think this was about $14 and it was about 7" in diameter, could barely taste any cheese and they skimped on the serrano
- Fish stew - I counted 5 clams, 4 chunks of fish, 6 chunks of potato and a small amount of broth. $17

The service was very nice, and the atmosphere was great - not too loud. comfortable, open space.  But, the food was lacking. Our total bill was around $140 for 4 people. We left feeling hungry. I really want to like this place but I can't recommend it for the food at this point. Also,  there was used lipstick on one of the water glasses.

Another CON:  They charge for bread, and we were 5 people, they brought out 4 slices, we asked for more so each person could get at least one piece, they brought out another basket of 4 slices - and charged us TWICE - nickel and diming customers for bread, which costs almost nothing is not acceptable when you're paying so much for the entrees and starters.
author: Spoon G.

description: fantastic! i miss barcelona.... the atmosphere was fantastic (i loved the decor, the cute glasses made out of wine bottles, etc). food was *BOMB*-- it's a daily menu so i assume recommending something may not be all too useful, but i'll do it anyway. patatas bravas, churros con chocolate, & albondigas! they were solid. prices are reasonable & service is good. definitely check it out, you may need to make a reservation, this place fills quickly.
author: linda t.

description: At 6pm service was attentive and quick.  Our waiter was great - helpful in choosing a wine and clearly knowledgeable about the wines that they served, next time I would have sherry.  We ordered two of the sardine toasts which were yummy if you like the flavor of sardines, oveja cheese salad with a perfect blend of flavors and textures (loved the hazelnut dressing), the calamari which was oversalted making it a bit difficult to taste all of the flavors, fried potatoes (too much sauce so ask for it on the side), abondigas which were perfect and flatbread (the most ordinary of all that we ordered).  Probably ordered one dish too many for two people.  No dessert as we were stuffed!  Would be very fun with a group.
author: Suzanne G.

description:
Um, I ate a cow's stomach last night, EW.

It was our own fault; we had no idea what "tripe" was when we ordered it.  No offense to those of you that like it.. but I mean, it had like spores all over it and it tasted like, well, what I probably would have imagined a stomach tastes like.  

Anyway, this place is so so SO amazingly good; it doesn't even matter that we ate a stomach!  It was worth every spongy, chewy, sporey bite.  Every other dish we had was unbelievable.  Topping the list: the beets and clementines, the octopus salad and the insanely delicious pork belly entree.  I don't care that I might be 5 lbs fatter after taking down that belly.. it was melt-in-your-mouth divine.  Every dish was unique, surprising and incredibly satisfying and each ingredient tasted fresh and flavorful.

I can't think of a single flaw.  Even though the stomach freaked us both out, we ate most of it (well, until we asked the waiter what tripe is).. and I was dipping my flatbread crusts into that yummy tomato sauce until it was all gone.

The restaurant has a warm and inviting ambiance and is lively but not overly loud.  My friend and I sat on the back patio which was heated and SO wonderful.  The service is friendly.. our waiter was so nice, though wasn't the fastest, especially toward the end.  I'll give him the benefit of the doubt and say he's probably an amateur.
author: Rachel M.

description: Wow! Contigo is what the five star rating was made for. The atmosphere was fantastic! Our waiter was knowledgeable, nice, funny, full of great recommendations and just plain swell. We had Tinton (sp?) vino which was basically a Tempranillo and it was amazing (especially for $43). The prosciutto which is "there one year cured pig" was fantastic. I am such a huge fan of this place! Love love love the flan & individual french press coffee for dessert. YUMMMMM May I go back tonight please????
author: Kristen T.

description: Warm, lively, smart-casual vibe that is intimate but not too tight. Did not expect to find this in Noe Valley. The food was good, not amazing, but the atmosphere made up for it. Definitely looking forward to another visit.
author: Matt B.

description: Last night for dinner....  Service was timed perfectly.   We debated over a couple of wines and the waiter brought out two tasting of each with great recommendations.  We especially enjoyed the asparagus salad and flank steak.  Great dinner!
author: William L.

description: After all the hype, I expected much more and I got MUCH less.  The food was mediocre and WAY over salted.  The portions were minuscule too.  The best part was the wine but that's not worthy of eating there.  I could not recommend this place to anyone.  I can't believe people are liking this place.  Just because it's new; I guess!
author: Chris G.

description: Went here over the weekend and it was great. We had about 10 different items on the menu and ALL of them were great. The highlight of the evening was the steak. It was cooked perfectly and the bleu cheese was fantastic. I'd go here again in a heartbeat if I could.
author: Avid E.

description:
Had a great experience here this weekend. Food is delicious.  Highly recommend the tasting menu, especially if you are only going with one other person.  We had: 
-  wood oven roasted monterey sardine and avocado toast with pickled onions and smoked salt  (great start!)
-  little gem salad with roasted beets, garlic chips, mint and sherry mustard vinagreta (mint was such a great addition - delicious)
-  charred asparagus with mojama (cured tuna), pimenton almonds and an olive oil fried farm egg (this was one of my favorites - the charred flavor of the asparagus, the saltiness of the tuna and the crunchy nuttiness of the almonds on top of the olive oil fried egg - yummy)
-  wood oven roasted spring calcot onions with salvitxada sauce (no idea what the sauce was, but it was delicious)
-  calamars a la planxa with arros negre, fava beans, chorizo, alioli and guindilla chile oil (another winner - amazing flavors)
-  sauted greens with toasted almonds, golden raisins and garlic (great with the steak)
-  seared flat ion steak with rosemary papas fritas,  sauce and crumbled cheese. (perfectly medium rare and tender)

The "arros negre" that came with the calamari was like a squid ink risotto.  The whole dish was amazing, but my favorites were the vegetable dishes.  I really love places that can make a dish with just vegetables so amazingly delicious and completely satisfying.  

Counter seating is great - I think I might prefer that to a table.  4/5 stars because the server didn't do a very good job of explaining all of the dishes.  Does everybody really know what mojama is???
author: Sarah B.

description: I went here with a pal on a weekday night and it was super crowded. We wanted a table outside but that area was full. Thankfully, they were able to put us at a table close to the patio. The doors and windows were open so that was nice. We had three pica-pica's and one entree. My favorite small plate was the one with beets - super tasty! Our entree was the steak and blue cheese which was also good. This is the perfect place for a warm day when you want a relaxed atmosphere. We both had wine and the bill was about $35 each.
author: Joy A.

description: This is a beautiful restaurant with food that is only so-so. It was fun for a group and is a good date place too. The service was also very good. I would go back for sure but wish they would tighten up their dishes.
author: Catie S.

description: goood food but way to expensive and way to small!!!! i dont like paying 12$ for 4 shrimp and paying for bread is not cool!!!
author: Shauna P.

description: It's a fun addition to the neighborhood. Good-to-great food. They've only been open for two weeks, so I'll give them a bit more time to work out their service glitches before I return. I wish they would accept reservations for small parties.
